HEADLINE: Martin Marietta Net Down

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Martin Marietta Corporation said today that third-quarter net income fell 8 percent from a year earlier, when earnings were helped by one-time gains.
Net income for the quarter ended Sept. 30 was $100.1 million, or $2 a share, compared with $108.8 million, or $2.16 a share, in the 1990 quarter. Sales slipped 4 percent, to $1.44 billion from $1.49 billion. 
 Earnings in the 1990 quarter were helped by $12.6 million gain from a real estate sale and the resolution of a legal arbitration. Without those gains, 1991 third-quarter earnings would have been up 4.7 percent.
The electronics, information and missiles group reported higher earnings, while the astronautics group had a slight dip in sales and earnings, largely because of the phase-out of the Peacekeeper program.
A decline in sales and earnings in the company's materials group was attributed to the recession.
Martin Marietta shares closed at $50 apiece today, down 50 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
End of the Game For Motor City?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TO the armies of auto company lawyers, victory in the trade war over mini-vans turns on definitions: Have Toyota and Mazda "dumped" the car-truck hybrids by selling them to Americans below the price charged Japanese consumers, as the plaintiffs allege? If the Japanese did sin by offering better deals in Toledo than Tokyo, did they "injure" Chrysler, Ford and General Motors in the process?
But to many analysts, Detroit's decision to seek protection in the anti-dumping laws says more about the companies' survival strategies than Japanese prices. A decade after the Big Three vowed to beat the Japanese on cost and quality, they are still losing market share. Apparently the goal now is to convince the Japanese to ease off. 
 The mini-van market seems an odd site for a trade skirmish. American makers sell roughly 9 out of every 10 mini-vans. And their two Japanese rivals have made no attempt to elbow their way into the heart of the market, aiming instead at the high end where Japanese vehicles are prized for cachet as well as quality.
The case is even more puzzling because it strains the already fuzzy economic logic behind dumping rules. Dumping is usually seen as unfair because foreigners are assumed to be selling cheaply abroad after recouping their overhead back home. But the primary market for Japanese mini-vans is America. Thus if the Japanese dump them here they have no hope of making a profit.
The Japanese flatly deny the dumping charge. And they insist that Detroit cannot have been injured by their modest sales in the one segment of the car market that is still showing healthy growth. But David Palmeter, an American lawyer who heads the International Bar Association's trade law subcommittee, argues that dumping suits are hard to beat because the law is stacked in favor of plaintiffs. For example, the Commerce Department uses an average of all sales to compute the defendant's home market price, while it uses the lowest available price in the American market for purposes of comparison.
In any event, a legal victory may not be necessary for Detroit to accomplish its objective. Robert Crandall, an economist at the Brookings Institution, sees the suit as a warning to the Japanese to keep margins high or face the political consequences. And while Toyota denies it, the warning may already have been heeded. The big Japanese auto maker just raised the sticker on its already pricey Previa model by 10 percent -- double the average increase on its cars.
But a victory on mini-vans would hardly constitute a knockout blow. And by all accounts, Detroit will have a hard time defending its remaining turf.
Critics agree that American cars look better, drive better and are more reliable than standard Detroit iron of the mid-1980's. But better has not proved good enough to slow the Japanese. Nor is there evidence that Japanese auto makers are about to pause to sniff the cherry blossoms. Snazzy new models like the Mazda 929 are piling into the market for near-luxury sedans, challenging yet another profit center for Detroit.
Most ominous, argues Clifford Winston, Mr. Crandall's colleague at Brookings, Japan is riding a wave of brand loyalty. While owners of aging American cars are tempted to shop around, few owners of Japanese cars are inclined to defect. Thus all those little Civics and Corollas purchased in the 1980's guarantee a market for the Toyota Camry and other upsized Japanese challengers to Ford's cash cow, the Taurus.
Ford and General Motors resist the protectionist label. But Lee Iacocca of Chrysler is not so coy. Last week he announced that Detroit's salvation lies in a quota on Japanese models -- one that includes Japanese "transplant" production in America as well as imports.
A cartel-like arrangement would not be well received by Toyota, which has never been a team player. But it might not displease the Japanese Government bureaucracy, which rarely passes up an excuse to meddle in exporters' affairs. Nor would it be anathema to most Japanese car companies , which learned to enjoy the "voluntary" restraints that limited Japanese sales in the mid-1980's -- and allowed everyone to raise prices by thousands of dollars a vehicle.
The big question, then, is how far Washington will to go to keep Chrysler alive and the Big Two kicking. Two years ago, the Bush Administration would have laughed away the idea of muscling Japan to raise car prices. But then, two years ago Detroit did not expect to lose $6 billion in 1991, and George Bush did not expect to be running for re-election with 6.7 percent unemployment and economic growth on hold.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Coke vs. Pepsi As an Investment

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

 BODY:
COKE and Pepsi are often compared on taste and on the potency of their advertising, as people did recently when Pepsi introduced a new logo. But how do the companies compare as investments?
"They are two different animals," said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in San Francisco. Other experts also view the two companies as a study in contrasts. 
 The Coca-Cola Company is essentially a one-product company with a global focus, whereas Pepsico Inc. does business mostly in the United States, and soft drinks account for only about a third of its profits. Chips are Pepsi's biggest business, contributing 42 percent of profits, while restaurants account for the rest.
The companies battle for the soft-drink market primarily in the United States, a market that accounts for less than 20 percent of Coke's profits but about 30 percent of Pepsi's.
Buying Coke's stock is betting on the continued popularity of soft drinks in the international market, which is growing by about 10 percent a year, assuring Coke solid growth for years to come, analysts say.
"Coke is the best fundamental story I have ever followed," said George E. Thompson of Prudential Securities. "It's a true growth story."
In an average year, Coke's earnings grow by about 20 percent.
Coke's strength overseas "is more of a circumstance of history than anything else," Mr. Thompson said, pointing to a post-World War II pledge by a top Coke executive to provide free Cokes to G.I.'s stationed in Japan and Germany.
Thanks to that legacy, Coke today earns more money in Japan than in the United States. In all, 80 percent of its operating profits are from international markets.
Because of the immense potential of the international market and Coke's dominance -- the company says it controls nearly half the international soft-drink market -- analysts say Coke is likely to continue building its impressive record for shareholders. During the 1980's, the company's stock outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500 by more than 3 to 1. Including dividend payments, Coke says, every $100 invested in Coke stock in 1980 was worth $1,231 in 1990.
Coke stock closed at $62.75 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, down 37.5 cents.
Mr. Goldman of Paine Webber expects Coke to continue growing by close to 20 percent a year. "We expect the stock price to grow at least with earnings," he said.
While Pepsico is having an off year, some analysts see an equally compelling investment.
Pepsi's plight illustrates the hurdles facing companies seeking the investment premiums awarded growth companies -- it is growing at a mere 9 percent rate during the recession. Pepsi stock closed yesterday at $27.125 a share, down 75 cents and off its 52-week high of $35.625.
"The stock has definitely lagged since early this year, and it's directly related to the lower trend in earnings," said Robert J. Cummins, an analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York.
Pepsi is hurting largely because of problems of its own making. Considered the first large consumer-products company to have identified consumers' interest in low prices, Pepsi kept prices low at its restaurant chains, which include Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and Kentucky Fried Chicken. The strategy gained market share, but now competitors have matched the cuts and profit margins are being hurt with no gain in new customers.
At the same time, the company faces heavy competition in the snack-food business and is cutting prices to maintain its dominant market share. The company recently eliminated 1,800 jobs, or 7 percent of the work force, at Frito-Lay Inc.
Mr. Cummins predicts that Pepsico's earnings will grow by 20 percent next year, and, as a result, the stock is one of his principal recommendations. "It's an unusually good buy at this price," he said, projecting that Pepsico would reach $36 to $40 a share in the next 12 months.
Mr. Thompson of Prudential favors Coke as a long-term investment, but he said that Pepsi had more potential to respond to an earnings rebound in the next 12 months.
Pepsico is also aggressively looking overseas. Frito-Lay is buying foreign snack companies, and Mr. Cummins said that Pepsico had an opportunity to establish Frito-Lay as a global snack-food brand matching Coke's record in the soft-drink business. "There is no other multinational company in that business," he said.
Pepsico is also trying to expand its restaurants and soft-drink business overseas, but is likely to stay out of Coke's way. Mr. Goldman of Paine Webber said, "You don't mess with an elephant in the jungle."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises in New York; Gold Prices Little Changed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was higher in New York and mixed overseas yesterday in trading that largely lacked direction.
Gold prices were little changed, with bullion rising 10 cents an ounce to close at $363.90 on the New York Commodity Exchange. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $363.25, unchanged from late Monday. 
Analysts said the dollar traded in a narrow range and was unable to latch on to any trend.
The dollar did take some support from Bush Administration and Democratic proposals for a middle-income tax cut as a means of stimulating the economy. The proposals drove interest rates higher in the bond market, which is concerned that too much stimulus could drive up inflation, and in turn, interest rates.
But the prospect of higher interest rates is a positive sign for dollar traders. Like all currencies, the dollar is strengthened by higher rates, which increase foreign demand for American investments.
Many traders are awaiting the release tomorrow of figures on durable goods orders for September before making any significant moves. That is the only major economic indicator expected this week.
 
Yen Moves Lower
 There was more interest in foreign currencies yesterday than in the dollar itself. The dollar rose against the yen, which was hurt by expectations that interest rates will decline in Japan when a new Government takes office next month.
Japan's chief economic planner, Michio Ochi, quoted Yasushi Mieno, the Bank of Japan governor, as saying the trend for lower Japanese rates was "clear."
The dollar rose to 131.40 yen in New York, from 130.80 late Monday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.85 yen to close at 131.45 yen, and in London it was quoted at 131.10 yen.
The British pound gave way to the dollar, falling to $1.7085 in New York trading, from $1.7165 late Monday. In London, the pound slipped to $1.7145 from $1.7185.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.7000 German marks, up from 1.69333; 1.4850 Swiss francs, up from 1.4835; 5.7970 French francs, up from 5.7750; 1,270.75 Italian lire, up from 1,266.00, and 1.12635 Canadian dollars, up from 1.12625.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The decline in yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts continued unabated for another week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, the publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., that covers interest rates.
"While financial markets have long-term concerns about the prospect of inflation next year, savings yields, nevertheless, continue to show short-term declines," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. "The numbers should fall even lower in the next few weeks." 
 Because of the steady fall in yields, Mr. Heady said there would be another cut in the Federal Reserve's discount rate and in banks' prime rate this year. Both are key rates on which other rates are based.
The week's largest cut in yields on money market funds among New York area banks was made by the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, which lowered the yield by 26 basis points, to 4.33 percent. It also made the largest cut in three-month certificates of deposit, lowering the yield by 16 basis points, to 4.95 percent. For six-month certificates, the largest cut was made by National Westminster Bank, which dropped its yield by 15 basis points, to 4.92. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The Monitor's list shows 10 banks in the New York area with yields below 5 percent on six-month certificates.
At New York banks, the average yield on money market accounts has been cut to 4.66 percent, down 3 basis points, while the average yields on three-month and six-month certificates were down 4 points, to 4.84 percent and 4.93 percent, respectively.
At savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut to 5.23, down 3 basis points, for money market accounts; to 5.30, down 2 basis points, for three-month certificates, and to 5.51, also down 2 basis points, for six-month certificates.
The Monitor said the average yields at 20 major banks outside the New York area had been cut by 5 basis points, to 4.87 percent, on money market accounts, and by 4 points, to 5.13 percent, for six-month certificates.
By comparison, at the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday interest rates rose, with the three-month bill auctioned at an average discount rate of 5.04 percent, up from 4.99 the previous week, and the six-month bill averaging 5.11 percent, compared with 5.03 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Record Profit At McDonald's

 BODY:
Continued weak sales in the United States and in some foreign markets caused the McDonald's Corporation's revenues to drop 2 percent in the third quarter, although the company yesterday reported a record profit for the quarter.
Profits increased nearly 7 percent, to a record $258.7 million, compared with $242.2 million in the quarter a year earlier. Earnings per share increased 6 percent, to 71 cents, from 67 cents a year earlier. 
 Revenues fell nearly 2 percent, to $1.74 billion from $1.77 billion.
The company said the poor United States economy caused domestic revenues to drop. McDonald's did not disclose additional details, but it said the sale of some company-operated restaurants to franchisees also contributed to the lower revenues. Outside the United States, the troubled economies of Canada and Britain held revenue growth to just 1 percent in the quarter.
Jack M. Greenberg, the company's chief financial officer, said in an interview that there were no signs that American sales would soon pick up. "We are still in a very difficult marketplace," he said, adding that the company was "awfully cautious" about the prospects for the next three months.
John J. Rohs, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company in New York, said, "The difficulties domestically continued, and international results were far weaker than expected."
McDonald's stock fell $1 a share yesterday, to $35, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Bankers Trust Earnings Rise 8.8%

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation yesterday announced a greater-than-expected profit of $185 million in the third quarter, up 8.8 percent from a year ago, largely on the strength of increased revenues from its various trading activities.
The profit gain at Bankers Trust is a reminder that banks with specialties in trading are faring well, while those that rely more on lending have been troubled by a combination of weak loan demand and growing losses on delinquent and defaulted loans. 
 Among other large banking companies, the Mellon Bank Corporation said its third-quarter profits rose 6.1 percent. The Pittsburgh-based banking company would have reported a decline in earnings except for a profit from the sale of securities in its investment portfolio.
"Those banks with a lot of trading and risk-management expertise are doing well," said James Rosenberg, a banking analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers. The business of what bankers call risk management -- creating and selling relatively new financial products, like swap contracts for interest rates, foreign exchange and commodities -- is a rapidly growing market with potential for continued growth, Mr. Rosenberg said.
"Companies such as Bankers Trust and J. P. Morgan that have strong credit ratings and have made the investments in people who know the businesses are gaining market share at the expense of other banks," Mr. Rosenberg added. J. P. Morgan & Company last week said its third-quarter profits of $373 million were led by a doubling of trading revenues to $360 million.
Following are the details of the banks' results:
 
Bankers Trust
 At Bankers Trust, the third-quarter profit of $185 million equaled $2.17 a share, up from $170 million, or $1.98 a share, a year ago. It was one of the most profitable banks in the country during the quarter, with a return on equity of about 25 percent.
While Bankers Trust reduced its loans to $18 billion, from $20.8 billion a year ago, its revenues from trading increased 22.3 percent, to $323 million from $264 million. About $35 million of the increase was from trading in the market for loans to less-developed countries, where trading volume and prices have increased rapidly this year. Foreign exchange trading revenues fell sharply, to $40 million, from $118 million, but that decline was offset by a 93.8 percent gain in other trading revenues to $283 million from $146 million.
Bankers Trust also benefited from a slower growth rate in expenses, which grew by more than 19 percent annually during the five years ended with 1990. Expenses in the third quarter totaled $554 million, up only 3.9 percent from a year ago.
Bankers Trust stock rose after the earnings announcement, and ended the day at $63.625, up 37.5 cents a share on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Mellon Bank
 The Mellon Bank announced third-quarter profits of $70 million, or $1.10 a share, up from $66 million, or $1.19 a share, a year ago. Earnings would have fallen except for a $38 million profit from the securities sale.
The bank said its earnings benefited from recent acquisitions and a widening of the spread between the rates it pays on deposits and the rates it collects on loans. But earnings were hurt by the need to set aside $80 million in a reserve for bad loans, up from $45 million a year ago.
The banking company said it wrote off as a loss $59 million of loans, up from $41 million a year ago, and that badly delinquent loans and foreclosed real estate on its books rose to $932 million from $907 million at midyear.
Mellon's stock rose 75 cents, to $35.375 a share, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: Earnings Off At Three Oil Companies

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Several big oil companies reported lower earnings yesterday, as reduced prices for crude oil and natural gas and slack demand for chemical products pared profits.
Companies with operations mainly in the United States, where natural gas prices and gasoline demand declined more than in other nations, fared worse than companies with global operations. 
 Mobil said net income fell 3.7 percent in the third quarter, Texaco was off 24.9 percent and Phillips Petroleum 68.5 percent, while Ashland Oil rose 6.8 percent.
 
Surge at Occidental
 Occidental Petroleum, in the midst of a broad reorganization, said profits surged 58.3 percent on gains from the sales of several divisions.
Analysts said the rate of profit decline for top oil companies over all in the period ended Sept. 30 will be the steepest for any quarter since oil prices plunged from a peak near $40 a barrel in 1981.
"The industry fundamentals are lackluster," said George F. Friesen, senior oil analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital. "The third-quarter earnings are probably the bottom for the industry, but earnings comparisons will still be unfavorable for the fourth quarter and first quarter of next year."
Prices at most oil companies in the quarter averaged more than $4 a barrel below the levels a year ago, when prices surged in the months after Iraq invaded Kuwait, and remained high until the Persian Gulf war began in mid-January.
For example, Texaco said the average price for its sales of Middle Eastern crudes fell to $18.70 in the quarter, compared with an average of $24.60 in the comparable 1990 period.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Mobil
 Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil company after the Exxon Corporation, said net income fell to $365 million, or 87 cents a share, from $379 million, or 89 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenues of the company, based in Fairfax, Va., fell 7.5 percent, to $15.03 billion from $16.25 billion.
Excluding special items that increased Mobil's profits sharply in the third quarter of 1990, the company posted a 47 percent increase in operating profits, to $395 million from $268 million. The biggest surge came from refining and marketing operations, which earned $173 million, compared with $5 million a year ago.
Allen E. Murray, chairman and chief executive, said lower crude and natural gas prices pared profits in the company's exploration and production operations in the United States.
But foreign operations reported no change in profits; lower crude prices and higher costs were offset by higher volumes of crude production, higher natural gas prices and wider profit margins in Nigeria.
The gains in refining and marketing reflected the unusually small profit from the quarter a year ago, when retail gasoline prices in the United States did not rise as rapidly as costs. For now, Mr. Murray said, refineries are operating at the highest rates in company history. "Excellent refinery performance continues to be a strong contributor to earnings," he said.
Mobil's share price gained 87.5 cents, to $72.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Texaco
 Net income for Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, fell to $286 million, or $1.01 a share, from $381 million, or $1.38 a share, in the period a year ago. Revenues fell 14.5 percent, to $9.36 billion from $10.95 billion.
"The economic slump in the United States, and several other major markets in turn has depressed the margins in chemicals as well as petroleum products," said James W. Kinnear, president and chief executive of Texaco, based in White Plains. "Market conditions have been particulary weak on the U.S. West Coast."
Profits in the international refining and marketing unit nearly doubled, to $118 million, from $61 million in the period a year ago, but results at most other divisions were lower.
Earnings from exploration and production in the United States fell to $129 million from $207 million, and in the foreign unit, profits fell to $89 million from $139 million. Profits in petrochemical manufacturing fell to $3 million from $12 million.
Spending on new plants and exploration was pared to $813 million, from $930 million in the period last year. Texaco's share price fell $1.125, to $64.875, on the Big Board.
 
Phillips
 Phillips's net income plunged to $56 million, or 21 cents a share, from $178 million, or 72 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1990. Revenues for the company, based in Bartlesville, Okla., fell 8.8 percent, to $3.1 billion from $3.4 billion.
The company said the decline was steeper if one-time profits from unusual transactions were removed. The special items included a $20 million gain from asset sales and a $19 million legal settlement on disputed Federal taxes.
"The slowdown in the U.S. economy continued to depress profits in our major chemicals product lines," said C. J. Silas, chairman and chief executive.
Phillips Petroleum's share price fell 37.5 cents, to $26.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Occidental
 Occidental's net income rose to $171 million, or 56 cents a share, from $108 million, or 36 cents a share, in the quarter last year. Sales fell 14.8 percent, to $2.3 billion from $2.7 billion.
The Los Angeles-based company's report included several transactions in the quarter that were part of a wide-ranging reorganization begun early this year by Ray R. Irani, chairman and chief executive.
The company posted a gain of $534 million after taxes from the sale of oil-and-gas properties in the British North Sea. It lost $57 million in transferring its 51 percent stake in IBP Inc., the meat processor, to its shareholders.
Occidental's share price fell 75 cents, to $22.625, on the Big Board.
 
Ashland
 Ashland, the large oil refiner based in Ashland, Ky., said profits for its fourth quarter rose to $63 million, or $1.07 a share, from $59 million, or $1.06 a share, in the period last year. Sales rose slightly, to $2.76 billion from $2.69 billion.
Operating income fell in refining, gasoline retailing and construction, increased for Valvoline motor oil and nearly doubled in chemicals. John R. Hall, chairman and chief executive, said rising crude prices in recent weeks had pinched refinery profits.
For the 1991 fiscal year, the company said net income fell 20.3 percent, to $145 million, or $2.58 a share, from $182 million, or $3.27 a share. Sales rose 3.1 percent, to $9.9 billion, from $9.6 billion.
Ashland Oil's share price fell 62.5 cents, to $28.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Decline Slightly

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell slightly yesterday in active trading, but dealers said the recent rise in long-term interest rates had sparked some demand for bonds.
"At around 8.10 percent, there seems to be some sponsorship for these securities," one government-bond trader said. 
 Despite the nibbling, traders said they remained defensive. The talk of tax cuts is a concern, along with worries that the Federal Reserve Board will continue to ease monetary policy to help revive the economy in an election year.
"By backing up the way it has the past few days, the market is saying that the Fed will give in to political pressure and cut rates some more," the trader said. "At the moment, the Fed has lost some credibility, and it will have to earn it back."
 
Dwindling Recovery
 The talk of tax cuts arose because the strength of the recovery that most analysts assume began in April dwindled in the summer quarter. Over the last week, no new evidence has emerged to change that assessment.
Nevertheless, analysts said the market's shift in sentiment over the last week or so has effectively precluded any move by the Fed.
"The Fed can't afford to fight this environment," said Ram Bhagavatula, chief financial economist at Citicorp Global Finance. "Until the market rallies, I don't think they are going to move."
Aside from worrying that efforts to stimulate the economy may generate higher inflation, traders said a coming flood of new notes and bonds over the next few weeks had also been responsible for the backup in yields.
2-Year Sale Today
The stream of new issues begins today, when the Treasury is expected to sell $13.5 billion of new two-year notes. Tomorrow, $9 billion of new five-year securities will be auctioned.
And next week, the Government will announce the size of its quarterly refunding auctions, to be held the first week in November. Most analysts anticipate that the Treasury will sell a total of $38 billion worth of new 3-year and 10-year notes, and 30-year bonds.
Late yesterday, the two-year notes to be sold today were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.01 percent. The five-year notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 6.98 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 10/32, down 9/ 32, to yield 8.09 percent, compared with 8.07 percent late Monday.
 
Fire Sale Rumors
 Rumors circulated through the market yesterday that much of the selling of bonds was being done by California insurance companies to pay for expected claims from the Oakland fire.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 13/32, down 10/32, to yield 7.66 percent. And the outstanding 6 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/32, down 2/32, to yield 6 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.04 percent, up two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.12 percent.
 
New Corporate Issues
 A number of new debt issues were priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market.
Among the issuers was Commonwealth Edison, which offered $250 million worth of securities through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
Half the issue is made up of 15-year securities maturing Oct. 15, 2006. The 8 3/8 percent securities were priced at $99.28 to yield 8.46 percent, 80 basis points more than the yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The remaining $125 million worth of securities are 9 1/8 percent bonds maturing Oct. 15, 2021. They were priced at $99.71 to yield 9.153 percent, 1.08 percentage points more than the yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing. These securities are noncallable for five years.
Both parts of the issue are rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Missouri Tax-Exempts
 A $157 million competitive offering by the State of Missouri highlighted new-issue activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
A bid from an investor group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won the issue, which consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2012. The securities were reoffered to investors with yields ranging from 4.25 percent in 1992 to 6.35 percent in 2012.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Despite the high quality of the issue, investment bankers with knowledge of the deal said that demand from investors was not terribly strong. Late yesterday, as much as $90 million of the securities remained unsold, the bankers said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: Building a Lost-Cause Portfolio

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Samuel Zell, the brash Chicago investor who has made a fortune by turning around down-on-their-luck companies and properties, is dredging the bottom again.
Earlier this month, Zell-Chilmark Partners, a $1 billion venture led by Mr. Zell, won creditor approval to buy the debt of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., the Los Angeles-based department store chain. That means the Zell partnership will probably end up controlling the company, which owns the Emporium, Broadway and Weinstock's stores and which Mr. Zell says he wants to run. 
 In a separate move this month, the partnership -- looking to invest in turnaround situtations with money put up by pension funds, banks, universities and Mr. Zell himself -- submitted a bid for the Executive Life Insurance Company of California. The troubled Los Angeles-based insurer was seized by California regulators last April amid a run by policyholders. David Schulte, one of Mr. Zell's partners in the Executive Life bid, said the group liked Executive Life's insurance franchise as well as the deep discount on the company's junk-bond portfolio.
Meantime, Merrill Lynch & Company has raised more than half of a proposed $500 million fund which, using Mr. Zell's eye for good deals, would invest in troubled real estate. Just last week, the fund made its first purchase: a half-empty Connecticut office building.
Mr. Zell, a self-described "grave-dancer," has played scavenger for 25 years, buying everything from high-vacancy apartment buildings in the Midwest to cash-squeezed industrial companies and busted real estate partnerships.
With few exceptions, he has managed to reap huge profits when properties he has acquired have recovered. His transactions have made him, at 50 years old, one of America's wealthiest men, with a net worth recently estimated at more than $400 million by Forbes magazine. On any given day, he says, he doesn't know exactly how much real estate he owns but figures it is "easily 10 million square feet" -- the equivalent of more than four Empire State Buildings.
"I have been very good at seeing around the corner," Mr. Zell said in an interview last week. "My role and my job is to anticipate economic trends and to act accordingly. I am a voracious consumer of information, and I seem to have the ability to bring that information together and reach conclusions."
For example, in the Itel Corporation of Chicago, Mr. Zell in the mid-80's spotted a comeback opportunity in the depressed railroad-car business. So he bought control of Itel in early 1985, shortly after it emerged from bankruptcy.
Mr. Zell knew that the obsolesence rate of aging rail cars would eventually bring supply back into line with demand, and he figured that the price he was paying for Itel's cars equaled about half the cost of building new ones from scratch. Such a low cost base enabled Mr. Zell to undercut rivals' lease rates and keep his cars rolling. When lease rates eventually rose, his profits did, too.
While Itel has not continually realized net profits under Mr. Zell, who remains chairman and chief executive, the operating results of the various divisions have consistently been positive.
When Mr. Zell bought Itel, it had a sea-cargo container business that ranked fourth in the industry. Mr. Zell subsequently bought the No. 3 and No. 7 businesses when container lease rates were at rock bottom. He also helped make the entire operation more efficient. Five years later, in 1990, he sold the division to the General Electric Company for a $250 million profit, he said.
"It's not just that Sam excels at spotting undervalued assets," said Philip Handy, a longtime friend of Mr. Zell's and an Itel director. "He's able to see the big trends."
 
Some Rough Spots
 Not all of Mr. Zell's bets have been winners. He lost $13 million in 1984, after investing in the Raines Tool Company, a Houston-based oilfield services concern that was liquidated. And his investment in the Commodore Corporation, a builder of mobile homes, was also wiped out when that company filed for bankruptcy.
He has also left a trail of executive-suite casualties. More than one officer has been summarily dismissed after Mr. Zell has taken control of a company and gone to work cuttng expenses.
And while Mr. Zell clearly has a charitable side -- in 1988 he helped endow a secondary school in the name of his late father, Bernard, at Chicago's Anshe Emet synagogue -- friends and associates say they dread his occasional temper tantrums. "Zell is a helluva asset manager, but he a brusque sort of man and not very genteel," said Herbert Kunzel, Itel's retired chairman.
 
Seldom Seen in a Necktie
 Most days, Mr. Zell travels to his downtown-Chicago office on a Ducati motorcycle, dressed in running shoes, jeans or leather pants, and a sweatshirt or sweater.
Owing to the fact that he suffered from painful neck boils while in law school in the early 60's at the University of Michigan, Mr. Zell rarely wears ties. He typically deigns to wear a business suit only when meeting with investors who are considering backing him. And even then, friends say, Mr. Zell changes into executive attire only at the last minute, dashing into an airport restroom if he is on the road.
Mr. Zell is so fiercely competitive that he wears cleats when he plays touch football in a Lincoln Park league, although friends regularly rib him for being a butterfingered receiver. And every fall, to match wits against some of his partners and friends, Mr. Zell is host of a treasure hunt in which participants, including some of Chicago's business elite, decipher clues that lead them through the city by limousine until they eventually wind up a a huge bash paid for by Mr. Zell.
 
Prom Photos and Racier Fare
 The son of a Polish grain broker who fled for America the night before the Nazi blitzkrieg began in August 1939, Mr. Zell grew up in the Chicago suburb of Highland Park. He got started in business by taking and selling photographs at his eighth-grade prom.
It was around this same time that young Sam Zell noticed a new magazine on Chicago newstands that he was sure would be of interest to his teen-age friends. He bought dozens of copies of Playboy, at at 50 cents apiece, marked them up to $1.50, and made a killing on the playground.
Mr. Zell's start in real estate came in the mid-60's, when, as a law student , he refurbished apartment buildings in Ann Arbor, Mich., in his spare time. In lieu of paying rent, he managed the apartment building he lived in, while also running other landlords' buildings. Unclogging toilets, unjamming locks -- thus began a property management business that he eventually sold to a fraternity brother, Robert Lurie, who remained Mr. Zell's partner in the Equity Financial and Management Company until Mr. Lurie's death last year from cancer.
After graduating from the University of Michigan, Mr. Zell and Mr. Lurie began buying troubled urban apartment buildings and offices several Midwestern states.
A regional construction boom in the late 60's had created a property glut, undercutting many building owners' ability to make their mortgage payments. Buying such properties at prices far below their replacement costs, Mr. Zell and Mr. Lurie cut rents to the bone and filled the buildings with tenants. When inflation soared in the the mid-1970's, the Zell-Lurie balance sheet swelled, too.
One example illustrates the pattern: Mr. Zell and Mr. Lurie bought Chicago's landmark Field building in in early 1978 for $52 million and sold it three years later for $94 million.
"His investment policy for real estate made all the sense in the world to me," said Robert Steiner, a money manager in Chicago who has invested with Mr. Zell for more than 20 years.
By the early 80's, Mr. Zell and Mr. Lurie, convinced that real estate values had peaked, turned their attention to buying companies. Their first stop was Great American Management Inc., a bankrupt real estate investment trust that the two men acquired for its substantial tax benefits, which could be used to shelter future profits.
"GAMI," as this publicly traded company is known, is now the holding company for dozens of Zell-controlled manufacturing companies, including a fertilizer concern for which Mr. Zell provided the venture capital.
Next came Itel, which also had substantial tax benefits from prior losses. Mr. Zell was able to use Itel, too, as an acquisition tool, purchasing such diverse businesses as a dredging company, a ship container business, a wire distribution concern and a 15 percent stake in the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation. Although the debt taken on to acquire those businesses has generated rumors that Mr. Zell was suffering a cash squeeze, he denies that Itel is having such troubles. So far, he said, "investors have earned 20 percent compounded annually since I took control."
 
Stalking Carter Hawley
 The question now is whether Mr. Zell can be equally successful with Carter Hawley Hale. The analysis is familar: Replacement costs for the stores is far greater than what Zell-Chilmark, his investment partnership, is offering for them. Mr. Zell wants to run the stores with less debt, modernize them and bet on a turnaround in retailing. He will not divulge other details of his strategy.
"This is not a real estate play," said Mr. Schulte, Mr. Zell's main partner in the Carter Hawley bid.
Robert F. McCullough, a San Francisco-based money manager who holds a large stake in Carter Hawley and is opposing Mr. Zell's bid, contends that the retailer has an underlying net worth -- including the value of its land, buildings and favorable leases -- of $800 million. By Mr. McCullough's calculation, the $300 million Zell-Chilmark bid is a half-billion dollars too low.
If the buyout indeed goes through, Mr. McCullough said, "This is another fantastic deal for Sam Zell."

HEADLINE: Big Losses For Top 2 In Detroit

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation posted a $1.1 billion third-quarter loss today and the Ford Motor Company recorded a $574 million loss as the recession-ravaged United States auto industry skidded toward its worst year in history.
The Chrysler Corporation is not scheduled to announce third-quarter results until next week, but auto analysts say it, too, will post a sizable loss, which would push total industry losses for the first nine months of the year to about $5 billion. In 1980, its worst year ever, the American auto industry lost $4 billion. 
 Auto makers said the main reasons for the poor quarterly showing were lower sales of vehicles to dealers here and abroad, and the cost of rebates to customers. Revenue and profit in the auto industry are booked when a car is sold to a dealer. As for rebates, Ford said incentives cost it about $1,050 a vehicle, compared with $1,000 last year.
 
A Traditionally Weak Quarter
 Even in good years, the third quarter is traditionally the weakest, because of lost production from the annual model changeover.
Ford said again today that it expected to show a loss in the current quarter, although it declined to predict how much. Last year, as the recession was worsening in auto showrooms, the No. 2 auto maker had a $519 million loss in the fourth quarter, cutting its profit for the full year to $860.1 million.
Analysts expect G.M. to lose money in the fourth quarter, and they are divided whether Chrysler will break into the black by the end of the year.
Last year, General Motors had a fourth-quarter loss of $1.62 billion and a full-year loss of $1.99 billion. Chrysler earned $3.1 million in the final 1990 quarter and had a $68 million profit for the year, aided by an accounting change.
On the New York Stock Exchange today, Ford shares lost 37.5 cents to close at $28.625, and G.M. was down 37.5 cents, to $36.875, but Chrysler rose 37.5 cents, to $11.25.
 
Comparison With 1980
 Even with the higher losses, the auto makers said they were in better financial shape today than in the depth of the recession in 1980, when Chrysler was saved from bankruptcy by the Federal Government and many people were worried that Ford was in dire trouble.
"Things are difficult, I wouldn't want to discount that," said David C. McCammon, Ford's vice president of finance. Still, he added, "we have a stronger balance sheet, better products and lower costs."
Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, said, "If you could tell me that the industry was going to have another couple of years like this, I would be concerned." But he predicted the economic upturn would soon lift sales and motivate buyers to choose more expensive cars, which are more profitable for the industry. "The industry's earnings will recover nicely," he said.
 
A Lack of Confidence
 With plenty of new-car offerings, and the national economy in the early stages of a recovery, auto executives could not provide precise reasons why consumers have not been buying cars more aggressively. Robert C. Stempel, the chairman of General Motors, said surveys showed that consumers were optimistic about the national economy but less confident about their personal finances.
"We're in a recovery in a technical sense, but it's very slow," said Mr. McCammon. "We can only hope the consumer becomes more confident." He suggested that unemployment, lack of construction spending, tight credit and Government deficits all could be hurting automotive buying.
Mr. McCammon said one important reason for the Ford loss was an erosion in sales in its two-door sporty-car segment, which has been profitable in the past. He said sales of the Ford Probe, Mercury Cougar and Ford Thunderbird had been disproportionately hurt by the recession.
Also, sales of Ford's full-sized pickup truck have slowed as buyers turn to compact versions, which are less profitable.
Ford's $574.4 million quarterly loss came on revenue of $21.12 billion, compared with a profit of $101.7 million, or 22 cents a share, on revenue of $22.99 billion in the comparable period last year. For the nine months, Ford has lost $1.78 billion, on revenue of $66.3 billion, compared with a profit of $1.38 billion, or $2.99 a share, on revenue of $73.46 billion.
G.M. reported a loss of $1.06 billion on revenue of $28.94 billion, compared with last year's third-quarter loss of $1.98 billion on revenue of $30.77 billion. For the nine months, G.M. lost $2.22 billion on revenue of $89.45 billion, compared with a loss of $368.7 million on revenue of $94.83 billion last year.
 
Ford Sales Down 2%
 Ford's worldwide factory sales were down 2 percent, to 1,278,000 cars and trucks. American operations were weak, but Ford has had even more trouble abroad, especially in Britain, which is in the midst of a deep recession. Third-quarter losses from automotive operations in the United States were $197 million, while foreign losses were $554 million.
Ford's financial-services group, which includes Ford Motor Credit, the First Nationwide savings and loan operations, and the Associates Corporation, posted a profit of $177 million, compared with $141 million last year.
Ford's third-quarter share of the car market in the United States was 20 percent, down from the 21.1 percent share posted for all of last year.
Ford's share of the truck market dropped to 28.7 percent, from 29.3 percent.
 
G.M.'s Explanation
 G.M. said its loss was a result of weak demand for autos in the United States and production losses from extensive retooling for new models in Europe and this country.
Worldwide factory sales of cars and trucks for the quarter were 1,582,000, down 10.5 percent from the 1990 period. G.M. said the cost of its incentives, while sizable, was slightly lower than in the period last year.
Yesterday G.M.'s three non-automotive subsidiaries -- Electronic Data Services, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the GM-Hughes Electronics Corporation -- reported an aggregate net profit of $530 million for the quarter, down from $580 million in the 1990 period.

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns of Phone Industry Lag

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Commerce Department warned today that American telephone companies were investing less to modernize their networks than their leading competitors in the industrial world. But its main recommendation was for the Government to stay out of the business.
The report comes after a season of breakdowns that have raised new concerns about the reliability of today's telephone networks and is likely to heat up a growing national debate about lifting restrictions on the seven regional Bell telephone companies. 
 The report was initiated by the Commerce Department and reflects a consensus of most departments in the Government, as well as the White House. Officials pressing for greater deregulation repeated the Administration's support for letting the Bell companies provide electronic information services and enter the cable television business. But experts representing large corporate communications customers and individual consumers argued for more regulation.
 
In Last Place
 Prepared by the department's National Telecommunications and Information Administration, the report estimated that America's local and long-distance telephone companies invested an average of $88 for each telephone line -- household and business -- for modernization in 1989, placing them last among compamies in the Group of Seven leading industrialized countries. The rate of American investment plummeted by an average of 8.1 percent a year between 1980 and 1989, the most recent year for which figures were available, according to the report.
Companies in what was formerly West Germany led the world by investing $238 for each line in l989 and increasing their annual investment an average of 5.1 percent in the decade.
The comparison provided vivid evidence of a lag in the installation of advanced new network technologies in the United States, though some experts said such comparisons painted an unduly pessimistic picture.
United States officials, though shying away from generalizations about the nation's communications network, said that by some measures it remains the best in the world. The report noted that the average American telephone line carries 3,516 local and long-distance calls a year, 75 percent more than in any other country and nearly three times as many as the average line in Japan.
Officials said said this heavy use was evidence that telephone companies had stimulated demand by providing good service at good prices.
"Competition and deregulation in this country have worked very, very well," said Thomas J. Sugrue, Deputy Assistant Commerce Secretary. "Yet the landscape is littered with a number of Government-imposed barriers."
These barriers, he said, had "created a series of little economic fiefdoms in the country." He added: "While everyone wants to get into someone else's turf, they don't want anyone else moving onto their turf. What we're saying is that what's good for the goose is good for the gander."
The report also said that by 1994 the United States will fall behind some other countries in rolling out a number of new technologies. The report predicted that Japan, western Germany and France would complete advanced transmission lines that can simultaneously carry both voice and data throughout their telephone networks. The United States is expected to install the technology, known as an integrated services digital network, on only 49.8 percent of all telephone lines by 1994.
The report also predicted that by that year only 57 percent of all American telephone exchanges will use an advanced call-routing technology, called Signaling System 7, that allows new services like Caller ID, voice-mail and selective call screening. All of France's exchanges will use the system, as will about 83 percent of the exchanges in Britain and 60 percent of those in Canada.
Experts representing consumers and large corporate customers argued that the report's indicators were misleading and that the United States continued to have the most advanced communications.
"We think the larger number of economists around the world say that U.S. infrastructure is far superior to that of other countries," said Page Montgomery, senior vice president of Economics and Technology Inc., a Boston consulting firm that has prepared reports for large corporations and the Consumer Federation of America. "There is no other country that has the same set of capabilities."
Brian Moir, head of the International Communications Association, which represents the nation's largest business users of telecommunications, added that the Government had successfully promoted competition. "Everybody's for competition," Mr. Moir said. "But competition today came despite the existence of monopolies. We have competition because of Government regulation."

HEADLINE: Japan Ending Sanctions Against South Africa

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Japan said today that it was lifting most of its trade sanctions against South Africa, paving the way for the country to resume its role as one of Pretoria's largest trading partners.
The move, which came after strong pressure from Japanese businesses that were reluctant to obey the trade embargo for the last five years, means that Japan's nuclear power industry can once again buy South African uranium and that Japanese companies can now build factories there. 
 The Government also said it was withdrawing its request that the Japanese public shun Kruggerands, the South African gold coins that were so popular during the height of Japan's financial boom in the 1980's that they were advertised in Tokyo taxi cabs. And Japanese Government officials said they would soon restore air travel between the countries.
 
Helping Black Majority
 The Government's chief spokesman, Misoji Sakamoto, said this morning that the reform process in South Africa was now "irreversible," and that improving conditions for the country's black majority required "restoring growth to South Africa's economy."
The Bush Administration lifted a number of sanctions against South Africa in July, and last week the Commonwealth Governments agreed to phase out restrictions.
South Africa's Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, said in a statement issued in Pretoria today that his country welcomed Japan's move, according to the South African Embassy in Washington. Mr. Botha said that South Africa and its neighbors would benefit from expanded trade and that the Japanese move would help his country's internal negotiations.
South Africa's white minority Government has been discussing with black political leaders a possible new Constitution and multiracial political process.
 
Diplomatic Talks Weighed
 The chief spokesman for Japan's Foreign Ministry, Taizo Watanabe, said Tokyo was considering whether to begin discussions to restore diplomatic relations between the countries, which were never resumed after World War II. But he said no schedule had been set, and he declined to comment on news reports here that South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, might visit Tokyo in the near future.
Japanese officials said they were keeping a ban on equipment sales to the South African police and military in place, at least for the moment.
South African trade has repeatedly been a sore point for the Japanese Government, which was embarrassed to discover in 1987 that it had become the country's largest trading partner, with two-way trade of more than $4 billion.
After a considerable struggle between the Government and the business community here, amid international concern about the South African policy of apartheid, trade was restrained through sanctions and political pressure. Although the embargo had a number of loopholes while in place, allowing trade in many areas to continue, two-way trade has still fallen significantly since.
Last year, Japan exported $1.47 billion in goods to South Africa, primarily metal products, automobiles and textiles, and imported $1.8 billion in goods, chiefly metal ores.
In late 1988, Japan's utilities, under considerable political pressure, said they would stop importing South African uranium for their nuclear power plants. Until then, South Africa accounted for about 11 percent of Japan's uranium supply, a vital fuel for a country with no oil and no nuclear fuels of its own.
But it was never clear whether the ban fully took effect. Japan buys its processed nuclear fuel from other countries, including the United States, and it is widely thought that some South African uranium is mixed in.
 
No Formal Gold Ban
 The Japanese Government never formally banned the sale of South African gold, and much of it is still traded here. But it is unlikely it will prove as popular as it was a few years ago, when the Japanese economy was booming and some of the country's wealthiest individuals sought to put much of their winnings into gold.
With the investment restraints lifted, Japanese companies should be in a good position to quickly resume business. After a number of American companies departed in the mid-1980's, Japanese computer makers, consumer electronics concerns and car makers seized much of the market share before the Japanese Government cracked down.
For example, Japanese companies control more than half of South Africa's mainframe computer market, although their share in the United States and Europe is much smaller. Much the same is true in automobiles.
"We are in a much better position to go back in than the American firms are," a senior executive of a large Japanese car maker said today. "But we don't want to seem to be rushing in, for obvious reasons."

HEADLINE: Stocks Retreat Again; Dow Drops by 20.58

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stock prices pulled back yesterday for the second straight day, with a weak bond market seen as the main culprit. New York Stock Exchange volume was heavy, even with a power failure giving traders an unexpected morning coffee break.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.58 points, to 3,039.80, on Big Board volume of 194.4 million shares, up from 154.2 million on Monday. Declining stocks outpaced gainers by 914 to 685. 
 Again, high among investor concerns were weak corporate earnings. The stocks of companies that posted good results rose, but gains were limited by a broader gloom generated by a weak bond market and worries about inflation, analysts said.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 2.19, to 387.83, while the Big Board composite slipped 1.01, to 213.87. On the American Stock Exchange, the composite was up slightly, by 0.06, to 381.84.
With smaller issues trading higher, the Nasdaq composite of over-the-counter trading moved up 0.19, to 537.15, and the Russell 2000 index rose 0.03, to 183.
 
Effect of Program Trades
 Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said that afternoon program trades combined to pull the Dow down by about 25 points. The firm also noted that Philip Morris, down 2 3/8 to 69 3/8, accounted for 20 percent of the Dow's decline.
Philip J. Roth, chief technical analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, thought the biggest drag yesterday was the weak bond market. He noted that the weakness was concentrated in blue-chip issues and high-priced institutional favorites and that the broad market was only narrowly negative.
"The market's overall look is a consolidation, not a big decline. Mr. Roth said. "When you have a narrowly negative market and limited price volatility on the downside, it points toward consolidation."
Stocks had small gains in the morning amid some positive earnings reports. But as bond prices extended their losses, blue chips began moving into negative ground as selling increased.
The positive earnings yesterday included Quaker Oats and Bankers Trust. Quaker jumped 3 1/8, to 59 3/8, on stronger-than-expected profits, which analysts said represented a significant turnaround. Nomi Ghez, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs, repeated her "buy" recommendation.
Bankers Trust rose 3/8, to 63 5/8, after it, too, posted higher-than-expected earnings. The bank company also said it had signed an agreement to sell its Bankers Trust Company of California's San Francisco unit to First Bank System Inc.
In the retail sector, Ann Taylor fell 3 3/8, to 16 1/2, after lowering earnings estimates for the second time in the quarter.
Toys "R" Us, removed from the Bear, Stearns recommended list by Joseph Buckley, the firm's analyst, fell 3 1/4, to 29 3/4. The concern is for growing pressure on profit margins and expectations of stiff price competition with rival Child World Inc.
Shares of Electronic Arts, a maker of interactive entertainment software, rose 3, to 32 5/8, after the company posted higher earnings.
Rubbermaid Holding rose 1 1/4, to 59 1/2. The company split its stock 2 for 1, its fourth split in nine years, and announced a 13.3 percent increase in its dividend.
Morgan Stanley rose 1 3/8, to 55 7/8, on a 69 percent increase in third-quarter earnings.
Duracell International declined by 1/4, to 28 5/8, as the battery manufacturer priced a 12-million-share offering at 28 3/4 a share.
The formation of a technology partnership with Eastman Kodak sent Novell stock up 3/4, to 45 3/4.
General Motors fell 3/8, to 36 7/8, in reporting a $1.1 billion third-quarter loss. Ford was also down, 3/8 to 28 5/8, after reporting a $574 million loss.
Traders said Monday's decision by the Supreme Court to hear new oral arguments on whether cigarette makers are liable for smokers' illnesses pushed tobacco stocks down. Besides the drop in Philip Morris, RJR Nabisco was down 3/8, to 10 3/8.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
3M's Profit Down 12%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MAPLEWOOD, Minn., Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, citing weak global economies, said today that its third-quarter earnings fell nearly 12 percent and that it expected a similar decline in the fourth quarter. The company earned $296 million, or $1.35 a share, compared with $336 million, or $1.52 a share, in the 1990 period. Sales rose 1 percent, to $3.38 billion, from $3.34 billion in the comparable 1990 period. Allen F. Jacobson, 3M's chairman and chief executive, said a decline in domestic economic activity and slow growth abroad had held back demand for many 3M product lines and resulted in continued pricing pressures, and added that there was no evidence of meaningful economic improvement. The company's stock fell 75 cents today, to $92.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Wang Has $9.8 Million Loss

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 22

 BODY:
Wang Laboratories Inc. reported a quarterly loss today of $9.8 million, but the troubled computer maker said its revenues had started to stabilize.
The loss for the first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 compared with a net profit of $2.6 million, or 2 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year. 
 Revenues were $460.7 million, down 18 percent from $563.8 million in 1990.
"The general economy and the state of our industry continue to be difficult," said Richard W. Miller, the chairman of Wang. "However, we are encouraged by these results."
The company noted that before interest and tax expenses, Wang posted a $4 million operating profit after three straight losing quarters.
The company said it was waiting to realize revenue from a new alliance with the International Business Machines Corporation. Frank Ryan, a Wang spokesman, said the company expected to see revenue from I.B.M. products in early 1992. Under the alliance, Wang will sell I.B.M. computers, some under the Wang label.
Wang has been plagued by losses for more than two years, and the company has sharply reduced its work force. Wang class B stock rose 25 cents in Amex trading today, to $3.

HEADLINE: Europeans in Accord to Create Vastly Expanded Trading Bloc

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Europeans took a decisive step today toward building a unified Europe, agreeing to create the world's largest trading bloc. It will embrace 380 million Western European consumers from the Arctic Circle to the shores of the Mediterranean.
The 12-nation European Community, now the world's largest trading bloc, and the 7-member European Free Trade Association concluded two years of tough negotiations at a make-or-break overnight session in Luxembourg early today. After compromising on nettlesome details like fishing and trucking rights, they agreed to form a new common market, to be known as the European Economic Area. 
 That paved the way for several new countries to seek full membership in the European Community, which is rapidly moving toward social and political, as well as economic, integration.
 
'Important Trial Run'
 "Now we are heading full speed toward the community," Sweden's Prime Minister, Carl Bildt, said today. Of the seven members of the Free Trade Association, Sweden and Austria have already applied to join, and Finland is expected to do so soon, while Switzerland, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein are still undecided.
Jacques Delors, president of the community's executive commission, said today that the accord would serve as "an important trial run" for countries hoping to join the community and at the same time aiding the community's "spiderlike strategy to organize the architecture of a Greater Europe." The community members are France, Britain, Ireland, Germany, Greece, Portugal, Spain, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark, Luxembourg and Italy. 
The agreement would allow for the free flow of most goods, service, capital and people among its 19 member nations and should go into effect just as a single regional market is formed by the European Community on Jan. 1, 1993.
At the same time, it could mean tougher global competition for the United States and Japan, particularly in areas of trade that depend on negotiations between regional blocs, such as in agriculture, textiles and automobiles.
The agreement is now subject to approval by each of the 19 national parliaments, some of which are still expected to hold lengthy debates about the merits of the accord. Switzerland is also required by its constitution to approve the accord by referendum. But the private sectors in many of the nations of the free trade association are particularly eager for greater access to the community's markets.
European officials said that today's accord should also encourage community members to agree on the next economic and political stages of their own integration process when a year of difficult negotiations culminates in a summit meeting in Maastricht, the Netherlands, on Dec. 9 and 10.
"It increases the chances that the heads of government of the community members will agree on substantial progress in deepening cooperation within the European Community," Germany's Chancellery Minister, Rudolf Seiters, said today.
Community members are hoping to work out a timetable to create a single regional currency and central bank, as well as to agree on mechanisms for reaching a common foreign and security policy to give the community a stronger political voice in world affairs.
If the Maastricht meeting achieves these goals, even after today's agreement goes into effect, the community's higher level of economic and political unity will continue to give it a separate identity within the European Economic Area. In essence, the Luxembourg agreement involves acceptance by the seven members of the Free Trade Association of community trading, financial and labor rules. It will also require them to adopt community laws on consumer protection, company law, environmental protection, competition and social policy.
In exchange, goods, workers, services and capital from the seven nations, which have a combined population of 40 million, will be given broad access to the community. Even now, with $220 billion in annual trade, the seven do 60 percent of their trade with community countries; 25 percent of community imports and exports are with the Free Trade Association.
The talks were deadlocked for several months over demands for special arrangements by members of both blocs. Finally, early today, compromises were found in the three key areas of dispute -- fishing rights, trucking rights and special payments for poorer community members.
The fishing dispute, which stemmed from the refusal of Iceland to open its fishing grounds to community members, was finally resolved when Norway allowed Spanish fishermen a larger quota of fish from Norwegian waters in exchange for gaining greater access for its own fishing products in the larger market.
Poor community members had been demanding a larger contribution from Free Trade Association countries to a special regional development fund. The seven finally agreed to provide $1.8 billion in low-interest credits and $600 million in grants.
The final dispute involved Austria's and Switzerland's environmental opposition to heavy truck traffic from community members. Under the compromise, Greece was offered a special quota, and the community agreed to reduce truck emissions by 60 percent over 12 years in Austria and to make greater use of railroads in Switzerland.
 
Farm Issues Postponed
 The two sides also decided to postpone integration in the highly sensitive area of farm products, principally because community members are still trying to revise their own Common Agricultural Policy so that the current round of world trade liberalization talks can resume.
But the agreement also includes features that suggest the parties intend to go beyond formation of a common market. They will establish a court modeled after the community's European Court of Justice to settle disputes and, in an important step toward political cooperation, they will form a joint council of ministers.
The move toward greater integration will be strengthened by Austria's and Sweden's negotiations to join the community. These talks are expected to start next year, with a view to completion by 1995. Negotiations with other applicants may take place at the same time.
"We hope today's agreement will make it easier for Norway and Finland to approach a decision on the question," Denmark's Foreign Minister, Uffe Ellemann-Jensen, said. Norway's main parties disagree over community membership, but Finland's Prime Minister, Esko Aho, has signaled that Helsinki will apply next spring.
Several of Eastern Europe's new democracies, notably Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, have also expressed hopes of eventual membership in the community, but they have been told this will only be possible when their economies are strong enough to compete with more developed nations.
But Frans Andriessen, the community's commissioner in charge of external affairs, said today that the European Economic Area should nonetheless help Eastern Europe because "we will be able to function even better and take our responsibility in the reforms taking place there."

HEADLINE: Leftist Party in Canada Wins Power in 2 Provincial Governments

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The left-leaning New Democratic Party has swept into power in two more Canadian provinces -- British Columbia and Saskatchewan -- creating a new source of economic tension for the Conservative-led national Government in Ottawa and altering the dynamics of efforts to keep the country united.
Saskatchewan's 1 million voters on Monday joined British Columbia's 3 million last Thursday in electing New Democratic Party premiers. Ontario, Canada's richest and most populous province with 9.6 million people, have been led by the New Democrats for the past 13 months. In addition, one of Canada's two territories, the Yukon, has had a New Democratic Party government since 1985. 
 The new elections mean that three of Canada's 10 provinces and 52 percent of the country's 26 million people are now under control of the New Democratic Party, which was born in the farm depression early this century and generally has been ranked as a third party after the Progressive Conservatives and the Liberals.
 
No Swing to the Left
 While it has managed western provincial governments in the past, never has the New Democratic Party had as broad political support as today -- a sign, many politicians said, of disgruntlement with economic conditions and disenchantment with the traditional parties and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, whose standing in political popularity polls has reached new lows.
Yet the politicians cautioned against interpreting the vote as a massive swing to the left. "There is no direct correlation between how a party does nationally and provincially," said Dr. Angus Reid, a pollster. Noting the predominance of local issues, as in American gubernatorial campaigns, he added, "there tends to be almost an inverse correlation."
In British Columbia, the new premier is Michael Harcourt, 48 years old, a storefront lawyer from Vancouver. He was helped by scandals in the Social Credit party of philosophical conservatives who had ruled the province for all but three of the past 39 years.
In Saskatchewan, Roy Romanow, a 52-year-old former provincial attorney general in an earlier New Democratic government, was aided by the general discontent with the Conservatives, especially by farmers hit by low grain prices. His chief opponent was Premier Grant Devine, the Conservative incumbent who had won back-to-back elections in 1982 and 1986.
 
Farm Bailout Announced
 In a bid to help Mr. Devine two weeks ago, Prime Minister Mulroney announced an $800 million farm bailout, nearly half of which was destined for Saskatchewan's grain belt.
A decline in the polls of Ontario's Premier Bob Rae, the first New Democratic leader ever in this province, was seen as further evidence that the country is not veering dramatically to the left.
Although the 43-year-old former labor lawyer has backtracked on a number of socialist proposals, such as nationalizing the Ontario automobile insurance, Mr. Rae has been in running battles with the business community for a year over other economic issues.
The New Democrats, seeking improved social and economic conditions for the disadvantaged, generally believe in a bigger role for government. But such policies run counter to the current trend in Ottawa, where leaders are trying to engage the private sector more, and where a large public sector is now seen creating risks for investment and savings and eventually the living standards of ordinary people.
In the unity debate, the National Democrats, in effect, now have veto power, since Ottawa's constitutional reform plan, unveiled last month, needs approval of seven provinces with at least 50 percent of the population.
