HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
$70.3 Million Deficit Posted By Compaq

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The Compaq Computer Corporation, besieged by price-cutting rivals and under pressure from lagging sales, said yesterday that it would slash its work force by 1,400, or 12 percent, and reported its first quarterly loss ever, $70.3 million for the third quarter. Separately, the Control Data Corporation said it lost $7.5 million in the quarter,
Following are the details of the companies' results:
 
Compaq
 Compaq's loss contrasted to a profit of $123.6 million, or $1.38 a share, in the corresponding period last year. Revenues in the third quarter fell 17.8 percent, to $709.4 million from $863 million. 
 The Houston-based company earned $17 million from operations in the quarter, but took a special charge of $135 million to cover layoff-related costs.
Compaq's share price gained $1.25, to $34.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. The announcement came early yesterday morning before trading opened.
Analysts said the cutbacks by Compaq were widely expected, and some said they were overdue. Apple Computer, International Business Machines and many other personal computer makers announced layoffs earlier in the year.
Compaq, which had been a strong performer since it shipped its first personal computers in January, 1983, has faced tough price competition this year from smaller companies, like Dell Computer, Gateway Computer and Northgate Computer. It has scrambled in the last five months to slash prices in an effort to blunt their gains.
Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's chief operating officer, said in an interview that job cuts among the company's 11,800 employees would come from all operating divisions.
The company plans to begin notifying employees who will lose their jobs within the next two weeks, and that all of them will have left the company by the end of November, said Debra Globe, a spokeswoman. "Now that people are aware of the situation, we don't want to leave them hanging," she said.
All employees included in the layoffs will receive a minimum of two months' pay. The severance terms are to include two weeks' pay for every year of employment, as well as counseling on seeking new jobs.
Mr. Pfeiffer said Compaq had to realign costs so that it could sustain gross profit margins of about 35 percent of sales, down from more than an enviable 40 percent of sales in recent years.
Joseph (Rod) Canion, Compaq's president, said last July that the company hoped to avoid layoffs by improving manufacturing techniques, broadening its distribution methods beyond dealer chains like Computerland and other steps. But Mr. Pfeiffer said the sales outlook had darkened since then.
Charles R. Wolf, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation, said the job cutbacks at Compaq should be interpreted as a sign that the personal computer market will have little, if any, growth for the next few years.
 
Control Data
 Control Data cited a weak economy and slumping demand for computers in reporting its $7.5 million loss. A delay in shipments to the Soviet Union for computers designed to improve safety in the nuclear industry contributed to the deficit, the company said.
The current quarter is expected to be profitable, with the shipments completed to the Soviet Union, the company added.
Control Data, based in Bloomington, Minn., earned $8.5 million, or 20 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Revenue fell 20.5 percent, to $344.9 million from $434.1 million.

HEADLINE: RJR Nabisco Reports Neet Of $123 Million in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
Once beleagured by a crushing load of debt, the RJR Nabisco Holding Corporation is now on the upswing. The food and cigarette company's third-quarter net income rose to $123 million, compared with a loss of $86 million for the corresponding period last year.
The gain was attributed in large part to the company's continuing efforts to reduce its huge debt, said Jason Wright, a spokesman for RJR Nabisco. In its most recent debt-reduction move at the beginning of this month, the company disclosed a plan for large offerings of common and preferred stock that would help the company retire some of the debt. 
 Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company bought the company in 1989 in a deal worth $25 billion. Mr. Wright said RJR Nabisco has since reduced its debt from a high of about $29 billion in 1989 to $16.7 billion this year.
As a result, interest payments dropped during the third quarter to $500 million, compared with $770 million for the corresponding period a year ago. For the first nine months of 1991, interest payments were $1.6 billion, down from $2.3 billion in 1990.
Ronald Morrow, an analyst with Smith Barney, said the company had made huge strides in reducing its debt. "It's very encouraging," he said. "The situation should continue to improve during the next several months."
The company was also helped by sales in the company's food and tobacco businesses that were healthy despite the recession, Mr. Morrow said. Sales for the quarter rose 6.5 percent, to $3.76 billion, compared with $3.53 billion in 1990. Income per share rose to 7 cents, compared with a loss last year.
RJR Nabisco's worldwide tobacco business, the maker of Camel and Salem cigarettes among other brands, had sales of $2.17 billion, up 3 percent from 1990's sales of $2.11 billion. The rise was primarily attributed to growth in Europe, the Middle East and Asia, where sales rose 13 percent.
One problem the tobacco business faces is a dip in domestic sales, some analysts said. RJR's sales in the United States fell 1 percent over last year. "They are going to have to spend aggressively to turn the domestic business around," Mr. Morrow said.
The company's food business also performed well. At the Nabisco Foods Group, which includes Blue Bonnet margarine and Planters nuts. sales rose 13 percent, to $1.6 billion, in the quarter, compared with $1.4 billion for the previous year.
Mr. Wright said the food group's sales have been fueled by the continual introduction of new products this year, like Mini Oreo cookies, Mr. Phipps pretzel chips and Life Savers (holes) candies.
The company's shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday to close at $10.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 3; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Car Sales Languish as Uncertainty Deters Buyers

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 23

 BODY:
With worries about the economy and job security apparently weighing heavily on car buyers, vehicle sales were sharply lower in recent days from last year's level. Several dealers said showroom traffic had fallen 20 to 30 percent.
But while analysts said the poor sales suggested that the recovery was having trouble maintaining momentum, they said the latest figures did not signal that the economy was about to dip back into recession. 
 Price increases on 1992 cars appear to be dampening some excitement that buyers may feel about new models, dealers said. Sizable rebates are also no longer motivating buyers, who are more surprised when models do not carry incentives, they added.
 
A 16.1% Decline
 Auto makers reported today that sales of cars and light trucks built in the United States declined 16.1 percent in mid-October from the period a year earlier.
"Sales remain weaker than expected," said William H. Steele, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco. "It does not bode well for the recovery."
The annual selling rate of domestic cars, based on seasonal factors, was 6.2 million in mid-October, down slightly from a 6.4 million rate in the third quarter and sharply off the 7.2 million rate in mid-October 1990.
Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch in New York, said he expected the annual rate for all of October to be roughly 6.2 million.
"This recovery is two steps forward, one step back, and it looks like October is a step back," he said.
Mr. Heinbach added that auto sales for the fourth quarter may be hurt by production cuts in November and December. Ward's Automotive Reports stated earlier this week that suppliers expect that Ford, General Motors and Chrysler would cut production by 4 percent, or 100,000 cars and trucks, for the fourth quarter over all. The report suggests that car makers are receiving weak orders from dealers, Mr. Heinbach said, "and that's not inspiring."
Dealers confirmed Mr. Heinbach's suspicion. "People have money but they're afraid to spend it," said Joel Avery, sales manager of Rockingham Toyota-Dodge-Nissan in Salem, N.H.
As for rebates, "It's not really an issue anymore," said Jerry Holsman, sales manager of Riley Chevrolet-Geo in Jefferson City, Mo. "But I'm sure it would be if we didn't have them."
Sales were up approximately 10 percent in recent weeks over the period a year earlier at Longo Toyota in El Monte, Calif., according to Patrick J. Verrona, general sales manager. But Mr. Verrona said the dealership's salespeople were working harder to strike deals. Customers are taking about two weeks to make their final decisions to buy, compared with just a few days a year ago, he said.
The manufacturers that produce vehicles in the United States sold 136,881 cars between Oct. 11 and 20, and 73,357 light trucks, a category that includes mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles as well as pickup trucks.
 
16.7% Drop for Big 3
 The Big Three companies posted a collective sales decline of 16.7 percent in car sales during mid-October, while Japanese companies that build cars in the United States reported an overall drop of 11.8 percent. These Japanese "transplant" manufacturers raised their share of the American car market to 15.9 percent in mid-October, from 15.2 percent a year earlier. The Big Three saw their market share decline to 84.1 percent, from 84.8 percent a year earlier.
Of the Big Three, the General Motors Corporation's car sales dropped 13.1 percent, to 62,234, and light-truck sales dropped 21.2 percent, to 28,486.
The Ford Motor Company reported a drop of 22.6 percent in car sales, to 35,349, and light-truck sales fell 20.7 percent, to 24,459.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales dropped 16.5 percent, to 17,500, based on estimates by Ward's; the maker's truck sales dropped 1.6 percent, to 16,300.
The Honda Motor Company sold 8,998 American-built cars, a drop of 15.9 percent, and the Toyota Motor Corporation reported a sales drop of 21.5 percent in the period, to 6,429 cars.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Worldwide While Gold Prices Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled higher on world currency markets yesterday in trading driven largely by technical factors.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $362.30 an ounce, down $1.60 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $362, off $1.25. 
 With no fresh news to move the markets, the dollar was driven higher in technical trading. Dealers said that once the currency broke through 1.7100 German marks, there was a spinoff effect that lifted the dollar against other key currencies. In New York, the dollar settled at 1.7113 German marks, up from 1.7000 on Tuesday.
 
'Relatively Tight Ranges'
 "Nothing was happening very fast," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank. "There was good volume, but the dollar held to relatively tight ranges."
Analysts noted a basic shift in market psychology concerning interest rates. Traders are beginning to consider the possibility that the Federal Reserve may not loosen credit to stimulate the economy; the Fed has been expected to lower rates in the wake of a string of sluggish economic reports.
Lower interest rates are generally bearish for the dollar because they erode the value of dollar-denominated securities.
"People are looking at fiscal policy instead of monetary policy as the tool that will extricate the economy from the recession, and that means no more lower rates," said Randolph Donney, an analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Mr. Donney also said that lawmakers' efforts to fashion a tax-cut package, which could result in higher consumer spending and in turn spur the economy, "bodes well for the dollar," even though the results of any legislative changes would not be felt in real terms for some time.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 131.75 yen, unchanged from Tuesday. Later in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 131.30 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 131.65 yen, up from 131.40 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7056, from $1.7145 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.6985 to buy a pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.7085.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Revamping for Ogilvy & Mather

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide announced a restructuring yesterday in which the subsidiary of the financially troubled WPP Group P.L.C. will scale back the services it directly offers to clients in order to concentrate on advertising and direct marketing.
Under the restructuring, said Graham Phillips, chairman and chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather, its public relations and sales promotion units will become free-standing companies within London-based WPP. Jonathan Rinehart, chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Public Relations Group in New York, and Keith Bantick, chairman and chief executive of Promotional Campaigns Inc. in London, will report to WPP rather than to Mr. Phillips. 
 The restructuring is not meant to cut costs, an Ogilvy spokeswoman, Nora Slattery, said, but rather will "get senior people freed up to work for clients" in Ogilvy's primary operations.
That would make sense, said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at Paine Webber in New York. "When business is like this, you've got to focus on business," he added, citing the need for Ogilvy to strengthen its hold on its advertising accounts like the American Express Company's green card.
Nevertheless, the move "is a sign of the increasing pressure that WPP is feeling," said James Dougherty, vice president of research for County NatWest U.S.A. in New York. Despite a $1 billion refinancing in April, WPP continues to face financial pressures exacerbated by the recession and the high price of its 1989 acquisition of Ogilvy.
As part of the restructuring, Jerome W. Pickholz, 59 years old, chairman and chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather Direct, becomes a new vice chairman of Ogilvy, and Reimer Thedens, 42, chairman of Ogilvy Direkt in Germany, becomes a new vice chairman of Ogilvy Europe.
Also, Ogilvy's Asian-Pacific operations will be combined into a single region under Rod Wright, regional head of Southeast Asia.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Move Up

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher and interest rates fell slightly in moderately active trading yesterday, helped by a set of reports reaffirming the notion that economic activity remains stagnant and a successful auction of new two-year notes.
The reports included auto sales, which remained weak; the sense from regional Federal Reserve Banks that economic conditions across the country were "weak or growing slowly" in September and early October, and a poll of the nation's home builders, which showed that customer traffic has receded to levels not seen since January. 
 "To have the lowest mortgage rates in 14 years and still have very few people looking at houses is very disturbing," said Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Homebuilders, the group that polls homebuilders each month.
Still, the market's response was measured. Traders said concern about action by Congress and the Administration to cut taxes remains an overriding issue.
"The real side of the economy is not showing any signs of growth in final demand, and yet the bond market is basically just holding its own," said Joseph Liro, senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
"With all these new issues to be auctioned, the tax cut thing came at just the wrong time," one government bond trader said. "Once the market can refocus on economic fundamentals, it should do better."
 
$13.5 Billion Note Sale
 The first batch of new Treasury issues were auctioned yesterday, and market participants said the sale of $13.5 billion of two-year notes went well.
The new notes were sold at an average yield of 6.01 percent, down from the average rate of 6.14 percent at the last two-year note sale on Sept. 24. It was the lowest rate since an auction on April 19, 1977, when the rate was 5.87 percent.
In marked contrast to the last two-year auction, New York-based primary dealers bought well over 90 percent of the securities sold yesterday.
In what was seen as a possible reaction to the Salomon Brothers scandal, customers at the auction in September bypassed Wall Street houses.
Today the Treasury is expected to sell $9 billion of new five-year notes.
Those securities were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 6.97 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 19/32, up 1/4, to yield 8.07 percent, compared with 8.09 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 13/32, unchanged from late Tuesday, to yield 7.66 percent. And the outstanding 6 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/4, up 1/32, to yield 5.98 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills eased slightly.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.02 percent in late trading, down one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell the same amount, to a late offered rate of 5.08 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, two companies priced a total of $800 million worth of new debt securities.
The General Motors Acceptance Corporation offered $400 million of 7.50 percent four-year notes through an underwriting group led by the First Boston Corporation.
The securities were priced at $99.952, to yield 7.512 percent, 90 basis points over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
The notes, which mature Oct. 15, 1995, are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Morgan Stanley Group offered $400 million of five-year and 10-year notes through its principal subsidiary, Morgan Stanley & Co.
The $200 million worth of 8 percent five-year notes were priced at 99.915, to yield 8.02 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing when-issued yield on the new five-year Treasury notes to be sold today.
The remaining $200 million of 8 7/8 percent 10-year securities were priced at par, or $100, 1.20 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
Both portions of the issue are rated A-1 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poors.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority priced a $300 million offering of serial and term bonds.
Yields on the serial bonds range from 4.70 percent on securities maturing in 1992 to a maximum yield of 6.80 percent on bonds maturing in 2005.
A 6.50 percent term bond maturing in 2019 was priced to yield 7.05 percent.
Goldman, Sachs & Co. acted as lead manager for the negotiated sale. The securities are rated A by Moody's and A-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were little changed in fairly active trading.
Prices continued to weaken in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds.
Traders said most widely quoted securities dipped by about 1/8 of a point.
"Buyers aren't showing a lot of interest, and there is a heavy supply of new issues coming next week," one municipal bond trader said.

HEADLINE: Deficit in Bank Insurance Fund Is Triple the Previous Projection

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Federal regulators released new estimates today that more than triple the deficit projected for next year in the fund that protects bank deposits.
The new estimates of a $9.6 billion deficit compare with the $3 billion previously predicted and reflect the view of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation that an increasing number of large banks are likely to fail in 1992 because of the weak economy. 
 The estimates raise serious questions about whether the industry will be able to repay the $30 billion taxpayer loan that the Administration has proposed to protect depositors. They also strongly suggest that $30 billion may not be enough.
The estimates put further pressure on the deposit corporation to raise once again the premiums that financial institutions pay the fund and to pass the costs on to customers in the form of increased fees and rates. But agency officials said today that no increase would occur before June at the earliest.
Representatives of the banking industry said the new figures were not surprising, given the state of the economy. "Clearly, with the recovery as slow and weak as it is, the new estimates are understandable," said Robert H. Dugger, chief economist of the American Bankers Association.
Legislation has been introduced in the House and Senate that would provide the taxpayer loan, and a bill could reach the floor of the House as early as next week. The chairmen of two House committees, who have been at odds over how to overhaul the banking system, said today that they had reached an agreement.
"Many of us have long felt that the estimates have been too optimistic, and this just corroborates that view," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, a member of the House Banking Committee. "Even these estimates will probably be too optimistic."
In a letter to Congress, the acting chairman of the deposit insurance corporation, Andrew C. Hove, warned today that "if the banking industry deteriorates further, $30 billion will probably not be sufficient." But he declined to provide a figure, saying any estimate would "be speculative at best."
 
Larger Line of Credit
 The fund is now worth $2.6 billion, and it has a $5 billion line of credit with the Treasury. The Administration has proposed increasing its credit line to $30 billion and providing an additional $45 billion in loans to be used as working capital. Officials say the loans would be repaid through the sale of assets from failed banks.
According to the estimates the F.D.I.C. sent to Congress today, the insurance fund is likely to need to borrow at least $9.6 billion next year and $8.7 billion in 1993, for a total of $18.3 billion.
These projections are based on an assumption that the economy will continue to sputter along at its current rate, or do slightly better. If the economy slides into a deeper recession, the F.D.I.C. predicted, the insurance fund may need to borrow $14.1 billion next year and $14.8 billion in 1993, for a total of $28.9 billion. That would leave the insurance fund with a cushion of only $1.1 billion going into 1994, to protect about $2.3 trillion worth of deposits.
"It should be recognized that under a more pessimistic set of assumptions, a $30 billion cap on loss borrowings could ultimately prove insufficient," Mr. Hove said in his letter. Mr. Hove has been acting as chairman until the arrival of William Taylor, who was confirmed Tuesday night as the new chairman by a voice vote of the Senate. He replaces L. William Seidman.
As he left last week, Mr. Seidman said $30 billion might be insufficient if the economy did not grow, but he did not provide significant details. He is expected to be asked about the latest estimates in an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee tomorrow.
Mr. Taylor is expected to arrive in his new office on Friday.
 
Economy Is Cited
 Alan Whitney, a spokesman for the deposit corporation, attributed the new projections to the weak economy.
"The economy, including most local commercial real estate markets, has not shown signs of a strong recovery," he said, pointing particularly to weakening bank earnings in California and New England.
The latest figures show that at least 200 banks with $86 billion in assets are likely to fail in 1992. But the figures show that if the economy declines, 239 banks holding $116 billion could fail. This year, in contrast, the regulators expect 137 banks holding assets if $73 billion will be seized.
Mr. Whitney said the board of the deposit corporation concluded yesterday that "while it is apparent that there may be a need to increase bank premiums, staff analysis is not complete," and will not be done by Nov. 1. That is the date by which a premium increase would have to be announced to take effect in January. As a result, he said, "bankers can be assured it will not be until June" that the F.D.I.C. will be able to raise premiums. Banks now pay 23 cents for every $100 in deposits.
The Treasury Department, which has consistently maintained that $30 billion would be enough to handle the problem and that it could be repaid by the banking industry, said today that it would not seek more money because it continued to believe its request would be sufficient to handle the fund's deficit.

HEADLINE: Chevron Earnings Dropped 22.3% in the Third Quarter

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
The Chevron Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, said yesterday that its net income declined 22.3 percent in the third quarter, extending the pattern of lower profits in the period for big oil companies.
Net income was $313 million, or 90 cents a share, compared with $403 million, or $1.14, in the comparable period last year. Revenues for the San Francisco-based company declined 5.1 percent, to $10.01billion, from $10.55 billion. 
 Like most international oil companies, Chevron said its operations were weakest in the United States. Low natural gas prices, gasoline price wars on the West Coast, sluggish demand for chemicals and a sluggish domestic economy were all factors in the profit decline, said Kenneth T. Derr, the company's chairman and chief executive.
Chevron's refining unit lost $10 million from operations in the United States, partly from the gasoline price wars, a 5 percent drop in sales and because lower operating rates at its refineries forced the company to buy gasoline from other refiners.
The same unit lost $53 million in the third quarter last year, when crude costs soared after Iraq invaded Kuwait and jawboning by the Administration kept marketers from raising retail prices enough to match the higher crude costs. Chevron spent $53 million in both quarters on pollution-control programs at its refineries and Chevron-brand service stations.
Earnings in the company's exploration unit declined sharply in the United States, to $29 million, from $201 million in the period a year ago, when crude prices soared. The company sold crude at an average price of $16.95 per barrel in the quarter, down from $22.20 in the comparable period a year ago.
But profits from foreign exploration rose to $327 million, from $285 million. Natural gas prices were higher outside the United States.
Chevron's share price fell yesterday $1, to $75.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Fed Finds Recovery Has Stalled

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
In a survey that tends to confirm that the recovery has lost momentum, the Federal Reserve reported today that retail sales have been virtually flat in recent weeks and that factory output, while still improving, is doing so at a slower pace.
Over all, according to the Fed's compilation of anecdotal evidence from its 12 regional banks, the nation's economy was "weak or growing slowly" in September and early October, with merchants "cautious" about the holiday season ahead. 
 Such language presents a somewhat less optimistic picture than the one in the report the Fed issued five weeks ago, in which it said "the economic recovery continues to be uneven across the country."
 
Sluggishness in Cars
 Underscoring the sluggishness, Detroit announced another dismal sales period today. Sales of cars and light trucks fell 16.1 percent in mid-October. [Page D6.]
The Fed survey, formally called "Current Economic Conditions" but usually referred to as the "beige book" after the color of its cover, is intended to aid Fed policy makers in advance of meetings of the Open Market Committee.
The market panel, consisting of Fed governors and regional presidents, meets eight times a year to set monetary policy, with the next session scheduled for Nov. 5.
 
Little Gain in Retail
 "In most districts, there has been little improvement in retail sales, and a few reported some slowing," stated the latest survey, which was based on information collected through Oct. 10 and prepared this time by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. "Manufacturing output is still improving," it added, "although at a slower pace in some areas."
The Fed's respondents -- mainly companies, stores and banks but also port officials, farmers and business groups -- repeatedly asserted that consumers were holding off buying big-ticket items, including cars, because of uncertainty over jobs and incomes. They also cited an inclination by consumers to buy at discounters rather than department stores, and they noted heavy activity in refinancing mortgages at lower rates.
By region, where the variations were perhaps less pronounced than usual, much of the relative strength was in the Chicago and Cleveland districts, which take in most of the Midwest, while the San Francisco district -- California and most of the Northwest -- seemed the weakest. Consistent with previously reported statistical data, the manufacturing areas did better than others.
In the New York district -- New York State and New Jersey -- developments "remained mixed" in recent weeks, the survey stated, with department-store sales sluggish despite greater promotional activity. The survey also cited "subdued interest" among potential buyers of new homes.
On the plus side, however, the vacancy rate for midtown -- but not downtown -- Manhattan office space declined. And in the western part of the district, twice as many Buffalo-area companies as in the last survey reported an increase in new orders.
The San Francisco district reported "deteriorating" factory activity in California and the Pacific Northwest, "sluggish" retail sales and "plummeted" rents for Los Angeles offices, where the vacancy rate could reach 30 percent next year.
Somewhat ominously, 17 percent of the district's business leaders said they expect the next 12 months to be characterized by recession, up from 7 percent five weeks ago and breaking a string of improved expectations that began in January.
 
Concern in New England
 Elsewhere, most respondents in the Boston district, which includes all of New England, said there was as yet "no clear uptrend" in manufacturing, with most expecting none until next year and several suspecting that the recent trend has, in fact, turned down.
On the other hand, some steel mills in the Cleveland district reported they were operating in the range of 85 percent of their capacity and that they had bulging order books for flat-rolled steel products, which lengthened the delivery dates of those products to late in the year and early 1992.
In the Richmond district, economic activity was described as "generally weak" in the period, with retail activity slowing further. But exports rose in September at the district's main ports: Baltimore; Charleston, S.C., and Hampton Roads, Va.
In the Atlanta district, which runs from Tennessee south to include Florida and Lousianna, retailers were described as "pessimistic" about holiday sales, but in the Minneapolis district -- the northern states from the Great Lakes to Montana -- sales were "fairly strong" with the aid of a September surge for trucks. And the Minneapolis-St. Paul area expects to garner $6 million in direct spending for each baseball playoff and World Series game held there.
The Dallas district, mostly Texas, is "growing very slowly," with car sales "anemic," the survey also showed. Activity is strongest along the Mexican border, where retail sales are benefitting from a strong peso.

The Economy
The deficit in the fund that protects bank deposits will more than triple next year, to $9.6 billion, according to new estimates by Federal regulators. This reflects the F.D.I.C. view that an increasing number of large banks are likely to fail in 1992. [Page A1.] 
 A new insurance industry called managed care is expanding rapidly into psychotherapy to block, alter, shorten or effectively end treatment where appropriate. [D1.]
The Fed said retail sales were virtually flat in recent weeks and factory output, while still improving, was doing so at a slower pace. [D1.] The White House is sharpening its focus on economic issues as the election nears. White House Memo. [A1.]
The first savings and loan deal in a program to bundle and sell billions of dollars in properties should be terminated, the chairman of a Congressional panel told the Government. [D2.]
Sales of U.S.-built cars and light trucks declined 16.1 percent in mid-October. [D6.]
The way to cut auto pollution and burn less gasoline is not to make new cars run cleaner, some economists say, but to stop the old ones from running at all. [A20.]
 
International
U.S. executives applauded the European agreement to create a barrier-free market, saying it would reduce the cost of doing business in Europe. [D1.]
Japanese auto makers are sending a new message: small is back. At the opening of the Tokyo Motor Show, there was a flood of two-seater sports cars influenced by Mazda's Miata. [D1.]

Compaq Computer said it would slash its work force by 1,400 and reported its first quarterly loss ever, $70.3 million. [D4.]
Other earnings news abounded: Goodyear said it earned $59.1 million, or $1.01 a share, in the third quarter. [D4.] Chevron was off 22.3 percent, extending the pattern of lower profits for big oil companies. [D7.] RJR Nabisco earned $123 million. [D14.]

Big airlines plan to raise fares for business travelers by lowering the discount on a seven-day advance purchase ticket. [D4.] United Airlines has chosen Indianapolis International Airport as the site for a $1 billion maintenance base. [D4.]
Prodigy Services has allowed the spread of anti-Semitism on its electronic bulletin boards, the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith has charged. [A21.]
 
Markets

HEADLINE: Baghdad Journal;
Who's Acting Tough Now? Why, Saddam Hussein.

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 23

 BODY:
After pinning several pounds of medals and hanging multiple sashes and honorary swords from the "mother of battles" on his top lieutenants and political cronies on Monday night, President Saddam Hussein told a nationwide television audience that Iraq was like the woman who chose to be killed rather than submit to rape.
Iraq's honor, Mr. Hussein said, is more important than surrendering to the dictates of the allied coalition, which has forced Iraq to submit to one ultimatum after another since Iraqi forces were driven from Kuwait last winter. 
 The 90-minute program of bravado and political bonding between Mr. Hussein and the Baath Party apparatchiks who continue to stand beside him because there are few other choices for them was part of a forceful new campaign by Mr. Hussein to pull the country together for a long-term survival strategy against a United Nations trade embargo and political pressure from the United States and its allies.
Over the last two months the Iraqi leader has swept aside the interim Government he put in place last March under a Baath Party stalwart, Saadun Hamadi. And he has dropped the conciliatory tone with which Iraq sought in the first months after the war to re-establish economic if not diplomatic ties with its neighbors in the Middle East and with major European trading partners.
Talk of democratic change has been dropped from official vocabularies.
In other words, the old Saddam Hussein is back, in the view of many Iraqi officials and foreign diplomats here.
"Before the war, Saddam was deeply convinced that the other side would never start and he was dancing on a high wire," an Eastern European diplomat said. "And now, with his tough new talk, he is repeating the same bluff: believing the world will never permit the Iraqi people to suffer so much and thinking that with an open border to Jordan, he can manage to do many things."
There are several elements in Mr. Hussein's new survival strategy, Iraqis and diplomats said in interviews.
Iraq is trying to accelerate its compliance with the United Nations cease-fire resolution to remove the pretext for continued international trade sanctions. Iraq's decision to admit this week that it was working on nuclear weapons is evidence of this strategy. Iraq still faces months of occupation by United Nations inspection teams, but Mr. Hussein is clearly looking forward to the day when this humiliating intrusion ends.
Further, Iraqi officials are working to maintain subsistance nutrition and key subsidies to the country's 18 million people to prevent food riots or a military insurrection that could threaten his grip on power in Baghdad. Mr. Hussein is printing money, raising salaries of key military and Government personnel and lowering gasoline prices.
Mr. Hussein appears to have given up for the moment on reconciling with Arab leaders who joined the allied coalition, but he has renewed an active campaign to court Arab opposition parties, intellectuals and other sources of Arab nationalist political influence to plead his case that Western nations are trampling on Arab pride and dignity in Iraq.
With this strategy, Mr. Hussein is betting that he can feed his economically devastated nation well into next year, or at least long enough to get out from under United Nations sanctions, which have separated the Iraqi leader from Iraq's enormous wealth of crude oil.
This will certainly not bring an end to Mr. Hussein's problems, but re-establishing Iraq's place in the international oil market will start a powerful dynamo in the economy.
 
The Effects of Rumors
 The critical factor for Mr. Hussein is maintaining domestic tranquillity. The precarious nature of his position became publicly evident this week when rumors flew through the city that United Nations trucks had barricaded the highway from Jordan, on which most food shipments enter Iraq. The rumor held that President Bush, in response to Mr. Hussein's fiery claim of Oct. 12 that Iraq could withstand a 20-year seige, had decided to test the Iraqi leader's mettle.
The rumor set off panic buying in Baghdad, sending food prices, already 10 times higher than a year ago, soaring another 30 to 50 percent.
The rumor was said to have been started by food traders angry that the Goverment was trying to impose tough new currency regulations that threatened to cut into their profit . Whether they were to blame or not, the currency restrictions were relaxed somewhat on Tuesday.
 
Providing Food and Shelter
 To combat the growing sense that United Nations relief agencies are doing as much as Mr. Hussein to provide food and shelter to Iraqis, the Government has invited a top United Nations official, Saddrudin Aga Khan, to come to Baghdad to begin negotiations on removing United Nations administrative offices from Iraq.
United Nations food shipments to the country could continue, the official said, but the food would have to be trucked in from Jordan or Turkey.
"We want to establish an understanding that this presence should not go on forever," a Foreign Ministry official said.
For now, the message being conveyed to the Iraqi people, and to President Bush and others who are working for Mr. Hussein's removal, was summed up on Monday night on Iraqi television by Izzat Ibrahim, vice chairman of Mr. Hussein's Revolutionary Command Council:
"Saddam Hussein is Iraq, and Iraq is Saddam Hussein."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The old Saddam Hussein is back, in the view of many foreign diplomats. The Iraqi President, left, pinned medals on his top lieutenants in a 90-minute show of bravado this week on Iraqi television. (Visnews)

HEADLINE: Florio Urges Democrats To Fight Back

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
With even his top advisers warning that the Republicans could seize control of both houses of the New Jersey Legislature for the first time in 20 years, Gov. Jim Florio says Democrats should "get off their knees" and come out fighting for the elections on Nov. 5.
In his first major political address of the legislative campaign, Mr. Florio told Democrats at a fund-raising dinner on Tuesday night in Mercer County, "Democrats are javelin throwers, not javelin catchers," and urged them to take the offensive. 
 Aides say the Governor, although stung by the way some Democrats are keeping their distance from him in their campaigns, is more concerned that they are abandoning the party's principles to keep their seats and making serious long-term political mistakes for short-term gains.
 
$2.8 Billion Tax Increase
 The Democrats clearly are in trouble.
"Sure, it could happen," said an aide who conceded that the Republicans could gain control of the Legislature. The Democrats control the Senate, 23 to 17, and the Assembly, 43 to 37, margins built in large part on Mr. Florio's race in 1989, when he defeated Jim Courter by a 3-to-2 margin. But the Governor's popularity has plummeted since then because of the $2.8 billion tax increase that he and the Democrats pushed through the Legislature after a campaign in which Mr. Florio said repeatedly that he did not think an increase would be necessary.
A political analyst, Cliff Zukin, associate professor at the Eagleton Institute, said a host of "tidal forces" were working against the Democrats. The problems include an extremely unpopular governor, the traditional midterm loss of legislative seats by the party in power, redistricting that favors Republicans, a stagnant economy and decisions by far more incumbent Democrats than Republicans not to seek re-election.
"These are tidal forces," said Mr. Zukin, a former director of the respected Eagleton Poll, which the institute conducts. "Individual candidates can swim against the tide, but all the tidal factors point to the Republicans coming out much advantaged." Although Mr. Zukin declined to predict flatly a Republican Legislature next year, he said, "I would certainly say that is the expectation."
Besides factors like the economy and the unpopularity of Mr. Florio, who receives a favorable rating from fewer than 1 in 4 voters in many polls, Mr. Zukin cites a fact of political life: the party that controls the governor's mansion loses Assembly seats in midterm elections, even when the Governor is popular. And the loss is usually half the seats that the party picked up in the previous gubernatorial election. Thus, in 1985, when Thomas H. Kean won re-election by a 40-point margin, the Republicans picked up 14 seats in the Assembly. But in 1987, even with Mr. Kean enjoying a 70 percent approval rating, the Republicans lost eight seats.
 
Didn't 'Raise Taxes by Himself'

 That pattern, he said, has held virtually without variance since 1973. The Republican strategy is clear. Run against Jim Florio and run against taxes. "Our strategy is quite simply to point out that Jim Florio did not raise taxes by himself," the executive director of the Republican State Committee, Jeffrey Michaels, said. "He had the help of the Democratic Legislature."
Some Democrats are complaining the tactic is a bit overdone.
In the 13th Legislative District in Middlesex and Monmouth Counties, for example, Kathy Olsen and Bob Murray, Assembly candidates, complain about a Republican brochure linking them to the tax increase.
"Who helped Florio raise our taxes?" the brochure asks. "Democrats Robert Murray and Kathleen Olsen, that's who," it answers. "They stood by and did nothing as Florio and their Democratic colleagues in Trenton gave use the biggest tax increase in state history."
Mr. Murray and Ms. Olsen concede that they indeed did nothing when the taxes were approved. Neither was in the Legislature.
"It is the height of deception to imply that Bob Murray or I had anything to do with the Florio tax program," Ms. Olsen said. "When the Florio taxes passed, I was nothing more than a schoolteacher and a citizen activist. Bob Murray was nothing more than a retired teacher."
Both, she said, oppose the taxes. They are running against Assemblywoman Joann D. Smith of Aberdeen, who voted against the increases, and former Assemblyman Joseph Azzolina.
Republican campaign literature, some emanating from state headquarters, shows pictures of Mr. Florio with legislative candidates.
State Senator James T. Phillips, Democrat of Old Bridge, who is filling out an unexpired term and was not in the Legislature when the taxes were approved last year, has made a point of carrying around a cardboard cutout of Mr. Florio and shoving it away to dramatize his desire to "push Florio aside" as an issue.
 
'They Should Counterattack'
 He was dismayed to find the device backfired when Republicans produced Republican literature with Mr. Florio, the cutout, not the real thing, and asking in big type: "Jim Phillips and Jim Florio. Which is the real tax-and-spend Democrat?"
Although aides to Mr. Florio say privately that he is concerned about the negative effects, he is more concerned that the Democrats appear to be on the run. "He understands how the game of politics is played," said one top aide who insisted on anonymity. "But what he honestly feels is that Democrats should stand up for what they believe in. He really thinks they should counterattack."
Mr. Florio made that clear on Tuesday. "Democrats have got to stop being a punching bag," he said. "I've always believed it's better to be a javelin thrower than a javelin catcher. It's time for some Democrats around this state to get off their knees and start to stand up for the principles and the policies we represent."

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Economic Ills Cast Shadow Over Bush Re-election Plans

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Concerned for months about President Bush's image on domestic policy, the White House is sharpening its focus on the economic issues that have suddenly complicated a re-election effort that seemed like a sure thing just a few months ago.
As early as August, at Mr. Bush's first major 1992 campaign strategy session, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, warned that interest rates had to come down by year's end to improve the economy by election time, officials said today. 
 Interest rates have fallen slightly since that session, and the White House acknowledges that the recession is not ending as fast as the President had hoped. That could leave Mr. Bush running in the shadow of his own economic record, a victim of successes in foreign policy that have helped salve Americans' fears for their military security but left economics as virtually the only item on the nation's electoral agenda.
 
Possible Threat From Cuomo
 Indeed, some Republican strategists view renewed talk that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York might run for President as a sign that the economy is bad enough to entice stronger Democratic candidates into the race. A longtime adviser to Mr. Bush said that of all possible Democratic contenders, it is Mr. Cuomo and his sharp oratorical skills that most worry the President.
Another Republican strategist, Charles Black, said he had long believed that the economy, rather than any individual Democrat, was a threat to the President's re-election. "If we are still in the same kind of economy that we have today a year from now," he said, "a lot of folks are at least going to take a look at the Democrats."
With Democrats in Congress starting to offer measures to cut taxes and improve the economy, there are abundant signs of a White House coming to grips with this troubling scenario for an incumbent President: a stagnant economy, a disillusioned electorate that thinks he spends too much time on foreign policy and no handy solutions in sight.
Mr. Bush's advisers are hurrying efforts to produce a legislative package to stimulate the economy. Until now, Mr. Bush has clung to his insistence that only a cut in the capital gains tax rate is acceptable, but White House officials are now considering other measures as well, including the possibility of embracing one of the more conservative Democratic proposals. There are at least a dozen proposals from members of both parties and the White House will not say which, if any, it finds acceptable.
Presidential advisers are also scheduling more events like the ones Mr. Bush has held in recent months to demonstrate his concerns about domestic issues. Just today, the White House issued a new set of proposals for overhauling the American legal system and tried to reach a compromise on a new civil rights bill.
It also disclosed that Mr. Bush, who loves above all else to fly abroad to meet with foreign dignitaries, was considering cutting short one of the three overseas trips scheduled for the next month, a two-week Far East excursion.
Mr. Bush has received the highest ratings in opinion polls of any President since such records have been kept. But he is not just trying to get re-elected. He also is hoping to get more Republicans elected to the Democratic-controlled Congress, and political strategists say economic problems are starting to erode what Republicans hope will be wide margins in states that could help other candidates.
George Christian, a Democratic strategist who was an aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson, said: "In Texas a couple of months ago, all you heard was talk of a Bush landslide and that Republicans were going to win some other offices from it; the Democrats don't have a real sword for the battle. But that talk is beginning to fade and the coattails suddenly seem shorter."
In Texas and other parts of the country, Mr. Bush is facing a dangerous combination: large numbers of electoral votes and a bad economy.
"In the East, especially New England, there's no indication that things have improved," said Marcia Howard, deputy director of the National Association of State Budget Officers. "There's some hope that maybe they've hit bottom, but that's pretty low."
Lorelei Kinder, executive director of the California Republican Party, said she was confident the economy would improve. But she said: "When you sit in Washington you can see the end is there. When you're out in Carmichael, Calif., you can't."
 
Worries About U.S. Economy
 The most recent New York Times/ CBS News poll, conducted Oct. 15-18 among 1,280 Americans, including 991 registered voters, showed that the least support for Mr. Bush's handling of the economy was in places where there was the greatest concern about it.
In the Northeast, 45 percent of those surveyed said the economy was getting worse, as against 40 percent of Midwesterners, 37 percent of Southerners and 39 percent of those in the West. Sixty-six percent of Northeasterners said they disapproved of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, compared with 57 percent nationwide.
Sixty-four percent of Northeasterners said Mr. Bush was spending too much time on foreign policy, and 81 percent of registered voters there said domestic issues would matter more than foreign policy in 1992. Eighty-one percent of Midwesterners, 78 percent of Southerners and 76 percent of Westerners said the same. The nationwide telephone survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Democrats are moving quickly to portray their economic proposals as favoring the middle class and Mr. Bush's as favoring the wealthy. Today, Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, urged revision of last year's budget agreement to allow a quick $30 billion tax cut for the middle class to "jump start the economy."
But Democrats are divided. Mr. Sasser's House counterpart, Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, said that "there is no jump start" and that any tax cuts should be offset by spending cuts or other taxe increases.
Spencer Abraham, co-chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, said that with this indecision, Republicans "can argue that in foreign affairs, the President's policies, have been given a chance to work."

HEADLINE: In a Florida Haven for Guatemalans, Seven Deaths Bring New Mourning

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANTOWN, Fla., Oct. 22

 BODY:
Along the main street of this farm town just east of Lake Okeechobee, it is not unusual to see small, brown-skinned women dressed in huipiles, colorful woven blouses that are a trademark of Mayan culture, chatting easily among themselves in Kanjobal, Quiche, Acatec and other Indian languages.
Just a few weeks ago, marimba bands and dancers convened to celebrate the feast of San Miguel, patron saint of a village in the Guatemalan mountains that was once home to several hundred families who have settled here. 
 But today Indiantown is in mourning over the deaths of seven farmworkers from a Guatemalan village in Huehuetenango province who drowned just south of here last week after their car plunged into a canal. The deaths have shattered the sense of security of the estimated 5,000 Guatemalan Indians who have flocked to this area over the last decade, making it probably the largest single concentration of Guatemalan Mayan peoples in the United States, ethnologists and community leaders say.
 
Long List of Tribulations
 For the proud but reserved descendants of the Maya, Indiantown has become a haven, known to villagers in even the most remote corner of the Sierra Madre of Guatemala as a place where the Mayan way of life can be enjoyed without fear. As friends and neighbors prepared the seven men's bodies today for a funeral Mass and shipment back to from their home village in Huehuetenango (pronounced way-way-teh-NAHN-go), there was a sense that this is yet another in a long list of tribulations to be endured and overcome.
"We have lived through tragedy after tragedy," said Antonio Silvestre, a teacher and parent counselor at the Hope Rural School, where Guatemalan students are the largest nationality. "The indigenous peoples of Guatemala have always been exploited, marginalized and killed, so something like this merely enhances a feeling of solidarity in suffering."
The presence of several thousand Guatemalan Indians in this rural section of Florida is itself the result of encroachments on Mayan ancestral lands by Spanish-speakers, which over the last half-century has forced many of the Indian peoples of the Guatemalan highlands to become migrants. They travel annually to coastal areas of their own country and to southern Mexico to harvest coffee, cacao, sugar and cotton, working long hours for low pay.
That habit of migration for work is what drew the first of these people to Florida about a decade ago, Mr. Silvestre said. Once they arrived and quickly found work harvesting sugar, oranges and cucumbers, they discovered the quiet rural setting to be congenial and passed on the word to relatives back home as well as to the many Guatemalans in Los Angeles.
"Most people in Guatemala live in small towns in the mountains, not big cities," said Dominga Xunkax Gaspar, a 27-year-old Mayan woman who works for Holy Cross Church's community outreach program. "This is a place where families can stay united, where the atmosphere, and even some of the trees are similar to what we knew."
This sleepy town of some 5,000 residents is said to have derived its name from the Indian burial mounds that impressed the first white settlers when they arrived less than a century ago. But the Mayans believe it was "a good omen we happened to find a place with this name," said Andres Cruz."
The vast majority of the Guatemalan Indians are living here legally, having qualified for that status under the 1986 immigration bill that permitted foreign immigrants who arrived illegally to qualify for resident status. Many newcomers are arriving under family reunification provisions of the immigration laws.
Many of the early arrivals here were fleeing fierce political repression at the hands of the military forces that ruled Guatemala for more than 30 years. Mr. Silvestre, for example, was forced to leave his job as an agronomist a decade ago when he developed "certain problems with colonels and generals," as he delicately phrased it.
"A lot of my best students and my friends, indigenous people like me who had become lawyers or doctors identified with the most poor, were killed," he said. "It was the kind of situation in which a death threat or warning was a luxury, because it at least gave you time to hide or flee."
Father Frank O'Loughlin, who was parish priest here when the Guatemalan influx began and now handles migrant services for the Diocese of Palm Beach, said several children arrived mute or crosseyed, which psychologists attributed to the trauma of having seen relatives and fellow villagers killed. In the classroom, he said, they first drew pictures of massacres or of helicopters spraying bullets and bombs at farmers in their fields, but gradually came to feel a sense of security.
"I can still remember my grandma telling us that the soldiers were coming and that we would have to hide if we didn't want to be killed," said Carlos Lopez, who is now a 19-year-old senior at South Fork High School. "I was kind of scared when I first got here, because of the new language and all, but my dad definitely did the right thing by getting us out of there."
With the passage of time, young people like Mr. Lopez have become comfortable with American ways. So comfortable, in fact, that some of their elders, much like other immigrant groups, worry that the youngsters are losing touch with their Mayan roots.
"The world of the children is neither 100 percent Guatemalan nor 100 percent American, but a mixture of tastes and styles," Ms. Xunkax acknowledged.
Mateo Andres, a 21-year-old farmworker and neighbor of the seven men who drowned, said he hoped that his 9-month-old son would grow up to be "100 percent American" and marry an American woman. He added that he saw no real point in passing on Mayan languages or customs.
Many older people have also succumbed to the conveniences of American life. Midwives, many of whom are illiterate and speak neither Spanish nor English, cannot get licenses and have been supplanted by doctors; curanderos, or medicine men, have suffered a similar loss of prestige and authority for the same reason.
The tradition of a weekly market, where news and gossip are exchanged and fruits, meat and vegetables bought, has given way to shopping in supermarkets. Mayan religious rites, which have coexisted with Catholicism since the time of Columbus, are said to be weakening, as newly arrived immigrants look to the Roman Catholic Church and its affiliated agencies for guidance in matters both religious and secular.
Few of the Mayans think seriously of returning to Guatemala. The political situation there continues to be unstable, jobs are scarce, and there are greater opportunities here, where many families now own cars and refrigerators and some have even bought their own homes.
"Here, I can make as much as $5.25 an hour," said Diego Felipe, a 43-year-old farmworker who has been in the United States 11 years and has saved enough money to bring his wife and children to Indiantown in January. "In Guatemala, I would be earning $2 a day if I could find work."

HEADLINE: 3 Latin Presidents Press Castro for Faster Change

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COZUMEL, Mexico, Oct. 23

 BODY:
In a meeting that underscored their differences with the United States over how to promote democratic change in Cuba, three Latin American Presidents today urged President Fidel Castro to quicken the pace of reform in his country offered the prospect of closer relations in return.
In public, Mr. Castro showed limited interest, insisting in tough, familiar language that Communism had not failed in Cuba. 
 But Latin officials said he was more conciliatory in private, effectively pledging that the modest reforms announced at a Cuban Communist Party congress last week were part of a process that would continue.
"He said, 'I know the magnitude of my problems and I know I have to carry out reforms,' " said a senior Mexican official who participated in Mr. Castro's sessions with the Presidents of Mexico, Venezuela and Colombia. However, the official said that Mr. Castro added: "Don't ask me to make them and I don't want to talk about them so as not to confuse my people."
 
Reaction of 3 Leaders
 If Mr. Castro persuaded the three Presidents -- Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela and Cesar Gaviria Trujillo of Colombia -- it was not obvious.
While they pledged to help end Cuba's isolation in Latin America and offered to mediate in its conflict with the United States, they said pointedly that economic subsidies to Cuba were out of the question. Mr. Salinas and Mr. Perez emphasized that they had no intention of helping Cuba replace the cut-rate oil that the Soviet Union has said it will stop supplying to the island.
Even so, the encounter seemed likely to maintain the gap between the United States and three of its closest and most important hemispheric allies over how to loosen Mr. Castro's hold on power. Those differences have become clearer over the past two months as Cuba's deepening economic crisis and the withdrawal of Soviet support have raised expectations of change.
Bush Administration officials, while sharing the goal of greater democracy, have insisted that Mr. Castro's hand will have to be forced.
In Washington and abroad, United States officials have argued for continued if not heavier economic and diplomatic pressure on Cuba, opposing its readmission to the Organization of American States and suggesting efforts to patch the leaky American economic embargo of the island. They have also pressed the three Latin nations not to come to Mr. Castro's economic rescue.
"We aren't saying that Castro has to be violently overthrown," one American official said last week. "But it seems to us that easing the economic situation isn't going to help get him out, either."
The three Presidents' initiative on Cuba reflects a growing assertiveness in regional foreign policy at a time when their countries' economic and political affinity with the United States is stronger than it has been in years.
Latin officials have noted that the three nations have similar motives to intervene. All three have at times used a conciliatory approach to Cuba to counter leftist criticism at home. But more importantly, Mexico and Venezuela especially are in the midst of a profound economic restructuring that hinges on foreign investment. And as Mr. Salinas noted today, "What happens in Cuba will have repercussions in all of the other countries."
In contrast to the sharp tone that characterized their opposition to Reagan Administration policies in Central America, Mexico, Columbia and Venezuela have for the most part gone quietly about their efforts on Cuba. Mr. Perez, for instance, was reported to have invited Mr. Castro to Caracas for secret talks in July, and twice sent the Venezuelan Foreign Minister to meet with officials in Cuba.
Today, Mr. Perez was particularly sharp in his criticism of the American blockade, painting it as archaic and counterproductive. "It has been there for 30 years," he said. "That says it all."
In a joint communique, the three Presidents said they were determined to "contribute to the creation of a climate of understanding and cooperation in the region and offered the Government of Cuba and the countries with which it may have differences its good offices to initiate a rapproachment."

HEADLINE: Connecticut State Police Lay Off 79 of 974 Officers

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The state police force, which supervises everything from highway traffic enforcement to small-town patrol duty, saw its ranks thinned by layoffs today as 79 officers traded their guns and badges for unemployment vouchers.
The layoffs of more than 8 percent of the statewide patrol force, which were all based on seniority, leave the agency's ability to do its basic jobs intact but severely strained, a spokesman, Adam F. Berluti, said. 
 Mr. Berluti said the 79 troopers, all of whom had been assigned to highway patrol units, were being replaced by transfers of senior officers. Those transfers will in turn gut many of the elite investigative units and reduce the number of officers assigned to work some of the state's medium- sized communities.
Radar squads devoted solely to catching speeders are also being disbanded, although patrol troopers will still be watching for violators along with their other duties. At least three towns that had four full-time troopers will see the patrols cut by 75 percent.
"You can't have no police force," said Robert B. Percoski, the top elected official in Somers, which is to begin newspaper advertisements on Thursday to hire three officers to fill the gap.
 
Long-Term Implications
 The police layoffs, while dramatic, are only a small part of the 3,700 layoffs ordered over the last month by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in a dispute over wage and benefit concessions linked to the state's new income tax. And while negotiators for the unions and the administration continued talks today and expressed optimism about a settlement, the layoffs seemed likely to have long-term implications, no matter how quickly troopers are called back to work.
Several laid-off troopers, including the last two to turn in their guns and shields at the state police complex in Meriden, said they intended to seek more stable work with Federal law-enforcement agencies and would not wait around for the leaders to reach an agreement.
"It's either going to be real quick or real long," said John A. Aiello, a 27-year-old trooper who had been on the force for almost two years. "I think it's going to be long."
Other changes in how Connecticut patrols its highways are also likely to be permanent. The Public Safety Department had already ordered the police to stop using all hand-held radar units because of possible links to cancer, and those devices will not be reintroduced regardless of the outcome of labor talks that might restore the squad that catches speeders.
 
Health Concerns
 A police union spokesman, David McCluskey, said his members were reluctant to use radar now, even when the devices are mounted outside the car. "Over time, not having the traffic squads will result in people driving faster on the roads," Mr. McCluskey said.
Mr. Berluti said the decisions to eliminate the hand-held radar units and to disband the radar squads were not related. Cutting back on use of the hand-held units was done purely out of health concerns until further studies can be completed about the microwave energy used by the devices. Disbanding the squads was purely a manpower issue, he said.
The layoffs, which brought the total state police force down to 895 officers, made it all but impossible to do anything but provide basic patrolling and a minimal presence in towns, Mr. Berluti said.
In Somers, a community of 8,000 people on the Massachusetts border, those manpower arguments do not hold much water because local law-enforcement concerns are so high, according to Mr. Percoski, the town's First Selectman.
Somers is the site of Connecticut's only maximum-security prison, with two other prisons -- including a super-maximum-security jail -- in planning or construction, and Mr. Percoski said that whatever the cost of hiring temporary officers, it would simply have to be borne. Somers, along with the 52 other small towns in the resident trooper program, already pays part of the cost.
The police union, along with other state bargaining units, has faced off against the Weicker administration in refusing to give back pay raises that took effect on July 1 while the state was operating temporarily without a budget.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Connecticut state troopers turning in their guns, badges and equipment yesterday in Meriden as 79 troopers were laid off. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For Cleaner Air, Scrap Dirty Cars, U.S. Is Told

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The way to cut down pollution from the nation's 123 million cars, and to make them use less gasoline, is not to make the new ones run cleaner, some economists say, but to stop the old ones from running at all.
When the Senate takes up the National Energy Strategy, probably next week, most of the debate will center on how far a 1995 Ford Taurus or a 1996 Plymouth Sundance should go on a gallon of gas, or whether they should run on natural gas or methanol to reduce pollution. But the problem, according to more and more economists, may lie in the 1966 Ford Galaxie and the 1965 Plymouth Barracuda. 
 Some regulators are beginning to see their point.
Yesterday a Massachusetts consulting firm proposed that instead of pressing for new fuels or raising the mileage standard to 35 or 40 miles per gallon from the current 27.5, the Government should buy 9 million vehicles dating from 1967 to 1978 -- anything with a big gas tank or a cloud of blue smoke behind it -- and send them to an early grave. If the bumper sticker says Impeach Richard Nixon or Impeach Earl Warren, presumably the car would qualify.
"It is somewhat off the beaten track," acknowledged Bernard G. Campbell, director of the consulting firm DRI/McGraw-Hill. But he said that for the next 10 to 20 years, it is by far the cheapest and fastest way to cut pollution and oil imports.
More and more, economists are taking control of the pollution debate, with ideas like trading among industries of rights to emit pollutants.
And the notion of buying up old cars may emerge as a tool in the fight for clean air, if not as an alternative to better cars or cleaner gasoline.
Under a plan drawn up by the consulting firm, owners would offer the cars for a "bounty" of $700 each, the money to be raised by a 2-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, although it could also come from other places, including payments from auto makers that failed to meet Federal fuel economy standards.
The firm predicted that the trade-in would increase the sales of new cars and thus raise employment and gross national product, cut pollution and save billions of gallons of gasoline, all for less cost than requiring new cars to achieve higher fuel economy or cleaner performance.
Although the major beneficiaries would appear to be the auto companies, the study was commissioned by three oil companies: Arco, Chevron and Texaco, all of which would have to reformulate gasoline to cut pollution.
Another oil company, Unocal, tried a "scrappage" program as an experiment a year ago, sending to the crusher 8,400 cars, some of which, Unocal said, were 67 times dirtier than new cars.
"I think the Unocal program makes a lot of sense," said Michael Bradley, the executive director of the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, an eight-state organization that has already arranged a change in the formulation of fuel. He said scrappage could used as a way for auto companies to "buy" extra pollution emission rights if their cars failed to perform as required.
 
Skepticism Remains
 But others are skeptical. "What do these people do when you give them $700 for their car?" asked William Sessa, a spokesman for the California Air Resources Board. "Typically they go out and buy an old car, and that's marginal, too."
Cars built with carburetors and without catalytic converters emit more than 25 grams of hydrocarbons and 100 grams of carbon monoxide per mile; new ones emit 90 percent less, and generally get twice as many miles from a gallon of gas. As of July 1, 1990, 37.8 million cars, or 30.7 percent of the fleet on the road, were from 1980 or earlier, meaning that they did not have catalytic converters, according to R. L. Polk, another consulting firm.
All those cars will eventually wear out anyway, so that the benefits of scrapping them prematurely is short-term, advocates acknowledge. Mr. Bradley said that scrappage should not be a substitute for demanding better cars now from automakers. Otherwise, he said, "won't we be in the same bind 15 years from now?"

HEADLINE: Mary Painter Garin, 71, Innovator In Economic and Statistical Work

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
Mary S. Painter Garin, an American economist who was an important innovator in the use of statistical techniques during and immediately after World War II, died Monday in Toulon, France, near her home in Sollies-Toucas. She was 71 years old.
The cause of death was cardiac arrest, said a niece, Sarah Wells. 
 Miss Painter, as she was known professionally, was one of a small group of economists who made national-income analysis a powerful tool for government and military policy-making from World War II on. She served in the Marshall Plan and at the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris,
A native of Minneapolis, Miss Painter graduated from Swarthmore College in 1942 with high honors and went directly to the Board of Economic Warfare and then to the Office of Strategic Services. There she pioneered the development of original techniques for analyzing Nazi Germany's military abilities. She devised a statistical model for estimating the size of the German submarine fleet in the North Atlantic, which after the war, was found to have been startlingly accurate.
 
Calculated Past G.N.P.
 After the war, she served at the Federal Reserve Board in Washington and at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Her article "Estimates of Gross National Product, 1919 Through 1928," published in the Federal Reserve bulletin in September 1945, used new Commerce Department concepts to calculate the gross national product for the 10 years after World War I.
In 1948, Miss Painter went to Paris in the first wave of economists who set up the European headquarters of the Marshall Plan. She was in charge of analyzing the French and German economies at the United States Mission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and other regional organizations until 1960. She returned to the United States for two years, working on problems of arms control and disarmament with Prof. Emile Benoit at Columbia University.
In 1962, she returned to Paris to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the successor to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation, originally established to administer Marshall Plan aid to Europe.
Miss Painter was also known as a remarkable cook. In 1969, she married Georges Garin, one of the outstanding chefs of France, who was the proprietor of Chez Garin, a restaurant on the Left Bank.
 
Work in Restaurants
 When Miss Painter retired as an economist from O.E.C.D., she became, in the best French tradition of restaurateur's wives, la Patronne of Chez Garin, presiding over its cash register.
The Garins closed the restaurant in 1973 and established a new one, Le Lingousto, at Sollies-Toucas. Mr. Garin died in 1979, and Miss Painter lived there the rest of her life.
She was a close friend and early supporter of the author James Baldwin, and his book "Another Country" is dedicated to her.
She is survived by her sister, Charlotte Morse of Minneapolis, five nieces and three nephews.
