HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Art and Power, or, the Fist That Grips the Brush

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 18

 BODY:
One of the most hotly debated issues in the boom-market art world of the 1980's and now in the politically contentious art world of the 90's has been power: who has it, how did they get it, and what are they doing with it. Every week, it seems, there are panels on power and whatever -- you can almost fill in the blank: power and the artist, the collector, the museum, the critic. Power, in fact, has become prominent not just as an issue swirling around art, but as one of its central subjects.
Now comes a provocative, tightly organized exhibition at the Indianapolis Museum of Art titled "Power: Its Myths and Mores in American Art, 1961-1991." The title itself exudes considerable authority, especially when you see it spelled out in metallic red on the institutional gray of the catalogue's cover. 
 This survey, the museum's first thematic treatment of recent American art, has been organized by Holliday T. Day, who is, not incidentally, the museum's first curator of contemporary art.
The forms of power tackled by the 28 artists here are many and various, including political, economic, military and social power, as well as the power of advertising and of the art object itself as a symbol of wealth and prestige. Fortunately, plain old visual power is included, too. One of Ms. Day's achievements is that she has managed to embed her theme in the surfaces, forms and images of the art on view, rather than leaving it dangling overhead like a vague literary umbrella.
The show starts with crisp Pop Art paintings and Minimalist works (both paintings and sculptures) by important 60's artists like Donald Judd, Frank Stella, Andy Warhol and Roy Lichtenstein, who appropriated the power of industrial materials and media imagery into their work. It ends with works by Krzysztof Wodiczko and Lorna Simpson, whose efforts examine the problems of homelessness and racism. Even without the recent Senate confirmation hearings, Ms. Simpson's big untitled photographic work -- which features a reclining black woman in a hospital gown bracketed by the ambiguous affirmatives "You're Fine" and "You're Hired" -- evokes the specter of sexual harassment.
In between, the exhibition touches on the psychologically charged efforts of post-Minimalists like Bruce Nauman, Vito Acconci, Robert Morris and Richard Serra, whose installation works have an interactive component that frequently throws the viewer back on "inner" powers. And it devotes most of its space to 80's artists for whom power has been a central issue, among them, Robert Longo, Cindy Sherman, Jenny Holzer, Jeff Koons, Peter Halley, Richard Prince and Ashley Bickerton.
In markedly different ways, which nonetheless draw on the strategies of Pop and Minimalism, this younger generation is famous for questioning certain power relations in American society while also being extremely successful within the art world's own power structure.
For the most part these achievements are well known, but in tracing the way power has changed its form, meaning and direction in the hands of successive generations of American artists, Ms. Day ties these generations together in a new way.
In addition, the show is marked by a lively self-consciousness that attempts to reveal its own authority to its audience. The installation is accompanied by catchy, almost parodistic chapter headings ("The Fast Track and the Power Lunch" for the 1980's section), plentiful explanatory labels and a catalogue whose essays argue energetically among themselves. One essay, by the anthropologist George Marcus, even ranks according to importance the various private collectors who have lent artworks to the show.
In fact, Ms. Day has been inspired by anthropology to approach American art with the attitude that it reflects "cultural myths, social structures and rituals" as surely as the art and artifacts of any non-Western so-called primitive culture.
At every turn in this somewhat crowded exhibition, the viewer is invited both to enjoy and question, to experience the artworks at face value, and then peel back the different possible meanings like the layers of an onion. And at every turn, the artists' efforts are seen as challenging some of the forces and myths at work in American culture, while unconsciously reflecting or incorporating others.
For example, it is suggested that while Mr. Judd's sleek metal sculptures debunk the value of the handmade art object in their use of factory fabrication, they also celebrate the power of American industry and technology.
Similarly, one gets the sense that the rituals of consumerism are being both unmasked and elevated in Mr. Bickerton's "Tormented Self-Portrait (Susie at Arles) No. 2," a high-tech black metal relief that pokes more than a little fun at Minimalism while sporting over two dozen brand names that reduce the artist to the sum of the products he consumes. Cindy Sherman's big photographs featuring the artist in myriad disguises may be send-ups of various Old Master paintings, and yet part of their appeal lies in their evocations of older art.
The show's focus on power doesn't tell the whole story of the art on view. Ms. Day conveniently ignores the Romanticism and even the odd religiosity inherent in the purity of Minimalist sculpture, which has been likened to Shaker furniture as well as steel skyscrapers. More significantly, the exhibition is hampered by that most American myth, the myth of progress, as if each generation of artists, by being more critical than its predecessor, is somehow moving onward and upward toward total consciousness.
And of course one thing that clearly empowers almost all the 80's art in this exhibition is the way it can be linked back to the halcyon days of Pop and Minimalism and the 1960's, still one of the most mythical decades in the history of American art.
Nonetheless, this exhibition represents an unusually successful marriage of art and theory, of visual pleasure and intellectual skepticism. In the process, it creates a vivid portrait of late-century American society and of the different ways artists have mined it for both source material and targets.
"Power: Its Myths and Mores in American Art, 1961-1991," is at the Indianapolis Museum of Art through Nov. 3. It will travel to the Akron Art Museum, Akron, Ohio (Jan. 18 to March 21) and the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, Richmond (May 11-July 12).

GRAPHIC: Photo: An untitled work by Lorna Simpson in the exhibition "Power: Its Myths and Mores in American Art, 1961-1991" at Indianapolis Museum of Art. (Ellen Page Wilson/Josh Baer Gallery)

HEADLINE: ALBANY FISCAL GAP IS NOW ESTIMATED AT A HALF-BILLION

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Despite adopting some of the sharpest spending cuts in state history when it put together a budget last spring, New York State is now facing a financial deficit of between $500 million and $800 million, Cuomo administration officials said today.
The state budget division's estimate of the gap in the $29 billion budget will not be completed until next week. But the officials said the extraordinary bleakness of the state's fiscal picture was a result of higher spending on welfare and Medicaid and of a continued falloff in projected tax revenues -- trends that are themselves stark reflections of the state's weak economy. 
 Budget experts in the Legislature said they had no specific deficit estimates of their own yet but generally agreed with the magnitude of the problem outlined by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's office.
 
Echo of Last Year
 The assessment, at the midpoint of the state's fiscal year, comes three months before New York City, which operates on a different fiscal calendar, is to go through a similar exercise. But the state's bad news bodes ill for the city because it is generally affected by the same trends.
The news is also an unwelcome repetition of last year's debacle, when a series of progressively gloomier revenue estimates forced a painful $900 million midyear budget revision. When they completed this year's budget, Mr. Cuomo and lawmakers vowed that they had cut so deep that no midyear revisions would be necessary this time. And, recalling last year, the Governor is now saying a special session of the Legislature may become necessary.
No matter how big this year's gap is, there is nothing close to a consensus here on how to eliminate it, although many lawmakers have said they want to avoid a disaster like last winter's, when they were forced to cut popular programs like aid to schools and local government. The cuts in the middle of the budget year caused havoc for New York City and other communities struggling with their own budgets.
State Senate Republicans blamed most of the deficit on Medicaid spending, which has risen by 18 percent in the last year, and they vowed an all-out assault on the program -- including limiting some services or the number of doctor's visits -- to balance the budget.
Whatever explanations for the state gap are offered, it comes as a huge embarrassment to the Legislature, whose leaders insisted last spring that the state would be able to spend hundreds of millions of dollars more than was in the $29 billion budget that it ultimately negotiated with Mr. Cuomo. The Governor forced them to drop some of the spending through a series of vetoes.
While lawmakers also pledged there would be no "bounced checks" in that spending plan, they may now be forced to make cuts that take back some of the money they promised to local governments when they approved the budget in the spring.
For Mr. Cuomo, official disclosure of the deficit will also be annoying, particularly because it comes amid his ruminations about whether to run for President as a vivid reminder that the state he governs remains in fiscal turmoil. Mr. Cuomo has repeatedly said he would be reluctant to campaign for the White House if he felt his state needed his presence to help solve its fiscal woes.
On the other hand, given the Governor's near-limitless capacity to cast crisis as opportunity, he may simply turn the bad news into a new and urgent rationale for a Presidential run. Because he frequently says New York's problems are similar to those in states from Connecticut to California, and that their cause is Federal neglect, he could argue that going to the White House would be the most appropriate course for him to take.
While New York City adopts its budget later in the year than the state does and thus has yet to make any firm estimates about its own budget projections, it received a bleak assessment of its outlook today in the form of reports from both the State and City Comptrollers.
Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller, said the city's economy had contracted by 7 percent and lost 207,000 jobs in the last two years, while its welfare caseload had soared by 17 percent to its highest level since 1977.
 
Possible Special Session
 If the national economic downturn continues, Mr. Regan warned, "the consequences for the local economy could prove disastrous and could prolong the local recession for several more years."
The Governor's press secretary, Anne W. Crowley, cautioned today that budget officials were still reviewing the state's finances and that there was no firm estimate of what the gap would be. But administration officials confirmed that they believed it would be $500 million to $800 million.
Mr. Cuomo himself has repeatedly warned that there was looming trouble in the budget but has not been specific about its magnitude. "I can't give you a number," he told reporters tonight after speaking at a Liberal Party dinner in Manhattan. He has also not publicly suggested how he would close it. But he did raise the possibility that, as he did last year, he would call the Legislature back into special session to deal with the problem.
"I would lean toward acting as fast as we can act, and if you need the Legislature for that, that means we would lean toward having the Legislature back as soon as we could," he said.
For the first six months of the year, the number of Medicaid recipients was 1.4 million people, an increase of 8.9 percent over the same period last year. And the number of welfare recipients was up by 9.9 percent, to about 1.3 million, according to the State Department of Social Services.

HEADLINE: The Lowdown on Curtains From Lady Velcro Herself

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
SOME people analyze the mood of a culture through politics. Some use economics. But Lady Caroline Wrey, otherwise known as Lady Velcro, the Barbara Woodhouse of windows, has a foolproof barometer. Curtains.
World War II spelled "the death knell" for curtains. But the 1980's turned out to be a "very, very energetic" time for them, with windows smothered in pagoda reef pelmets, trumpets and goblets.
Ah, the swags and tails of history. 
 "There was a lot of money you see," said Lady Velcro, pleating her eyebrows the way she might pleat a pelmet. "When you're deeply insecure and unhappy, you don't have the courage to try something new."
She was explaining this world view last week -- using an eight-foot-high mock-up of a window instead of a globe -- to a riveted, all-female audience assembled at an Upper East Side fashion house in Manhattan to hear her, notebooks in hand.
Never mind the proceedings of the Senate Judiciary Committee. The subject at hand, outlined in great detail in her new book for Overlook Press, "The Complete Book of Curtains and Drapes" (in England, "The Complete Book of Curtains and Pelmets," but more on that later), concerned such pivotal questions as whether to puddle or not to puddle, whether to line or not to line, and whether to speak one's mind to those hopelessly thick, predominantly male architects who insist on designing windows with no room for curtains.
"They are the most amazingly irritating people, actually," said Lady Velcro, whose answer was yes.
Above all, the 34-year-old author, who runs a business in London specializing in window treatments and gives lectures and five-day hands-on courses on the subject, is obsessed with pelmets, which are known in this country as valances. They may be pencil-pleated, French-pleated, goblet-pleated, smock-headed, box-pleated or diamond-buttoned, in a single continuous curve or of arched serpent-tail construction.
"I see the window as a face and the pelmet as its hat," she is fond of saying. "If the hat is too small for the face, it will remind one of a great fat face with a beret that is far too small perched on the top."
"These are perfectly all-right windows," she said by way of explanation, gazing past the walnut-shaped silver pill boxes and ostrich-egg candlesticks in the lecture room. "Perfectly all right. But they aren't thrilling."
For thrilling, readers are advised to consult Lady Caroline's Seven-Prong Plan, the accumulated wisdom of her 10 years of curtain-making. The plan, which she calls fail-safe, advocates an awareness of oft-forgot details like outdoor obstructions and the direction the window faces. ("For goodness' sake," she told her audience, "write it down!" They did.)
Those who ignore even one prong do so at their peril. "You will risk creating an unsettling effect," she warns, her words as crisp as a purse snapping shut. The plan, she said, is "a process, like the seven cycles of a washing machine."
Those who follow the plan, she writes, will be rewarded by (1) peaceful simplicity; (2) comfortable abundance; (3) discreet subtlety; (4) immense luxury, and (5) bold drama.
To Lady Caroline, diamonds are not a girl's best friend, but table clamps, Velcro and a staple gun are.
Those who suffer from math phobia will also want a pocket calculator to deal with Lady Velcro's controversial theory on pelmet proportion: for every 12 inches of curtain drop, allow two inches for pelmet drop.
"You don't have to be brilliant at math," she contends, to execute a lead-weighted, interlined, interlocked, French-pleated curtain, or even a simple bed valance, known in this country as a dust ruffle.
As befits a "bossy curtain-maker," as she sometimes calls herself, she is a woman of definite opinions:
"A bare window is dull. I do not like looking at a black hole at night."
On poles: "I'm not wild about them."
On long curtains: "Length is elegance. But too long becomes a mess. I have a naughty Tibetan spaniel that loves to lie on those great wads of silk that hit the floor. Such a bore."
She cannot abide a naked window, with the possible exception of a pointed Gothic one. "No," she said. "Never. The average window is not, to me, a very exciting object. I want to be decorative. This is the excuse."
Decorative configurations are seemingly infinite, from static heads with Maltese crosses to "caterpillars with ears" (a ruched tie-back with a frill along the sides, which she exhibited at her lecture the way a high school science teacher might a regenerated planarian).
At least a dozen different specimens were on display in the slides Lady Caroline showed of the London apartment of an Australian tycoon's mistress. One pair of windows was festooned with six-inch handmade pleats, goblet pleats, a serpent pelmet, a big chintz bow, double inset frills, piping, edging and shirred muslin Austrian blinds.
"He went bust," she reported.
To Lady Caroline, decorated windows are a touchstone of English civilization: "We want to shut out the cold. It's the most wonderful detail of the room. I've never gone beyond it."
Lady Caroline, the daughter of the 15th Earl of Lindsay, grew up in London, spending holidays at Castle Kilconquhar in Fyfe, Scotland, "which was all turrets." Like many of her female contemporaries, she learned to sew. "We're a very D.I.Y. country," she said, giving the shorthand for do-it-yourself. "As children, we never watched television. We never ate sweets. We had a fantastic mother who taught us how to use our leisure time effectively."
Effectively indeed. Her 35-year-old-brother, Viscount Garnock, has just written an equally detailed book called "Trellis: The Creative Way to Transform Your Garden." You might call him Lord Trellis.
Her journey into the delicate art of curtain-making began after she was married in 1981. (Windows, she believes, are the prerogative of the mistress of the house.) Upon her marriage, she found herself with both a mews house in Kensington and a 16th-century farmhouse in Devon.
She began as a first-grade teacher, but soon after her marriage she decided it would be more fun to start a curtain business. In England, she said, people do not usually hire decorators; rather, they inherit furnishings and paintings and "then bring someone in to do the curtains." She added, "We're great squirrels."
Soon she had "sleepless nights and ghastly clients"; now she has learned to keep the most "finickety" at bay. "I know who's going to be difficult," she said. "The ones who say 'I don't like the way that crease is there.' I double the estimate."
The best way to learn, she contends, is by undoing a worn-out but "fantastically made" pair of curtains. By unraveling the curtain-maker's secrets, "you can see how it all goes together," she said.
Although Lady Caroline can make a rather complicated pair of curtains in six hours, it will take the inexperienced curtain-maker far longer. "If you want something in life, you make time for it," she said.
This truism extends to curtains.
Lady Caroline believes curtains can fit in anywhere, even in Malibu, where she would go with "plain poles with some calico thrown over them, as in Provence or Tuscany."
"You could think about this forever," she sighed, as her lecture came to a close.
The enlightened will think of the window not just as an object of wood and glass, but as a blank canvas for human artistry.
"A hideous window," she said, "is an excuse to do the very best you can."
 
TO TALK CURTAIN
 CURTAIN-MAKING comes with an arcane language all its own.
BALLOON SHADE A curtain that is gathered horizontally across the heading and, as it is pulled up, is also gathered vertically. The British call it an Austrian shade.
CURTAINS "Correct" term for what hangs on windows.
DRAPES A vulgarism for curtains. According to the designer Mark Hampton, Nancy Mitford wrote that a drapery is something used in a photographer's studio; in upper-class language ("U" rather than "non-U," as Miss Mitford put it), the word "drape" is never used.
DUST RUFFLE A wide ruffle encircling the bottom of a bed to the floor. The British call it a bed valance.
VALANCE A short drapery or frame used as a decorative heading of fabric across the top of the window to conceal the tops of curtains. The British call it a pelmet.
ROLLER BLIND British term for window shade.
 
OTHER EXPERTS, OTHER THOUGHTS
Stylistically, curtains parallel the details of 18th-century clothes. Today, there is a general drift to more restraint than in the 1970's and 1980's when, as the decorator Albert Hadley put it, chintz curtains "were like a ball gown too done up." Here is what some decorators and architects are thinking.
 
What the Decorators Say

 
 "Architectural details in North America are often zilch, so curtains become a point of distraction. As we get more into neoclassical decoration, I'm using a lot of tapes and ropes. I don't like curtains fanned out on the floor. I puddle two to four inches, except in very grand rooms. If you want curtains to hang properly, you have to line them." -- MARIO BUATTA
 "I'm not terribly keen on overdoing. We use French curtains a lot, which are semitransparent and cover the lower half of the window. A lot of fabric drooping doesn't make sense. It's an affectation." -- ALBERT HADLEY
 "The definite trend in the past 4 or 5 years has been to simplify. We're making fewer and fewer lined and double-interlined curtains. We're using simple, elegant unlined fabrics. We're using binding with different bias-cut stripes that change directions as they go down. It's subtle, like detailing on an expensive suit. As for puddling, the nine-inch days are gone. Our curtains just break on the floor." -- KEITH IRVINE
 "No one can tell me that those ruffled chintz curtains are passe. They're here forever.
"I see a lot of 1820's Federal Revival influence, classical French curtains with small rings and finials, and the use of simple bronze rods. I wish we could have those pure white starchy gauzes like you see in those Schinkel rooms, but in New York City, that's out.
"I also like crunchy taffetas on bare floors dragging on the floor.
"I don't understand what they do in those West Coast modern houses. I think they must sleep with eye masks." -- MARK HAMPTON

 
What the Architects Say
 "I've always hated 'em. Curtains are there to cover up, to conceal. Levolor blinds are O.K.; they have a diaphanous quality, but are also hard and rigid. They're of architecture, not decor. Curtains are decor, which relates to decorum and propriety. They're a finishing touch. But architecture doesn't need to be finished. That's my problem with curtains." -- STANLEY TIGERMAN
 "Curtains are O.K. in Los Angeles because people go to work so early it's dark when they get up anyway. In houses for clients in the film business we sometimes use blackout curtains so they can review the dailies. Sometimes we even put them in sleeping areas." -- BRIAN MURPHY
 "In many of our buildings, the windows just don't lend themselves to curtains, because they're freewheeling and very eccentric. We once designed wavy curtain rods for an apartment in New York.
"I like classic Venetian blinds, two inches wide and made of wood. They remind me of Miami in the 1930's and 1940's, which is why a lot of people don't like them, including my mother. I like the striped shadows they cast and their clackety-clack sound." -- LAURINDA SPEAR

HEADLINE: WHERE TO FIND IT;
A Night's Sleep in a Wall

BYLINE: Terry Trucco

 BODY:

Murphy Bed Company
65 Mall Drive, Commack, N.Y. 11725; (516) 543-0234.
"It's not the usual pullout couch," said Clark Murphy, president of the Murphy Bed Company. Mr. Murphy, of course, was discussing the Murphy bed, the steel-frame pull-down wall-mounted bed invented in 1900 by his grandfather, William L. Murphy, and still manufactured, in an updated version, by the family company. 
 For years, Murphy beds were the butt of countless jokes in silent films by Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton. But the modern Murphy bed is a sedate piece of furniture that can be installed in a closet or a custom-built cabinet with folding doors.
It has come back into fashion, more or less, thanks to its space-saving qualities. It is now found in studio apartments, fire stations, ocean liners and retirement communities.
The company sells simple wood-laminate cabinets for its beds but specializes in folding steel frames. Murphy's latest steel frame, devised in 1964, has a spring-operated mechanism that bolts to the floor. The mattress foundation, used in lieu of a box spring, consists of steel ribbon strips or a foam-covered wood frame. Beds are available for every mattress size.
The company installs beds in the New York City area and can provide the names of distributors elsewhere. Steel frames and foundations cost $500 to $825 for the Styleline, a bed for every-night use, and $380 to $440 for the Econo-Recess, a guest bed. Mattresses and cabinets are extra.

The Building Block
314 11th Avenue (near 30th Street), New York, N.Y. 10001; (212) 714-9333.
Noah Block, an owner of Building Block cabinetmakers, calls the Sico wall bed the Mercedes of wall beds.
"And it's at Mercedes prices," he added.
The Sico, made in Minneapolis, pulls down directly from the wall. When it is up, the underside, available in a variety of colors and woods, is flush with the wall. No doors are needed to cover it.
Anchored to the floor, the Sico is outfitted with a compressed spring device. It uses a conventional box spring and mattress, sold separately. A bed frame in any size and a simple surrounding cabinets cost about $3,000, including delivery, installation and taxes.

Murphy Bed Center of New York
110 West 17th Street (near Avenue of the Americas), New York, N.Y. 10011; (212) 645-7079.
Most people who want a wall bed are in a tight spot, both for space and money, says Robert Meyers, owner of the Murphy Bed Center of New York. So Mr. Meyers, whose showroom is nearly two years old, specializes in what he calls package deals.
Steel frames, made by Comfort Wall Beds of Tampa, Fla., can be bought alone for $435 to $535. But Mr. Meyers also sells accompanying cabinets. Through the end of the year, a folding-door cabinet, a frame and mattress for a double bed starts at $950.

HEADLINE: Battle of Insurers vs. Therapists

SERIES: Psychiatry for Profit: Private Hospitals Under Fire -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
The 26-year-old woman's moods swung violently. She went from joy to anger to sadness to despair, and was treated four times at a hospital emergency room after slitting her wrists. She was finally admitted to Sheppard Pratt, a psychiatric hospital in Baltimore. But after two weeks, her insurance company questioned her need for hospitalization. Panicked, she threw herself down a flight of stairs.
The insurance reviewer, upon hearing this, remarked, "Clearly the treatment isn't working," according to Dr. Steven S. Sharfstein, the hospital director. Against her doctor's wishes, the reviewer ruled that the hospital would have to discharge her immediately, Dr. Sharfstein said. 
 The case illustrates what psychotherapists say is one of the most profound changes in 100 years of mental-health treatment and care. A system has been put in place that has, in effect, interposed a third party into the previously sacrosanct, confidential relationship between doctor or therapist and mental health patient.
The insurance companies and American employers insist that the new system is essential to control costs. American expenditures on health care in general and psychiatric care in particular are skyrocketing, and mental-health care represents the sharpest rise in such costs for insurers.
As a result, insurers have in recent years helped to form a whole new service industry called managed care to monitor health treatments. Managed care is now expanding rapidly into psychotherapy and, where it deems appropriate, is blocking, altering, shortening or effectively ending treatments.
Therapists are up in arms over what they regard as serious and often dangerous interference that puts severe limits on their ability to conduct their practices. It is not unfair to say that therapists and insurers are engaged in all but open warfare.
Not that these two opposing forces always end up in disagreement. In the case of the 26-year-old woman, her hospital fought the insurance company and it agreed to reverse its decision. "We sent angry letters, and the family got a lawyer," Dr. Sharfstein said. In the end, the woman was hospitalized for five months, was stabilized emotionally and released.
Managed care in one form or another is being applied to almost all hospitals and clinics that provide psychiatric care whether they are public or private, for-profit or nonprofit. But much of the impetus for managed care began with the rapid growth in the 1980's of for-profit private psychatric hospitals along with growing charges of overuse of hospitalization and misdiagnoses.
Psychotherapists say the pendulum has now swung much too far, that more people who really need psychiatric care are being told that they will not be reimbursed for their doctors' bills. These insurers have "become more aggressive and restrictive about paying for psychotherapy than ever," said John Docherty, a psychiatrist at Brookside Hospital in Nashua, N.H. "It's escalated enormously."
Doctors also contend that managed care, with its new employees and extensive bureaucracy, has itself added substantially to health-care costs. The managed-care companies say that to the contrary, they have helped control costs, though health economists say no good overall studies have been done.
 
Hot Line for Doctors
 The American Psychiatric Association has installed a hot line for its members, an "800" number on which it is receiving 150 to 200 calls a month. Most calls are from therapists complaining that patients who genuinely need hospitalization for serious illnesses are being denied it. They complain, too, about what they say is the lack of sufficient knowledge or experience among some managed-care monitors.
"There's a great deal of anger and frustration among psychiatrists," said Ruth Yoshpe, a health economist whose office runs the hot line.
The managed-care companies contend that professionals in the psychiatric-care community are the most resistant to change and the least flexible in seeking new ways to reduce costs of all members of the health-care community. These companies say they are not trying to usurp doctors' roles but say they are simply trying to prevent abuses or unneeded expense.
Nancy Cannon, an official of Private Healthcare Systems of Lexington, Mass., a managed-care company for 17 insurance companies, called the nation's psychotherapists the "most recalcitrant professional group, the most reluctant to participate in change-making."
In general medicine, when alternatives to surgery are proposed, for example, physicans begin to explore or make changes, but mental-health care doctors "tend to mystify the treatment experience when it is not always so mysterious," she said. Medication with outpatient care alone is sometimes cheaper and more effective than hospitalization.
The aim of the managed-care companies, about 400 of which have been created in the last five years, is to conduct a case-by-case consideration to try to match a patient's medical needs to the most effective but least expensive treatment.
Even opponents of managed care say that when it is done well, it can serve patients better than the old system, through improved and informed review of the options. But, they add, the focus is too often placed simply on saving money, accomplished too often through capricious and arbitrary denial of benefits.
Dr. Paul Fink, former president of the American Psychiatric Association, said there was no question that abuses had occurred in the mental-health field that have driven up costs and in some cases been harmful to patients.
 
Some Good and Some Bad
 "Trying to get control over the ethical behavior of hospitals and doctors in hospitals is a tough task," he said. "The people who suffer are the patients. And the people who have caused the suffering had better clean up their acts."
He said managed care, however, has done both "some good and some bad, depriving people who need care of care where extended stays would be helpful, adhering to rules instead of paying attention to legitimate needs of patients."
Whatever its strengths or drawbacks, the economics alone suggest that the new system is here to stay. The amount of money spent per person on health care in the United States is the highest in the world, and from 1987 to 1988, the last year for which statistics are available, employers' overall health costs rose 18.6 percent, while those for mental health rose 27 percent, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute.
The fact that some form of cost containment and careful management of psychiatric care is needed is also underscored by economic pressures applied by a reduction in mental-health benefit plans themselves. As fee payments have risen, employers have been steadily cutting back their benefit packages.
In 1982, 43 percent of employers' health plans had more restrictive coverage for mental-health problems than other ailments; by 1988 the figure was 71 percent, a Department of Labor study shows. The plans typically limited the duration of psychiatric hospital stays to 20 or 60 days, versus a minimum of 120 -- and often no limit at all -- for other illnesses.
Office visits to a therapist have been restricted even more drastically, the report found. In 1982, therapy visits were already subject to limits in 84 percent of plans. By 1988, that was true of 95 percent.
Because the sharpest rise in costs has been so high, "employers are asking for their mental-health benefits to be managed, where they do not ask the same for other medical problems," said Tom Joyce, a spokesman for the Prudential Insurance Company of America. In some cases, the companies are insisting that their representatives interview patients directly about their psychiatric care.
"They'll make a direct suggestion to a patient," Dr. Yoshpe said. 'Your doctor's not good enough. You should see one on our approved list, or we'll cut off your payments."
Dr. Yoshpe contended that "sometimes the companies have people reviewing cases who are not physicians, telling psychiatrists, 'Why don't you just give some medication, without psychotherapy?' or, 'Our guidelines say four therapy sessions are enough,' when the doctor thinks the patient needs 20."
In general, the managed-care companies deny that their reviewers are not adequately trained, though they acknowledge that they often are not medically trained.
At any rate, the tighter fiscal policies have threatened the very existence of some forms of therapy. The most endangered species is the longterm, open-ended core of psychoanalysis that was the norm for decades after Freud developed the field.
There are some still willing and able to scrape together fees for four-times-a-week sessions that can last four or five years and cost $100,000 or more. But most cannot, and there are virtuallly no health plans that will help with the cost.
There are physicians in mental health who think this is as it should be. "Psychoanalysis is great, but your employer shouldn't have to pay for it," said Dr. Bernard Rappaport, medical director of American Biodyne, a managed-care company in San Francisco.
"The old model was that you went into long-term therapy, and more or less got fixed once and for all," Dr. Rappaport said. "The new one is that you get a brief therapy that helps you get over what you're struggling with at the moment. And when down the road something else is troubling you, you come back for another short treatment."
 
When It's Done Well
 Even critics say that when managed care is done well, both patients and those who pay their bills can emerge winners. Dr. Sharfstein of Sheppard Pratt in Baltimore tells of a man who, at 38, had medical insurance but had been in hospitals or homeless because of schizophrenia.
"He'd been tried on every medication," the doctor said, "but none worked until we included him in the clinical trial of a new drug, clozapine. His symptoms cleared for the first time."
The man's problems were not over, but they were much improved.
"What he needed was a sheltered living situation," the doctor said, adding that his hospital had such a patient residence that cost $115 a day. The man's insurance covered hospitalization at $400 a day -- but not the sheltered residency at $115.
Dr. Sharfstein talked to the managed-care monitor, and the company allowed an exception to its rules and provided six months in the residence.
"For the first time, he's not in the hospital, and not homeless on the streets," Dr. Sharfstein said. "It makes me hopeful that managed care can work."

HEADLINE: 4 PARTIES IN CAMBODIAN WAR SIGN U.N.-BACKED PEACE PACT; KHMER ROUGE SHARES RULE

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 23

 BODY:
With mutual distrust still lingering between longtime enemies, Cambodia's warring factions signed a peace treaty today aimed at ending a nightmare of war, mass murder, foreign occupation, starvation and exile that has devastated the Southeast Asian country over the last 21 years.
Under the agreement -- brokered by the United States, the Soviet Union and China -- a cease-fire in the round of civil war that began in 1978 went into immediate effect. It is to be followed by the demobilization of rival armies, repatriation of 350,000 refugees and elections by mid-1993. 
 But while the agreement today may offer Cambodia the hope of a respite from its pain, it also resurrected the specter of a return to power of the Communist Khmer Rouge movement. The Khmer Rouge was -- and is -- headed by the infamous Pol Pot, and under his leadership it was responsible for more than one million deaths in a total population of seven million from the time it seized power in April 1975 until it was ousted at the end of 1978 by Vietnamese troops.
 
Khmer Rouge Strongest Faction
 The Khmer Rouge remains easily the strongest of three Cambodian rebel factions, with an estimated 50,000 to 100,000 armed followers. And it now has two representatives on a new Supreme National Council and will be able to participate in the elections.
The two other rebel factions are the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, a conservative group headed by Son Sann, and a faction led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former head of state, who is to head the Supreme National Council during the transition to democratic elections.
The three rebel groups, ideologically disparate, have made an uneasy alliance to fight the Vietnamese-installed Government in Phnom Penh, now headed by Prime Minister Hun Sen.
The United Nations has been given the central role in insuring that the accord is respected. It is to send thousands of troops and civilians to help run Cambodia and share power with the 12-member Supreme National Council, which has been formed by the warring factions as a transitional administration until a democratic government is in place.
At the signing ceremony here today, a sense of perspective was provided by the French President, Francois Mitterrand, who said: "A dark page of history has been turned. Cambodians want peace, which means that any spirit of revenge would now be as dangerous as forgetting the lessons of history."
 
'Magnitude of the Suffering'
 The agreement was also hailed by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. "What makes the case of Cambodia so extraordinary -- and its claim for international support so compelling," Mr. Baker said, "is the magnitude of the suffering its people have endured."
Western diplomats said peace in Cambodia was made possible mainly by changes taking place outside the country -- both new cooperation between Washington and Moscow to settle regional conflicts and moves by China and Vietnam to encourage their Cambodian political clients to negotiate in good faith.
In return for Hanoi's support of the Cambodian peace, the United States announced plans today to seek a gradual normalization of its relations with Vietnam, which invaded Cambodia in 1978 and installed its client government in Phnom Penh.
Mr. Baker also said that the Administration intended to move toward such ties with Cambodia and with Laos, where Washington now stations not an ambassador but only a charge d'affaires in Vientiane, the capital.
He said that the United States would now lift its trade embargo with Cambodia and support aid projects through a new liaison office to be opened in Phnom Penh.
Washington, along with other Western governments, decided not to establish full diplomatic relations with the Supreme National Council but rather to await election of a democratic government. In the interim, American officials said the liaison office would try to insure that American humanitarian aid does not help the Khmer Rouge.
Representatives of the 18 other nations that signed today's accord warned of the need to insure that Cambodia's nightmarish history is not repeated. But none was more scathing than Mr. Baker in condemning the Khmer Rouge for violence against its own people "that has few parallels in history."
Noting that both the United States and Cambodia have signed the United Nations-sponsored Genocide Convention, he added that "we will support efforts to bring to justice those responsible for the mass murders of the 1970's if the new Cambodian Government chooses to pursue this path."
Britain's delegate, Lord Caithness, also said it would be "incomprehensible and unacceptable" if Pol Pot, Ieng Sary and other Khmer Rouge leaders identified with the period of massacres were to try to return to power. "That must not be allowed to happen," he said.
The Khmer Rouge leader, Khieu Samphan, was nonetheless one of four Cambodian leaders to sign the peace agreement. The others were Prime Minister Hun Sen; Son Sann, leader of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, and Prince Sihanouk.
 
Sihanouk Urges Support of Pact
 Prince Sihanouk, who was the only Cambodian to address today's gathering at the Kleber Conference Center here, said he considered the agreement a charter to "put an end to the suffering and misery of my people," and he called for "loyal and scrupulous implementation" of its terms by all parties.
Prince Sihanouk governed the nation through much of the 1940's, 50's and 60's, and was deposed in 1970 by officers led by Lieut. Gen. Lon Nol. The previous year, General Lon Nol had cut back Prince Sihanouk's power and become Prime Minister. Prince Sihanouk's ouster was also played out at a time of intense American bombing in Indochina and ground incursions into Cambodia.
Today's agreement consists of three separate documents -- one covering "a comprehensive political settlement"; a second guaranteeing Cambodia's sovereignty, independence and neutrality, and a third committing the signers to aid the country's reconstruction.
The peace accord is written to govern the factions that have fought each other since the Vietnamese invasion of 1978.
 
U.S. Began Legacy of Death
 But Cambodia's legacy of suffering dates back to the American incursions of 1970, described at the time as an effort to attack Viet Cong sanctuaries and supply routes. It had the effect of drawing the small country into the larger Indochina war.
American bombing in Cambodia continued until 1973, but Washington was unable to prevent the toppling of the Lon Nol Government by the Khmer Rouge in 1975.
Years later in 1989 -- after both the Khmer Rouge terror was over and all factions seemed to be aware that the civil war was tearing apart what remained of Cambodia -- a first Cambodian peace conference was conducted in Paris, but it failed.
Then, beginning in 1990, the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council -- the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France -- joined the negotiations. This eventually set the stage for an accord by committing the world organization to play a major role in the transition to democracy.
 
China and Vietnam Joined
 Moves toward an agreement accelerated this summer when China and Vietnam, both eager to end their international isolation and apparently ready to put aside their traditional enmity, began leaning on the Khmer Rouge and Phnom Penh respectively to show flexibility.
After today's ceremony, however, the focus turns back to Cambodia itself. Prince Sihanouk has announced that he will return to Phnom Penh on Nov. 14, and Prime Minister Hun Sen has said he will accompany him. Khmer Rouge representatives, including Mr. Khieu Samphan, are also soon to arrive in the Cambodian capital.
Similarly, the first, 268-member contingent of United Nations military and civilian personnel is expected in Phnom Penh before the end of this month with the mandate of observing the cease-fire and recommending the size of what will become known as the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia.
Western diplomats have estimated that 20,000 to 30,000 soldiers and civilian administrators will eventually be needed. They also believe that the cost of the 21-month operation will be $1 billion to $2 billion, requiring the United Nations to establish a special fund.
The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, described the peacekeeping mission in Cambodia as "probably the most important and most complex in the history of the United Nations." It is also the largest-scale by far. The Secretary General will shortly name a special representative who will exercise enormous authority under the terms of the accord.
The immediate task of the United Nations force is to regroup the rival armies in special "cantonment" areas, where they are to surrender their weapons and help locate millions of land mines. The factions are also committed to demobilizing at least 70 percent of their forces before the voter registration period is completed.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is to oversee the voluntary repatriation of 350,000 refugees in camps along the Thai-Cambodian border, although the Khmer Rouge has already been accused of violating the spirit of the accord by trying to force some refugees to move into areas under its control.
During preparations for elections for a 120-member assembly, involving adoption of an electoral code and voter registration, the United Nations force will also be authorized to run Cambodia's foreign affairs, national defense, finance, public security and information in order to guarantee a fair vote.
 
Elections Within 18 Months
 After the elections, expected to be held within 18 months, a constituent assembly has been given a further three months to draft a new constitution, to be approved by a two-thirds vote. It will then transform itself into a legislative assembly and elect a democratic government.
In theory, the role of the United Nations ends at this point but, because of the grim record of Cambodian violence, both the United Nations and other signers of the agreement pledged today to continue monitoring human rights in Cambodia after the end of the transitional period.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 31, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A credit line in some editions last Thursday with a picture of Pol Pot, the Cambodian leader, bore an erroneous date. The picture was taken in 1977, not 1985. As the article noted, Mr. Pol Pot has not been seen in public since the late 1970's.

Chart: "The Peace Settlement"
 Main points of the agreement signed yesterday by representatives from the Cambodian Government, three guerrilla factions and 18 other nations.
 * Administration: The United Nations will take over administrative tasks of the Cambodian Government, and will work with the Supreme National Council, which includes representatives from the Cambodian factions. The United Nations has the power to run ministries, including defense, foreign affairs, finance and communications.
 * Elections: The United Nations adminstration will help organize free elections in early 1993 to elect a constitutional assembly charged with drafting a new national charter guaranteeing human rights.
 * Cease-fire: A cease-fire is in place. Three main guerrilla factions and Government troops will withdraw. Under United Nations supervision, 70 percent of their effective forces will be demobilized. Foreign military support will halt.
 * Refugees: The United Nation's administration and its High Commission for Human Rights will oversee the return of 350,000 refugees from camps along the Thai border.
 * Sovereignty: The independence sovereignty, neutrality and territorial integrity of Cambodia are recognized.
 * Reconstruction: The signers of the treaty commit themselves to financially supporting reconstruction efforts. (Source: Associated Press) (pg. A16)
 
Chronology: "Years of Torment, Steps Toward Peace"
 
Early History: At the height of its reach and power between the 9th and 13th centuries, the predecessor of modern Cambodia, the empire of Angkor, was a strong and culturally advanced civilization. At various times, it controlle territory from the Burmese border to the Mekong Delta, and south to the South Chia Sea. But by the second quarter of teh 15th century, the empire was declining and was attacked on either side by Thailand and Vietnam.
 
1863: Again under pressure from his neighbors, Cambodia requests French protection to stave off national extinction, and the French transform Cambodia into a protectorate. By the end of the 19th century, Cambodia is incorporated with Laos and a divided Vietnam into an Indochinese union under French rule.
 
1941: The French install Prince Norodom Sihanouk, then 18 years old, as King of Cambodia.
 
World War II: Japanese forces enter Cambodia in 1941. Japan permits Vichy France to continue administering the country until late in the war, when it dissolves the French colonial administration. In response, King Sihanouk declares independence in March 1945. An anti-colonial government is formerd, but allied occupation forces depose it in October.
 
1946: After the war, France grants increased autonomy to Cambodia, but nationalists, led by King Sihanouk, demand full independence.
 
1953 -- November: France grants independece to Cambodia. At the Geneva Conference of 1954, Cambodia, like Vietnam and Laos, is declared a neutral state.
 
1955 -- March: King Sihanouk abdicates the throne in order to play an active role in day-to-day politics. He sets up a national front.
 
1963 -- November: Prince Sihanouk severs economic and military reations with the United States, citing the increasing American activity in Vietnam, and he accuses the American forces of carrying out border incursions into Cambodia.
 
Late 1960's: Important groups grow restive under Sihanouk's rule. Military officers resent his policy of permitting North Vietnamese armed activity in the border area, business people oppose his refusal to accept American economic aid, and urban intellectuals criticize his political dominance.
 
1970 -- March: While Prince Sihanouk is abroad, civilian and military officals overthrow his Government and turn over power to Prime Minister Lon Nol, an American-backed general involved in a limited move to eclipse Prince Sihanouk the previous year. In October, the monarchy is abolished.
 
1975 -- April: Communist guerrillas of the Khmer Rouge seize the capital, Phnom Penh, after a string of victories in provincial cities, and oust Lon Nol's Government. Under the titular leadership of Khieu Samphan and leng Sary, and the underground control of Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge impose a brutal reorganization of society in which more than a million people die. City dwellers are forced into harsh labor in the countryside, members of educated or merchant classes are put to death, and a reign of terror coupled with an extreme form of agrarian Marxism previals. Prince Sihanouk, the virtual prisoner of the Khmer Rouge, is declared the titular head of state.
 
1976: Prince Sihanouk resigns and goes to Beijing. Pol Pot emerges from the Khmer Rouge's underground leadership to become Prime Minister, taking full charge.
 
1978 -- December: After a year of incursions into Cambodian territory the Vietnamese Army mounts a full invasion of the country. It consolidates its powwer and in January 1979 installs a new Government led by Heng Samrin.
 
1982 -- June: Under pressure from China, the United States and other countries, the three Cambodian guerrilla factions form a coalition government in exile with Prince Sihanouk as president, Khieu Samphan as vice president and Son Sann of the conservative Khmer People's Liberation Front as prime minister. Washington recognizes the rebel coalition.
 
1985 -- September: The Khmer Rouge announces the retirement of Pol Pot as military leader, but Western governments say he is still the real leader.
 
1987 -- May: Prince Sihanouk steps down for a year as head of the coalition agter attacks on his men by the Khmer Rouge, and he pursues his own peace initiative.
 
December: Hun Sen, now Prime Minister in Phnom Penh, and Prince Sihanouk hold talks in France. This and four other rounds in the next 18 months proves inconclusive.
 
1988 -- February: Under Chinese pressure, Prince Sihanouk returns to lead the rebel coalition.
 
1989 -- April: Vietnam announces that all its troops will leave Cambodia by the end of September, even if no settlement is reached.
 
August: Peace talks in Paris involving 18 nations and the waring Cambodian factions collapse.
 
September: Vietnam says all its troops have now been withdrawn from Cambodia, although guerrilla groups charge, and Vietnamese officials later confirm, that some remain.
 
1990 -- January: The five permanent members of United Nations Security Council draft a peace plan calling for a U.N.-supervised administration to run the country while elections are organized.
 
February: Hun Sen and Prince Sihanouk meet in Bangkok and agree in principle to the United Nations role.
 
July: The Security Council members issue a plea to the factions to set up a Supreme National Council that would prepare the way for elections. Washington reversing a nearly decade long diplomatic position, announces that it is withdrawing recognition of the rebels and is ready to renew a dialogue with Vietnam to help the peace effort.
 
August: The Security Council members announce the main elements of a settlement. The agreement provides for an interim administration combining elements from the United Nations and all four Cambodian factions to run the country until United Nations-supervised elections can be held. Factional armies would be disarmed and kept apart by U.N. troops.
 
September: The four factions meet in Jakarta and agree to accept the United Nations plan, and they select a Supreme National Council.
 
The 12-member council meets in Bangkok but breaks up when the faction fail to agree on the chairmanship, the size of the United Nations delegation, a cease-fire and other important issues.
 
November: The Security Council's permanent members agree on the final draft of the peace settlement. The plan calls for the use of thousands of United Nations administrators and peacekeepers during the transition period to elections.
 
1991 -- May: A temporary cease-fire among the factions begins, but the Government in Phnom Penh and the rebels accuse each other of violations.
 
June: The Supreme National Council agrees to an indefinite cease-fire. It also agrees to stop receiving foreign arms.
 
August: Meeting in Thailand, the Supreme National Council agrees to disband 70 percent of the military forces in Cambodia and put the rest under United Nations supervision.
 
September: In talks in New York, the Cambodians clear a major hurdle to a peace pact by agreeing to a compromise system for election. The compromise calls for a system of proportional representation that would allow each faction places in Parliament based on its share of the popular vote.
 
Oct. 23: Leaders in Cambodia's warring factions and the foreign ministers of 18 nations sign a peace treaty ending decades of civil war. (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: Orders for Durables Off 3.2% As Military Demand Drops

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Factory orders for durable goods plunged in September for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today, in what analysts cited as a fresh sign of a weakening economy.
"If you wanted to sift the tea leaves in the most optimistic way, there's not much to make you feel good," said Joel Prakken, an economist with Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis forecasting service. 
 The Commerce Department said September orders for durable goods -- usually expensive items expected to last more than three years -- fell 3.2 percent from August, paced by the steepest decline in military orders in more than seven years.
 
Downward Revision
 Orders also sank a revised 4.1 percent in August from July, even worse than the previously estimated 3.9 percent drop. Orders had risen 11.7 percent in July.
"September orders for durables reveal a recovery that is still on the skids and shows few signs of strength," said John M. Albertine, an economist who heads a Washington forecasting company.
"This gloomy-looking figure, in conjunction with other statistics such as higher unemployment claims, indicate the sustainability of the expansion is in question," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis.
The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that a survey by its regional banks pictured an economy that was "weak or growing slowly" in September and early October, with manufacturing "still improving although at a slower pace in some areas."
 
Signs of Faltering
 "So far, industrial production really has been the main source of economic strength," Mr. Sohn said. "But this durable goods report indicates that production may not go up, and may falter."
The Fed survey also found that the Boston and St. Louis regions showed a "growing weakness in defense industries" -- a finding reflected in the durable goods report.
The often-volatile military orders plummeted 48.9 percent in September, the steepest drop since a 51 percent decline in April 1984. Orders totaled $5.5 billion, the lowest level since falling to $5 billion in November 1990.
Some analysts said the reduction in military spending associated with the end of the cold war would continue to plague the manufacturing sector. "It's part of a trend," Mr. Sohn said. Excluding the military category, orders rose 1.1 percent.
 
Drop in Transportation
 The transportation sector, which also varies widely from month to month, sank 13.9 percent, to $29.6 billion, on top of a 9.1 percent tumble in August. Excluding that sector, orders rose nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The report said decreases in aircraft, shipbuilding and tanks offset an increase in motor vehicles.
But the automobile industry reported steep declines in sales during the first 20 days of October, the beginning of the new model year. Many analysts expect auto sales to remain weak and thus curtail new orders.
Unfilled orders, another barometer of economic health, decreased eight-tenths of 1 percent, the first decline in three months. Falling backlogs often mean slack demand and subsequent declines in output.
 
Higher Shipments
 Shipments of durable goods increased seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $125.3 billion, the sixth consecutive increase, although the level remained below the $127.7 billion posted a year earlier.
Still, the report said orders for non-military capital goods excluding aircraft rose 8.2 percent, to $26.9 billion -- the biggest gain since a 9.6 percent advance in January 1989. This gauge of business plans for expansion and modernization had fallen 2.1 percent a month earlier.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Investors in UJB Suggest a Merger

 BODY:
An investor group led by Neil J. Weisman, which has recently acquired 9.9 percent of the UJB Financial Corporation, a Princeton, N.J., bank holding company company that owns the various United Jersey banks, has asked the board to consider merging with another banking concern. Mr. Weisman, who is president of the Chilmark Capital Corporation, said other banks were interested in acquiring UJB, the third-largest banking company in New Jersey, with about $13 billion in assets. 
 Problems with bad loans and a weak economy have hurt UJB's profits the last two years, though it has avoided the major losses that hit other banks in the region. Barrie MacKay, a spokesman for UJB, said, "The decision about any merger or acquisition will be made by the board." Shares of UJB stock closed yesterday at $14.875 each, up 62.5 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls After New Data On Economy, and Gold Is Off

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday after a new round of statistics showing poor performance in the United States economy.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery closed down 20 cents at $362.10 an ounce. A late bid at New York Republic National Bank showed gold down 50 cents, to $361.50. 
 Several currency analysts expressed surprise that the dollar did not fall further after the latest economic reports.
Orders for manufactured goods dropped 3.2 percent in September, the second consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department said. Meanwhile, the number of unemployed Americans filing for benefits rose by 29,000, to 452,000, for the week ended Oct. 12.
David Jaques, senior corporate trader for Barclays Bank P.L.C., said the reports prompted many traders to speculate that the Federal Reserve might lower interest rates again to stimulate economic growth. Lower United States interest rates would make the dollar less valuable to investors.
Speculation about the Fed easing rates had quieted down last week after reports showed a rise in inflation.
In Tokyo, where the trading day begins, the dollar fell to a closing 131.33 Japanese yen, from 131.45 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 131.05 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar fell to 131.15 yen, from 131.65 in the previous session.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7125, from $1.7056 late Wednesday. In New York, sterling cost $1.7105, more expensive than $1.6985 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.7000 German marks, down from 1.7113; 1.4880 Swiss francs, down from 1.4970; 5.7990 French francs, down from 5.8365; 1,270.50 Italian lire, down from 1,279.00, and 1.12625 Canadian dollars, down from 1.12775.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
2 Advocacy Groups Set For TV Duel

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
IN households across America on Tuesday, the duel over the remote control for the television set could take on added intensity when two groups compete in urging viewers to turn off, or turn on, their sets. Their diametrically opposed advice, though largely symbolic, underscores the continuing struggle by special-interest groups to redirect the content of television programming in ways more to their liking.
On one side is Turn Off Your TV Day, organized by Concerned Viewers for Quality Television in Wilmington, Del., a group allied with conservative groups like the American Family Association and Morality in Media. 
 On the other side is Turn On Your TV Day, organized by the New York chapter of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, a group seeking to end negative portrayals of homosexuals in the media.
These advocacy groups hope that millions of Americans will alter their viewing habits and express their opinions by writing and phoning not only local stations and national networks, but also the advertisers whose commercials pay for programming. Yet, even if the ratings do not change by a tenth of a point, the organizers say, Tuesday will serve to remind advertisers that they are under constant scrutiny.
The gay-rights group decided to promote a counter effort, said Ellen Carton, its executive director, because it believes Concerned Viewers wants "to put fear into advertisers" on gay-themed programming.
The president of Concerned Viewers, Vicki Riley, called that "the farthest thing from the truth." She added: "Just as I wouldn't want to see two men making love, or two women, I don't want to see a man and a woman."
"Two groups go at it like this, and the advertisers get caught in the middle," said Thomas DeCabia, senior vice president of the Paul Schulman Company in New York, a national media buying service.
Executives at buying services and advertising agencies said yesterday that so far, no clients had requested changes in their plans for Tuesday.
Such changes are unnecessary, said Michael Drexler, executive vice president and worldwide media director of Bozell Inc. in New York, because "advertisers are already sensitive to program content." Most provide agencies and buying services with detailed guidelines for purchasing air time.
Peter Chrisanthopoulos, the president and chief executive of the Network Television Association in New York, which represents ABC, CBS and NBC, predicted that viewership levels would be no different from any other fall Tuesday. Americans, he said, reject "coercive tactics."
The turn-off adherents "should have picked a Saturday night," said Andrew Donchin, director of national broadcast for Media Buying Services International Inc. in New York. "Nobody is watching then, anyway."
Ms. Riley termed her effort "a message the American people can send about holding the line on decency, on traditional values." Among the kinds of content she is aiming at, she listed "sexual innuendo; gratuitous sex, even in commercials," and violence.
In explaining Glaad's effort, Ms. Carton said: "Advertisers are not the most courageous people. They might withdraw their support so as not to have to deal with controversy."
That possibility is more likely "in this economy," said Ed Ronk, director of marketing services for Media Buying Services, "when advertisers have enough things affecting sales to not want a controversy, too."
In a larger sense, Ms. Carton said, her group considers the turn-off day to symbolize "censorship -- trying to dictate what is on the air."
Ms. Riley, in reply, said that while "everybody has likes and dislikes, our concern is the explicitness" of program content.
Mr. Drexler of Bozell expressed his disapproval of any pressure group that attempts "to dictate in any way" program content by trying "to hammer advertisers to withdraw funds for certain shows."
Thanks to remote control, "it's easier than ever to avoid what you don't want to watch," he continued, adding, "You don't even have to walk up to the set; hit the button."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
P.& G. Net Is Off 3.4%; Sales Rise

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that profits fell 3.4 percent for the quarter, although sales increased by 8.4 percent.
Profits for the big Cincinnati packaged-goods concern were $536 million, or $1.52 a share, down from $555 million, or $1.57 a share, a year ago. 
 Sales climbed to $7.21 billion from $6.65 billion.
The company said that strong growth in the sales of its products was more than offset by lower profits in its wood pulp business.
 
Competition and Price Cutting
 The company is in the pulp business to supply paper for its paper towels, toilet paper and other paper products. The company also told analysts yesterday that profits were off because of heavy competition and price cutting for paper products. "Retail prices for paper products were down," said Diane Mustain, an analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago.
The company also said earnings were hurt by unfavorable foreign exchange rates and added costs related to the purchase of the Max Factor cosmetics business in July.
The company said the sales gain resulted from record volume growth in the United States and in some international markets. Ms. Mustain said that the volume pickup appeared to result from the company's price cutting and "a lot of discounting" in the United States.
 
Plans to Invest $400 Million
 Edwin L. Artzt, the company's chairman, said, "Had it not been for pulp prices, foreign exchange rates and added Max Factor costs, our first-quarter earnings would have been up in line with volume growth, and that includes the increased investment in product initiatives and global expansion."
The company said that it planned to invest $400 million in new products and international expansion this year, despite continued economic softness in the United States, Canada and some parts of Europe. It said it had chosen not to delay the investments, despite a short-term impact on earnings.
The results were in line with analysts' revised expectations. Estimates were cut after Mr. Artzt recently disclosed the planned high level of new product investment.
P.& G.'s share price fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $80, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Increase in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
New signs of economic weakness helped push up prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday, sending interest rates lower.
Traders said that statements by Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, also contributed to the price rises. 
 Mr. Rostenkowski, whose committee initiates changes in tax policy in the House, told reporters yesterday that he was reluctant to forge a tax-cut bill this year, and would prefer to wait to see what the Bush Administration proposed before considering any changes.
"The statement from Rosty helped," one government bond trader said. "Most people know that the process that leads to tax cuts takes time, but they needed reminding. After his statement, people realized the only thing the Government can pursue right now to stimulate the economy is for the Fed to keep easing monetary policy."
The economic reports showed that orders for durable goods fell for the second consecutive month in September, an indication that manufacturing output may be slowing. And the Labor Department said that initial unemployment claims rose to the highest level in six months for the week ended Oct. 12.
"It strikes me that the economy is so weak that something needs to be done," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America. "And any sort of fiscal policy change is months and months away."
 
Five-Year-Note Auction
 The reports helped establish a good tone for credit market participants bidding at yesterday's auction of $9 billion worth of new five-year notes. The securities were sold at an average yield of 6.92 percent, down from an average yield of 7.05 percent at the last five-year auction on Sept. 25.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 101 1/8, up 19/32, to yield 8.02 percent, compared with 8.07 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 5/8, up 7/32, to yield 7.63 percent. And the new 6 percent two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.93 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were pushed down partly by the thought that the Fed may be close to easing monetary policy again soon.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.97 percent, down seven basis points, or seven one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by six basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.03 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by seven basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.03 percent.
New issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market remained heavy.
Among the companies offering new issues was the Ford Credit Corporation, which priced $958 million worth of securities backed by auto loan receipts through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 6.50 percent securities, which mature Nov. 15, 1996, have an expected average life of 1.8 years. They were priced at $99.843 to yield 6.73 percent, 74 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's new 6 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
ANR Pipeline Inc. offered $300 million of 30-year securities through an underwriting group led by Lehman Brothers.
The 9 5/8 percent bonds were priced at $99.434, to yield 9.683 percent, 1.65 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and BBB- by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues improved by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most widely-quoted issues rose by about 1/4 point.
A notable exception to that move was New York City. Negative assessments from various state and city officials about the economic climate in the city helped push down prices of some long-term city bonds by about 3/8 point, traders said, pushing yields up to around 7.75 percent on securities maturing in 2012 and 2022.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended week ended Oct. 14. M-1, the narrowest measure, fell by $3 billion. The $3.2 billion increase in M-2, the aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, was larger than most analysts had anticipated, but had little market effect.

HEADLINE: Brazil Ignores Protests And Begins to Privatize

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Oct. 24

 BODY:
As riot police and left-wing protesters traded rocks and tear gas canisters outside Rio de Janeiro's stock exchange today, investors inside inaugurated Brazil's privatization campaign, bidding $1.1 billion for controlling shares in a state steel company.
In a rare victory for the beleaguered government of Fernando Collor de Mello, the bids represented an 11 percent premium over the minimum asking price of $1 billion for the company, Usiminas Siderurgicas de Minas Gerais. 
 "The state is starting to get out of activities that don't belong to it," Mr. Collor said today in Brasilia. When this free-market advocate was inaugurated President in March of 1990, he vowed to privatize one state company a month.
 
Growing Social Tension
 But scenes of violence televised from streets around the stock exchange underlined the growing social tension in this nation, Latin America's largest.
As 600 military policemen sought to protect investors, protesters waving red flags rained stones on the officers' plastic shields. The afternoon of running street battles brought light injuries to 8 policemen, 5 journalists and 25 demonstrators. On Wednesday morning, a small bomb exploded outside the stock exchange, without causing damage or injuries.
Earlier this week, Brazilian television showed pictures of a factory assembly line smashed by laid-off workers in Sao Paulo, and of landless peasants attacking police with pruning hooks in the southern state of Santa Catarina. Fueling the desperation, food prices have jumped 27 percent this month in the middle of a deep recession.
"The privatization of Usiminas is an extremely positive step, but it is coming in the midst of a situation that could hardly be worse," Alden Brewster, a trader in Brazilian debt securities, said from New York today. "Inflation is out of control, and there are tremendous problems with reserves."
Historically, high monthly inflation rates in Brazil have provoked the replacement of the Economy Minister. If the current minister, Marcilio Marques Moreira, is replaced, negotiations over Brazil's $48 billion commercial bank debt would be set back for months.
Although polls give general support to privatization, the sale of Usiminas has rallied Brazilian nationalists.
From Rio, Leonel Brizola, the state governor, vowed Wednesday that if elected President in 1994, he would again nationalize Usiminas. "The foreign group that gets their hands on Usiminas should know that they will have to face some Brazilians down the road," he warned.
Opposition to the sale has come from figures as diverse as Itamar Franco, Brazil's Vice President, and Luis Ignacio Lula da Silva, the Workers' Party candidate, who was narrowly defeated by Mr. Collor in the 1989 election.
 
Foreign Bids for 6 Percent
 Today, contrary to nationalist fears, foreign buyers bid successfully for only 6 percent of the 839 billion shares. The two largest buyers were in Brazil's state sector. The state minerals company, Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, and Previ, the pension fund of Brazil's state bank, Banco do Brasil, each bought 15 percent.
During the two-and-a-half-hour auction, the price for 1,000 shares rose to 843 cruzeiros from 739 cruzeiros. Since the United States dollar rose to a black-market exchange rate of 710 cruzeiros today, 1,000 shares cost about $1.19 at the end of stock trading.
During an earlier attempt to auction off the steel company, virtually anyone wearing a coat and tie in the vicinity of the exchange fell victim to the protesters' eggs and kicks. Today, many investors slipped in and out of the exchange dressed in sports shirts and slacks.
