HEADLINE: American Express Net Plunges 91%

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The American Express Company, reeling from recession-induced problems in its charge- and credit-card businesses, said yesterday that its earnings for the third quarter plunged by nearly 91 percent, to $31 million, or 5 cents a share. The company added that the problems were likely to continue into the fourth quarter, when earnings might drop by as much as 45 percent.
The quarterly earnings performance, worse than the company had predicted only three weeks earlier, reflects the disproportionately large effect of the recession on American Express's white-collar customers.
 
World Travel Off
 It also reflects a drop in lucrative international air travel because of the Persian Gulf war, as well as American Express's own mistakes in dealing with the widening consumer debt crisis, especially in the company's ambitious Optima credit-card program. The company is investigating why the operation faltered, reporting better results than were warranted. 
 American Express's primary subsidiary, Travel Related Services, reported a loss of $88 million, or substantially more than the company's estimate on Oct. 2 of a loss of $50 million to $75 million.
"We just made a bad estimate," said Lawrence A. Armour, an American Express spokesman.
The third-quarter earnings drop includes one-time charges of $265 million that had been previously announced. The company has $155 million in new reserves for bad-credit losses and $110 million in restructuring charges, principally for closing certain offices in New York and on Long Island. The company plans to offer severance and early retirement packages to 1,700 employees, or 3 percent of its work force.
The company also said the poor performance would continue into the fourth quarter, when consumer spending historically rises because of holiday gift giving. American Express, based in New York, said it expected its earnings for that quarter to be around $75 million, or 16 cents a share, to $125 million, or 26 cents a share.
In the fourth quarter of last year, the company posted a net income of $138 million, or 28 cents a share.
American Express reported the earnings at 6 P.M. yesterday, well after the primary stock exchanges closed. Its shares fell 50 cents each on the New York Stock Exchange, to $20.625.
American Express's decline is most vividly expressed in three numbers. The company's return on equity, a widely followed measure of financial strength and one that has historically been robust for the company, was halved from the 28.5 cents of profit for every dollar of net worth in the 1990 third quarter, to 14.2 cents for every dollar in this year's period.
In addition, volume per charge card dropped from $770 in the 1990 period to $760 in this year's quarter. And traveler's check sales, a good indicator of travel volume, dropped by 10 percent, to $7.8 billion.
American Express's revenues in the third quarter rose by about 7 percent, to $6.48 billion, largely on the strength of good performances at IDS Financial Services, the company's financial-planning unit, and the Information Services Corporation, which processes credit-card transactions, bills for hospitals and cable-television companies and provides telemarketing services.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Damage Control On Banking Bill

BYLINE: By Stephen Labaton

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE nation's largest banks joined the Treasury Department in damage control yesterday, clearly caught off guard by the agreement reached Wednesday by two long-feuding House chairmen on comprehensive banking legislation.
For months, the Treasury and the banks have called for sweeping legislation to broaden bank powers -- legislation far different from what was hammered out by the two Democrats. 
 So anxious about the deal was the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, that he telephoned Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, in his office Wednesday night, even before Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, chairman of the Banking Committee, and John Dingell of Michigan, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, had finished their briefing on the compromise.
Mr. Brady said in a statement yesterday that he was not happy with what he heard. "It turns back the clock, restricts competition, and protects special interests," he said. "It will weaken the banking system and impede the economic recovery."
Representatives of many of the nation's most powerful banks -- Citicorp, Morgan, Chemical, NCNB and Bank of America -- along with officials of the largest bank lobbying groups, met yesterday with the House leadership to complain about the form of the compromise, which would revise more than 60 years of banking laws.
The legislation approved by Mr. Gonzalez and Mr. Dingell drops the Administration's proposal to permit industrial enterprises like General Motors to own banks. In 1993, it would repeal the Glass-Steagall Act restrictions that have limited mergers between investment banks and commercial banks, but it would still retain the high firewalls that securities firms wanted and that the Treasury and the large banks opposed. It imposes tighter restrictions on banks' ability to enter the insurance business than the Administration has sought. And it would eliminate the costly restrictions to bank expansion across state lines.
For months, the warfare between Mr. Dingell and Mr. Gonzalez had presented the biggest obstacle to broad banking legislation.
"They've been sparring and dueling and frothing on matters of not real substance," said Thomas (Lud) Ashley, an informal adviser to President Bush on banking issues and head of the Association of Bank Holding Companies, which represents many of the largest banks. "But as these events have shown, on matters of substance, these two gladiators are heading in the same direction," Mr. Ashley said. "Neither one wants any real bank reform." He predicted a White House veto if the measure is ultimately adopted by Congress.
The two chairmen defended the agreement yesterday. Mr. Gonzalez said it "reflects the views of the majority of Democrats," a proposition that could be put to the test as early as next week, when the measure may reach the House floor.
To make matters worse for the Administration, it has inadvertently set up a situation that encourages Congress to act quickly on the banking legislation. Mr. Brady's own Treasury officials had privately told the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to delay an increase in the premiums banks pay to finance the deteriorating deposit insurance fund. The current rate is 23 cents for each $100 in deposits. Their opposition was motivated by the belief that any increase would aggravate what is perceived at the Treasury as the No. 1 economic problem -- tight credit -- by raising bank expenses.
That decision now puts additional pressure on Congress to churn out the banking legislation because the bill also provides a proposed taxpayer loan of billions of dollars to keep the bank insurance fund afloat.
Treasury officials are privately talking about possibly moving to scuttle the entire measure and just push for a narrow bill that does little more than provide new money for the insurance fund.
"I don't think anybody is in control of this thing," said Edward Yingling, the top lobbyist for the American Bankers Association. "At this point, we are bracing ourselves for a chaotic floor fight."
Mr. Yingling said his organization had already begun to mobilize a grass-roots effort to defeat the agreement when it reaches the House floor.
But like so many issues in the complex banking package, the industry is far from united. The happiest bank representative in town was Kenneth Guenther, executive director of the Independent Bankers Association, which represents many of the nation's smaller banks.
Mr. Guenther, who has long criticized the Administration's proposal as a sop to the big banks, hailed the agreement as "very pro-community banking."
"A comprehensive bill has left the station," Mr. Guenther said. "Sorry, Lud Ashley. Sorry, Citibank."

HEADLINE: 5-Month High for Jobless Claims

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The number of first-time applications for unemployment insurance benefits climbed 6.8 percent, to 452,000, in the second week of October, the highest level since May, the Labor Department reported today.
While weekly claims figures tend to be erratic -- and for that reason are often viewed skeptically by analysts -- today's report represented the fifth consecutive advance for claims when they are averaged over the latest four weeks. That, analysts say, is strong evidence of a faltering economy. 
 "There's evidence that the jobs situation is getting worse again," commented Robert A. Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities in New York. "There are some real signs of deterioration."
 
Other Weaknesses
 Weakness also showed up today in the Government's report on orders for durable manufactured goods over the last two months. The Commerce Department said that orders fell 3.2 percent in September and that August's decline was 4.1 percent instead of the 3.9 percent estimated originally. Last month's drop was larger than expected but was concentrated in military goods, reflecting political trends and possible end-of-fiscal-year procurement gyrations. [Page D6.]
Today's figures on initial jobless claims came under particular scrutiny from economists since they covered the week during which the Government conducted its monthly labor market survey, prompting some analysts to predict an uptick in the nation's unemployment rate when it is published Nov. 1. In September, unemployment edged down one-tenth of a point, to 6.7 percent.
Democrats have seized on weak job and other economic data lately to press their case for extending benefits for idled workers whose benefits have run out. The House remained in session all night Wednesday debating the matter, with members waxing eloquent on cable television into the early morning in support of extended benefits.
Fearing they might lose political ground on the issue, Republicans pointed out that they, too, support extended benefits but do not want to increase Federal spending to pay for them. But the White House announced Wednesday that President Bush would probably veto a third attempt by Democrats to extend benefits.
Initial claims for jobless benefits, which gauge the ranks of the newly unemployed and are thus a predictive indicator of the economy, climbed to a peak four-week average of 511,500 in late March and then subsided to a low of 403,000 in late July. Since then, however, the average has risen for 11 of the latest 12 weeks, including the last five. It stood at 435,000 in the latest period.
"The data are saying that labor-market conditions have resumed weakening," said Carl J. Palash, senior economist at the New York consulting firm of McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei.
Mr. Palash was wary, however, of assuming that a rise in initial claims during the week of the monthly survey -- which is always performed during the week containing the 12th of the month -- meant that the unemployment rate for September would rise. He said a study he conducted as an economist at the Federal Reserve showed no correlation, with only a 50-50 chance that the pre-survey claims figure would even point in the right direction.
He also noted what seems to be a tendency of initial claims, which are adjusted for seasonal variation, to rise at the beginning of a new quarter. This could reflect some workers' waiting to file for maximum benefits based on their latest full quarter of earnings.
 
Military and Auto Layoffs
 The rise for the week ended Oct. 12 was 29,000, paced by "military and auto layoffs in the Texas and Michigan region," according to Kathleen Stephansen, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Claims for the preceding week remained unchanged, at 423,000.
Without seasonal adjustment, claims were 389,100 in the week, up 22,000 from the preceding week, with the year-earlier level at 356,200, the department's report showed.
In all, 3,431,000 people on a seasonally adjusted basis were collecting jobless benefits under state programs during the week of Oct. 5, 89,000 higher than in the week ended Sept. 28 when the level, now revised, was 3,342,000. The insured unemployment rate rose to 3.2 percent, from 3.1 percent the week before.
The states with the highest insured unemployment rate for the week ended Oct. 5 were Alaska, at 4.5 percent; Rhode Island, at 4.1 percent; California and Massachusetts at 3.5 percent, and New Jersey and Oregon at 3.4.
The five states with the biggest increases in initial claims for the Oct. 12 week were Texas, with 6,300; Michigan, with 3,500, followed by Minnesota, Pennsylvania and Washington. The biggest declines were in Illinois, Ohio, Massachusetts, Florida and Arkansas.

HEADLINE: Exxon's Earnings Rise 3.7% On Surge in Global Refining

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Citing sharply higher profits in global refining that overcame sluggish domestic demand for its products, the Exxon Corporation today reported a 3.7 percent gain in its third-quarter profits.
Net income rose to $1.12 billion, or 88 cents a share, from $1.08 billion, or 85 cents a share, in last year's third quarter. But revenue fell 5.2 percent, to $27.5 billion from $29.0 billion. 
 Exxon, the nation's biggest oil company, is one of only a few large oil companies to report a profit increase for the quarter. Texaco, Chevron, Amoco and Phillips Petroleum all reported sharp declines this week. Mobil reported a slight decrease because of special charges, but its profits from operations were higher.
 
Growing Foreign Operations
 All those companies, as well as Exxon, were hurt by crude prices that were more than $4 a barrel below the average for the 1990 quarter and by the lowest natural gas prices in the United States in several years. But Exxon, like Mobil, was better protected because of the growing foreign makeup of its operations.
Exxon, based near Dallas in Irving, Tex., sells 60 percent of its natural gas output from fields outside the United States. Most foreign countries regulate natural gas prices and did not permit them to fall as steeply as those in the United States, so Exxon's profit margins were not cut so severely as those of mainly domestic producers.
"Exxon had a good quarter, considering the soft economic conditions in many markets," said Lawrence G. Rawl, the company's chairman and chief executive.
The third-quarter earnings were helped in part by the absence of the operating troubles at refineries and losses in foreign chemical sales that the company experienced a year ago, said Michael Mayer, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder & Company, in San Francisco.
 
Lower Energy Prices
 Over all, profits in worldwide exploration and production fell by 19.1 percent, to $752 million, because crude oil and natural gas prices were lower than in the 1990 quarter.
But net income surged in refining and marketing to $410 million from $246 million, because refineries had lower operating costs and wider profit margins. Crude oil and natural gas liquids are the most common raw materials for refineries. Foreign refining operations, where earnings rose to $312 million from $94 million a year earlier, provided all of the increase in this sector's overall profit.
Exxon's shares fell 37.5 cents, to $60.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: U.S. RAISES HOPES ON 'BOAT PEOPLE'

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The announcement by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday that the United States was ready to seek normal relations with the Hanoi Government has raised hopes among diplomats and officials of international refugee agencies that a turning point is at hand in the unceasing flow of "boat people" from Vietnam.
They believe that the ending of Vietnam's virtual international isolation could alter a mood of hopelessness and encourage Vietnamese to see their future at home. 
 Officials at the headquarters here of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, as well as representatives of humanitarian organizations, have long held a view that by boycotting Vietnam, the United States has strongly contributed to the economic deprivation that has prompted many Vietnamese to flee.
Successive American Administrations have ascribed their hard line to Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia and the continued uncertainty over the Americans missing in action since the Vietnam War. Some international officials have detected an emotional resistance to come to terms with the Communist Government that humiliated the United States in the war.
 
Hong Kong Is the Goal
 Indonesia shelters 20,000 Vietnamese, Malaysia and Thailand 12,000 each, and the Philippines 7,400. But the present focus of the "boat people" problem is Hong Kong, which since last year has become virtually the sole goal of those fleeing Vietnam. About 64,000 Vietnamese are housed in detention camps there.
Britain and Vietnam are involved in protracted negotiations over the return of about 20,000 of the refugees who have been ruled to be economic refugees without legitimate fear of persecution at home, and therefore not entitled under international law to refugee status.
In an unusual congruence of views, the United States and Vietnam oppose any forcible return. A forcible repatriation in 1989 brought an international outcry led by the United States. Since then, only those who volunteered have been sent back. They number 14,000.
The Bush Administration has asserted that Vietnam's human-rights record raises doubt that Hanoi will respect its international pledge not to punish those who fled. But aides of the High Commissioner asserted that their visits had made them confident that there is no ground for fear.
"We get incredible cooperation," an official said. "They do anything we want."
 
A Liberalized Atmosphere
 The official, who accompanied a group of representatives of refugee-aid organizations from the United States and other Western nations to Vietnam in May, said they had found a greatly liberalized atmosphere in which ordinary Vietnamese were no longer afraid to criticize their Government to foreigners.
"Those among the team who had visited Vietnam previously remarked how they were surprised and impressed with the considerable progress the country was making toward becoming a more open society," the delegates said in their report.
The High Commissioner's aides said that almost none of the Vietnamese who are fleeing now would qualify for immigration to the United States. They said that only 4 or 5 percent originate from the former South Vietnam and had been connected with the American-backed Saigon government or had relatives in the West.
American and international officials said southern Vietnamese were now leaving largely legally, under a system called the Orderly Departure Program. An American official said American immigration aides interviewed 10,000 applicants a month in Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon, and a High Commissioner's aide said legal immigration to the United States would reach about 100,000 this year.

HEADLINE: 2 Bills Seek Affordable Health Insurance

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
The powerful chairmen of two Congressional committees introduced bills today to guarantee that private health insurance would be readily available to all people who work for small businesses with fewer than 51 employees.
In offering the companion bills, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Finance Committee, signaled the Democrats' intention to seize the election-year initiative on one narrow aspect of the health-care issue without waiting for a consensus in support of comprehensive changes. 
 Members of both parties said the health insurance legislation had an excellent chance of passage in the next 12 months.
Most people who work for big companies have health insurance bought by or through their employers. But small businesses often have difficulty obtaining coverage. Insurers usually charge them higher premiums because the costs are less predictable: claims for a small group may rise suddenly if one employee has a serious health problem. So Congress is addressing the insurance needs of small businesses separately from the needs of the nation as a whole.
 
Disagreement on Tax Cut
 Even as Mr. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat, and Mr. Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, announced agreement on health insurance for small businesses, it was clear that they disagreed on another potent political issue that is likely to figure prominently in next year's election campaigns: a tax cut to stimulate the economy. A recession began in the middle of last year, and the economy remains sluggish.
Mr. Bentsen said, "This economy is dead in the water." But at a joint news conference, Mr. Rostenkowski said today that he doubted that the economy would benefit from Mr. Bentsen's proposal to help middle-income families by cutting taxes $72 billion over the next five years.
Mr. Rostenkowski said he was firmly committed to the fiscal discipline of last year's budget agreement, and he added, "Most of the more respected economists are suggesting that to do anything in the tax code with respect to the economy is very dangerous."
Asked if he intended to move tax legislation to the floor of the House, Mr. Rostenkowski, said that the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, "has not yet directly told me that he wants a bill this year."
 
Symbolic All-Night Session
 In symbolic solidarity with millions of unemployed workers, House Democrats held an all-night session to discuss the need for extending unemployment insurance benefits.
The session ran from 9 P.M. Wednesday to 9:40 A.M. today. The Bush Administration has not clearly stated its position on the health insurance bills introduced today. It rarely supports greater Federal regulation of any industry, but it has acknowledged the existence of the problems that the bills are trying to solve.
Under the proposals, the Federal Government would become deeply involved in regulating private health insurance, which for decades has been regulated mainly by the states. The bills do not require small businesses to buy health insurance. But they say insurers offering coverage to small businesses may not refuse to cover employees because of their medical history, claims experience or health problems.
 
Rates for Small Businesses
 Both bills would reduce the variation in insurance premiums for small employers, requiring insurers to set rates within about 20 percent to 25 percent of the average for a community. Congressional aides said the Senate bill allowed more leeway for insurers to adjust rates to reflect differences in the age and sex of their customers.
Under the Senate and House bills, insurers would be subject to a special Federal excise tax if they failed to comply with Federal standards for health insurance.
The bills would also increase the tax deduction for health-insurance costs of self-employed individuals. Under current law, self-employed people are allowed to take a deduction from gross income for up to 25 percent of amounts paid for insurance for themselves, spouses and dependents. Under the bills introduced today, such people could deduct the entire cost.
Insurers like Blue Cross and Blue Shield say the inevitable result of Federal limits on variation in premiums would be to increase the cost of insurance for healthy, low-risk groups.
Mary Nell Lehnhard, vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, said both bills "move too fast" to reduce the variation in insurance rates for small businesses. "If you reduce rates for high-risk people, rates for healthy people go up," she said.
Linda S. Jenckes, vice president of the Health Insurance Association of America, which represents more than 300 commercial insurers, said her group would prefer to see states adopt the type of standards proposed by the two bills. "We hope the introduction of these bills will encourage states to act next year to negate the need for Federal legislation," she said.
While the House and Senate bills are similar, Mr. Rostenkowski's proposal includes more stringent measures to control health-care costs. Under his proposal, private insurers could pay doctors and hospitals at the rates set for Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. Medicare often pays less than private health insurance.
"We're trying to end the national scandal where more than 15 percent of our citizens, 34 million Americans, are uninsured," Mr. Rostenkowski said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lloyd Bentsen, left, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, announcing yesterday that they have introduced bills to guarantee the availability of health insurance to workers in small businesses. (Andrea Mohin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: How the Budget Gap Is Estimated

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Estimating New York State's budget deficit is an exercise that is partly technical, partly speculative and, certainly, partly political.
The Cuomo administration, which has already projected that the deficit would range from $500 million to $800 million, is expected to come up with a more precise figure next week. 
 Much of that estimate will be based on numbers already in hand. For instance, personal income-tax collections, the largest source of state funds, are about $130 million less than what was projected when lawmakers passed a budget last spring. And Medicaid enrollment has jumped almost 10 percent, 3 percent more than expected.
But there is also conjecture at work, because part of the estimate is derived from projections about how tax revenues, the economy and spending on entitlement programs like Medicaid will grow or shrink between now and April 1, when the state fiscal year ends.
No one can say what the trends will be in the next six months, although one reason there is a deficit in the first place is that weaknesses in the economy turned out to be worse than the bleak assumptions built into the original budget projections.
And this is why the deficit-estimating game is political as well: Although state budget officials say the process is objective, they control the economic assumptions built into the estimate, so they have some latitude in setting the number. And whatever estimate Gov. Mario M. Cuomo comes up with next week, some lawmakers here will surely deride it as overly pessimistic and others will say it is too optimistic.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Political Memo A Cuomo Bid Or a Hamlet On Hudson?

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 24

 BODY:
If Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is running for President, his public agonizing in the last two weeks makes perfect political sense. If he is not running, his recent actions are hard to understand and could prove a political embarrassment, cementing his position in political mythology as a Hamlet on the Hudson.
With any other politician, that theorem might suggest strongly that Mr. Cuomo plans to join the race. But Mr. Cuomo is not any other politician. 
 Some of those closest to Mr. Cuomo, including many who believe he will not run in 1992, maintain that the Governor's unconventional political style has made him easily misunderstood. Despite what may appear a grand political game, they say, Mr. Cuomo is engaged in the most fundamental self-examination of his political life.
His decision requires him to analyze the depth of his ambition, his commitment to his state and its voters, and his own capacity to hold the most important office in the land. While other candidates have conducted that debate in their living rooms and offices, Mr. Cuomo has done it largely in public because it is his nature to do so, his aides and advisers said.
"We are conditioned to seeing people who only speak when there's a motive," said Gary G. Fryer, Mr. Cuomo's former press secretary. "He has never been like that. He has frequently got in trouble in the past because he thinks out loud."
But Mr. Cuomo has been known in the past to speak with a motive from time to time. And if he is running, the strategy of the last two weeks has been executed with great dexterity.
His public discourse on the Presidency has insured him a place at the center of the country's most intriguing political story, a story that he has advanced just enough each day to win headlines from Los Angeles to Boston.
By not disclosing his decision, he has generated national interest with the question of whether he will run, feeding the perception that the Democrats badly need his services and sparing himself the scrutiny afforded to announced candidates.
As a noncandidate, he has been able to mount harsh attacks on the Bush Administration -- indeed, every public appearance has become an opportunity for such attacks -- with little risk of return fire.
A sampling from the last two days alone includes his remark at a public health forum on Wednesday that, "For the last 10 years, we've said all you need a Federal Government for is for an army or to cut taxes on rich people."
That night, he told listeners at a Liberal Party dinner in Manhattan, that "things have never been as obviously wrong in America as they are now." At a law-enforcement forum in Albany today, he said the Bush Administration had sent the message that "the war we fought in Iraq is more important than the war we fought in the 103d Precinct."
After complaining bitterly last month that the press was ignoring such pronouncements because he was not a candidate, his critiques of Federal policy on the economy, drugs, and health care are once again the stuff of newspaper articles and television sound bites.
But those closest to Mr. Cuomo continue to say they will be surprised if he joins the race, and the Governor conceded today that the state's worsening fiscal situation would weigh against a national campaign. Cuomo administration officials are projecting a midyear budget gap of between $500 million and $800 million, and the Governor has raised the possibility that the Legislature may have address the problem in a special session.
"It's certainly an important factor and something to consider," he said today at a news conference. "Obviously, I would think if you have difficulty with the budget it's an argument for dealing with the budget."
So while Mr. Cuomo seems to be relishing his chance to pummel the Republicans, his dire warnings about the state budget seem designed to provide a rationale for why he cannot run. Curiously, Mr. Cuomo issued his first public warnings about a budget gap on Oct. 11, the same day he first told supporters in a private meeting that he would think about running for President.
Meyer S. Frucher, a New York City real-estate executive and longtime Cuomo adviser, has implored Mr. Cuomo to run but believes the Governor will not do so because Mr. Cuomo feels he cannot abandon his obligation to the state. Mr. Frucher said he also believes the Governor fears that New York would be victimized by Republican political attacks that could further damage the state's fragile economy.
 
Serious Consideration
 But Mr. Frucher said the pressure on Mr. Cuomo to run has been intense, and that the Governor's public decision-making process was necessary to convince Cuomo enthusiasts that the Governor has given the issue serious consideration.
"You have no idea how angry people are at the thought that he is not running," Mr. Frucher said. "To the people wanting him to run, saying no without an explanation or without the feeling that he gave it real deliberation would be unacceptable."
If Mr. Cuomo does not run, political analysts believe that his national reputation may be irreparably damaged by his second unconsummated flirtation with the Presidency in four years.
"There simply would have been no point to it, and he's done it in such a public way," said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution. "It simply wasn't necessary, and it's getting close to becoming a joke with the 'Hamlet on the Hudson' stuff."
Mr. Cuomo's defenders disagree. "If he decides not to run, it would be irrelevant," said Mr. Fryer. "It would be a one-day story: Cuomo isn't running and here's who's racing at Aqueduct. Who would care?"

HEADLINE: New Fight In Albany Over Budget

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and top lawmakers are not sure yet how big the budget deficit announced yesterday is, but today they appeared to be heading for a collision over the question of how to get rid of it.
Governor Cuomo said today that he favored a broad approach to finding the savings, or the revenue, to close the $500 million to $800 million gap. He gave no details, saying he would not do so until he knew the deficit's exact size. 
 The Senate Republicans say the problem is almost entirely a result of spending on the state's Medicaid and welfare programs. The spending has, in fact, significantly outpaced the projections built into the budget that both parties had insisted last spring was balanced.
But yesterday Mr. Cuomo and his Democratic colleagues had specific complaints of their own.
Mr. Cuomo derided the Republicans for portraying "poor, sick people" as the only culprits in the budget turmoil. And Assembly Speaker Mel Miller dismissed the Republican vow to focus almost solely on social-service programs as a target for spending cuts. He said such programs made up less than a fifth of the budget and simply could not yield all the savings needed to pare the deficit.
 
Uncertainty Over Medicaid
 So for all the trauma of last year's mid-year budget cuts, when all sorts of local-aid programs were reduced and state workers were forced to defer a week's worth of pay until retirement, the fight over this year's budget gap could be even more vehement, lawmakers in both parties say.
The looming battle also creates new uncertainty for the much longer-range proposal Mr. Cuomo outlined last month to have the state eventually assume all local Medicaid costs, a move that the Governor said would provide significant budget relief for New York City and other struggling municipalities.
The majority leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate, Ralph J. Marino, suggested today that his chamber would not even consider the proposal unless it were accompanied by major cost-containment initiatives, like new limits on medical services or doctor's visits.
"Without dealing with the problem here, which is out-of-control growth in spending on the program, the state simply can't afford it," Mr. Marino said of the Governor's proposal.
The Governor has repeatedly countered that he is at least as committed as the Senate is to reining in the Medicaid program. Nevertheless, Mr. Marino's ability to withhold support for the state Medicaid takeover -- which some Republicans complain could be of greater benefit to New York City than the suburban or upstate areas they represent -- may give him an unusual degree of influence in how the present gap is closed.
On top of all this is the basic question of why the budget has fallen out of balance at all, given the solemn statements in the spring by the Governor and the legislative leaders that their spending plan would not fall in the red.
The Governor has wasted little time in attacking the Legislature for the problem, noting that the amount of spending they added back into the budget last spring after he vetoed parts of it appeared to be roughly equivalent to the size of the current gap.
"I did plead with them," Mr. Cuomo said the other day at a news conference. "But I lost again because they said no, you've got to spend." The extra money was mainly for local-assistance programs like school aid.
That argument will probably not hold up, however, because aside from putting his name to the final budget accord last spring, Mr. Cuomo also took credit for getting the Legislature to pay for that additional spending. So it might be a stretch of logic for him now to blame the spending for the deficit.
Similarly, Republicans like Mr. Marino say the problems with excessive Medicaid spending were Mr. Cuomo's fault because the program, which his agencies oversee, had not achieved the cost savings projected when the budget was passed. But not only did the State Senate concur with the savings projections, it actually originated several of them.
Some independent observers think, in this case anyway, that the Governor and the legislative leaders have no need to blame themselves or each other. "I don't think you can do much too much faulting here," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the nonprofit Citizens Budget Commission. "What is driving the deficit, essentially, is that we are learning just how badly the economy is performing, and it's worse than almost anybody ever thought it would be."

HEADLINE: Gene Roddenberry, 'Star Trek' Creator, Dies at 70

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Gene Roddenberry, the Hollywood writer and producer who created the 1960's science-fiction television series "Star Trek," which inspired six feature films, a sequel series in the 1980's and legions of space-age devotees known as Trekkies, died yesterday at Santa Monica Hospital Medical Center in California. He was 70 years old and lived in Los Angeles.
Mr. Roddenberry had been ill for about six weeks and died of a blood clot, said John Wentworth, a spokesman for Paramount Pictures. But Wendy Gullies, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said the cause of death was listed as cardiopulmonary arrest. 
 A tall, soft-spoken man with a silver mane and a dazzling imagination, Mr. Roddenberry was a much-decorated B-17 pilot in the Pacific in World War II, a pilot for Pan American World Airways, a speechwriter for the Los Angeles police chief, a writer for episodes of "Dragnet" and "Naked City," and head writer of the 1950's television series "Have Gun, Will Travel."
But with "Star Trek," which made its in 1966 and ran until 1969 on NBC, Mr. Roddenberry took a generation of viewers along on a journey into "space, the final frontier," aboard the Starship Enterprise, to "explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations, to boldly go where no man has gone before."
 
The Galaxies Beyond
 It was an idea that, in various permutations, consumed more than a third of Mr. Roddenberry's life and made believers out of the most skeptical critics. It gave American popular culture such futuristic hardware as "phaser guns" and "transporter beams," and a living-room window on worlds and aliens far beyond the reality of a bright new space age.
It introduced a cast of characters whose names became familiar to millions: the dashing commander, Captain Kirk (played by William Shatner); the omnisciently logical, pointy-eared Vulcan First Mate, Mr. Spock (Leonard Nimoy); Dr. McCoy (DeForest Kelley); Scotty, the chief engineer (James Doohan); Mr. Sulu (George Takei), and Lieut. Uhura (Nichelle Nicols).
And it spawned a worldwide fascination that led to Trekkie conventions, products ranging from books and T-shirts to lunch boxes and toys, reruns of its 79 original episodes in 48 countries for more than a decade, a half-dozen feature films starting in 1979, and a sequel series, "Star Trek: The Next Generation," which was launched in 1987 and is still running, with audiences of more than 12 million households and numerous awards to its credit.
 
Entertainment With a Message
 "Few ideas in the annals of motion picture and television history have inspired more passion and allegiance on the part of the audience than has 'Star Trek,' " said Brandon Tartikoff, chairman of Paramount Pictures, which made both the "Star Trek" series for television and all the feature films.
For Mr. Roddenberry, the Star Trek phenomenon was more than entertainment, as he explained in an interview with The Los Angeles Times in May.
"It has become a crusade of mine to demonstrate that TV need not be violent to be exciting," he said. "I wanted to send a message to the television industry that excitement is not made of car chases. We stress humanity, and this is done at considerable cost. We can't have a lot of dramtics that other shows get away with -- promiscuity, greed, jealousy. None of those have a place in 'Star Trek.' "
 
From a B-17 to Starships
 Eugene Wesley Roddenberry was born in El Paso, Tex., on Aug. 19, 1921, the son of an Army cavalryman who later went into law enforcement in Los Angeles, where the boy grew up. He attended Los Angeles City College, the University of Miami and Columbia University, studying pre-law, then aeronautical engineering. He qualified for a pilot's license and flew a B-17 Flying Fortress in World War II on 89 missions, including Guadalcanal and Bougainville. He won the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal, among other decorations. While in the South Pacific, he began to write stories and poetry for magazines and newspapers.
After the war, he joined Pan Am as a pilot, flying for four more years. From 1949 to 1953, he was a sergeant with the Los Angeles Police Department, working as a department spokesman and a speechwriter for Chief William H. Parker. He also began writing for television, and from 1953 to 1962 he wrote scripts for "The U.S. Steel Hour," "Goodyear Theater," "The Kaiser Aluminum Hour," "Four Star Theater," "Dragnet," "The Jane Wyman Theater" and "Naked City."
He won his first Emmy Award for "Have Gun, Will Travel," a western that, according to some film and television critics, was a precursor of "Star Trek" in that its wit, characterizations and themes were only incidentally set in a particular time and place.
The original "Star Trek," Mr. Roddenberry told an interviewer a few years ago, was technically primitive, but it aimed high for adventure and in the way it portrayed people and their relationships.
"We had to explain computers," Mr. Roddenberry said. "And our effects were primitive. Our stars were a black cloth with holes in it and light behind. The episodes cost $186,000. They're $1.3 million for 'The Next Generation.' I wanted to cast a woman as second in command. NBC said no way."
Mr. Roddenberry, who said he always thought of himself as a storyteller, wrote not only the original shows, but also what he called a bible for later writers to follow. It detailed characters, the ship and its technology, the 23d century and the fantasy of deep space, in which they all traveled.
Some writers told him it was the hardest show in television to write for because they had to know so much about history, economics, moral values and the personalities of the running characters. There was formula in it, but the shows were hardly the standard television fare of car chases and grim faces.
Mr. Roddenberry was producer of the first "Star Trek" film and executive consultant on the next three. He was the executive producer of the sequel series.
Survivors include his wife, the former Majel Leigh Hudec; a son, Eugene, known as Rod; two daughters, Darleen Incopero and Dawn Compton; a brother, Robert; a sister, Doris, and his mother, Carolyn Glen Roddenberry.

HEADLINE: Pop/Jazz;
Singing The Praises of Cabaret

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
"AN endangered art form that asks us to strip away our urban defenses for an hour and admit a little vulnerability."
That is how the writer James Gavin distills the essence of the cabaret experience in the final chapter of "Intimate Nights: The Golden Age of New York Cabaret" (Grove Weidenfeld), his richly atmospheric history of Manhattan nightclub life over the last half-century. 
 The shoring up of this economically fragile but artistically flourishing art form will be the main order of business next week at Town Hall, where the Second Cabaret Convention is presenting seven concerts at bargain prices. Starting on Sunday with a gala opening concert tied to Town Hall's 70th anniversary, and concluding on Nov. 2 with a grand finale, the convention will bring more than 100 cabaret performers onto the hall's stage. Tickets for each concert are $10.
The participants range from cabaret legends like the singer and comic actress Dorothy Loudon and the pianist Stan Freeman to up-and-coming performers like Molly Scates and Phillip Officer. The youthful cast of "Forever Plaid," the hit musical-comedy revue about a squeaky-clean male harmony group from the 1950's, is appearing, as are performers from outside New York City, including Amanda McBroom from Los Angeles, the composer of "The Rose," and San Francisco's most popular cabaret singer, Weslia Whitfield. For anyone interested in exploring a world in which classic popular music and refined sensibility come together, there is no better opportunity.
Except for Sunday's concert, at which Jeff Harnar, Bruce Hubbard, Ms. Loudon, Helen Schneider and B. J. Ward are to perform short sets, each show will feature about a dozen performers doing two or three numbers each. Tuesday's concert is a tribute to Raymond Jones, a co-director of the Mabel Mercer Foundation who was an important figure in San Francisco cabaret. "Bistro Night" on Wednesday adds comedy and revue material (including excerpts from "Forever Plaid") into the mix. Thursday's program is a showcase for cabaret songwriters. Friday's concert focuses on singing pianists, among them Blossom Dearie, Barbara Carroll and Ronny Whyte.
The driving force behind the Second Cabaret Convention is Donald F. Smith, a publicity agent, promoter, party-giver and close friend of Mabel Mercer, the quintessential cabaret artist. Shortly after her death in 1984, he established the Mabel Mercer Foundation to perpetuate the genre and to keep alive the memory of the singer who epitomized it.
"Less than six months after Mabel's death, I began to get calls from people who wanted to write pieces about it being the end of an era," he recalled recently. "Often they were not well informed about Mabel. I kept worrying about what would happen in a couple of years to the reputation of a woman who had had a 66-year run in the clubs and who had affected so many major artists, but who never had hit records and had made very little impact on television.
"I got some chums together. We went to see a lawyer and set up a foundation that had two aims. One was to make sure that Mabel Mercer was remembered accurately over the years and that the size of her contribution would not be forgotten. The other was to try to give an ongoing visibility to the whole field of cabaret."
This convention's predecessor, in 1989, included four concerts at Town Hall and panel discussions. It attracted an audience of 6,000, and in its wake, Mr. Smith said, he received 900 letters about the problems facing the cabaret industry. High on the list were the unavailability of classic popular American music on radio and television and the prohibitive costs of going to nightclubs.
This year the foundation is presenting "cabaret classic awards" to Ms. Loudon, Steve Ross, Barbara Cook, Tony Bennett, Anne Francine and Julius Monk. Starting next fall, it will also present six Thursday-evening showcase concerts at Weill Recital Hall featuring up-and-coming cabaret performers, who will also be given honorariums. Each week, Mr. Smith said, the foundation receives 20 to 50 video and audio cassettes and at least three dozen press kits from aspiring performers around the country.
Depending on how it is viewed, the state of cabaret could be described as everything from precarious to flush. In recent years, two national stars, Harry Connick Jr. and Michael Feinstein, have ascended from New York cabarets. So have several Off Broadway shows, including "Forever Plaid," "Nunsense," "Closer Than Ever," "Beehive" and "Daugherty and Field Off Broadway." The list of cabaret stars who do consistently good business in major clubs like the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel, the Ballroom, Michael's Pub, Rainbow and Stars, and the Cafe Carlyle includes not only veterans like Bobby Short, Miss Cook, Julie Wilson and Mel Torme, but also younger performers like Karen Akers, Andrea Marcovicci, Dixie Carter, Helen Schneider, Maureen McGovern, Jeff Harnar, Susannah McCorkle and John Pizzarelli.
 
Networks and Albums
 Mr. Smith has been instrumental in starting two successful new series in Manhattan, and he is working to establish the beginnings of a national network. A series of Sunday-evening concerts upstairs at the Russian Tea Room has been wildly successful since it began a year and a half ago. The three-year-old Cabaret Comes to Carnegie series, which has presented 24 performers since its inception, is to resume in the spring at Weill Recital Hall with appearances by Miss Wilson, Adelaide Hall, Hildegarde, and Daugherty and Field. A flourishing farm system for up-and-coming performers in Manhattan includes the Skylight Room at Danny's Sea Palace, Don't Tell Mama and, most notably, Eighty-Eight's, the Greenwich Village club that has showcased Mr. Harnar and the very promising Billy Stritch, who has been booked into Rainbow and Stars this winter.
Last year, DRG Records, an independent company based in New York, inaugurated a series of cabaret albums beginning with records by Ms. Marcovicci, Sylvia Syms and Margaret Whiting. The latest releases are two live albums, recorded at the Carlyle and featuring Miss Carroll and Miss Carter.
The series has sold surprisingly well, said Hugh Fordin, the owner of DRG and the producer of the series.
"I would have been satisfied if the records did well in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles and Chicago," he said. "But we've been selling in places like St. Louis, Kansas City and in the South." The 16 titles in the series have sold an average of 10,000 copies each, he said.
But if there has been a small upsurge in the last decade, the cabaret world is certainly not booming as it did in the 1940's and 50's, before the age of television, when New York was filled with boites where singers could be heard for just the price of a drink.
 
Fond Memories
 "It was a completely different scene," recalled Mr. Freeman, who is appearing at Michael's Pub in "At Wit's End," a one-man show about Oscar Levant. The show is the first stage appearance in 15 years by the pianist and wit, who used to be a regular headliner at the Blue Angel. He now lives in Los Angeles, where he has worked as a television writer for many years.
"Going to a nightclub was just something one did because there was no television to watch," he recalled. "I have very fond memories of it. It wasn't just going to a club. Especially for a performer, there was a kind of amity to it that made the whole evening fun. You would sit around until 4 or 5 in the morning gabbing and drinking and listening. Now you get up and pay the bill and go."
Ms. Loudon, who is performing at Sunday's gala, has made cameo concert appearances in recent years, but she hasn't played a regular nightclub engagement since 1962. With a standing invitation to play Michael's Pub, she said, she is seriously considering re-entering cabaret.
"I had many happy years in those little dumps and saloons and remember it as a very sweet time," she recalled. "But it was very hard work. If you can work those little rooms, you can do anything at all."
The singer recalled the moment she was forced to realize that she was a comic personality. "I had always wanted to be a serious singer," she said. "And I remember auditioning for Julius Monk and singing 'My Man' very intensely. He screamed with laughter all the way through. And at the end of it, he said, 'Have you ever considered comedy?' I really hadn't."
 
Building a Future
 If today's younger cabaret performers don't have the same secure network of clubs and hotels that Mr. Freeman and Ms. Loudon once enjoyed, there is still a cohesive sense of community that can provide spiritual, if not financial, encouragement.
Miss Scates, who was discovered by Mr. Smith performing at Eighty-Eight's, moved to New York from Florida 12 years ago. She makes her living producing special events and doing public relations for the Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan. Trained in both theater and voice, she began working in small clubs about 10 years ago. She is putting together an act that deals with her Southern background and interweaves the writings of Tennessee Williams and William Faulkner, along with music that runs from Stephen Sondheim to Hank Williams. She sharpened her concept, she said, by attending the O'Neill Cabaret Symposium last summer at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.
"I met a lot of terrific people in the industry who gave me a lot of encouragement," she said recently. "They helped me think in terms of marketing. I stopped telling myself it was a vanity showcase and began looking at it as a mini-theater piece that could be sold if it was entertaining enough."
Mr. Officer, who was also discovered at Eighty-Eight's performing a show of Richard Rodgers songs, does word-processing for a law firm. But he has built up enough of a following that he makes a little money from performing. And he has earned the approval of the Rodgers and Hammerstein Foundation, which has discussed with him the possibility of making a record of his show.
"It's tough at the beginning to build an audience on your own," he said. "But with the turn cabaret seems to have taken, there are a lot more opportunities for us. There seems to be a surge in the number of rooms available, and I'm surprised at the number of people who want to see cabaret. It's becoming a really legitimate form of performing."
The author of "Intimate Nights," who is an inveterate clubgoer, agreed that there has been an upswing of interest in cabaret.
"Interest in the field has grown tremendously," Mr. Gavin said. "There are a lot more performers trying to break into the business. If they don't leap right into television and the movies, how else can they learn to stand before an audience and get some feedback as to how good they are? But I don't know what this amounts to in terms of audiences. A lot of the rooms are fighting for their lives. Just to go into a club that has a $10 cover charge is likely to be a $25 evening. That's a lot of money to pay to sit and listen to someone for an hour when you can stay at home and watch a $2.50 video.
"If I'm not optimistic about the future, I'm hopeful," he added. "Most of the people who are doing it are certainly not doing it for the money. They're doing it for love."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Frugal? A Cheap Shot, Maintains Nederlander

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
Robert Nederlander, the managing general partner of the Yankees, yesterday denied recent reports that the team planned to become more frugal and maintained that the club would pursue free agents this winter.
Several published reports have said that the Yankees would pass up potentially expensive free agents like Bobby Bonilla and that the team was heading toward an economic downswing. Nederlander sounded agitated that the Yankees, perhaps the richest team in baseball, were being cast as cheap and denied any economic changes had occurred within the organization. 
 "If it makes sense for the club to enter the free-agent market, we will do so," Nederlander said in a short telephone interview. "The Yankees have been involved before and we will do it again. I don't know where these rumors come from. I don't like responding to rumors."
Though Nederlander is forbidden under baseball rules from commenting on specific players until they are free agents, General Manager Gene Michael has said the major needs for the Yankees next season are at least one starting pitcher, another power hitter and a third baseman. All should be available in the free-agent market in pitchers Frank Viola and Tom Candiotti, sluggers Bonilla and Danny Tartabull and third baseman Steve Buechele.
When Nederlander was presented with a scenario of a certain type of player who could help the club being on the market and asked how the Yankees would act, he reacted enthusiastically about making a bid.
"If we feel a player will help the club, there is no reason to believe we will not take a chance," Nederlander said. "If it makes us a better club, we will be seriously involved."
Nederlander also attempted to defuse growing doubt about the power held by Michael, who disappointed the Yankees' limited partners by proposing former major league managers Hal Lanier and Doug Rader for the manager's job on the Yankees. Both were viewed by the partners as retread candidates.
When Nederlander was asked if Michael's power had eroded, the man who took over for George Steinbrenner said he did not understand the question. He was then asked if Michael had specifically lost some of his hiring power.
"Gene Michael is the general manager in charge of baseball operations and he will continue in that position and continue to have the power one ordinarily has in that position," said Nederlander. "Leonard Kleinman and I are not the baseball experts."
Even so, Nederlander and Kleinman, the chief executive officer, were the ones who delivered the message to Michael last weekend to reconsider Buck Showalter -- who had been fired from his job as the Yankees' third base coach on Oct. 7 -- as a managerial candidate. It was a message Nederlander refused to address yesterday.
"I don't want to talk about what I said to Gene Michael," he said.
Nederlander also declined to comment when asked if Showalter was the lone candidate left to replace Stump Merrill, as a club official indicated Wednesday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
DDB Needham Laying Off 35

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
In another sign that the advertising industry recession continues unabated, DDB Needham Worldwide, New York, has dismissed an additional 35 employees.
In a memo from Peter Falcone, president of the agency's New York office, the layoffs were attributed to further erosion in client spending levels. The cutbacks, which follow the dismissal of 22 people earlier this year, are being made from the ranks of corporate employees as well as from New York office staff. Total employment in New York now stands at 672. 
 Among other agencies that have cut staffing levels this year are Ayer Inc.; Levine, Huntley, Vick & Beaver, and Ogilvy & Mather.

HEADLINE: For Haiti: The Essential First Step

 BODY:
The crisis in Haiti will not be over until the legitimate President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is restored to office. Despite resistance to his return by much of Haiti's narrow political elite, and disturbing allegations about his style of rule, the entire hemisphere has a stake in his return.
What's at stake is not Mr. Aristide's personal franchise but constitutional legitimacy, a principle not yet secure in nations like Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Peru, Uruguay or Paraguay. All have recently liberated themselves from long periods of military rule. But all suffer from economic and social problems that make them vulnerable to military pressure. 
 For a decade, the U.S. has threatened to make life untenable for any Latin American nation's military that moved against a democratic government. Haiti is a test of Washington's resolve.
Mr. Aristide first won renown as a radical Catholic priest. But as President he cultivated good relations with the U.S. and the International Monetary Fund. His approach to domestic politics, however, was provocative. He had deadly enemies to contend with. Holdovers in the military, the police and the judiciary were determined to block reforms that threatened their privileges. The new President felt he had a popular mandate for reform, even if it meant bulldozing the opposition.
Democrats, including many of his electoral allies, were excluded from power. Parliament was ignored and intimidated by pro-Aristide mobs. Business and military leaders willing to accept his radical changes were spurned. Lynch mobs were tolerated.
These abuses explain the Sept. 30 military coup but cannot justify it. With no mandate beyond brute force and naked greed, the army massacred innocent civilians. It heaped more abuse on the constitutional order in a few days than the Aristide Government had in seven and a half months.
The other nations of the hemisphere have the right to insist that President Aristide publicly commit himself to Haiti's popularly approved Constitution once he is returned to office. The Organization of American States could then establish a monitoring presence to guarantee constitutional order against infractions from any side.
That won't be enough for President Aristide's bitterest enemies. But it should be enough for democrats. The best way to assure that the day of the dictator is truly over in the Americas is to bring Mr. Aristide back.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Cuomo and U.S. Policy

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
One of these days a Democratic Presidential candidate may wake up, rub his eyes and shake his head and decide it is time to challenge President Bush on foreign policy.
This country, so deeply involved in the world, somehow leaves foreign policy to diplomats except in time of crisis. Foreign policy is life and death and too important to leave to diplomats or any other single group of Americans. 
 At least during Presidential campaigns the voters should hear a clear-minded running debate on American objectives abroad, what they are and should be. But in the campaign under way no such thing is in sight.
Maybe the Democrats now in the field are just not smart enough to know what has gone wrong with the Bush foreign policy. Maybe they and their party think Americans are too stupid to care about such things as stopping weapons of mass death from being peddled around the world, or building up Middle East dictators again.
Maybe they are too scared of Mr. Bush's reputation as a foreign policy hotshot, which compared to some of them he may be. Maybe it is all the maybes.
The Democratic candidate most likely to wake up would be Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York. It startles me that I think so, because his foreign policy record is not vast and where it cropped up most noticeably I was immediately allergic -- his opposition to fighting Saddam Hussein.
Mr. Cuomo did not seem as great a sinner after Mr. Bush left Saddam Hussein alive and in power and Iraqi rebels dead or in flight. But if Mr. Cuomo had been President the U.S. would be facing a nuclear-armed Iraq by now. So Americans on both sides of the Persian Gulf line can point fingers at each other.
Anyway, among Democrats Mr. Cuomo alone has shown that he has what's needed to grasp what is wrong with the Bush foreign policy -- a taste and talent for intellectual, ethical and moral challenge and combat. It is precisely in the fields of intellect, ethics and morality that the policy has gone wrong.
In the Soviet Union, Mr. Bush built his entire policy around Mikhail Gorbachev's fantasies that he could reform the Communist system and party enough to stay in power and that the central authority and K.G.B. could put down national and ethnic movements trying to break out of the Soviet political prison.
The Soviet Union collapsed -- which any number of dissidents could have told the U.S. had Washington paid them a smidgeon of the attention it lavished on Mr. Gorbachev alone.
The Bush nuclear arms proposals could not have been made nearly as soon had Soviet central power remained under the chiefs of the party, the army and the K.G.B. The threat to the U.S. from the Soviet Union was always in a centralized dictatorship with enormous military strength, not in its dissolution. Now the tendency in the U.S. bureaucracy is to keep together as much central Soviet authority as possible -- fantasy time again.
In China, Mr. Bush supports what is now the world's most grinding repression, which imprisons millions of Chinese to sell the sweat of their labor at home and on the world market, and which is also becoming the world's most active salesman of mass destruction.
In the Mideast, the Bush Administration has decided that Israeli settlements on the West Bank are the greatest threat to peace. This must be a real surprise to Arab countries that for a half-century have waged military, economic, terrorist and propaganda warfare against Israel and still do.
The thread that runs through all these examples is drearily familiar in American foreign policy -- a taste for foreign dictatorships. They seem so much easier to deal with than messy democracies.
The problem, of course, is that dictatorships wind up going to war against their neighbors where the messy democracies find other ways of settling their problems.
That is a traditionally deep fault line in American policy and officialdom. It is waiting there for Mr. Cuomo to see, explore and persuade Americans to leap over.
Speaking of awakening, quoting from an Alice Walker poem last Friday, I left out the name in a line that should have read: "Good night, Willie Lee, I'll see you / in the morning."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Politics of Resentment

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
When a former Ku Klux Klan leader and neo-Nazi has a good chance to be elected governor of an American state, it is time to think about what is going wrong in the politics of this country.
David Duke came a close second in the Louisiana gubernatorial primary, finishing just two percentage points behind former Gov. Edwin Edwards. Because it happened in Louisiana, there was a certain tendency to put it down as another example of that state's eccentricity. But it is not a joke. 
 The Duke phenomenon is extremely serious, and its implications are not confined to Louisiana. The votes for him were a cry of political resentment, a cry that I think was aroused by economic pain manipulated by the factor of race.
Millions of Americans -- many millions -- are suffering from a prolonged and devastating economic recession. Real wages have fallen for three straight years. Unemployment has hit not only wage-earners but many middle-class people. And there is no convincing sign of a meaningful recovery.
The physical conditions of life are becoming more and more unpleasant for Americans. Highways are crowded and crumbling, cities unable to cope with the homeless, schools and myriad other problems. Even medical care is priced out of the reach of many ordinary people.
Sixty percent of those reached in a New York Times/CBS Poll released this week said things had got "pretty seriously off on the wrong track" in this country. They said the most important problem was the economy. Yet President Bush offers no program for economic recovery or reconstruction. He says, essentially, that nothing can be done.
In the circumstances, a historian would expect political repercussions -- would have expected them, indeed, before now. And here they are, in the vote for David Duke. It is the vote of people who have lost faith in established political leaders.
President Bush's spokesmen tried to distance themselves from Mr. Duke. He was not a real Republican, they said.
But Mr. Duke has remodeled himself in the image of the contemporary Republican Party. Not so long ago, in the 1980's, he celebrated Adolf Hitler's birthday and told an interviewer that the Nazi death camps had been built not to kill Jews but to kill lice that infested Jews. But he has muted that kind of talk, as he has remade his face by plastic surgery.
Nowadays Mr. Duke talks to his political audiences about affirmative action, "quotas," welfare abuse, crime. The same rhetoric has been used by President Bush and his people. It can be -- it often is -- a genteel code to evoke anti-black feelings.
A few days after the Louisiana primary, White House spokesmen rejected a compromise Senate civil rights bill on the ground that it would encourage racial "quotas." It is a charge that practically no one else supports. But by all signs Mr. Bush wants not a bill but an issue: the issue of race.
One lesson of the Duke phenomenon is that when national leaders use race for short-term political gain, as President Bush has repeatedly done, the country is likely to pay a price. Senator John Danforth, Republican of Missouri, who led the fight for Clarence Thomas's confirmation and is trying to get a civil rights bill passed, has given his own party exactly that warning.
On the racial question, there is not much to be done now except to hope that George Bush's better instincts will somehow overcome political temptation. But there is a way for our system to deal with rising public resentment over the economy. That is for the opposition, the Democrats, to offer an alternative.
An alternative means, first, a policy. The broad outlines are in view, put forward by a number of Democrats already in the race for 1992: Rebuild our physical infrastructure, care for our cities, have a rational system of health care and so on.
But in this country change requires a candidate. Franklin Roosevelt offered not a program but hope, in his voice and his person. As the times look more like 1932, Democrats have their eyes on another Governor of New York. Perhaps David Duke and the politics of resentment will be enough to make Mario Cuomo face the challenge.

HEADLINE: Foreign Buyers Pushing Up Condo Prices

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
While the values of most apartments have stabilized or are still falling in New York City, those pied-a-terre along Manhattan's most elegant streets continue to climb, with well-heeled foreign investors setting new price records for high-end condominiums, real-estate studies show.
Most of the buyers, many of whom are seeking that fourth home or refuge from tumultuous times in their own countries, continue to pour cash into a sliver of New York's vast residential real-estate market -- expensive condos. They are bidding up prices along the city's "Gold Coast" avenues while the values of cooperative apartments are stabilizing or still declining. 
 For example, an investor from Hong Kong, possibly jittery over what may happen when Britain turns that city over to the Chinese Government, has been negotiating to buy 47 condominiums -- or 6 floors -- in Trump Palace, at 200 East 69th Street at Third Avenue.
One buyer paid $2 million in September for a four-and-a-half-room condominium at Trump Tower that sold for $1.62 million just five years ago, while another buyer paid $2.57 million for a four-and-a-half-room condo at 30 East 85th Street.
 
A West Side Condo
 Such prices are not confined to the East Side of Manhattan. A buyer spent $1.8 million for a four-room condominium at the Park Belvedere, on West 79th Street at Columbus Avenue.
In most cases, the studies said, the apartments bought and sold between January and June were smaller than those bought and sold in the same period last year. As a result, buyers paid more for less, with the East 85th Street condominium, for example, selling for $1,531.82 a square foot.
Because the apartments being bought are in a category all their own, the prices paid had no effect on those being paid for cooperative apartments or even the rest of the condominium market, which is relatively small in New York City.
In fact, most of the foreign buyers concentrated their purchases in the condominium market, in part as a way to avoid baring their finances and personal lives to co-op boards and also because state law prohibits corporate ownership of co-ops. About half of the foreign buyers buy their apartments through some kind of corporation.
Alan Rogers, a managing director of Douglas Elliman, one of New York's top real-estate brokerage concerns, said that it was important to remember that condominiums were only a small part of the New York apartment market and that even in that slice, American buyers still predominate. It is in the top 10 to 15 percent, he said, where foreign money has stabilized condo prices or forced them up.
"In the spring there was a spate of Italians buying and they were looking for substantial discounts," Mr. Rogers said. "But there were also a lot of Spaniards and they bought as much as the Italians. We have also seen the South Americans come back, and they are always at the top end."
The average two-bedroom condominium in Manhattan sold for about $330 a square foot in August, according to Yale Robbins Inc., a condominium research concern.
 
Quality and Quantity
 Barbara Corcoran, who heads the Corcoran Group, a well-known residential broker, said buyers of the most expensive apartments tended not to be sensitive to prices. "People cut back in their own ways," Ms. Corcoran said. "These people are not that quick to cut back in terms of quality, although they may cut back in quantity. Many of them would be comparing the apartments to a similar product in Paris or London because it's a third or fourth home."
Over all, condominium prices were down 4.6 percent in Manhattan for the second quarter of 1991, according to a study by Susan Wachter, a professor at the Real Estate Center at the Wharton School.
That study, which was done for Heller Equities Inc. and was based on the 728 condominium sales in Manhattan in April, May and June, showed that the average price for condos on the Upper West Side rose 11.2 percent in that period from the preceding three months. In the Lexington Avenue to York Avenue district, bounded by 50th Street and 86th Street, prices fell 13.3 percent in the second quarter, the study said.
The study said most of the increase on the Upper West Side occurred because condos bought years ago were recently sold at current market prices.
 
The Trump Factor
 In the world of the super-rich, the one name that dominated this year was Trump. Of the 10 most expensive condominiums bought in New York from January to June, seven were in buildings built by Donald J. Trump, with most of those in Trump Palace, his latest luxury tower.
Jack Heller, the head of Heller Equities, which is building luxury apartments at 86th Street and Fifth Avenue, said there was an increase in the number of top-end condo sales over the summer, with prices rising roughly 5 percent during that period.
Native New Yorkers may be dumbfounded to hear that foreigners will pay $2.5 million for four rooms, but it is a matter of perspective. On average, a square foot on Fifth Avenue in the 60's through the 80's costs half as much as comparable areas in Paris and about a third of the $2,143 a square foot for apartments in Tokyo's Azabu section.
The very rich may be paying more on a square-foot basis, but in some instances they are economizing by buying fewer rooms. So the final purchase prices of the 10 biggest deals were slightly lower than the 10 biggest in the first half of last year. The single most expensive condo sold in the first six months of this year, based on purchase price, was a seven-room penthouse in the Trump Palace that went for $3.51 million.
The provenance of those willing to pay such prices for apartments has also shifted to reflect the troublesome political and economic climates abroad. The influx is now from Hong Kong, instead of Japan.
"Flight capital has fueled this city's condominium market for the last 10 years and it's just a question of the nationality," Ms. Corcoran said.

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Friday with an article about foreign investments in New York City condominiums referred incorrectly to a $2.57 million purchase at 30 East 85th Street. It was for two apartments, totaling nine rooms, not a single apartment of four and a half. The article also referred incorrectly to a prohibition on the sale of co-op apartments to corporations. It was a Federal restriction, no longer in effect, not a state law.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Little Changed; Gold Is Down in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday amid mixed signals about the direction of interest rates. Gold prices fell in New York after rising overseas.
Comments by President Bush "reinforced an attitude that perhaps the Federal Reserve is going to ease policy again" and that helped push the dollar lower, said Kevin Logan, chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation. 
 The President said: "The economy has been sluggish. It hasn't been near as good as I would like to see it or certainly the American people would like to see it."
Traders have been expecting the Fed to nudge interest rates downward, which would depress the dollar by decreasing foreign demand for American investments.
Susan Phillips, Mr. Bush's nominee to the Fed, told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday that the economic signals were mixed and that additional easing might be needed.
Yet Mr. Bush said there was a limit to how far interest rates could fall. He again argued in favor of a cut in the capital gains tax to stimulate business investment and create new jobs.
More negative economic news came from the National Association of Realtors, which said existing home sales fell 4.3 percent last month. Declines were recorded in all regions of the country.
Analysts said the dollar was mired in a narrow trading range.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York, rising to 131.45 yen, from 131.15 late Thursday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar edged up to 131.36 yen, from 131.33 yen Thursday, and later, in London, it rose to 131.40 yen.
The yen has also been hurt because Japanese interest rates are expected to decline when the country's new Government takes office next month.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.7135 in New York from $1.7105. In London, sterling fell to $1.7115, from $1.7125 late Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.7000 German marks, unchanged; 1.4870 Swiss francs, down from 1.4880; 5.8000 French francs, up from 5.7990; 1,270.75 Italian lire, up from 1,270.50, and 1.12625 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.7050 German marks, up from 1.6975; 1.4890 Swiss francs, up from 1.4865; 5.8045 French francs, up from 5.7900; 1.9165 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9135; 1,271.50 Italian lire, up from 1,267.50, and 1.1255 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1250.
Gold dropped $1.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $360.90 a troy ounce.
