HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Price of Oil Drops Again; Week Shows Big Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices fell yesterday, wrapping up a week that broke the ack of an extended rally.
Light crude oil for delivery in December settled at $23.12 a barrel, down 37 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. For the week, oil for next-month delivery fell $1.02 a barrel. 
 Crude-oil prices have now given up almost half the ground they gained in their recent rally.
Home heating oil for delivery in November settled at 68.43 cents a gallon, down 0.85 cent for the day and 1.38 cents for the week. Unleaded gasoline for delivery in November settled at 64.72 cents a gallon, down 0.54 cent for the day and 1.01 cents for the week.
"It seems that this is the most downward activity we've seen in this market for a long time," said Peter Beutel, an oil futures analyst at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
One reason for the drop, he saaid, was that warm weather in the Northeastern United States was restraining demand. Also, demand for gasoil, the European equivalent of home heating oil, had slackened after weeks of buying fed by fears that supplies from the Soviet Union would be disrupted.
Traders also got news that the Kuwaitis hope to extinguish all their burning wells during November, suggesting that the market could soon be seeing more Kuwaiti oil than it had been anticipating. Most of Kuwait's wells were set ablaze by Iraqi troops as they retreated last winter.
Amid all that, oil managed to show a gain only once during the week, rising 21 cents a barrel in Thursday's session.
Prices of natural gas were mostly higher, with contracts for delivery in December settling at $2.081 for 1,000 cubic feet, up 1.2 cents. For the week, natural gas for next-month delivery was up 5.6 cents, but that rise was largely explained by technical trading factors related to the expiration of futures contracts for November delivery.
In London, North Sea Brent blend crude oil for delivery in December settled at $21.79 a barrel, down 31 cents for the day and 80 cents for the week, at the International Petroleum Exchange.

HEADLINE: Avon Posts A Deficit In Quarter

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
After taking a $75 million charge for discontinued operations, Avon Products Inc. yesterday reported a $27.3 million loss for the third quarter, in contrast to a $44.6 million profit in the corresponding quarter a year ago.
Earnings per share for the cosmetics manufacturer were 59 cents in the period a year earlier. 
 Sales increased 4.1 percent, to $865.2 million, from $830.8 million in the third quarter of 1990.
The charge was taken to write down notes and other securities that Avon received when it sold some health-care and other businesses in 1987 and 1988, Avon said. The company said the value of the securities had decreased.
"The company expects 1991 income from continuing operations will be good," said James E. Preston, Avon's chairman and chief executive. "We continue to benefit from a global portfolio that hedges the risk of recessions in individual markets or regions."
In a conference call to stock analysts, Mr. Preston said Avon was still dealing with uneven results overseas and competitive pricing pressures.
Promotional pricing ate into profits in the third quarter, but Mr. Preston said new efforts to control costs should offset pressure on the company's margins for the rest of the year.
Sales in Avon's international division grew 5 percent in the third quarter, while the United States division reported a 6 percent increase in sales.
The company attributed sharply declining sales and pretax profits at Giorgio Beverly Hills, its prestige fragrance subsidiary, to "dismal United States retail sales for luxury goods."
"Consumers are buying very conservatively and trading down to lower margin items," Mr. Preston said in his comments about the Giorgio division's performance. "Retailers, too, are cautious and are keeping their inventories to a minimum, sometimes a less-than-adequate minimum, which is probably costing them and us sales."
Avon also reported that it had reduced its debt load 8.4 percent, to $552.6 million, on Sept. 30, down from $603.3 million at the end of last year's third quarter, and that it would continue to emphasize debt reduction.

HEADLINE: Dow Declines 11.40 More, to 3,004.92

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Blue-chip stock prices declined steadily throughout a rocky afternoon session yesterday, but they recovered slightly in late trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down more than 25 points within an hour of the close, rebounded a bit to finish at 3,004.92, down 11.40 for the day and 72.23 for the week. 
 Analysts said investors continued to be chilled by disappointing corporate earnings reports and a lack of encouraging news on the economy. In particular, the proposals floated this week to stimulate the economy through tax cuts had dashed investors' hopes that the Federal Reserve Board would soon lower interest rates, analysts said.
 
'Perfect Excuse' to Take Profits
 "The uncertainty over when the Fed will ease interest rates was a perfect excuse for those who had profits to take them," said John H. Shaughnessy, senior vice president and director of research at Advest Inc., a brokerage based in Hartford.
A moderate 167.3 million shares changed hands on the Big Board yesterday, compared with 179 million on Thursday. Losers outpaced gainers by 920 to 682.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 0.87, to 384.20. The New York Stock Exchange composite index dropped 0.50, to 211.82. And the American Stock Exchange market value index fell 1.30, to 376.43.
Smaller issues were also lower, with the Nasdaq composite index falling 3.62, to 525.13.
The Dow, which had begun the day with a quick bump upward, seesawed throughout the morning before declining during the afternoon. Program traders contributed significantly to that drop, with a rash of sell programs pressing the Dow down 18 points between 2 and 3 P.M., according to Birinyi Associates, which monitors computer trading.
With 5.1 million shares changing hands, American Express -- down 1 3/8, to 19 1/4 -- was the most active stock on the Big Board. Several analysts lowered their fourth-quarter estimates for the company yesterday, following its announcement Thursday that its third-quarter earnings plunged by nearly 91 percent, to $31 million, or 5 cents a share. The company said it anticipated its difficulties would persist in the fourth quarter.
Glaxo Holdings, up 2, to 51 1/4, was one of the biggest winners on the Big Board. As had been speculated earlier in the day, a Food and Drug Administration panel voted yesterday afternoon to recommend approving Imigran, the British company's new, highly touted migraine drug, for sale in the United States.
Compaq Computer fell 2 3/4, to 30 1/4, on what traders described as the shocking news that the company's board had ousted Joseph (Rod) Canion, its president and co-founder. The announcement capped a volatile week for the company, which on Wednesday announced the first quarterly loss in its nine-year history, as well as the first layoffs.
Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's chief operating officer, was named yesterday to succeed Mr. Canion. A heavy 2.6 million shares of the stock changed hands, making it one of the most aggressively traded issues on the Big Board.
The biggest dollar loss on the Big Board belonged to Delta Air Lines, which dipped 4 1/8, to 61. Geoffrey Dann, an airline analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said Delta officials told him and several other analysts in a conference call Thursday that its acquisition of most of the assets of Pan American World Airways would be dilutive in the near-term.

HEADLINE: Treasury Auctions Opened Up

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
In its latest response to the scandal at Salomon Brothers Inc., the Government announced today that the auctions that raise money to finance the nation's debt would be open to all brokers rather than just Wall Street's largest banks and investment houses.
The decision is intended to encourage greater participation in the auctions and weaken the role of the 39 primary dealers who have long been given special treatment for acting as middlemen between the Government and the secondary market of institutions and customers that buy and sell Treasury instruments. 
 Most analysts and market participants said the changes would have their most significant impact once traders were able to execute bids electronically, rather than using the current method in which runners drop slips of paper with bids at the Federal Reserve. A new computer system is being developed, and the Treasury Department urged today that it be expanded "to help increase the liquidity and depth of the market."
 
A Matter of Perception
 "There's been a perception that some insiders have enjoyed a competitive advantage," said Jerome H. Powell, an Assistant Treasury Secretary, in an interview today. "This is an attempt to level the playing field for the full range of participants."
The first test of whether the new rules will make a difference will come on Nov. 5, with the auction for three-year notes.
Under the changes, any registered broker will be able to bid competitively in the auctions on behalf of themselves or their customers. The bidders will not have to meet the existing requirement of posting a deposit in advance of the auctions, but they must sign a special agreement approved by a Federal Reserve Bank that authorizes charging the bidders' account at the Fed when the securities are issued.
Individuals have long been able to buy Treasury instruments directly from the Federal Reserve, but only at the average price and yield of all submitted bids and with a maximum of $1 million. Today's changes primarily open the market for the competitive bids. But in a concession to smaller banks, pension funds, municipalities and other institutional investors, the $1 million limit on noncompetitive bids was raised to $5 million.
The close relationship between the primary dealers and the Treasury Department had come under intense Congressional criticism in the wake of disclosures in August that Salomon Brothers, the most powerful dealer, had submitted phony bids and sought to corner the market.
In light of the scandal and calls for even more significant changes in the auction, reaction on Wall Street was generally either resigned or positive, and in many instances tempered by a curiosity about how it would work.
"The objective of increasing competition has got to be a good one," said Heather L. Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association, a trade group of banks and dealers, including the primary dealers, that trade government debt and other securities. "Whether it will work depends upon the details, which we have not seen, and how it will operate in practice."
 
A Critical Primary Dealer
 William Pike, head of government debt trading at Manufacturers Hanover Securities, one of the primary dealers, told the Bloomberg News Service that the changes "will not make any material difference."
Other analysts said today's steps were an important incremental step that might make a significant difference over the longer term, but were not likely to mean much in the near future because of the costs of hiring runners and setting up a system to participate in the auctions.
"This fits into the broader movement of eliminating the primary dealer system and gradually eroding their franchise," said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates. He said the new rules, combined with an automated system for bidding that would disclose prices and other information, would go much further toward ending the domination of the market by the primary dealers.
Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who heads a House subcommittee on securities regulation, said today that he would introduce legislation to give the Securities and Exchange Commission more authority to police the government securities market, "although Treasury is to be applauded for seeking to take some remedial steps in the auction process."
The Government Securities Act of 1986, the main law governing the market, expired at the beginning of this month and has not been extended, leaving in doubt the Treasury's authority to issue regulations. Today's action was done under the Liberty Bond Act of 1917, which authorizes the Treasury to set the auction rules.

HEADLINE: Court Says Holders' States May Bar Charge-Card Fees

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
In a victory for holders of bank credit cards, a Federal court in Boston has ruled that banks issuing cards may not charge fees to customers in states that prohibit such fees, even if the fees are allowed under the laws of the state where the bank is based.
States vary widely in the amount of fees they allow card issuers to charge for late payments, annual renewals and bounced checks. Bankers worry that the court ruling, if not overturned, will require them to adjust their prices for each state, or perhaps charge higher interest rates to compensate for fees they would no longer be allowed to collect. 
 In 1978 the Supreme Court ruled that the interest rate banks charge on credit cards could be based on the maximum allowed in the bank's home state, even if that rate exceeded limits set in other states.
 
Delaware vs. Massachusetts

The ruling this week by Judge William G. Young of the United States District Court was issued in response to a suit filed in November 1989 by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts against the Greenwood Trust Company, a Delaware-based affiliate of Sears, Roebuck & Company. Greenwood issues Sears's Discover card, a credit card similar to Visa and Mastercard. It was charging Massachusetts residents a $10 monthly fee for late payments, as allowed by Delaware. Massachusetts law does not permit late charges.
The Massachusetts Attorney General, Scott Harshbarger, said the ruling would have "major positive consumer protection implications for people throughout the country."
Beth Metzler, a spokeswoman for Greenwood Trust, said an appeal of the decision was planned. While the ruling applies only to Massachusetts, it could be cited as precedent anywhere in the country. Discover has issued 39.1 million cards, which have outstanding balances totaling more than $12.1 billion.
Greenwood Trust argued that fees, along with the interest rate on unpaid balances, are part of the overall price of a card, and that the meaning of earlier court rulings was that the overall price was controlled by a bank's home state, not the state where its customers live.
"The Supreme Court has clearly recognized the relationship between interest rates and fees," said John L. Culhane Jr., a lawyer at Wolf, Block, Schorr & Solis-Cohen, a Philadelphia law firm that represented the Consumer Bankers Association. He noted that in a case involving the Marquette National Bank of Minnesota, the Supreme Court said that Minnesota law allowed annual fees "to compensate for the reduced interest" allowed by state law at the time.
No Comment From Citibank
Susan Weeks, a spokeswoman for Citibank, which has issued more credit cards than any other bank, said the bank was watching the case closely but would not comment on it. Citibank has one schedule of charges and fees for credit card customers across the country, regardless of state laws.
Citibank issues its cards from South Dakota, a state that, like Delaware, has attracted many bank credit card operations because of laws allowing them to charge a variety of fees and an interest rate that now stands at 19.8 percent for most large banks.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The Government announced that auctions of Treasury securities would be open to all brokers rather than just Wall Street's largest banks and investment houses. The move came in response to the trading scandal at Salomon Brothers. [Page 33.] 
 Investor-owned psychiatric hospitals are suffering financially, raising doubts that medical entrepreneurs could fulfill needs for patient care more efficiently than traditional institutions. [33.]
President Bush was obviously annoyed at Edward M. Rogers Jr., a former aide to John H. Sununu, who has agreed to represent a Saudi Arabian sheik linked to B.C.C.I. [33.] The C.I.A. admitted it failed to tell the Fed what it knew about B.C.C.I. [34.]
Banks issuing cards may not charge fees to customers in states that prohibit such fees, a Federal court in Boston has ruled, even if fees are allowed under the laws of the bank's home state. [37.]
 
 Companies
McDonnell Douglas said it would start taking airline orders for a proposed jumbo jet to be built with Asian partners that would be likely to get a stake in the American aerospace industry. [33.]
Compaq Computer's board ousted the company's president and chief executive, Joseph (Rod) Canion, one day after Compaq reported its first loss since the company started in 1982. [33.]
Three trustees were named to preside over the liquidation of Drexel Burnham Lambert. They include Robert P. Rittereiser, a former president of E. F. Hutton. A filing showed Drexel would have an estimated net deficit of $841 million next February. [33.]
Sears, Roebuck moved to make its corporate governance appear more responsive to shareholders, but experts were divided on wehther investors would indeed have a greater say. [35.]
New York City's tabloid war is hotter than ever, according to circulation figures. The Daily News has regained about half the circulation it lost in last year's devastating strike, and The New York Post and New York Newsday have kept some gains. [1.]
Avon Products reported a $27.3 million loss for the third quarter after a $75 million charge for discontinued operations, but said it expected good 1991 income from continuing operations. [35.]
Aetna Life and Casualty said its profit jumped 30 percent to $115.3 million, despite considerable losses from Hurricane Bob and an anemic real estate market. [35.]
F.D.A. approval for a new drug to treat migraine headaches was recommended. It is made by Britain's Glaxo Holdings. [20.]
ARCO Alaska Inc. said it had discovered oil in an exploratory well 32 miles west of Anchorage in Cook Inlet. [35.]
 
 Markets
Blue-chip stock prices fell, then recovered slightly in late trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 3,004.92, down 11.40 for the day and 72.23 for the week. [36.]
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in slow trading. The yield on 30-year bonds of 2021 rose to 8.04 percent. [36.]
Oil prices fell, wrapping up a week that broke the back of an extended rally. Crude oil for delivery in December settled at $23.12 a barrel, down 37 cents. [42.] The dollar was little changed, and gold prices fell in New York after rising overseas. [42.]
 
 International
I.M.F. approval appeared likely for a $2.2 billion loan to India, which has made broad efforts at economic reform. [37.]
 
 Today's Columns
A time-honored way parents have helped their children get off on a sound financial footing, co-signing loans, has been deemed a taxable gift by the I.R.S. in a recent ruling. Your Money. [34.]
The Educational Testing Service has developed a computerized examination system using probability theory to pass or flunk people, based on as few as two dozen questions. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Odessa Journal;
They Laugh Now, but Then Didn't They Always?

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ODESSA, U.S.S.R.

 BODY:
In all the rush to claim "sovereignty," nobody has really spelled out what that means in the Soviet context. But whatever it is, the people of Odessa, in the Ukraine, are certain they have it.
They have the Black Sea, its beaches and ports glittering down below the grand Primorsky Boulevard. They have a worldly history as the third major city of the Russian Empire. They have their elegant sycamore-lined avenues, their rich literature, an abundance of local food and drink and a sharp tongue that even 70 years of homogenizing Soviet dreariness failed to dull. 
 "Is it possible for the Communist Party apparat to go underground?" asks the satirical weekly Akh, Odessa. "It's possible, but only in such an underground that has smoked salmon, caviar, Posolsky vodka, American cigarettes and other materials of the 28th Party Congress."
 
Funeral and Parrot Jokes
 Or did you hear the one about two old Odessites watching the funeral of a third?
"What did he die of, cancer?"
"No."
"Or perhaps it was a heart attack?"
"No, no. He just caught cold and died."
"Oh, thank God. I thought it was something serious."
Whatever the conversation, somebody will invariably recall an anecdote. This, after all, is the city where Jewish humor flourished in those prewar times when Jews were half the population.
"Hello, K.G.B.? This is Rabinovich. Have you found my parrot? Well, if you do, I just want you to know I categorically disagree with him."
Odessa produced the premier satirists of the early Soviet era, Ilf and Petrov, and the premier satirist of perestroika, Mikhail Zhvanetsky. At City Hall, instead of souvenir pins, Mayor Valentin K. Simonenko hands out Odessan funny money ("One Yeltsin") and an Odessan passport.
Former construction boss, former Communist and ardent Odessite, Mr. Simonenko is convinced that with its port, its tradition and its very psychology, Odessa is eminently ready to prosper under a market economy, if only it is left to its own devices.
"Odessites are genetically international," he boomed, maneuvering a Winston from one corner of his mouth to the other and ticking off the Russians, Jews, Greeks, Bulgars, Turks, Bessarabians, Ukrainians and many others who shaped the singular Odessan type.
The worldliness came with the foundations. Founded almost 200 years ago by Catherine the Great on the site of a former Turkish fort, the city was named after the ancient Greek colony of Odessos and had as its most influential founding father the Duc de Richelieu, future Prime Minister of France. Odessites still address women as "madame."
In the Soviet scheme of things, however, Odessa was assigned to the Ukraine. Under Communist rule that did not really mean much, because real authority was always in Moscow. But now that the Ukraine has declared its independence and is aggressively affirming its nationhood, many Odessites -- the vast majority of whom speak Russian -- wonder whether they're in the right republic.
The question is inherent in a campaign to restore a statue of Catherine the Great -- which was replaced by the Bolsheviks first with a bust of Karl Marx, which subsequently blew over in a gale, and then with a memorial to the battleship Potemkin, an icon of the 1905 Revolution. The fledgling International Business Club of Odessa has published ads asking anyone who knows where the statue of our "god grandmother" is.
The statue would confirm the Russian heritage of the city, and the Ukrainian authorities have shown little enthusiasm for it.
The problem is not limited to Odessa. The Crimean peninsula and some other regions now in the Ukraine should arguably be in Russia, and many other republic borders across the Soviet Union could be questioned.
But the very suggestion by Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, immediately after the unsuccessful hard-line coup in August, that Russia may want to reconsider some of its borders raised such a furor that republic leaders subsequently agreed to leave their borders as they are.
That has not fully put the issue to rest. Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, for one, proposed in a letter to Trud recently that every oblast, or county, in the Ukraine should be allowed to decide for itself in a referendum on Dec. 1 what republic it wants to be in.
Mayor Simonenko insists that he is not looking to get Odessa out of the Ukraine. His campaign, rather, is to create a "free economic zone" around a free port in the city, where conditions would be created for foreign investment and private business.
The Mayor has argued that the Ukraine would be a major beneficiary of the rapid economic development of the port. But he acknowledges that the plan has run up against some resistance in Kiev.
"Among some it rouses political suspiciousness, among others jealousy, among others indecision," he said.
The latter has been particularly noticeable in the Ukraine in anticipation of presidential elections on Dec. 1. With the republic sharply divided on virtually every issue, every candidate -- including Leonid M. Kravchuk, the Parliament President -- has ardently worked to bolster his image as a true Ukrainian.
Mr. Simonenko avoided overt criticism of the new Ukraine, but left little doubt of his feelings about Odessa. "What do I have in common with Lvov? With Kharkov? With Kiev? This," he declared, sticking his thumb through his fist in a Russian gesture of disdain.
In any case, whatever comes of his campaign, Odessa is not likely to be defined by being in the Ukraine any more than it was Russian under the czars or Soviet under the Bolsheviks.
Two women haggle at the legendary Privoz market over some fish.
"Your fish, they don't look fresh."
"Fresh? Why they're not even dead; they're only asleep."
"Then why do they stink?"
"And can you vouch for how you smell when you sleep?"

HEADLINE: The Middle East Talks;
Spain Is a Willing Host to Mideast Talks

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Delighted to be at the center of world attention, Spain seems more than happy to exchange the inconveniences of extensive security measures and huge traffic jams for the honor of serving as host of next week's long-awaited Middle East peace conference.
While Spain's direct role will be limited to a speech by Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez welcoming delegates to the conference hall in the 18th-century Royal Palace on Wednesday, the Government will be responsible for handling organizational aspects of the meeting and, above all, insuring the safety of those attending it. 
 As part of a security plan called Operation Pax, 12,000 police and paramilitary Civil Guards are being mobilized to protect sites including the palace, Barajas airport, embassies, hotels, airline offices, a press center and key roads. About 7,000 people, including journalists, are coming to Madrid for the meeting.
The most obvious security threat is posed by Basque separatist guerrillas who in recent days have exploded four bombs here and killed two civil guards in San Sebastian. The police have also stepped up their monitoring of Arab residents suspected of links to radical Islamic groups.
 
Coordinating Security
 A Government spokeswoman, Rosa Conde, said the Spanish authorities were working closely with security agencies from the United States and Soviet Union, which are responsible for security inside the palace itself.
The palace, situated on the western edge of the city and flanked on three sides by gardens, normally serves as a tourist attraction that features a collection of old clocks and tapestries. The conference itself will be held in the Hall of Columns, which is distinguished by a high-domed ceiling.
On Tuesday, a meeting is scheduled between Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who will be staying in their countries' ambassadorial residences. In the evening, they will be guests of King Juan Carlos at a private dinner including Prime Minister Gonzalez.
The selection of Madrid as the venue for the talks last week came as a surprise, since Lausanne, Switzerland, had been mentioned as the most likely site. Government officials here conceded that the Spanish capital might not have been everyone's first choice. "But nobody vetoed us," one senior Foreign Ministry official said. "That's the secret."
 
Good Relations on All Sides
 Although it remains unclear why Madrid was chosen, all sides involved in the talks have relatively close ties with Spain, which has excellent relations with Washington. In the Persian Gulf war, one-third of all American air traffic heading for the gulf passed through Spanish bases, while American B-52 bombers flew about 300 missions from a base at Moron de la Frontera in the south. Mr. Gonzalez was also an early supporter of President Gorbachev's efforts to bring political and economic change to the Soviet Union. More recently, Spain has urged its partners in the 12-nation European Community to step up emergency aid for Moscow.
No less important, despite joining the anti-Iraq alliance in the gulf war, Spain has maintained good ties with all the Arab parties -- Egypt, Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and the Palestinians -- that are taking part in the peace conference. And Madrid has rebuilt bruised relations with its North African Arab neighbors.
Further, the Palestine Liberation Organization was allowed to station a representative in Madrid in 1977 and has had a more formal mission here since 1986, with four officials who enjoy diplomatic status. Spanish newspapers have reported that the P.L.O. pressed for the peace talks to be held here.
 
Israeli Envoy Is Popular
 While it was not until January 1986 that Spain established full diplomatic relations with Israel, relations between the two countries are good, with the Israeli Ambassador, Shlomo Ben-Ami, considered one of the most popular and effective of foreign diplomats assigned here.
"This highlights the degree to which our foreign policy is accepted and, specifically, our policy toward the Near East," Spain's Foreign Minister, Francisco Fernandez-Ordonez said after the choice of Madrid was announced. "I won't hide the fact that I am delighted."
Some Spanish commentators have suggested that the decision also reflects Spain's historical links to Arabs and Jews. But in reality what the two groups have in common is that both were expelled from Spain in 1492, the Arabs when the fall of their last stronghold, Granada, ended their 700-year presence on the Iberian Peninsula, and the Jews when the Spanish Crown gave them the choice of leaving or converting to Christianity.
With the Spanish Government now welcoming the return of some Sephardic Jews from North Africa, the Jewish community in Spain has risen to about 15,000. The Arab population in Spain, though, is growing much faster because of a wave of illegal immigrants from Morocco and is now estimated at 150,000 to 200,000.

HEADLINE: Bush News Conference On Civil Rights Accord

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from today's news conference by President Bush as transcribed by Reuters.
 
 
 
OPENING STATEMENT
 After extraordinary debate and negotiation, we have reached an agreement with Senate Republican and Democratic leaders on a civil rights bill that will be a source of pride for all Americans. It does not resort to quotas, and it strengthens the cause of equality in the work place. Both the Administration and the Congress can present this legislation to the people of America as a new standard against discrimination and for equal opportunity. 
 This agreement was reached last night in marathon negotiations, shepherded by Senator John [C.]Danforth of Missouri, nurtured by Senator [Bob]Dole and other leaders of both parties.
It was a proud accomplishment for the Congress and the Administration. And now we can go forward together in progress on civil rights in this country.
I remember standing out there in the Rose Garden with Attorney General [Dick] Thornburgh more than a year and a half ago to make an unshakable commitment to the nation's civil rights leaders that I wanted a non-quota civil rights bill that I could sign. And assuming there are no changes in the bill as agreed to last night, we now have such a bill. And my promise will be kept, and I will enthusiastically sign this bill.
Another subject, on the Middle East peace conference, I want to note the historic nature of this meeting. The Middle East has been characterized by dangerous and tragic conflict for decades. The peoples of this region still have enormous differences.
But I want to commend the statesmanship of the leaders of all those parties attending the peace conference. Sitting down together is the beginning of understanding. And we cannot know the outcome of course. It will take patience and determination. The United States cannot make peace in the Middle East, only the parties themselves can do that. But we can and will be committed and an active partner in the search for peace.
Secretary Baker [Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d] has been patient, he's been steadfast. He's tirelessly disciplined in working with the Soviet Union and all the parties in the region to make this conference and the promise of peace a reality. We owe him a major debt of thanks. I also go to Madrid to meet with President Gorbachev, and I know that President Gorbachev joins me in wanting to put the hopes and aspirations of all the world behind these new opportunities for peace.
 
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Mr. President . . . millions are out of work and it seems almost daily statistics are pouring in [inaudible]. Aren't signs clear that some kind of action is needed, and what would you tell the Americans you will do?
A. I don't want to buy into the predicate about another recession. I don't feel that way. The economy has been sluggish. It hasn't been near as good as I would like to see it, or certainly the American people would like to see it.
What would I like to do about it? I'd like to see the Congress take the action that I've proposed way back starting in '89 and have continued to propose on growth. We need some stimulation to economic growth. And I think everybody is now familiar with the fact that I think capital gains cut would stimulate growth, and create jobs, and create opportunity. And we get assailed as this is a tax break for the rich.
I'd like to propose to Congress: let's try it, and I'll take all the blame on the political side, and then give me only half the credit on what good that would do for the economy. We've also had a program that includes enhanced R. and D. We've got banking reform legislation that would clearly be stimulative in terms of loaning. It's hung up in the capital.
We've put forward a program related to IRA's. We got a transportation bill that is job-intensive. We put forward for the most heavily adversely affected areas enterprise zones. Now there's a good six-point growth package for you, and the Congress has refused to do one single thing about it. And I don't think there is one person out across this country that is in doubt that we are for these things.
Q. May I give you an outline, a scenario of may have happened on the civil rights bill in the last couple of days and you tell me what's wrong with it? Wednesday afternoon you had some Republican senators over here and you and Boyden Gray [C. Boyden Gray, the White House counsel] passed out a piece of paper stating some objections to Senator Danforth's bill. These Republican senators went back to the Hill, some conservatives who normally would want to side with you, and they found out that the White House had misrepresented Senator Danforth's bill. They went ballistic and said you could no longer hold the line with 34 votes against veto if the civil rights bill is sustained, and at that point you decided you had to compromise and you basically caved.
A. It's wrong. It's just wrong, that's all. Next question. I said it's wrong. We didn't cave. We worked out, in the spirit of compromise, a negotiated settlement where I can say to the American people, this is not a quota bill. There was give and take on a lot of issues and you're just putting a political spin on it that is 100 percent wrong.
 
 
Cap on Damages
 Q. The civil rights bill that you do have caps damages in sex discrimination cases but not in cases of racial discrimination. Understanding that this is the first time any monetary damages have been allowed for sex discrimination cases, nonetheless how do you justify that to women who may see it as an indication that sexual discrimination cases just aren't taken as seriously as racial discrimination?
A. I just would try to dispel that notion and say look, the main thing is to get a civil rights bill that hits against sex harassment and hits against discrimination in the workplace. So that's the way I'd answer it. And this is the first. This is an historic first. Let me refer you to the lawyers.
Q. Mr. President, when you signed the budget agreement with Congress, the economy was not known to be in a recession. The Soviet Union had not collapsed, therefore you had not ordered a cutback in the nation's nuclear arsenal and estimates hadn't come out that the U.S. could live with a much smaller defense force.
Why not revisit the budget agreement in light of all this, and in light of the fact that the budget deficit is going to be higher than the agreement called for anyway?
A. I will not revisit it because I want -- it's the only cap we have on outrageous Congressional spending. It's the only way you control the excesses of spending. It is the only guarantee that the taxpayer has that his interests to some degree will be protected. And if you revisit it in the sense of removing these constraints, the spending gates would open. We've already seen it on some legislation. The unemployment benefits is a good recent example. Don't worry about budget deficits, don't worry about those people that are paying the taxes, just throw on some more spending.
 
The Thomas Hearing
 Q. Can I just ask: Did you think she [Prof. Anita F. Hill] was treated fairly?
A. I think -- I don't want to accuse . . . [Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware] of not running a fair hearing. . . . I've said in the very beginning I thought that he did a good job on that, and so please don't try to draw me into what was fair or not. Some people were disappointed in the results. They might not think it was fair. I was pleased with the results because I think the American people's confidence in this judge . . . has been proved to be correct.
Q. Some people sort of think that the message from the Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas hearing, that the message to women is don't bother to come forward on sexual harassment because you won't be believed. Sir, do you believe that is the message, or would you tell the American women that they should come forward?
A. I say they should come forward, but let's do it in a climate so that people are not destroyed in the process, and that's why I'm saying let's do it behind closed doors, or let's have procedures that you don't leak information that Anita Hill gave, that she asked be confidential, and then somebody goes out and insidiously leaks it, and she's drawn into a public debacle that she didn't want in the first place.
Yes, I'm concerned about that, and her feelings and everything else related to it, and I've made proposals that I think would help, including the way we handle F.B.I. reports.
So when people can't come forward for fear of their character being damaged and being dragged through the mud, of course I worry about it, and that's why I styled some proposals yesterday that I think will help address the problem.
And why can't we facilitate the process by guaranteeing as best we can against insidious leaks that damage people the minute the door opens?
And so I've made some proposals on that and yes, I'm concerned. But I don't want to end on a downer note here. I want to end by saying I can't tell you how pleased I am about this civil rights vote.
I have taken, you know, some people have said well, the President may not really want a civil rights bill, he wants an issue of some sort. My political opponents charging that over and over again.
And the fact now that we have a good, strong, reasonable civil rights bill, I think it's good for the American people. I think it transcends party politics. And I salute Bob Dole and Jack Danforth on our side and others on the Democratic side who've been willing to work in a constructive fashion -- ups and downs in the negotiating process, charge and countercharge. But today we have a good civil rights bill and I'd like to ask the Senate to promptly pass it without change and I'd like to ask the House to accede to it, and let's do something that's good and upright in the field of civil rights for the American people.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: Running or Not, Cuomo Steps Up Sallies at Bush

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo may not be a candidate for President, but he has a stump speech. In recent weeks, the Governor has honed a blistering critique of the Bush Administration's domestic policy by weaving fragments of old speeches and new thoughts into an unforgiving attack.
By focusing attention on his state's growing budget problems, Mr. Cuomo has convinced many of his closest aides and advisers that he will choose not to run in 1992. But by delivering speeches that blame the state's problems on the Federal Government, the Governor has also kept alive a local rationale for running: that he can do more for New York from Washington than from Albany. 
 The heart of Mr. Cuomo's message is that the recession is not the product of "cyclical economic gods," but of 10 years of misdirected Federal leadership. Rather than waiting for the economy to right itself, Mr. Cuomo urges stimulating long-term growth.
With the exception of his plan for a net investment tax credit, which would encourage investment in machinery and other production tools, Mr. Cuomo has offered few specifics. After telling a meeting of radio and television news directors in Manhattan yesterday that Congress should make cuts in both defense and entitlement programs, he declined to suggest a single entitlement program that should be pared.
 
'The Greed, the Stupidity'
 But the Governor was unrelenting in explaining the problems Republicans have created.
"It's not just some temporary cycle," he said in a speech yesterday at the meeting of the Radio-Television News Directors Association at the New York Hilton. "It is a dramatic response to the greed, the stupidity, the shortsightedness, the super-consumption attitude of the 80's."
He issued a five-page statement in Albany that made many of the same points.
Mr. Cuomo continued to insist yesterday that his message was more important than its messenger, and that any willing Democratic candidate could deliver it convincingly. He declined again to announce whether he would be a candidate.
 
'Stan, You're a Terrific Guy'
 The Governor stressed repeatedly that his primary problem concerns whether he can abandon the state to run for national office, leaving Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine to cope with a large midyear budget gap.
"Do you announce, 'Okay, now that I've told you how bad things are, I want you to know I'm leaving for New Hampshire?' " he asked. " 'But have a good time. And Stan, you're a terrific guy. Are you in shape Stan? Are you ready? See you. I'm going to Iowa and New Hampshire to tell people to save the country.' "
He later said he could imagine the fun that Roger Ailes, the Republican political consultant, would have with the Governor's abandoning the state.
Mr. Cuomo ridiculed the Republican notion, which began with the Reagan Administration and has continued in the Bush years, that supply-side economics is the answer.
"It was the easy answer to everything," he said yesterday. "It was narcotic: What a great world this is. We'll be the strongest people in the world. We won't have to pay for it. And our budget will balance.
"We got conned because we were tired," he said, "we were tired of ineffectuality. We were hungry, we were stupid, we were short sighted. And here we are. They were wrong by $3 trillion."
Mr. Cuomo's message is that of the angry outsider, and it is likely to generate a Republican response that he is a doom-and-gloom Democrat. But the Governor says that he has been speaking the truth, and that the durability of the recession is leading Americans to wake up to his warnings. Nonetheless, he acknowledges that his message may be a hard sell politically.
"If you go to the American people and just con them, you might be able to win -- a Democrat might be able to win -- because President Bush is not going to get more popular," he said yesterday. "The truth is going to be very tough. Maybe you can't win with it. I don't know, because I'm not a candidate."

HEADLINE: NATO, Victim of Success, Searches for New Strategy

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The NATO alliance won the cold war, but it is not yet clear how it will survive the victory.
The corridors of the sprawling headquarters building here are bustling with urgency these days, with 4,000 military officers and diplomats all trying to put the finishing touches on a sweeping new strategy in time for a meeting of the alliance's 16 leaders in Rome on Nov. 7 and 8. 
 What will not be on the agenda, but is on practically everybody's lips in private conversation here, is a crucial question: How much longer will the United States continue to be the key to European security?
 
The U.S. Is Needed
 The answer the summit meeting will provide seems clear. The United States is needed, they will say, as long as there is uncertainty or instability in the former enemy camp -- the old Warsaw Pact, and the Soviet Union as it had been from Stalin's days until the era of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Indeed, the new strategy will de-emphasize the forward deployments, quick reaction times and "last resort" nuclear option the alliance needed to counter that now-vanished imminent threat, relying instead on longer warning times to transport arms and soldiers back in the unlikely event they are ever needed.
Though the leaders of the alliance are less certain about how to deal with the myriad other smaller nuisances that could confront them from the Balkans or outside of Europe, at the summit meeting they will reach out to their old adversaries. They will not offer the full membership and security guarantees sought by Czechoslovakia, for instance, but they will extend promises of cooperation and consultation on a whole range of security issues nonetheless.
But over the longer term, assuming that the eastern part of Europe stays on its present course, the bigger question is whether Western Europe will continue to feel the need for an American presence that it felt in the cold war.
The United States has reduced the number of troops in Europe from 320,000 at the end of the 1980's to 260,000 now and could continue down to 150,000, according to Gen. John R. Galvin, the American commander of NATO. And last month President Bush announced unilateral decisions to remove almost all American nuclear weapons from Europe, to encourage the Soviet Union to keep reducing its arsenal.
The alliance as a whole will soon have only about half the number of troops it had in standing armies only a few years ago, because the threat that mobilized them is gone.
 
'Risk Is in Uncertainty'
 "The classical threat has disappeared," Manfred Worner, NATO's Secretary General, said in an interview. "The risk is in uncertainty -- about the future political structure of the Soviet Union, the bad economic situation, and all its consequences, in a country which still has more than three million people under arms and tens of thousands of nuclear weapons."
"The Soviet Union, or even just Russia, is such an enormous land mass that it needs a geopolitical counterweight," he said. "I don't think that Europe alone can provide it."
But some Europeans, led by France, think that lessening their dependence on the Americans is either a good thing, or else an unavoidable necessity whether they like it or not. Others, like the British and the Germans, though less now than before unification, fear that weakening ties to the Americans could lead to catastrophe. But even some of them are beginning to worry that the Americans themselves do not really want to stay forever.
Lingering doubts about the reassurances that American officials try to give about United States staying power are among the factors shaping the debate not only about the future of NATO, but also about the nature of European unity.
 
European Meeting Set
 Decisions about European monetary union and the future of political and military cooperation among the present 12 members of the European Community are expected to be made at a European summit meeting in Maastricht, the Netherlands, six weeks from now, and one of the most difficult is how to shape the future defense of Europe, with or separately from the United States.
"With all the problems you have in the United States at home, how much will any American President after George Bush care about emphasizing the security role of the United States in Europe?" asked a diplomat from a NATO country that sees its interests as closely bound to the United States. But his was only one variation of the question. Governments in every country in Europe are asking themselves the same thing, their diplomats say.
Mr. Worner, a former West German Defense Minister, also expressed the concern, and alluded to some of its possible effects.
"The United States and Canada really contribute in a very substantial way to the stable political development of Europe," he said. "NATO enabled the process of European unification to go ahead at that speed. There is a substantial risk that if you took the U.S. away and broke our alliance, the nations of Western Europe could fall back into competing alliances and counteralliances."
 
New Force Proposed
 This has not happened yet, but some British and American officials thought it had almost begun to happen on Oct. 14, when President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany surprised most of their European Community partners by proposing a new European defense force, with an existing French-German brigade as the core.
The new force, their proposal said, could include soldiers of other countries that belong to the nine-nation Western European Union, a vestige of NATO's early days that was also at the heart of an earlier British-Italian proposal to strengthen NATO's European "pillar."
The difference between the two proposals was basically that in the French-German plan, the emphasis was on linking the Western European Union with European political union, and in the British-Italian plan, it was on strengthening the Western European Union's links with NATO.
German officials, somewhat embarrassed by all the fuss, now concede that the proposal to build a 35,000-member European force out of the existing two-nation brigade in southwest Germany was added as a footnote, apparently at Mr. Mitterrand's suggestion, to the rest of their paper on European defense. They insisted, and American officials agreed, that they had consulted extensively with the United States and Britain on everything else.
 
Shortcomings Noted
 Mr. Kohl was eager to give European union a lift before the December meeting in the Netherlands, an official close to him said. NATO's inability to agree on sending forces to the Persian Gulf in the war last winter, and Europe's military impotence in dealing with the civil war in Yugoslavia, showed everybody that something needed to be done. "This is not an attempt to replace a part of the Atlantic alliance's security guarantee with a European defense policy," he said.
Foreign ministers of the Western European Union are to meet in Bonn on Tuesday to try to marry the various proposals for European defense and come up with an approach that will be acceptable to everybody, including the United States, which has been calling for greater European defense contributions for decades. But diplomats from some member countries say the best thing to do would be to put the whole debate off for a few years.
Germany, Italy, Britain, France, Belgium, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain belong to the organization, which has a headquarters and small staff in London but may soon move to Brussels.
Some skeptical American and British diplomats said there were fears that Mr. Mitterrand's hidden goal in pushing the new European force was quietly to push the United States out of European defense. French forces have not been integrated in the NATO command for nearly 20 years, and European strategic independence from the United States has been a cherished French goal for years. It was inconceivable, Mr. Mitterrand told a French radio audience on Tuesday, that the United States would always stand ready in the front lines of European defense.
NATO officials say the summit meeting in Rome next month will approve a new statement of alliance strategy that makes that commitment credible -- a new charter that clearly states why the alliance is still necessary, and explicitly addresses the changes in the East.
"We are moving clearly in the direction of institutional consultation and more concrete cooperation," Mr. Worner said, and regular meetings with the representatives the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries have accredited to NATO are expected to be part of that.
"The next step is that we agree on more concrete projects -- perhaps the conversion of defense industries, verification, even studies of migration problems," Mr. Worner said.
There seems to be little support for the idea of extending NATO's security guarantees to Hungary, Czechoslovakia or Poland after the withdrawal of Soviet troops. Diplomats from several NATO countries said the idea that attack against one member of the alliance would be regarded as an attack against all was difficult to apply to new geographical areas unless the basic charter of the alliance is changed.
And though it will continue to engage the Soviet Union and its increasingly independent republics in dialogue, NATO will not invite President Gorbachev to come to the summit meeting in Rome, though it would welcome him to the headquarters here before or later, several officials say.

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Decides Against Proposed Fare Increases on Most Commuter Lines

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
There will be no fare increases next year on the Long Island Rail Road and most of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority decided yesterday.
The decision will not affect a possible fare increase for New York City subways and buses. The present $1.15 fare could rise to $1.25 and perhaps even to $1.50, M.T.A. officials have said. A decision is expected in December. 
 The M.T.A. also gave final approval to a $65 million renovation at the north end of Grand Central Terminal that would create four new entrances along Park Avenue between 45th and 48th Streets. They are intended to reduce crowding at the terminal.
Both suburban lines had been preparing for fare increases averaging about 8 percent, and had scheduled hearings on the proposals for next month. But M.T.A. officials said on Monday that they had found new ways to close projected deficits for the railroads next year, making a fare increase unnecessary.
 
Concern Over Ridership Losses
 The M.T.A. board approved the plan unanimously yesterday. The board's chairman, Peter E. Stangl, said that with the lines' ridership declining because of the recession, he did not think it wise to raise fares and cause additional riders to stop using the railroads.
"At least this will hold our ridership, as best we can," Mr. Stangl said after the board meeting.
Connecticut commuters who use Metro-North's New Haven line still face an increase. The Connecticut Department of Transportation sets that fare, and it is planning an increase on Jan. 1. Connecticut officials have not yet determined the size of the increase, said Bill Keish, a spokesman for the State Transportation Department.
The Grand Central project was part of the M.T.A.'s five-year capital plan that expires at the end of the year. It had to be redesigned and scaled back when an additional $8 million in private financing did not materialize, Metro-North officials said. Construction is expected to begin in the fall of 1993.
Currently, passengers leaving Metro-North trains must walk south on the station platforms to the terminal's main concourse. About 40 percent of the passengers then head for offices north of Grand Central, usually by walking through the Pan Am Building, Metro-North officials said.
The new entrances would allow commuters to avoid such back-tracking, saving them as much as 10 minutes in walking time, railroad officials said. It would also eliminate bottlenecks in the flow of commuters in and out of the terminal and would reduce overcrowding on the narrow platforms, they said.
 
Future Deficits Still Looming
 Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road face a combined deficit for 1992 of $36 million. But Mr. Stangl and other M.T.A. officials decided that a fare increase could be prevented by two actions: saving about $17 million by refinancing bonds and obtaining another $19 million from unspecified administrative cuts.
The Transit Authority, which operates the city's subways and buses, confronts such a large projected 1992 deficit -- about $460 million -- that similar cost-reduction efforts could not prevent a fare increase, M.T.A. officials said.
They also said that the suburban commuter lines would benefit in 1992 from a one-time state commuter tax surplus of $90 million. The suburban railroads will face substantial projected deficits in 1993, in part because they will not get the $90 million surplus a second time and also because they will not have the revenues from the 8 percent fare increase that had been proposed for 1992.
By state law, the commuter surplus cannot be shared with the Transit Authority.
Several M.T.A. board members said yesterday that while they favored holding the line on the suburban fares, they also wanted the M.T.A. and the State Legislature to reconsider the distribution of subsidies from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which are now basically shared by the city and suburban mass-transit agencies.

HEADLINE: Oakland Struggles to Restore Hills, and Faith

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 25

 BODY:
For the second time in two years, the resilient citizens of Oakland are cleaning up their ruined neighborhoods, burying their dead and comparing themselves to latter-day Jobs.
The deadly one-two punch of earthquake and firestorm has driven home the lesson that rich and poor alike can be bowed by nature, since the 1989 quake devastated the city's poorest area and this week's roaring blaze devoured the lush hillsides where Oakland's wealthiest and most powerful lived. 
 Looking for a bright side to the calamity, city officials here noted that recovery would be easier this time because the vast majority of fire victims have insurance, bank accounts and the skill to deal with cumbersome bureaucracies.
Unlike the thousands of people who were forced by the quake from welfare hotels and dilapidated downtown buildings, the 5,000 people dispossessed by this fire do not need cots in Red Cross shelters, sandwiches from the Salvation Army or grants from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The Federal emergency office has yet to untangle the red tape and pay all the claims on damages suffered in the Bay Area's last disaster.
But the well-to-do fire victims do need help from the city: To have building permits issued quickly and without undue fuss, to control soil erosion and thus prevent mudslides and to restore roads and utilities in neighborhoods where nothing remains but white ash and blackened rubble.
If these residents are frustrated in their efforts to rebuild, local leaders note with trepidation, many may quit Oakland for other communities nearby, leaving this beleaguered city without the assets, leadership, energy and philanthropy of its racially integrated middle and upper classes.
"This is a watershed for the future of Oakland," said Don Perata, an Alameda County supervisor, whose district includes lower class precincts in the flatlands and professional enclaves in the hills. "If we lose this strata of the population, we will become, and I say this advisedly, another Newark, N.J. There will be no one left with the wherewithal to bridge the widening gulf between those who have and those who don't. And the great sociological experiment that is called Oakland will be over."
A more optimistic spin is put on the situation by Edward J. Blakely, the chairman of the city planning department at the University of California at Berkeley and one of many blacks who lives in a neighborhood in the Oakland hills that survived the fire.
Mr. Blakely said that many hill-dwellers who are not usually dependent on services like public assistance, transportation and health will suddenly have a personal stake in local government and that their involvement will make "the city run better for everyone."
As Mr. Perata and Mr. Blakely considered the future, search teams, fire officials and engineers continued searching for bodies, counting ruined houses and shoring up 1,800 acres of bare hillside against the rain that fell tonight, raising the threat of mudslides. At last count 24 people were known dead and 13 missing, and officials said more than 3,000 houses and apartments were destroyed.
 
A Misunderstood City
 This disaster has drawn attention to a part of Oakland that few outsiders were aware of: a band of gracious residential neighborhoods high in the hills that were home to professionals, civic leaders, academics and artists.
More often this misunderstood city of 372,000 is viewed merely as San Francisco's ugly stepsister and a caldron of poverty and violence. That image is so rooted in the national imagination that television coverage of the fire on Sunday described it as occurring in the hills "above" Oakland, as if these fine homes with their valuable art collections and libraries of first editions could not be part of a city that is best known for crack and crime.
But what makes Oakland special for the people who live here is just that diversity, a much-overused word these days, but a reality in a city that sociologists have characterized as America's most integrated, not only in its neighborhoods but also in its halls of power.
The divisions here are economic, not racial. The poor, most of them black, are concentrated in the housing projects and tumbledown Victorian houses in the flatlands, near the collapsed highway that claimed 42 lives in the earthquake. The middle-class and the rich have settled on the hillsides, where professional people, white and black alike, live peaceably side by side, enjoying wide vistas of San Francisco Bay and flowers that bloom year-round. Many hill-dwellers are children of the flatlands, and their move up is a true expression of the American dream.
 
Lovely Streets, Now Gone
 It is these lovely hillside neighborhoods that no longer exist, turned into charred craters by a raging inferno that, at 2,000 degrees, was nearly as hot as a crematory. Gone are the homes of a state senator, a county supervisor, a city councilwoman and a municipal court judge. Gone are the homes of star baseball players, best-selling novelists and television newscasters. Gone are the homes of corporate executives, doctors, lawyers and professors.
But there was virtually no gloating in the hardscrabble flatlands when these homes of privilege burned. A few people on the mean streets of West Oakland, near the fallen freeway, were heard to comment that nature, at least, was fair. A few others noted wryly that Chez Panisse, the bastion of California cuisine, sent sandwiches to evacuation centers in this disaster, while the quake victims here got Salvation Army grub.
But far more common were extraordinary acts of kindness and expressions of concern. Oakland's poor were among the first to volunteer to help fight the fires and work in evacuation centers. At Jubilee West, a community development organization in West Oakland, thrift-shop clothing donated by a well-to-do parish in the hills will be donated back to the original owners.
"We're sorry, sorry as can be," said Ralph S. Williams Sr., a retired truck driver and a community leader in West Oakland. "They're rich, they're powerful and yet they're helpless, just like us."
After the earthquake, the kindness flowed downhill not up, much of it in the form of donations to relief efforts. And in ordinary times, as well, the people of the hills have looked for ways to help their less fortunate neighbors, by serving on the boards of charitable foundations and community development organizations, by doing pro bono legal work and volunteering in medical clinics, by contributing ideas and supplies to a struggling school system.
"Many of the people up there are as committed to the poor of Oakland and their children as any flatland activist," Mr. Perata said.
It is this sort of synergy that Mr. Perata and others fear will be lost in the wake of the great fire if too many hill residents move rather than rebuild, either because of bureaucratic hassles, fear of remaining in such a fragile landscape or convenience.
That may be happening already among those who lost their homes and have found places to rent while they figure out what to do next.
Peter Persoff, for instance, a scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory at the University of California, has moved his family into a rented house in Lafayette, a suburb on the eastern slope of the charred hills. And Warren Widener, a member of the Alameda County Board of Supervisors, is renting just a few miles north of his ruined Oakland home, but on the other side of the Berkeley border.
The ability to grab a rental house, however overpriced, is one of the clearest advantages that the rich have over the poor. Many of the dispossessed here have enough money in the bank or a credit rating that is good enough to allow them to move and to replace their lost belongings, even before an insurance claim is settled.
 
Many Have Options
 Others have already received advances from their insurance companies to cover costs. Mr. Widener, for instance, saw his insurance agent for the first time yesterday and was handed a check for $25,000 on the spot.
Virtually nobody who was burned out here needed to sleep in the Red Cross centers that opened on Sunday night and closed a few days later for lack of need. Many people are staying with friends who have rambling houses with room to spare. Others are in hotels, where one man noted that he and hundreds of others had "evacuated by using credit cards."
Another advantage is the ability to find the right agencies, pull the right strings and get their needs met. Victoria Larson, a graphics designer, like so many of the fire victims, showed no self-pity as she set about rebuilding a life for herself, her husband, a landscape architect, and their 2-year-old daughter.
"We don't deserve that much sympathy," she said. "We have so many resources. I guess it's lucky for everybody that it happened to us."

HEADLINE: Bush Selects An Opponent

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25

 BODY:
President Bush's seemingly contradictory actions of the last 48 hours -- first assailing Congress as "a privileged class of rulers" answerable to no one, then closing a deal with Congress on a new civil rights bill -- were aimed at dampening the volatile political consequences of racial divisiveness and de-emphasizing the stalled economy.
On race, the President clearly hopes he has found a path through the mine field by putting himself in a position to assert with some credibility that he is not the implacable foe of civil rights progress that some have accused him of being, while at the same time leaving himself room to assure white middle-class voters that he has protected them from the quotas they hate. 
 On the economy, he has begun to lay the groundwork for a 1992 Presidential campaign in which he apparently intends to argue that a self-indulgent, undisciplined Congress, not his own economic stewardship, is the nation's big problem.
Mr. Bush denied at his news conference this morning that he had caved in and changed his position on civil rights, but several Republican senators said he had decided to accept, with only relatively minor changes, a deal that had been available to him for weeks. He had dismissed every attempted compromise as "a quota bill"; today he hailed what he called "a non-quota bill."
In fact, the issues had been so thoroughly beclouded that the distinction between quotas and non-quotas had become almost entirely subjective.
Although the White House is convinced that the President was the winner in the fight over the nomination of Judge Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, in the sense that most voters favored his confirmation and thought that Congress handled it badly, Republican political strategists have been worried about how women would vote next year.
Already unpopular with some women's groups because of his oppostion to abortion, Mr. Bush risked narrowing his potential support further among the influential minority of women angry about Republican attacks on Prof. Anita F. Hill, who accused Judge Thomas of sexual harassment. 
There were also problems in the President's party, starting with Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, who led the fight to confirm Judge Thomas but is also deeply committed to civil rights legislation. And there is a group of more pragmatic Republicans, eager to increase the trickle of blacks supporting their party, who have been worried in recent days about the success of State Representative David Duke of Louisiana, a former Ku Klux Klan leader who is seeking the governorship as a Republican, though the national party disavows him.
George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader in the Senate, used the Duke candidacy to score partisan points today, calling it "the inevitable consequence of the racial politics of the Reagan and Bush administrations."
Both sides said they got what they wanted in the civil rights bill, but Mr. Bush, with his bigger megaphone, could proclaim the achievement of "a new standard against discrimination" that would be set without giving way to affirmative action, and no one was in a position to effectively gainsay him. That is the great advantage of the Presidency: Senator Mitchell and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, may have gained most of the legal language they sought, but Mr. Bush gained the country's attention, at least for now.
By accepting a bill intended to help both women and blacks who are victims of discrimination, Mr. Bush escaped from a civil rights struggle he might not have been able to win. He had threatened to veto a bill not terribly different from the one he now promises to sign, but he found himself in some danger, according to the count of Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, of losing several of the 34 Senate votes he would have needed to sustain a veto.
It will be more difficult to still unrest over the economy, which is widely considered by Democrats and Republicans alike to be the issue most capable of derailing a Bush re-election.
The President said at his news conference that he was unwilling to reopen the budget agreement he negotiated last year with the Democratic leadership on Capitol Hill because doing so would produce "a windfall of new spending." But he was careful not to rule out some sort of compromise with the Democrats on economic stimulus for the economy, because he does not want to be labeled "the recession President" or "the unemployment President" by his foes.
 
An Anti-Washington Mood
 So where does the attack on Congress fit in? While he talks about a civil rights bill that "transcends party politics" and gropes for ways in which he can outflank the Democrats on the economy, Mr. Bush apparently believes that he can simultaneously make political hay out of a growing anti-Washington mood in the country. His aides say the country's ire focuses on Capitol Hill.
Playing on the disclosures that members of Congress have had insufficient-funds checks covered and left their restaurant bills unpaid, things that ordinary citizens cannot do, the President called on Congress to end the exemptions it has granted itself in laws covering diverse subjects like privacy, safety standards and wages.
There will be more of the same next year. John H. Mr. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said in an interview that Mr. Bush "will make it clear in the campaign that the problem in Washington is the Democratic Congressional leadership," taking a leaf from Harry S. Truman's textbook on how to run against Capitol Hill.
Evidently Mr. Bush hopes to funnel the frustration of voters who feel ill-served by Washington into votes against senators and representatives who cannot get the job done rather than votes against a President on whose watch a recession has developed and lingered.
If the economic indicators continue to look sour, that will be no small task, even for Mr. Bush, who retains his overall popularity, according to the polls, despite most voters' lack of confidence in his economic management.

HEADLINE: Just What Are You Worth? Figure It Out

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Where do I stand financially and where am I going? Those are good questions to ask as any year nears an end, particularly when the national economy is slow. A good way to find out is to draw up a statement of personal net worth.
An individual can do what all corporations do: list what is owned on one side of a sheet of paper and what is owed on the other. Net worth is what is left after subtracting liabilities from assets. 
 "I don't think people can properly plan unless they have some idea of what they're worth," said Herbert M. Paul, a New York lawyer and certified public accountant. "A net worth statement pulls it all together."
This is a situation where literal accuracy doesn't count. Reasonable approximations will present a "still picture" of your finances on a specific date. The end of a month or year is generally preferable.
"Just do the best you can and don't worry if you're off 10 or 15 percent," said David S. Rhine, a partner of BDO Seidman, a certified public accounting firm, in New York. "In getting 5 percent more accuracy, it may triple your preparation time. There's no perfect score, and there's no passing grade."
 
Pencil or Computer Will Do
 Net worth statements come in different sizes and shapes. You can use either a sheet of paper or a computer software program. The American Bankers Association has a form that banks give loan applicants. The Internal Revenue Service has a form to be completed with estate tax returns.
What are the elements of a net worth statement? On the asset side, cash and cash equivalents usually come first. Cash is not only what is in your pocket or purse, but also in bank accounts and certificates of deposit. Cash equivalents are investments of such high safety and convertibility -- like Treasury bills and money market funds -- that they are considered the same as cash.
Next on the asset side are investments: stocks, bonds, mutual funds and investment real estate like commercial buildings and undeveloped land.
The current market value of your home or homes -- whether a house, a cooperative or condominium apartment or a vacation cottage -- should also be included. List the full value, regardless of any mortgage or home equity loan.
Personal possessions are difficult to assess, but they should not be ignored. Valuables are often insured and therefore have an easily established worth. However, the depreciated value of furniture, furnishings and clothing should be estimated as conservatively as possible, because they probably could not be sold easily or quickly.
Finally, there are your remaining, or "other," assets. This is the place to list things like the cash value of your life insurance, loans to family or friends and your vested interest in a pension plan.
 
And Now for the Downside
 As for liabilities, the largest item for most people is the mortgage on a home. Other mortgages on personal and investment real estate are also listed in this section.
Another liability is installment loans on major purchases, like cars, appliances and contractors' services. Multiply your monthly payment by the number of payments remaining on the debt.
Accounts payable come next. These include amounts owed to credit card companies, stores, utilities, doctors and the like. And then there is the category of miscellaneous debts, which includes Federal, state and local taxes still due, loans outstanding on insurance policies and pledges to charities.
"If you have something left over after subtracting liabilities from assets, that's your net worth," said Randy Neumann, a financial planner in Paramus, N.J. "And you can use that figure to project your needs."
And if your arithmetic leaves you with nothing left over, it might be time to take drastic action before disaster strikes.

HEADLINE: Pearl Harbor and Asian-Americans

 BODY:
Franklin Roosevelt said Dec. 7, 1941, was "a date which will live in infamy," but he could not have imagined all the reasons. As many Americans prepare to observe the 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, other Americans note a rise in acts of anti-Asian bias and fear the observance will bring more. They have reason to be concerned.
In January 1990, a scuffle in a Korean-American grocery in Brooklyn resulted in a long and ugly boycott of all the Korean-owned stores in the neighborhood. Pickets handed out leaflets to discourage shopping "with people who do not look like us."
In Orange County, California, in June three Japanese women were assaulted in a bar because they were speaking Japanese. The attack reflected a sharp rise in anti-Asian incidents in southern California. 
 In July, 100 young Asian men in Revere, Mass., were rounded up by police and the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Why? Because of tension over the killing of a non-Asian, apparently by Asian youths.
There are many explanations for such bigotry. Japan's economic successes have engendered resentments that peak when, for example, Japanese interests buy movie companies or a piece of Rockefeller Center. Asians are the fastest-growing minority group in the U.S. and many people of surly sentiments do not distinguish between Asians and Asian-Americans.
But whatever the case, explanations are not reasons. Accepting cultural differences takes patient understanding even in ordinary times. The imminent anniversary creates a special need for public officials and citizens alike to remember Pearl Harbor -- and also what it was that America fought for.
