HEADLINE: Public & Private;
In Our Backyard

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
Whenever anyone comes up with a plan to house the homeless, the response is predictable: NIMBY! NIMBY! NIMBY! NIMBY! That's short for Not In My Backyard. It's become America's ruling acronym.
And so when Mayor David Dinkins announced a plan to put smaller shelters for single adults throughout New York City, high-pitched cries of "NIMBY!" rang out from Staten Island to Queens. The speaker of the City Council even likened homeless people to a contagious disease. He backtracked from his ill-chosen words, but the sentiment behind them was epidemic among politicians and the people they represent. No one actually mentioned putting homeless people on a barge and letting them float out to sea, but that kind of feeling was in the air. Either that, or making them all go to Manhattan and then closing the borders. 
 No wonder. If empty shelves became a symbol for the failure of Communism in the Soviet Union, people living in cardboard boxes are the most visible sign that America is on the skids. They are living, breathing symbols of an economy that, no matter what the Astigmatism President says, is a mess.
Soon there may be 1,000 men sleeping each night on cots in the armory in Washington Heights. There are sections for the mentally ill and those with TB. The predators range throughout, the people who steal from and torture the weak, the elderly, the handicapped.
Picture 1,000 men in a single room on cots, the dormitory from hell: the mutterers, the shouters, the sick all hacking away. Dickens could write it. We can't imagine it. They live it. And when they do not want to go there, when they prefer a suite on the A train, we call them crazy.
Someday some leader will admit that it is just the opposite, that only a lunatic would want to spend the night in the city's biggest shelters. The Mayor took a step in that direction by announcing that he was attempting to replace them with smaller facilities. That is half of a good idea. Smaller is better, but shelters are by definition substandard. Permanent housing is the answer, on the same sites now slated for shelters: why waste time or money on the interim step? The first answer to the problem of homelessness has always been housing, not cots. Soon the Washington Heights armory will celebrate its 10th anniversary as a shelter. I'm using the word celebrate loosely.
The Mayor would have to expend plenty of political capital to pull off a significant response to this problem. But if he is fated, as most people believe, to be a one-term Mayor, due to the deplorable state of everything from the Brooklyn Bridge to Harlem Hospital, he might as well go out in a blaze of glory. He could act like something we rarely see anymore: a Democrat. He could make sweeping changes in social policy not because they are politic, but because they are morally right.
And he could also teach people that NIMBY is a meaningless acronym. There is nary a neighborhood that doesn't have someone sleeping beneath the elevated tracks or in a corner of the playground. In fact, the obsession with our own backyard is the best way to sell housing for the homeless. See the little lady with the shopping cart? See the man urinating in the gutter? (I'm baffled by those who argue that this proves insanity; I wonder what they would do without bathrooms?) Those people you see every day: we are going to build those people a place to live.
Ellen Baxter, who has created five buildings to permanently house the homeless in Washington Heights, has coexisted pleasantly with her community because of this approach. Almost half her tenants came from the neighborhood, and with a room of their own many of them begin to heal. (And this happens fast; Ms. Baxter's latest project, an 82-unit rehab, was begun in February and will be finished in the next few weeks.) It is that happiest of initiatives, a project that benefits all while doing the right thing.
It has gone out of fashion, doing the right thing. And it used to be simpler. When Lyndon Johnson declared war on poverty more than a quarter-century ago, it had the flavor of foreign aid, a mission to a land we knew only from photographs, in the gullies of the Appalachians and the tenements of Harlem. Today that war is more difficult and less photogenic. Above all, it no longer has the safety of distance. It is right in our own backyard.

HEADLINE: Gene Roddenberry, 'Star Trek' Creator, Dies at 70

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Gene Roddenberry, the Hollywood writer and producer who created the 1960's science-fiction television series "Star Trek," which inspired six feature films, a sequel series in the 1980's and legions of space-age devotees known as Trekkies, died yesterday at Santa Monica Hospital Medical Center in California. He was 70 years old and lived in Los Angeles.
Mr. Roddenberry had been ill for about six weeks and died of a blood clot, said John Wentworth, a spokesman for Paramount Pictures. But Wendy Gullies, a spokeswoman for the hospital, said the cause of death was listed as cardiopulmonary arrest. 
 A tall, soft-spoken man with a silver mane and a dazzling imagination, Mr. Roddenberry was a much-decorated B-17 pilot in the Pacific in World War II, and later a pilot for Pan American World Airways, a speechwriter for the Los Angeles police chief, a writer for episodes of "Dragnet" and "Naked City," and head writer of the 1950's television series "Have Gun, Will Travel."
But with "Star Trek," which made its debut in 1966 and ran until 1969 on NBC, Mr. Roddenberry took a generation of viewers along on a journey into "space, the final frontier," aboard the Starship Enterprise, to "explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations, to boldly go where no man has gone before."
 
The Galaxies Beyond
 It was an idea that, in various permutations, consumed more than a third of Mr. Roddenberry's life and made believers out of the most skeptical critics. It gave American popular culture such futuristic hardware as "phaser guns" and "transporter beams," and a living-room window on worlds and aliens far beyond the reality of a bright new space age.
It introduced a cast of characters whose names became familiar to millions: the dashing commander, Captain Kirk (played by William Shatner); the omnisciently logical, pointy-eared Vulcan First Mate, Mr. Spock (Leonard Nimoy); Dr. McCoy (DeForest Kelley); Scotty, the chief engineer (James Doohan); Mr. Sulu (George Takei), and Lieutenant Uhura (Nichelle Nicols).
And it spawned a worldwide fascination that led to Trekkie conventions, products ranging from books and T-shirts to lunch boxes and toys, reruns of its 79 original episodes in 48 countries for more than a decade, a half-dozen feature films starting in 1979, and a sequel series, "Star Trek: The Next Generation," which had its premiere in 1987 and is still running, with audiences of more than 12 million households and numerous awards to its credit.
"Few ideas in the annals of motion picture and television history have inspired more passion and allegiance on the part of the audience than has 'Star Trek,' " said Brandon Tartikoff, chairman of Paramount Pictures, which made the "Star Trek" series for television and all the feature films.
For Mr. Roddenberry, the "Star Trek" phenomenon was more than entertainment, as he explained in an interview with The Los Angeles Times in May.
"It has become a crusade of mine to demonstrate that TV need not be violent to be exciting," he said. "I wanted to send a message to the television industry that excitement is not made of car chases. We stress humanity, and this is done at considerable cost. We can't have a lot of dramtics that other shows get away with -- promiscuity, greed, jealousy. None of those have a place in 'Star Trek.' "
 
From a B-17 to Starships
 Eugene Wesley Roddenberry was born in El Paso, Tex., on Aug. 19, 1921, and grew up in Los Angeles, where his father worked in law enforcement. He attended Los Angeles City College, the University of Miami and Columbia University, studying pre-law and aeronautical engineering.
He qualified for a pilot's license and flew a B-17 Flying Fortress in World War II on 89 missions, including Guadalcanal and Bougainville. He won the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal, among other decorations. While in the South Pacific, he began to write stories and poetry for magazines and newspapers.
After the war, he joined Pan Am as a pilot, and flew for four more years. From 1949 to 1953, he was a sergeant with the Los Angeles Police Department, working as a department spokesman and a speech writer for Chief William H. Parker. He also began writing for television, and from 1953 to 1962 wrote scripts for "The U.S. Steel Hour," "Goodyear Theater," "The Kaiser Aluminum Hour," "Four Star Theater," "Dragnet," "The Jane Wyman Theater" and "Naked City."
He won his first Emmy Award for "Have Gun, Will Travel," a western (starring Richard Boone as Paladin) that, according to some film and television critics, was a precursor of "Star Trek" in that its wit, characterizations and themes were only incidentally set in a particular time and place.
The original "Star Trek," Mr. Roddenberry told an interviewer a few years ago, was technically primitive but with high aims for adventure and in the way it portrayed people and their relationships.
"We had to explain computers," Mr. Roddenberry said. "And our effects were primitive. Our stars were a black cloth with holes in it and light behind. The episodes cost $186,000. They're $1.3 million for 'The Next Generation.' I wanted to cast a woman as second in command. NBC said no way."
Mr. Roddenberry, who said he always thought of himself as a storyteller, wrote not only the original shows, but also what he called a bible for later writers to follow. It detailed characters, the ship and its technology, the 23d century and the fantasy of deep space, in which they all traveled.
Some writers told him it was the hardest show in television to write for because they had to know so much about history, economics, moral values and the personalities of the running characters. There was formula in it, but the shows were hardly the standard television fare of car chases and grim faces.
Mr. Roddenberry was producer of the first "Star Trek" film, executive consultant on the next three and the executive producer of the sequel series.
Survivors include his wife, the former Majel Leigh Hudec, an actress who appeared in the two "Star Trek" television series under her stage name, Majel Barrett; a son, Eugene, known as Rod; two daughters, Darleen Incopero and Dawn Compton; a brother, Robert; a sister, Doris, and his mother, Carolyn Glen Roddenberry.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 28, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Saturday (reprinted from some Friday editions) about Gene Roddenberry, the creator of the "Star Trek" television series, misstated the day of his death. He died on Thursday.

HEADLINE: In New York City's Tabloid War, The Combat Is Closer and Fiercer

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
A year after the start of a devastating strike that nearly killed The Daily News, New York City's tabloid war is more competitive than ever, new circulation figures show.
The figures indicate that The Daily News has regained about half the circulation it lost during the strike, which ended in March. 
 The New York Post and New York Newsday have kept a significant chunk of the circulation they gained at The News's expense, but they also saw what appeared to be huge gains slowly dissolve as many readers returned to The News. The New York Times's circulation was not significantly affected by the strike.
In effect, the city's tabloid playing field, which was dominated by The News before the strike, has become more level, and all the combatants say they are pressing on.
But all of New York's papers, including The Times, have felt the impact of the region's economic slump, which has created one of the worst advertising environments in memory. For the first eight months of the year, combined advertising for all four papers declined more than 18 percent.
Six months ago, The Daily News had been all but stripped of circulation and advertising by the strike and seemed destined to become the first casualty of the city's newspaper war.
While it is impossible to say precisely what brought readers back to The News, it was probably a combination of their loyalty to the paper, their dissatisfaction with the alternatives, a pro-union sentiment following the strike and successful promotion tactics by its new owner, Robert Maxwell, who introduced circulation-building games like "Lucky Bucks."
For the six months ending on Sept. 30, The Daily News reported an average circulation of 762,000 on weekdays and 911,000 on Sundays. A year ago, the figures reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations were 1.1 million on weekdays and 1.4 million on Sunday, but circulation in both categories dropped to 300,000 to 350,000 during the strike. The paper says circulation is now about 800,000 daily and more than 1 million on Sunday, but these figures are not official.
New York Newsday reported an average daily circulation of 269,000 for the six months ending on Sept. 30. That is an increase of 47,000 over the same period a year ago. A spokeswoman said that the paper's average circulation for the six months ending on March 31 was 312,000. The Long Island edition of Newsday reported daily circulation of 695,000, an increase of 2,500 over the year before.
The most important battle for The Daily News and New York Newsday has been on Sunday, the issue richest in advertising. For the six-month period, New York Newsday reported Sunday circulation of 297,000, which represented a gain of about 147,000 over pre-strike levels. But average Sunday sales at the end of March were 373,000. The Long Island edition's average Sunday circulation through September was 578,000, an increase of about 15,000.
The New York Post has reported average circulation of 552,000, up from 510,000 in the same period last year. The paper's circulation at the end of The Daily News strike averaged 645,000. It has no Sunday edition.
The New York Times reported average daily circulation of 730,000 in New York City and its suburbs. Including figures for its national edition, the Times's overall daily circulation was 1.1 million, reflecting an overall increase of 6,400. For its Sunday paper, The Times reported circulation in the New York area of 1.1 million and overall circulation of 1.7 million, an increase of 13,800.
Perhaps the most telling sign that The News is once again a genuine contender is the decision by Rupert Murdoch's News America Corporation to resume inserting its coupon publications in The News beginning on Jan. 5. The coupons, which are considered an important tool for building circulation, were withdrawn during the strike, and Mr. Murdoch refused to restore them when the paper was acquired by Robert Maxwell, his archrival.
Ken Bortner, president of News America's freestanding insert division, said the decision to "put our personal differences aside" and go back into The News came at the request of Kellogg, Procter & Gamble, Quaker and other companies that use coupons.
"I think the paper is on an upward trend," Mr. Bortner said. "The only question is, Will it be around for the long term and will it be profitable in 1992?"
 
Big Debt for Maxwell
 Mr. Maxwell's efforts to sell parts of his worldwide empire to reduce his overall $3 billion debt has prompted speculation that the empire might collapse, taking The News with it.
Mr. Maxwell said that he has no repayment obligations until next October and that he is in no financial jeopardy. He said that just before Columbus Day the paper had its first profitable week since the strike.
"But a swallow does not make a spring," Mr. Maxwell said, acknowledging that the paper had not reached a position of sustained profitability, a goal he hopes to reach by next March, the first anniversary of his ownership.
The post-strike period has been a roiling one for The News, with the paper trying to rebuild while working to overcome the strike's residue of bitterness. Much of it arose when some members of the Newspaper Guild, which represents employees in the news, advertising and clerical departments, crossed picket lines.
Barry F. Lipton, president of the guild, said that about 140 of those who crossed the lines had been brought up on charges by the union and that a majority had been fined, in some cases more than $10,000. Those who crossed the picket lines have retained their own lawyers and have fought the fines.
Juan Gonzalez, a columnist and strike leader, said that an effort is under way to resolve the situation -- and put the strike to rest -- by establishing a maximum fine of $1,800, coupled with a mea culpa from those who crossed the line.
 
Apology by a Friend
 "We want to have the old spirit back, but there's a lot of bitterness still," Mr. Gonzalez said. He said he recently went on an assignment to Haiti with a colleague who had been a close friend until the friend crossed the picket line. He said that the two had not spoken since work resumed after the strike but that in Haiti his friend apologized.
While The News's advertising linage has shown a significant increase over pre-strike levels, it is impossible to know what impact that has had on the paper's financial health because it is not clear what rates the paper has charged. Indeed, newspaper linage can indicate only relative performance because rates can differ widely and ads can be offered at discounts..
On assuming control of the paper, Mr. Maxwell first prohibited all overtime but was forced to relent when it became clear that the paper could not be delivered without overtime pay. There have been few such reprieves, however, and both business and news executives say there is extreme cost consciousness throughout the paper, whose work force shrank to about 1,900 from about 2,700. A number of news executives say that while Mr. Maxwell is strongly interested in the paper's coverage, he has not interfered with it. His main direct involvement has been to write editorials occasionally, especially on foreign affairs.
The paper was stunned yesterday by the news that John Cotter, who was scheduled to begin work on Monday as the managing editor for news, had died at his home in Darien, Conn., apparently of a heart attack. [Obituary, page 26.]
The appointment of Mr. Cotter, who had been city editor of The Post since 1989 and had held a similar position at New York Newsday, had aroused controversy at the paper. In 1987 Mr. Cotter resigned from New York Newsday after he was accused of using a racial epithet in referring to his chief deputy, who is black. Mr. Cotter maintained that he had been telling associates what someone else had said rather than making the comment himself.
Yesterday, the paper's editor, James P. Willse, said that no decision had been made about a replacement for Mr. Cotter.
The Cotter appointment came at a time when Mr. Gonzalez and other members of minority groups have complained that the paper lost a disproportionate number of its minority members during the strike. But Mr. Willse noted that black journalists now fill several key positions, including metropolitan editor, editorial page editor and deputy managing editor for business news.
The New York Post, which has long been considered the most vulnerable of the city's tabloids, has also whittled costs to the bone. Peter S. Kalikow, the paper's owner, now says he expects the paper to be profitable this year.
An executive at the paper who spoke on condition of anonymity said that The Post's weekly costs are about $1.6 million, that weekly circulation revenue is just over $1 million and that advertising averages between 180 and 200 pages a week, generating about $950,000 in weekly revenue. The executive said the paper expects to earn a profit of about $9 million this year.
Last February, Mr. Kalikow obtained yearlong advertising contracts from large retailers by charging rates based on pre-strike circulation figures, though at the time The Post's circulation was much higher. As a result, The Post is the only one of the city's weekday papers to show an increase in advertising linage over last year for the first eight months.
Those contracts expire in February, and Mr. Kalikow said he thinks he will be able to renew most of them.
Should many of his major advertisers abandon The Post, the paper could quickly become unprofitable, and Mr. Kalikow has said that he will not operate it at a deficit.
Indeed, this summer he sought to protect his other holdings from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Now it is is doubtful that his creditors would allow him to use any of his remaining assets to shore up The Post.
Newsday, like all of the city's dailies, has cut costs in recent months, but Chiara Coletti, a spokeswoman, said that New York Newsday is maintaining a presence in Westchester County, where it expanded during the strike.
Of all the city's Sunday papers, only the combined editions of Newsday has maintained advertising linage at roughly last year's level, largely because of gains in the Sunday edition of New York Newsday.

HEADLINE: The Ever-Changing Literary Past

BYLINE: By Morris Dickstein; Morris Dickstein teaches English at Queens College and the City University of New York Graduate Center.

 BODY:
One of the best contributions to the debate on the classics and the curriculum was written 40 years ago in Buenos Aires. Jorge Luis Borges's essay "Kafka and His Precursors" is a fable about how Kafka's work somehow influenced writers who preceded him. His point is that they begin to look Kafkaesque once we've read Kafka himself. Borges's choices are fanciful but his conclusion is not: "Each writer creates his precursors. His work modifies our conception of the past, as it will modify the future."
The critic Harold Bloom once cited Borges's partly tongue-in-cheek essay as a key to poetic influence, but we can see it as a parable of the ever-changing canon, our literary past, always being reoriented by new departures in contemporary culture. 
 The canon today is full of writers resurrected or transformed because powerful new writers made them accessible, as when T.S. Eliot invented John Donne, Allen Ginsberg opened up a different Walt Whitman and Alice Walker rediscovered Zora Neale Hurston. These changes were in tune with broad cultural movements -- modernism, the 60's counterculture, black feminism.
This historical pattern demolishes the misguided notion of a fixed and unchanging canon, just as it undermines any calculated affirmative action approach to literary reputations. Instead, we observe the shifting tides of critical judgment, influenced by what each period needs and what the best new writers are creating.
Such a literary view of the rise and fall of writers and reputations holds little appeal for strident ideologues on both sides of the canon controversy. They debate the issues entirely in political terms: who controls the reading list? Who gets into the widely adopted anthologies? How is this text deceiving and indoctrinating us? What institutional forces lie behind it? Our sense of writers and their work has been swamped by this struggle for cultural power.
Multiculturalism has a long history in America. Our literature has repeatedly been enriched by outsiders who became insiders -- regionalists like the Southern and Western writers, Jews with their European and immigrant baggage, blacks bearing the historical weight of slavery and migration, women whose experiences undercut cherished male myths. There are political dimensions to this struggle for recognition, but many see only the political dimensions.
Conservatives like William Bennett and Lynne Cheney, who decry a tide of illiteracy and political correctness eroding Western values, are matched by cultural radicals who arraign the classics for bolstering racial, sexual and economic oppression.
Each side is profoundly ideological; each needs the other to confirm its caricature of a monolithic canon freighted with a particular set of values that one camp upholds and the other condemns. Neither will allow for the unpredictability of individual works, which constantly open themselves to new interpretations; for the enormous variety of the canon itself, porous, shifting, many-faceted; for the surprising tolerance of the Western tradition, with its varieties of dissent and internal contradiction.
We're seeing something different from previous conflicts over multiculturalism in America. As each side jockeys for academic influence and public support, as they strain to delegitimize their antagonists, they threaten to discredit the whole process by which marginal groups have always entered the mainstream.
The pressure for change is inevitable, thanks to the broader student population in the universities, the new outlook of faculty trained in literary theory, the genuine strength of some rediscovered writers, and the real history of prejudice and exclusion that helped undermine the idea of a common culture. But changing the reading list and altering the textbooks will not in itself reshape the canon or rewrite literary history.
Affirmative action in cultural studies is well meaning but futile. Only the best new writers will make us want to read their neglected forebears, and only the most thoughtfully chosen works will overcome the obstacles to literacy today. And it will take critics and teachers with unusual gifts to help us learn to read them without discarding the best our tradition has to offer.

HEADLINE: For Skiers, Bargains if Not Snow

BYLINE: By JANET NELSON

 BODY:
This is a great year for bargains in ski equipment. Since early August, ski shops around the nation have been holding sales with markdowns of up to 70 percent. It's not always clear that the equipment on sale is left over from the 1990-91 year, but that's not much of a drawback.
With changing technology in skis and boots, is last year's equipment as good as what is coming on the market this season? The answer is a qualified yes. "Every year skis are getting better," said Bill Tanler, a former editor of Ski Tech, a publication for ski-shop mechanics, as the artisans are called, "but the basic technology has been pretty well mastered, so there are not many dogs on the market anymore. 
 "The boots are good, too," he continued. "But 90 percent of finding a good boot is finding one that fits. Technological developments in bindings have plateaued in recent years, and the really dramatic reduction in the number of broken ankles and so forth proves their effectiveness."
The reason for the big discounts is that skiers weren't buying equipment last season. Snow droughts on both coasts discouraged skiing, the recession kept pocketbooks closed and people stayed home in front of their television sets watching the Gulf war. In addition, Japan, the fastest-growing ski market in the world, had poor snow. In Europe, where most of the ski equipment is manufactured, there was so little demand that most merchandise never left the warehouse.
"There is lots of inventory out there because both the ski retailers and the suppliers were left with equipment," said Glenn Heitsmith, editor of Ski Business, a trade publication. "At the same time, retailers didn't place tremendous orders for this year, so there won't be so much product-leftover next spring."
Taking advantage of the abundance of leftover 1991 equipment, many ski shop managers borrowed money to buy ski bindings and other items from manufacturers and suppliers as well as unsold merchandise from 76 ski shops around the country that went out of business at the end of last season. The biggest savings will be at promotional sales, but even after the sales, the shops will have bargains.
For 10 years Princeton Ski Shops, which has branches in Manhasset and Roslyn Heights, L.I., Elmsford, N.Y., and Clifton, N.J., has held a sale in Giants Stadium, in East Rutherford, N.J., that has attracted 50,000 people or more. This year, the sale will be held there Nov. 4 to Nov. 10.
"The only way to make money in this business is to take advantage of a bad situation," said Jack Meyers, the company's vice president. "This is the best and biggest inventory we've ever had. Skiers can get the best values in many years."
Prices at the stadium sale will be about 20 percent lower than the discounted prices in the stores, he said. K2 TRC skis, for example, which sold for $390 last season, will be $189 at the November sale, but $199 in the store afterward. Those who miss the sale will have another chance: Princeton's anniversary sale over the Thanksgiving weekend.
 
'Cheapest of the Year'
 Ski Barn, which has shops in Paramus, Little Falls and West Windsor, N.J., is holding a sale Nov. 22-24 at the Ski and Travel Show at the Meadowlands Convention Center in Secaucus, N.J.
"If you don't have to have the latest color and you can live with green instead of orange, you can get great deals," said Rob Lane, manager of the Little Falls store. "At the ski show, prices will be the cheapest of the year. New, 1990-91 stuff will be 10 to 60 percent off."
He added that last year's equipment would still be 30 to 40 percent off in the stores after the ski show, but there would be fewer selections.
Even this year's new ski equipment can usually be bought for less than the list price, particularly when it is packaged with two or three other items of equipment. With skis, boots and bindings, the discount could be 15 percent.
 
Alternating Sales
 The Exhibition Inc. ski shop in Mount Kisco, N.Y., plans alternating sales of skiing equipment that dates from this year to last November; boots one week, skis the next. "In this business, you almost never sell anything at list," said Michael Lowell, manager of the store. "The only place where we try to hold the price is on current-model boots because of the amount of fitting they need and our fitting guarantee that lasts for one year."
He said 1991 boots at 30 percent off the list price were a particularly good deal because prices on the 1992 lines were 7 to 10 percent higher. Some bindings are 30 percent higher, reflecting a tariff change as much as inflation and the decline of the dollar against European currencies; most bindings are manufactured in Europe. But, as with skis, ski bindings are usually marked down 10 to 15 percent.
Skis in the 1992 lines will be 7 to 10 percent higher than last year's comparable or identical models, with cosmetic changes. Mr. Lowell said the only skis hard to bargain down would be Monocoque-style skis -- the top of the ski is molded in one piece. But even Elan MBX skis, made that way, were $600 last season and are $550 this year
Most ski shop managers who were interviewed said that once the sales events were over this fall, prices would return to normal until late January or mid-February, when a new cycle of sales began.
"Of course, when the sales begin again depends on the snow," said Jeffrey Heanue, manager of the Pedigree Ski Shop in White Plains. "Last season, when there wasn't much snow, we started sales in mid-January."
 
 
 
IT'S NOT A SAVING IF THEY DON'T FIT
 Here is advice from experts about buying skiing equipment.
Be sure your skis and your boots match: no high-performance racing skis with recreational boots.
If the skis and boots are mismatched, decide which category of equipment you prefer.
Because comfort is critical, buying boots at shops that guarantee the fit may be worth the extra cost,particularly to those whose feet are difficult to fit.
Safety features of ski bindings have improved significantly in recent years. If a ski-shop mechanic declines to adjust or repair your bindings, simply replace them.
Don't expect special service or even knowledgeable personnel at many of the bigger sales. And two final things, perhaps most important:
Know what you want before you go.
And if a ski store doesn't offer a discount, ask for one.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Sinbad in a White Rolls-Royce

BYLINE: By Francine Prose; Francine Prose's new novel, "Primitive People," will be published next spring.

 BODY:

THE TRENCH
Volume Two of the "Cities of Salt" Trilogy.
By Abdelrahman Munif.
Translated by Peter Theroux.
554 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $25.  
 Certain novels inspire in us the visceral shock of discovery that we most often associate with travel and with landscape, with rounding a bend and coming upon a panoramic, breathtaking vista, at once eerily familiar and terrifyingly strange. One such book is "The Trench," Abdelrahman Munif's powerful saga in which the forces of history, greed, obsession and Machiavellian intrigue turn a somnolent desert outpost into a rich, corrupt Persian Gulf state.
Set in the 1950's in the invented but apparently recognizable city of Mooran (originally published in Lebanon, the novel was banned in Saudi Arabia, and Mr. Munif was deprived of his Saudi citizenship), "The Trench" sits on that stormy front where past and present collide and unleash a damaging hail of temporal dislocation. Oil has been discovered under the Sultan's land, imported earth-moving equipment has razed the camel dealer's souk, and emissaries no longer bring gifts of frankincense and myrrh but of sneakers, Faber pens and lucrative armaments contracts.
"The Trench" is the second volume in a trilogy, "Cities of Salt," but can be read totally independently of the first. Its skilled translator, Peter Theroux, writes that the title connotes an abyss, "a hole one is likely to fall into," in particular an undersea geological formation. As the novel progresses, seismic social and economic changes open chasms so wide that Mr. Munif's characters are always scrambling to keep from tumbling in. Their fates suggest the convolutions of a Victorian novel transcribed into Arabic calligraphy, or perhaps "The Arabian Nights" as retold by Stendhal -- with Sinbad driving a white Rolls-Royce and the Grand Vizier jetting off to Atlanta for counterintelligence training.
What makes "The Trench" so fascinating and so tricky to describe is that its texture and narrative methods embrace so many seeming contradictions -- paradoxes that mirror perfectly the book's atmosphere and themes. The novel is simultaneously epic and domestic, sweeping and claustrophobic, traditional and timely, linear and digressive, serious and satiric. It's a lengthy, complicated book, crowded with incident and character, requiring and rewarding close, unflagging attention.
At its labyrinthine center is a demonically ambitious Syrian, Dr. Subhi Mahmilji, who arrives to treat the dying Sultan. He finds a desolate Mooran where "fathers inherited from their forefathers a simple view of life and death; and because they did not expect much of life or fear death during the years they spent on earth, toiling for a crust of bread . . . they did find ample time to contemplate their surroundings, and took delight in memorizing poetry, verses from the Koran and old folktales. On the long summer nights they found their spirits departing beyond life and death and their eyes wandering the heavens to locate the stars and planets or trying to read in the wind the signs of dust storms, locusts and catastrophes."
What the doctor reads in the wind are the signs of change. "Forgotten, remote, a non-place," Mooran is about to wake up and mine the oily fortune beneath it. Plotting, calculating, flattering his way into the new Sultan's favor, the doctor weaves a web of influence that will allow him to control Mooran's leap into the future. The novel follows the doctor's career as he conspires to place his allies and spies in strategic places, and to construct the machinery of modern government that will soon render the old tribal ways -- and the doctor himself -- obsolete.
Our immersion in the doctor's machinations is so total and so dreamlike that Mr. Munif must rouse us at intervals to witness how the various projects initiated by Mahmilji, his rivals and co-conspirators are affecting Mooran. As we watch, a cluster of mud huts becomes a city of air-conditioned palaces, monitored by a repressive, C.I.A.-sponsored secret service and a state-controlled press. Camels are replaced by luxury cars, narrow alleys by boulevards; all at once the ancient market is prime desert real estate. "People's circumstances had changed, and so had their looks: they were fatter."
Even so, the past maintains its grip, not only on the Mooranis but on the novel's structure, with its flourishes suggestive of traditional Arabic storytelling. Frequent moments of foreshadowing give this tale of techno-modernization a feeling of mythic inexorability. ("A Moroccan astrologer . . . had warned Khazael against one thing: moving into his father's palace, since that palace would be ill-omened for the present Sultan's successors.") The characters speak in folksy, epigrammatic proverbs that, in this translation, sound natural and colloquial. Mr. Theroux's work should serve as a model for translators; its lovely, effortless cadences support an impressive range of tones, from the lyrical and poetic to the gritty talk of the souk.
The constant friction between present and past so undermines our own sense of time that, near the novel's end, we are almost as shocked as Mahmilji himself when his son returns from America to announce that the doctor's notion of palace intrigue is now hopelessly out of date. Because of Mooran's oil wealth and regional importance -- two factors that the doctor has helped to exploit -- "fate was more likely to be decided outside of Mooran than within. 'All this business about the Chamber of Commerce, Father, or whether or not So-and-so and What's-his-name aren't getting along, is meaningless.' " In an ironic, chilling scene, an American diplomat offers political advice that by contrast makes all the doctor's scheming look touchingly modest and bumbling:
"Very calmly and patiently -- the opposite of the way the doctor spoke -- he explained to him that the new circumstances in Mooran had helped to create a climate of stability and contentment, which required just two methods, or at least one: incentive and force. Incentives for those who saw the status quo alone as being their business, since it affected their interests; force toward the others, dissidents, those who were never satisfied with anything."
The novel glitters with brilliant, refractory character portraits, most strikingly of its women: Widad Hayek, the doctor's voluptuous, Emma Bovary-like wife; Ummi Zahwa, the ancient witchlike Sheikha, who rules the palace by the sheer force of spooky fear; and the elderly Umm Hosny, the mother of two mega-businessmen and a businesswoman herself, who cannot live without the intimacy and excitement of selling to women, in their homes, henna, incense and cosmetics. Such fully complex and moving characters enrich and deepen Mr. Munif's narrative and, together with the elegance of the writing, make it something more profound than a political roman a clef.
Reading "The Trench" is like seeing carved shutters thrown open or an embroidered veil drawn back, and glimpsing behind it the face of someone very much like someone we know. The book deepens, enriches and above all humanizes whatever sense of Arab culture we may have garnered from the Middle East experts we see regularly on television, and from the recent spate of nonfiction books about the history of the region. As our media, during and after the gulf war, attempt to portray the Arab as the unknowable Other, as faceless as a disembodied muezzin's chant announcing our evening news, Mr. Munif's wonderful novel is a welcome corrective. One wishes that it were required (or at least suggested) reading for every American. We celebrate the bravery, scope and precision with which he shows us how his people are and aren't like us, and the role that our intelligence community has played in what they have become.
 

 
SHEEP IN THE PALACE
 There had been no more than twenty or thirty cars in the days of Sultan Khureybit, and most of those belonged to the palace; their mystique had faded now, like a toy with which a child gets quickly bored so that he ignores it in favor of another, then another, and now cars were piled up in Mooran like discarded toys, changed as often as socks. And then Mooran moved on from cars to the love of a new game: palaces. People suddenly discovered that the tents that had shaded them and the mud houses that had sheltered them were hateful and degrading. . . .
Instead of one palace they had two or three, instead of one story they had several, instead of wide windows there were glass panels from wall to wall, which, they said, made them feel still a part of the nature around them. As they once named their horses, they now gave their palaces unusual or even ridiculous names and titles. They raised animals, especially sheep, inside the palaces, and the sheep roamed to the windows and sliding glass doors to rub their snouts against the glass and butt it, to the hilarity of passersby. -- From "The Trench."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Doctor, Doctor, Give Us the News

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN; Jan Hoffman writes about social issues and entertainment for The Village Voice, Mirabella and Premiere.

 BODY:
After four years of medical school and another three for internship and residency, a doctor chooses a subspecialty: cardiology. Dermatology. Ophthalmology. But broadcast journalism, Dr. Atkinson?
Indeed, a decade after receiving a master's degree from Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, Dr. Holly Atkinson set up practice in a television studio. Last month the 38-year-old former internist, who is a vice president at Lifetime Medical Television, joined NBC's "Today" show as its new medical correspondent, replacing Dr. Art Ulene, who has moved to ABC's "Home" show. 
 That newscasts need medical stories is almost a given. Audience surveys repeatedly indicate that "medical stories top the list after news updates and weather," says Jack Reilly, executive producer of "Good Morning America," which retains two on-camera physicians, Dr. Tim Johnson and Dr. Nancy Snyderman. More than half the morning viewers are women, ages 18 to 49, which begins to explain the soaring success of the vivacious Dr. Snyderman, who has also become a regular substitute for the show's co-host, Joan Lunden.
Though precise numbers are difficult to come by, estimates suggest that more than 250 physicians around the country appear on radio and television, at least on a part-time basis. And doctors like Dean Edell and James (Red) Duke have their own syndicated shows broadcast on hundreds of stations around the country. A Gallup poll of 101 TV news directors last year found that they all rated doctors to be the most credible and qualified to deliver medical news.
But do doctors need newscasts? Given the social prestige of American physicians, why would any of them soil their white coats by associating with the glitzy parvenus of TV?
Answer No. 1: The Noble Sacrifice. "We don't represent the public-health establishment; we represent the patient," says Dr. Bob Arnot, the medical reporter for the morning and evening CBS network news shows. "Patients trust doctors less, and they're looking for an independent source of medical evidence. I do things for viewers I wouldn't have time to do for patients: I read more journals, go to more conferences, and talk to specialists in many areas." And, he maintains, earns a good deal less money than if he'd stayed in private practice; though salaries vary wildly both in medicine and television, he and others declined to be specific.
Answer No. 2: We Were Destined for Each Other. "Being a doctor is the closest thing to being God, so we have perfect training to be on television," pronounces Dr. Dean Edell, who can be seen on 88 TV stations and heard on 300 radio stations five times a week. "I must get five phone calls a month -- typical doctors: 'Tell me what to do so I can get in!' Pathologists who've had their heads in formaldehyde for 20 years now think they're going to be TV stars."
As for his own motives, the unapologetic Dr. Edell, a San Francisco-based former eye surgeon/antique-store owner/traveling bus resident/hippie in good standing, says bluntly that as a media physician he earns "a very healthy seven-figure income" -- even though, he hastens to note, "I would have done it all for nothing."
Doctors might be bad patients, but they can be even worse media stars. Says Don Fitzpatrick, who recruits television talent: "I've dealt with on-air talent for 20 years, and the worst are the TV doctors. They've got all this education and they throw it in your face: 'I save lives and I'm grand!' You put that ego on TV, and you're magnifying it 400 times."
Though privately physicians may sniff that TV doctors aren't "real doctors," publicly the American Medical Association has aided and abetted them. For more than a decade, the A.M.A. has sponsored an annual Health Reporting Conference, a sort of three-day J-School 101 providing 150 star-struck doctors with seminars such as "Getting Started on Cable," "Advanced Interviewing," "Sharpening Your On-Air Image" and "How to Get on a Talk Show." And in 1983, a support organization formed, calling itself the National Association of Physician Broadcasters, which now claims some 250 members.
The doctors' notions of what topics they should cover varies. At one end of the spectrum is the ersatz family doctor, who provides gentle, clucking reminders about seasonal health hazards. That character is exuberantly exemplified by Dr. Red Duke, the popular cowboy-style physician and Willie Nelson buddy who's syndicated throughout the Southwest. He'll conclude a summertime admonition against sun exposure and skin cancer, for example, with, "If melanoma doesn't scare you, remember: sunshine causes wrinkles and" -- he doffs a 10-gallon hat and sunglasses, as the camera zooms in on his road-map features -- "you could end up looking like me."
Others differ less in approach than subject matter. Dr. Tim Johnson of ABC, a Harvard medical lecturer and associate minister, is especially adept at translating and evaluating the latest studies from the medical journals. Dr. Atkinson of the "Today" show, who has a background in public health, says she plans to cover mental health, as well as the "economic, human and political aspects of medicine, such as preventive care." Dr. Arnot at CBS, who is probably best known for research in sports medicine, has been rigorous in his coverage of international medical practices, having filed stories from 22 countries in the last 18 months.
But do they see themselves as physicians, reporters, or some curious, contradictory hybrid? "There's a tug of war between the roles," concedes Dr. Art Ulene, a former gynecologist who was with NBC for 15 years and is now ensconced at ABC's "Home" show. "I tend toward the doctor's role. As a physician on television, it is not inappropriate for me to give medical advice and talk about why I lean one way or the other on a medical issue. Reporters, who are supposed to be objective, can't."
Maintains Dr. Arnot: "I don't give advice. That's a trick of TV. I'm not setting myself up as better than your doctor -- I can't customize information enough to be responsible. So I try to give source lists and leave it up to the individual to pursue."
Dr. Edell not only files stories for the local San Francisco station KGO, but also dispenses opinions to callers on his regular radio and television shows. "I have no peers, and no hospital insurance. But I do my homework -- I read 80 journals a week. I let people ask me whatever they want" -- a typical broadcast may include inquiries ranging from AIDS to acne to narcolepsy -- "and I make a living because other doctors don't explain enough to their patients. I advise people to give their doctors hell.
"Am I practicing medicine on the air? Insurance companies don't know what to do with us."
Others are unabashedly doctrinaire.
"I'm a reporter," says Dr. Atkinson, the only one of the national pack with a master's degree in journalism.
"I'm a surgeon," retorts Dr. Snyderman without hesitation, the only national medical reporter to keep her day job. In addition to her responsibilities at "Good Morning America," Dr. Snyderman, a single mother of two young daughters and a full-time medical correspondent for San Francisco's KPIX, also has a practice as a head and neck cancer surgeon.
Last year, as she was preparing for the 5 P.M. broadcast, she got a call around 4:15 that a patient needed an emergency tracheotomy. "I caught myself thinking, is there anyone else around to do the operation?" and was immediately appalled at herself. "I left the station hanging with a big chunk of the newscast empty," she says. "But the news went on without me, so la-di-da."
The two professions of medicine and journalism, each fraught with ethical conundrums, can pose challenges when put to tandem use. Doctors are supposed to be hands-on; journalists are supposed to be hands-off. Using his journalist's credentials, Dr. Arnot managed to get into Kuwait City during the Persian Gulf crisis, where he canvassed hospital supplies and medical staffs, and then called Americares, an emergency relief organization. After he arrived with a CBS crew in Kurdistan, he filed some pieces, and then, after the cameras left, he stayed to treat patients. "I've probably broken rules and crossed lines," he says.
Dr. Atkinson points out that a doctor's commitment to confidentiality vies with the reporter's need to tell the big story; she tends to err on the side of caution if she thinks an interviewee has confided in her because she's a doctor. Nor does she belong to the A.M.A., in observance of the journalist's credo not to be affiliated with special-interest groups in one's area of reporting. Dr. Bob Lanier, a doctor and syndicated medical reporter for KXAS in Fort Worth, believes that medical journalists haven't been held up to enough professional scrutiny. The National Association of Physician Broadcasters, he notes, has a working relationship with the A.M.A. This summer he started the Academy of Radio and Television Health Communicators to work up a code of ethics.
"Doctors have the capacity to really violate ethics that journalists can't," he cautions. He offers a hypothetical situation: a prominent politician is hospitalized, nature of illness undisclosed. "As physicians, we can just pluck those medical charts and read them. As journalists, we can't. What should we do?"
Most part-time medical correspondents do maintain a practice. Most of the full-time physician-reporters think that's a bad idea. "How can you be responsible to your patients when suddenly you have to go to Iraq for two weeks?" wonders Dr. Arnot. Moreover, the on-air appearances "amount to a three-minute commercial for Dr. Phil," says Don Fitzpatrick, the recruiter. Lately, however, cost-conscious stations have begun to scale back their use of high-priced physicians, who in turn must rely more heavily on their practice for income.
But isn't having a practice why you went to medical school in the first place? So when are you going to settle down and buy some nice malpractice insurance? Dr. Arnot shakes his head, laughing, and shrugs his shoulders. "I never envisioned myself as having a little family practice at the foot of the street. My family did. They still do."
Booms Dr. Edell: "Are you kidding? My mom loves it -- I'm 'My Son the Doctor-TV Star!' "

HEADLINE: Blacks on TV: Scrambled Signals

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
When the name Malcolm X begins popping up, however casually, in prime-time entertainment, viewers are getting a signal that television may be gearing up to portray black Americans in their true diversity, their aspirations and their occasional rage. Blacks can no longer be kept in their standard electronic ghettos.
A couple of weeks ago, Judge Clarence Thomas and Prof. Anita F. Hill appeared live before the Senate Judiciary Committee hearings into sexual-harassment charges, and the ratings knocked baseball playoffs and lavish mini-series for a loop. Purely in terms of the medium itself, here was powerfully significant television, its "stars" accomplished black professionals who were clearly an integral part of the American mainstream. 
 But these are precisely the black people neglected on much of television entertainment. Prime time too often relegates them to scattered token roles (a judge and a litigator on "L.A. Law" or an assistant D.A. on "The Trials of Rosie O'Neill") or the clownish context of a sitcom ("Family Matters" or "True Colors"). Without the calculated efforts of a Bill Cosby, the black middle class would be virtually invisible on the home screen. Although its beginnings can be glimpsed on such new series as "I'll Fly Away" and "Homefront," both are set safely in the past.
At the other end of the economic scale, of course, encompassing the majority of black citizens, today's struggling poor are also just about ignored on prime time. For too many viewers, blacks are still simply the people who get busted the most on all those police "reality" shows. The diversity of the black community, the social and political ferment within that community, is reflected only occasionally. Both white and black viewers end up shortchanged.
One thing painfully clear about this season's new and returning shows is the almost complete absence of a sense of profound discontent in depictions of black life on prime time. Although sitcoms still wouldn't dream of an unhappy ending, polls show that a good many black people are fed up with the drugs and crime that constantly dim their lives. Many do not dismiss conspiracy theories that most whites would deem outlandish. Abrasive spokesmen like the Rev. Al Sharpton or Prof. Leonard Jeffries may be excoriated by both the white establishment and many blacks, but they continue to draw followers in portions of the black community. Rap singers uninhibitedly indict white society and are applauded by young audiences everywhere.
Significant in all this is the renewed prominence of Malcolm X, especially for black youth. Expounding on what he called "the castration of the black man," Malcolm prompted an incensed Mike Wallace in a 1959 telecast to warn America of his "gospel of hate that would set off a Federal investigation if it were said by Southern whites." Today, several young black film makers are gaining deserved prominence with their provocative explorations of the black experience, among them Spike Lee, who is making a major movie about Malcolm X.
The merest glimmers of these developments are allowed to penetrate the electronic curtain of television entertainment, controlled almost entirely by white males. And when those glimmers do appear, they are carefully softened around the edges. In "The Royal Family" (a new CBS series now in limbo because of the recent death of its star, Redd Foxx), a young Muslim character was brought into one episode only to be dismissed for his apparently silly unwillingness to appreciate good old down-home pork chops.
Fox's "True Colors," constructed around the racially mixed marriage of previously divorced parties, a white woman with a daughter and a black man with two sons, was considerably more provocative in a recent installment. The younger son, Lester (Adam Jeffries), feeling neglected by the family, suddenly withdrew to read "The Autobiography of Malcolm X."
In no time at all, Lester was bad-mouthing racially mixed marriages, calling his brother a clown in blackface and his sister a bleeding-heart liberal. But also in no time at all, Lester realized the error of his ways, especially after missing his own birthday party. Cake and ice cream, evidently, beat Malcolm X any day -- on a television sitcom.
There is only one new series this season in which the American black experience is given a unusually sobering dose of reality. Revealingly enough, though, NBC's "I'll Fly Away" is set in the late 1950's. Television is nearly always uncomfortable with harsh realities unless they are snuggled unthreateningly in the past. In any event, "I'll Fly Away" -- the title comes from a traditional spiritual -- is constructed around the beginnings of the civil-rights movement, viewed through the eyes of two families.
One is headed by white Forrest Bedford (Sam Waterston), local district attorney for a small Southern town; the other by black Lilly Harper (Regina Taylor), who works weekdays as the Bedford housekeeper. Lilly knows all about the Bedfords, tending to Forrest and his three children day after day in their comfortable home. They know little about Lilly, however, or her 6-year-old daughter living in the rundown "colored" section of town.
The series' intention is for the Bedfords to get to know more about the soft-spoken but forthright Lilly, to understand her as something more than an efficient employee. Small details can be perfect, as when Lilly's daughter mistakenly assumes that a cowboy hat belonging to the youngest Bedford boy is for her. Lilly's anguish, when she has to take the hat away, is painful. Developed by Joshua Brand and John Falsey ("St. Elsewhere," "Northern Exposure") "I'll Fly Away," is beautifully acted, ambitious and intelligent, and therefore something of a rarity this season.
There's also a black family on the new ABC drama, "Homefront," which goes all the way back to the 1940's, just after World War II. But this show, created by David Jacobs ("Knots Landing"), has wasted no time in getting down to traditional soap-opera shenanigans. Only a few weeks into the series, bed sheets are rumpled all over this fictional town. Race relations seem to unfold in a never-never land in which the local factory boss, a bigot and union-basher, plots privately with his black chauffeur as to how to best handle their touchy wives. Yeah, sure, Mr. Jacobs.
Nevertheless, television has come a long way from 1968 when NBC's "Julia" with Diahann Carroll could be considered a ground-breaker for having a black heroine who wasn't a domestic. The entertainment schedules these days feature black performers in a wide range of formats (newscasts, on the other hand, local and national, continue to be curiously inhospitable to black men as anchors). Have television executives grown more enlightened? Perhaps. But a more telling explanation can be found in bottom-line profit considerations, never far from a broadcaster's heart.
The fact is that, while the overall audience figures for networks have been steadily declining, black households -- accounting for 12 percent of the national pie -- have assumed major importance in the totals. A recent report from Nielsen Media Research, pegged to the November 1990 period, found that black households across the country watched just under 70 hours of television during the average week, some 48 percent more than "all other" households.
In one important subcategory, blacks age 2 to 17, watched a staggering 64 percent more than all others in that age range. The most popular shows in the black households: "A Different World," produced by Mr. Cosby; "The Cosby Show," and "Fresh Prince of Bel Air" -- all black-oriented and, as it happens, on NBC.
The report provides blacks with considerably increased clout to demand more and better programming having relevance to themselves. Since so many black youngsters are watching -- pressures on broadcasters for more socially responsible content, venturing more frequently outside the standard circle of criminals, athletes and entertainers, is likely to get more intense. For the moment, many of the plusses racked up in recent years for black audiences continue to be offset by lingering minuses, most of them stubbornly rooted in stereotyping.
On the sitcom front, for instance, a large step forward is being taken by Fox's new series "Roc," in which the title character is a Baltimore gar bageman with a gruff geniality as big as all outdoors. In most respects, the format is standard stuff, with one manufactured problem a week neatly resolved before the final credits. But "Roc" also has one of the best casts currently on weekly television, with Charles S. Dutton heading a repertory company recruited almost intact from the Broadway production of August Wilson's "Piano Lesson." Mr. Dutton's Roc can suddenly veer from broad comedy into a moving monologue about being a worker with sometimes impossible dreams.
At the other end of the spectrum is ABC's "Family Matters," another show about a workingman and his family. This one, though, has been taken over most weeks by the super-nerdy character of Urkel (Jameel White), a teen-age neighbor whose broadly caricatured antics uneasily smack of a modern Stepin' Fetchit in the making. "Family Matters" is sitcom business as usual, pouncing on every cliched teen-age crisis in the how-to-write-a-script book.
But some other seemingly ordinary shows can, at least occasionally, glance briefly in the direction of potentially controversial subjects, some more so than others. Time does change attitudes. Interracial marriages and affairs, for instance, used to be considered incendiary topics. Now "True Colors" and other black sitcoms are exploring it, and from a black point of view.
A recent episode of "Fresh Prince of Bel Air" began with fussy preparations for the wedding of Aunt Janice only for her black family to discover, just in time to use the cast's hanging jaws and a shrieking audience for a segue into the commercial break, that her boyfriend was white. The bride's sister minced no words: "Don't you have enough problems being an African-American woman?" adding pointedly, "Honey, I don't make the rules, but I know how to play the game."
The riskiest example was "Roc," in which Dad's kid brother showed up with the happy news that he was finally getting married and then his intended turned out to be a white man. This series clearly decided to play Double Jeopardy. Interracial marriages may be more acceptable these days, reaching into circles of prominence that include Judge Thomas and his wife. But being gay can still trigger howls of objection -- not least in the black community, as Marlon T. Riggs's angrily insightful documentary "Tongues Untied" illustrated on public television earlier this year.
So, there are more blacks employed on television these days. But why do so many of the sitcom fathers ("Family Matters," "Fresh Prince") have to be overweight and jolly when the dads in white situations can be played by ladies' men types like Patrick Duffy (ABC's "Step by Step") or Alan Thicke (ABC's "Growing Pains")?
And why do so many of the black young people have to appear so dimwitted or ridiculous, a phenomenon that extends well past the oddball Urkel to, for instance, the two brothers in "True Colors"? Clowning around is one thing, but these fellows, played by appealing actors, are sometimes made to seem positively retarded. Their white sister, though, is clearly no fool.
Images, images. Television researchers presumably have their reasons. The extraordinary attention paid to the Thomas-Hill hearings indicates that they should now get set to freshen up their tired repertory.

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Collectors Read the Bottom Lines of Vintage Comic Books

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Comic books as collectibles went WHOOM!!! this month. Two books were published surveying 50 years of the genre as pop culture, and Sotheby's in New York announced that on Dec. 18 it would hold the first sale at an international art auction house featuring only comic books.
Both survey books are selling extremely well. The initial printing of "From Aargh! to Zap!: Harvey Kurtzman's Visual History of the Comics," Simon & Schuster's $25 paperback, is already sold out. And "Marvel: Five Fabulous Decades of the World's Greatest Comics," by Les Daniels, is, at $45, the top seller this fall for Harry N. Abrams. About 100,000 copies are in print at this publisher, where a printing of 5,000 for art and coffee-table books is considered large. 
 "It's one of the biggest and fastest sales for a book of that price we've ever had," said Paul Gottlieb, Abrams's president and publisher. "One of the reasons for the resurgence of interest in comic books must be that it's an escapist medium. Right now, people are seeking just that."
Mr. Daniels agrees. "Nostalgia is what starts most collectors pursuing old comic books," he said. "The fantasy element and wish-fulfillment work like magic. I bought the comic books I had read as a boy in old magazine stores in Providence when I was at Brown in the 1960's. What I looked for then was the horror comics -- 'Tales From the Crypt' and that sort of thing."
For many people, one outrageous picture may summon up powerful feelings from their childhood. "For me, no image could ever replace that cover showing the superhero with a cape, holding aloft a black car," said Alexander Acevedo, a Madison Avenue art dealer who has handled some comic books since the early 1970's. "He's the Atlas of the 20th century."
When Superman made his debut on the cover of Action Comics No. 1 in June 1938, the Golden Age of comic books began. That era, and the 1960's Silver Age of the newer flawed and self-doubting superheroes, including Spider-Man, are well documented in Mr. Daniels's book and in the catalogue ($35) of Sotheby's forthcoming sale. Superman's popularity among collectors makes Action 1 -- a 10-cent purchase in 1938 -- the costliest comic book in the auction: The presale estimate is $28,000 to $38,000.
Most superheroes -- including Superman, Batman, Captain Marvel, Spider-Man, Flash and the Hulk -- are represented among the 350 vintage comic books and original artist's illustrations to be auctioned. Also up for sale are Detective No. 27 from 1939, which introduced Batman; the estimate is $24,000 to $28,000. A copy of the first Amazing Spider-Man from 1963, in near-mint condition, is expected to bring up to $9,000. Sotheby's, which is printing 8,000 copies of its catalogue, expects that the sale will total up to $2 million.
In his book, Mr. Daniels explains how the company now called the Marvel Entertainment Group was founded in 1932 as Western Fiction Publishing producing pulp magazines. Marvel Comics was added in 1939. "The comic book as we know it today," he explained in an interview, "is a hybrid of two late-19th-century forms -- the newspaper comic strip and the pulp magazine. In the late 20's, comic strips adapted some of this matter, and in the late 1930's, pulp fiction was adapted into comic books with the creation of their first superheroes."
Among the early 30's material in Sotheby's auction is a rare copy of the first comic book, "Funnies on Parade," a 1932 reprint of newspaper comic strips that is estimated to sell for $3,000 to $4,000.
Jerry Weist, a consultant to Sotheby's on the comic-book sale, is an owner of Boston's oldest comic-book store, the Million Year Picnic. According to him, collecting in the 1980's increased the prices for the rarest and most popular comic books.
"When we opened our store in 1974, an average copy of Action 1 would have gone for about $400," he said. "Today a good copy is $6,000 to $7,000, and one in near mint condition is $55,000 and up. No mint copy of Action 1 has been found."
At Sparkle City Comics, a mail-order concern in Glassboro, N.J., Joseph H. Vereneault, one of the owners, said sales of comic books dating from 1938 to 1975 are holding firm, even in the recession. "Oddly enough, at least at our end of the market, there has been no decline," he said. "In fact, there's been enormous increase." The biggest growth, he added, is to collectors overseas, primarily in Europe. This year the company anticipates sales of $500,000, up from $3,500 in 1976 when it first opened its doors.
"There are hundreds of comic-book shows all over the country each weekend," Mr. Vereneault pointed out. "Some comic books sell between $1,000 and $5,000. Others may be as high as $50,000. But comic books are still a collectible for the masses -- there are thousands and thousands of vintage ones to be had at 12 cents a copy."

HEADLINE: Home Buyers Holding Off Despite Low Interest Rates

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
DESPITE a steep decline in interest rates that has brought fixed 30-year mortgage loans to below 9 percent for the first time since 1977, home buyers are holding back across most of the nation in what experts say are stubborn fears that job cuts and other recessionary pressures will persist.
One area of relative strength, according to several studies, is the Northeast, including New York and its suburbs, which were hit first and hardest by the current housing slump, beginning in 1988. Home resales in the region increased suddenly in the spring and have continued since, although prices have continued to weaken. 
 Elsewhere in the nation, home sales have declined steadily at the very time that interest rates have dropped most sharply.
"Lower interest rates help, but the real problem now is consumer confidence," said Gopal Ahluwalia, research director for the National Association of Home Builders, a Washington trade group.
Home resales, which rose in March, April and May in what analysts described as a burst of optimistic buying after the Persian Gulf war, have fallen each month since then. The decline, amounting to a 10 percent reduction in monthly sales from June to August, the most recent month for which data are available, came while mortgage interest rates were falling a steep 0.4 of a percentage point.
New construction, as measured by the number of housing starts, has plummeted to its lowest level since 1982, when rates soared past 17.5 percent. For all of 1991, construction is likely to be at its lowest since 1945, Mr. Ahluwalia said.
To be sure, the lower rates are influencing the decisions of many home buyers. The strongest segment of the market, particularly in the Northeast, is in homes within reach of low-end, first-time buyers, who are taking advantage of low rates and steeply discounted prices.
But overall, the enthusiasm that infused the housing market during the spring has cooled, and those who had hoped reduced interest rates would reignite it have so far been disappointed.
So, too, have a large number of economists and business executives who hoped a rebounding housing market would emerge as a key engine driving the nation out of recession.
Now, they say, other segments of the economy are proving too weak to support improved demand for homes.
"The main thing people are worried about is the broad outlook for the economy, and they are not willing to commit themselves to the most important investment they will ever make," said Thomas Halloway, senior economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
Analysts say that demand for housing continues to build, even as many would-be buyers remain firmly on the sidelines. In one study, the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University found that only 36 percent of Americans 25 to 29 years old, and 51 percent of those 30 to 34 years old, owned homes.
Those rates of homeownership among people in the prime years of marriage and childbirth are far lower than a decade ago. They account for the relatively high current demand among first-time buyers and suggest that many more are poised to buy when the economy or their personal finances improve.
Other constraints may be at work. One is the more stringent lending requirements imposed by banks and thrift institutions since the savings-and-loan crisis began to unfold.
Where home buyers of the late 1980's were often able to get 90 percent financing with little documentation of their incomes, lenders now typically will not finance more than 80 percent of a home purchase. They also adhere more strictly to rules that limit mortgage payments to 28 percent of a buyer's gross monthly income and require voluminous documentation of employment histories, tax returns and assets.
"The only people who get a loan are those who can prove they don't need it," said Monte Helm, a spokesman for the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation, paraphrasing a line made famous by Will Rogers during the Depression of the 1930's.
Yet another drag on the housing market is reflected in a time-tested rule of buyer psychology. While interest rates are heading down, the rule goes, people wait, but at the first signs that rates have bottomed out and are beginning to rebound, they flock into the market.
"USUALLY the market bursts open just at the point when rates begin to trend up," said John Tucillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors.
He predicted that rates would continue declining gradually until next spring, when they will reach 8.5 percent on 30-year fixed mortgages, and housing demand would then rebound.
But until then, he said, the market across most of the nation remains mired in recessionary worries.
The relatively strong demand among first-time buyers in the Northeast is reflected in a study by Century 21, which franchises real estate agencies across the nation from its headquarters in Irvine, Calif.
It found that 52 percent of the 1990 home sales in six Northeastern states -- New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Maryland, Rhode Island and Massachusetts -- were made to first-time buyers.
Nationally, it said, first-time buyers accounted for only 38 percent of the purchases, roughly the same as during the previous six years.
Although no comparable analysis is available for 1991, real estate executives say that first-time buyers have continued to lead what they call the early stages of a broad recovery in home sales in the Northeast.
"The decline in rates made all the difference to me," said one first-time buyer, Marsha Champlin, a toy designer in Brooklyn who last month contracted to buy a three-story, two-family, 19th-century Federal style house in Park Slope for $210,000. The price was less than half the $460,000 originally asked in 1988, and 30 percent below the $299,000 that was asked when she first looked at the house in May.
Despite the huge price decline, however, she said, she could not have afforded the house without qualifying for a loan at below 9 percent interest.
Mortgage rates across the nation began falling rapidly a year ago, when they averaged 10.18 percent, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. After fluctuating during the first half of 1991, they stood at 9.62 percent in June, and had fallen to 9.01 by September.
Rates have continued declining in recent weeks, falling below 9 percent across the nation. Analysts say they expect continued declines until at least next spring, with fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages falling to 8.5 percent or perhaps lower.
Already, after steep declines in September and the first two weeks of October, the rate in the New York area is approaching 8.5 percent.
According to one mortgage broker in New York City and its suburbs, the Manhattan Mortgage Company, which compared rates at 10 of the region's lending institutions, fixed 30-year mortgages are now available at as low at 8.62 percent interest for one-family homes and condominiums and 8.87 percent for co-op apartments.
A decline of only one percentage point in interest rates can make a large difference in a homeowner's costs.
For example, Manhattan Mortgage said monthly payments for $100,000 in financing at its best current rate of 8.62 percent would be $777.79. In contrast, it said, its best rate as recently as August was a point higher, 9.62 percent. At that rate, monthly costs on $100,000 in financing were more than $70 higher, $849.99.
The combination of lower rates and deep reductions in home prices -- they are down 20 percent to more than 40 percent across the region -- mean that homeownership "is the most affordable it has been in years," said Ellen Feldschriber, a partner in Manhattan Mortgage.
The improvement is documented in an affordability index, which is calculated by the National Association of Realtors. With a median income of $36,533 in August -- and a median house price of $144,400 -- it said that people making the median income in the Northeast had an index reading of 93.5, or 93.5 percent of what was needed to buy a median-price house.
THAT meant the region remained more expensive than the country as a whole, where the August affordability index was 112.5. But while the nationwide index had declined since February, it had continued a period of rapid improvement in the Northeast. In August 1989, the Northeast index was at 68.9, the group said.
Analysts say the rapid gain in affordability accounts for the relative strength of home sales in the Northeast and should invigorate sales further as more first-time buyers come into the market and more people who sell their current homes move on to others.
In Connecticut, brokers report a rapid increase in sales volume since August but say the rise was largely among first-time, low-end buyers.
One large real estate concern, the William Pitt Agency, based in Stamford, said that in the first two weeks in October its Danbury office had 18 sales contracts signed, only one of them for a house priced over $145,000, and its office in Norwalk sold 26 homes, more than half to first-time buyers.
The Westchester County Board of Realtors said last week that its sales in the third quarter of 1991 had been higher -- both in the number of sales and the total dollar volume -- than in any quarter since it started keeping records in 1981.
The group said the largest number of sales were among homes priced between $200,000 and $300,000, which in most of Westchester's affluent suburban communities are at the low end of the price spectrum.
DESPITE the strong sales, however, recessionary worries have not bypassed Westchester.
"I'm seeing many buyers with one eye on the real estate market and another eye on their job security," said Merritt Mitchell, president of the Westchester Multiple Listing Service.
"We'll need broad economic recovery here to nail down the recent gains in residential real estate activity."
In another study of home sales in New York and New Jersey, Rae Rosen, an economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, found that resales, which had been declining steadily in both states from the end of 1987 to the end of 1990, have since begun a rapid rebound, particularly in New Jersey.
New Jersey sales, which last year reached their lowest point since 1982, have come back to their 1985 level, she said. In New York, where the decline was less steep, the recovery has been more gradual, she added.
Overall, "there is certainly no dearth of home sales" in the two states, she said. "Although national housing starts and existing home sales are anemic, the regional housing recovery has been comparatively robust."
Whether demand continues to strengthen in the region, and the recovery expands to the rest of the nation, now depends more on improvement in other sectors of the economy than on whether interest rates remain low or fall further.
"In previous periods when interest rate declines have prompted housing recoveries, other fundamentals in the economy were improving as well," said Mr. Halloway of the Mortgage Bankers Association.
"Now the key issue is that we have a lack of strong economic growth, and if consumers are worried about their jobs they will not buy homes."
