HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Nonprofit Tenants;
Wall Street Tower as a Site for a Service Association

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
MAYOR David N. Dinkins made it plain to his economic development team that this was to be a priority. Happily for them, Larry A. Silverstein offered up to 400,000 square feet in a Wall Street building with East River views, pledging a year's free rent, among other concessions.
One might think they were focused on some huge financial institution. Instead, they were trying to create a home for relatively small tenants, each of whom might need only 10,000 to 20,000 square feet: the nonprofit charitable organizations or trade associations that can no longer afford Manhattan. 
 Nonprofit tenants are big news these days. "They are very active," said Douglas Durst, whose family owns 733 Third Avenue, at 46th Street, one-fifth of which is now occupied by nonprofit tenants. "They are less affected, in terms of space needs, by the current economy. So while you see many businesses afraid to make a commitment, nonprofits don't have the same concerns."
The National Multiple Sclerosis Society recently signed a 15-year lease for 37,133 square feet at No. 733, where it will have its headquarters. Mr. Durst said the rent would be in the mid-$20's. The society is leaving the Durst Organization's 205 East 42d Street.
"We did look into the boroughs and we did investigate all the areas of Manhattan," said Mitchell S. Steir, senior managing director of Julien J. Studley, which represented the society. "What we were ultimately able to achieve was a competitive transaction in midtown, which was the location of choice."
The society is to move into No. 733 by the end of the year. It will be joined a month or so later by the American Foundation for AIDS Research (Amfar), now at 1515 Broadway, which has signed a 10-year lease for 16,000 square feet, in the mid-$20's. The Leukemia Society, which has been in the building since 1984, has 15,000 square feet.
In another recent development, Newmark & Company Real Estate announced that 305 Seventh Avenue, a 20-story building on 27th Street that is about 40 percent vacant, would be converted into 45 commercial condominium units, specifically targeting nonprofit purchasers. (Property that is owned and occupied by certain charitable organizations is not subject to real-estate taxes.)
And an all-day conference, "Nonprofits and Real Estate Opportunities," is to be convened Nov. 22 at the New School for Social Research, 6 West 12th Street, under the sponsorship of Studley and the city.
The biggest milestone this year was the announcement two weeks ago that 20 floors of Mr. Silverstein's 34-story tower at 120 Wall Street were to be set aside as an Association Center, for use as headquarters by national and international nonprofit groups that could easily leave New York. Prospective occupants will have the choice of renting space, at less than $20 a square foot, or buying it, for roughly $120 a square foot. Nominal title to Association Center space will be held by the city's Industrial Development Agency, which will remove it from property tax rolls and also allow for the use of bonds issued by the agency to finance tenant improvements.
City officials realized how urgent the situation had become when they almost lost the headquarters of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. earlier this year. "The Girl Scouts were really a watershed because we learned how much caring about nonprofits mattered," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
The Dinkins administration requested proposals from commercial owners in lower Manhattan who had up to 400,000 square feet available for an Association Center.
"We had a preference for downtown," Mr. Weisbrod said, "because we felt that the price would be better and we thought that the injection of a nonprofit community would add to the marketability of downtown generally, which is under severe economic pressure."
RESPONSES came from the owners of 13 buildings. Ten were south of Fulton Street, two were between Fulton and Canal Streets and one was around Cooper Square. Because of the implication that these buildings are in distress, city officials declined to identify them.
Mr. Silverstein's offer had a "combination of strengths," Mr. Weisbrod said. "It was very flexible about selling or leasing. It had the most attractive price to tenants. It had a central core and only one row of columns between windows and the core. The building was in very, very good condition. It had the best shared-facilities plan. It had a great location and great views."
The building was completed in 1930 to designs by Buchman & Kahn. Mr. Silverstein purchased it in 1980 for a price that was reported as $12 million, then spent what he said were "tens of millions" on its renovation. In the mid to late 80's, vacancy in the 615,000-square-foot structure was less than 5 percent. Today, it is approaching 40 percent.
An attempt to discuss the fate of 120 Wall Street in the context of Mr. Silverstein's fortunes generally was rebuffed when the developer declined to be interviewed. He did, however, respond to written questions submitted through Howard J. Rubenstein Associates, a public-relations firm.
Concerning a number of the biggest projects in which he has an interest -- none of which he has lost or intends to sell, he said -- Mr. Silverstein reported the following:
At Park Avenue Court, Lexington Avenue and 87th Street, "approximately half" of the 222 apartments have been sold. At A & S Plaza, on Broadway, between 32d and 33d Streets, "better than 75 percent" of the retail space has been leased. In the Childrenswear Center atop A & S Plaza, "approximately two-thirds" of the showroom and office space has been leased. At Seven World Trade Center, about 80 percent of the office space has been leased. Among his older properties, the enormous Equitable Building, 120 Broadway, is about 75 percent leased.
About the financial status of 120 Wall Street, Mr. Silverstein said operating expenses were about $6 a square foot and taxes about $5. He said he is current in his mortgage payments to Bankers Trust, but did not disclose the amount, and added that the bank had approved the Association Center plan.
As part of the Association Center announcement Oct. 16, Mayor Dinkins was quoted in a press release as saying that "no other city has set up this kind of facility to foster" the nonprofit industry.
The administrative director of the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments, Stephen B. Borko, took exception to that. "The Mayor of New York should know that his city is not the first or only to work with nonprofits," he said. "The city of Washington started working on this in 1986."
At the time, the council was facing rents on I Street that it could not afford. Instead of leasing new space, however, it formed a partnership with the International City/ County Management Association and the I.C.M.A. Retirement Corporation.
From Washington's Redevelopment Land Agency, they purchased a site on North Capitol Street, between H Street and G Place, near Union Station, which was then under reconstruction. The $1 million price was about 75 percent of appraised value. The partners also received a 10-year abatement of property taxes from the City Council.
The first phase was a nine-story structure with 212,000 square feet, developed by Quadrangle Development Corporation. Construction was financed with a $31.35 million loan from the First American Bank.
It opened last year and is now fully rented, he said. A second phase is being developed in partnership with the American Psychological Association, Mr. Borko said, and has already signed up the National Association of Social Workers as a tenant.
"The city validated an entire area it wanted to get built up," Mr. Borko said. "Associations that wanted to move to the suburbs are not moving to the suburbs. It's one of those rare instances where everybody won."

HEADLINE: Perspectives: The Planner in Jamaica;
Carrying the Torch for Downtown Growth

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
WITH a few swift pen strokes on a paper napkin at Wendy's on Jamaica Avenue in Queens last week, Carlisle Towery demonstrated how competing retailing hubs have carved up downtown Jamaica's historic trading region.
First came the Roosevelt Field and Green Acres malls in Nassau County (two big circles representing trading areas, menacingly encompassing sections of eastern Queens). Then Kings Plaza in Brooklyn (encircling eastern Brooklyn, with a partial incursion into Queens). Finally, Queens Center in Rego Park (another circle, lopping off much of northern Queens). 
 The malls did in Jamaica as a regional retailing center, says Mr. Towery, a planner who is observing his 20th year as executive director of the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation this year. But Jamaica has fought back.
Mainly it has primed the pump for economic revival with public investment. The biggest elements were a new campus for York College of the City University system, which opened in 1986; the long-delayed subway extension to Jamaica's downtown, now named Jamaica Center, which opened in 1989, and a new million-square-foot office building for the Social Security Administration's regional headquarters. It too opened in 1989.
"We have reached the point in the early 90's where a lot of little things and big things have been done," said Mr. Towery with the barest trace of an Alabama drawl. "That has primed the pump. We have reached the level that really can attract development."
Jamaica has the sites. It is a Long Island Rail Road hub. The subway now runs directly into its vital center. It has devoted boosters in government and the private world.
It also has Carlisle Towery. In New York City, no other professional architect-planner comes to mind who has devoted so many years to the revival of a single community, trying to fulfill a master-plan vision that the Regional Plan Association set forth in the late 60's. As a Regional Plan staff member Mr. Towery was project director of the Jamaica Center development plan. The Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, founded by local business leaders, hired him in 1971 to carry it forward.
The 55-year-old son of politically liberal Southerners, he grew up in Montevillo, Ala., a Birmingham suburb, studied architecture at Auburn University, in Auburn, Ala., and came to the architecture graduate program at Columbia to specialize in urban design. It was a time when the funds for redesigning downtowns were flowing. Mr. Towery worked on a plan for Dallas that the Murchison family funded, and wrote a master's thesis on redesigning 125th Street in Harlem.
In the late 60's The Long Island Press was still alive and publishing in Jamaica. Its editor, David Starr, was a Jamaica booster. So was Vincent M. Albanese, then president of the Chamber of Commerce and now an Urban Development Corporation board member. So were Joseph P. McMurray, a Jamaica native and president of Queens College, and Lawrence Cormier, who headed Ebony Oil, a Jamaica company.
THEY and Stanley Gertz, grandson of the Gertz department store's founder, invited Mr. Towery to head the development corporation. But no planning efforts were able to stave off the setbacks of the 70's and 80's. The Ideal Toy Company moved to New Jersey at a cost of several hundred jobs. The Long Island Press folded. Jamaica Savings Bank moved its headquarters to Lynbrook, L.I. Macy's closed its Jamaica store and in 1981 the big Gertz store closed.
"We took our hits," Mr. Towery said. "We survived those hits, I think because we had a plan and a public commitment and people could see that there was a future. And there was public consensus. York had a galvanizing effect on all constituent groups out here."
But the industrial employment level in the area, which had reached 10,000 jobs in the late 70's, had fallen to 5,400 by 1983. On the commercial front there were 1,400 job losses in the Macy's and Gertz closings alone.
Now industrial employment is back to 7,200, thanks in good part to employment in food-processing and distribution businesses. There are 2,800 jobs in the new Federal office building, and the conversion of the Gertz store to an office complex has produced 2,000 jobs. Total current employment in Jamaica is about 25,000, Mr. Towery says.
The Jamaica Avenue el has come down, public parking garages have been built, two hospitals have grown, the centrally located 11-acre King Park has been rebuilt, and with the development corporation's help local businesses have established two special assessment districts, one on 165th Street and another on Jamaica Avenue.
The question is, will private development follow the public investment?
IN the middle 80's it seemed about to happen. The Mack Corporation, a major New Jersey development company, undertook to develop a vacant site at Archer Avenue and Parsons Boulevard, across the street from the site on which the Federal office was built. But relations with the city's Public Development Corporation, now the Economic Development Corporation, broke down. The P.D.C. felt that Mack was stalling in the negotiations on the final terms of the land lease.
To the dismay of Mr. Towery, Mack was dedesignated as the site's developer. Mack had expected to build a 440,000-square-foot speculative office building, and swallowed with bitterness the loss of its significant investment in predevelopment work. The vacant Jamaica site and others nearby would seem to be ideal back-office locations. The former Mack land is fully cleared, on top of the Jamaica Center subway stop and zoned for a 440,000-square-foot building. A second site, also cleared, is zoned for 490,000 square feet. Mr. Towery believes both could logically accommodate greater bulk if the user needed it.
So far, private investment has focused on rehabilitating existing buildings. The development corporation itself has been one of the investors. Fred Trump, founder of the Trump Organization, once had his office in an eight-story, 55,000-square-foot building at 90-04 161st Street. He donated it to the development corporation in 1980. Now its 25-person staff occupies a floor, and other floors have been upgraded and rented out. Mortgages came from the Equitable Life and Crossland Savings Bank.
THE corporation has gone on to rehabilitate a three-story firehouse on 162d Street on a 50-year lease from New York City. A child-guidance firm is on the upper floors and a Sizzler restaurant on the ground level. National Westminster Bank supplied the financing.
The biggest rehabilitation has been done by the Gertz family at the former department store. It created about 400,000 square feet, occupied by state and city offices. There are two floors of retail space below.
Downtown Jamaica's largest current commercial project is neither big nor small, but medium-sized. This is a new Farmer's Market, in a permanent enclosed structure that is far advanced in construction on 160th Street half a block from Jamaica Avenue. Starting next spring farmers from afar will transport their produce to this 26,000-square-foot building at least three days a week, and perhaps six. Besides the selling in 16 stalls for farmers and plant growers, there will be food stores for on-premises consumption, and on a second level, 5,000 square feet for offices.
It is a $5 million development project, financed half by public grants and half by loans from the Equitable and the Urban Development Corporation. It will be owned and operated by the development corporation, which has run Jamaica's active open-air market for 15 years.
"Food and food-related businesses are our niche in the industrial field," said Mr. Towery. Continental Baking employs 500 people in Jamaica; Elmhurst Dairy/Honeywell Farms operates a milk-processing plant on Liberty Avenue that also employs 500.
The community's basic asset is its strategic position in the regional transportation network, with nine Long Island Rail Road lines converging there. The latest idea, by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, is to strengthen its role as a hub by establishing a direct train link to John F. Kennedy Airport.
"Our bottom line is jobs," Mr. Towery said. "Everything we've done has been aimed at priming Jamaica for substantial growth as an employment center."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carlisle Towery of Greater Jamaica Development Corporation has devoted decades to vitality of Queens area. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

M.C.I. Increase
 
Question: I have received a bill from my landlord for a retroactive major capital improvement increase for an 18-month period from February of 1989 until February of 1990, when I purchased my apartment after the building's conversion to a co-op. Do I have to pay a bill for a rent increase in an apartment where I am no longer a tenant? . . . Howard Hill, Brooklyn
 
Answer: Yes. According to Joseph D'Agosta, a deputy commissioner for the State Department of Housing and Community Renewal, a tenant is responsible for retroactive rent increases, even if he is no longer a tenant. The exception, Mr. D'Agosta said, would be if there was a provision of the offering plan in a conversion that absolved the purchaser of this debt.
"Even tenants who vacate the apartments are technically liable for the retroactive M.C.I. increase," said Mr. D'Agosta, "but because most increases are not that large, most owners do not bother with trying to collect once a tenant has moved away."
 
Liability for a Driveway
 
Question: I own a home that shares a driveway with other homes. It needs to be repaired, but not all homeowners want to contribute to the cost. If someone is injured because of its broken concrete, would all homeowners be liable, or would only the owner of the property in front of the section where the accident occurred be held responsible? . . . Barry Bloch, Flushing, Queens
 
Answer: All homeowners would be liable in case of an accident. According to Brook Boyd, an attorney with the firm of Herrick, Feinstein who specializes in real estate matters, all owners may be liable for accidents caused by driveway defects. "If one owner is sued," said Mr. Boyd, "the other owners are typically required to share the cost of judgment."
Anyone entitled to use the driveway, Mr. Boyd said, is required, in the absence of any agreement to the contrary, to share in the cost of maintaining it. Owners who use the driveway but fail to share these costs could be sued by others who do.
 
Liability for a Lease
 
Question: I live in a co-op building. Our board of directors allows owners to take tenants under some circumstances and charges them a $100-a-month sublet fee. We now have a situation in which one owner has moved away and has turned the apartment over to his brother. This was done with board approval. To help with the maintenance charge, the brother of the shareholder has taken a roommate.
Some shareholders have suggested that we charge the sublet fee. Does the board have the authority to do this? . . . Joseph A. Gisler, Woodside, Queens
 
Answer Maybe. But it would depend on the terms of the proprietary lease.
According the Marc Luxemberg, an attorney who specializes in real estate matters and who is a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, most leases include language that stipulates which relatives of shareholders have occupancy rights. Typically, Mr. Luxemberg said, it would be spouses, children, parents, grandparents and brothers and sisters of the named tenant on the proprietary lease.
Mr. Luxemberg said that the exact wording of this type of clause is important. "If the lease says the shareholder or his or her brother or other relatives have occupancy rights," he said, "then this situation described would not be a sublet. But if the lease granted occupancy rights to shareholder and his siblings, then that would mean that the named party would also have to be in residence for the arrangement not be be a violation of the lease terms."
If the lease does not allow the brother to live in the apartment without the named tenant, then the board would have the right to demand a sublet fee. But this would be paid by the shareholder, not his brother.
The board would have the right to cancel the shareholder's proprietary lease and occupancy rights if the fee is not paid.

HEADLINE: Radio Station Offers Everything But Consistency

DATELINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
NEARLY 22 years ago Bill Nolan was cruising down Interstate 95 in his apple-red Mustang flipping the radio knob and searching for the answer to his prayers. Mr. Nolan's passion was 50's rock and roll, which at the time had all but faded from the American memory, he said. As a record collector and devotee of music from the early-rock era, he said, he knew he could help spark new interest in it if only he could find a station that would allow him to broadcast his message. After switching to 89.5 on the FM dial, WPKN at the University of Bridgeport, Mr. Nolan said, he knew his search had ended.
"I remember they were playing some pretty hot acid rock," he said, "real controversial, pre-Woodstock stuff that the commercial stations wouldn't touch." 
 Soon after, Mr. Nolan, who works for the Ansonia Copper and Brass Corporation, became the station's first volunteer program host with a Sunday evening program called "Antique Blues." Using his record collection, he sought to educate as much as entertain, he said. By the mid-1970's "Antique Blues" had attracted a faithful audience, and Mr. Nolan founded an organization for lovers of rhythm-and-blues music, the R. & B. Society, which he called the first group in the country devoted to promoting rock and roll. The society now has 50,000 members worldwide, he said.
 
'Hobgoblin of Little Minds'
 Mr. Nolan's debut also changed the character of WPKN, which had been a training ground for broadcasting students. Now operated by 120 volunteers with a drive to promote music and points of view not often covered by the commercial media, WPKN has built its reputation on its eclectic and often unpredictable approach, said the station manager, Harry Minot.
"Ralph Waldo Emerson once said, 'A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds,' " said Mr. Minot, the station's only paid employee. "Here at WPKN we have made it a point to take our listeners down roads they normally wouldn't travel."
Two years ago when the university, faced with mounting financial problems, cut the station's $90,000 budget, WPKN's listeners came to its rescue. With the help of its staff and more than 150 more volunteers, the station raised $100,000 during a monthlong on-the-air fund-raising campaign that has since become an annual event held each October. As part of its independent status, said Mr. Minot, WPKN has become the only listener-supported radio station in New England, and perhaps the country, that accepts no program underwriting, commercial advertising, grants or membership dues. He added that WPKN's transition to self-supporting status has unified the station and brought its personalities closer to their listeners, who often drop by for coffee, attend monthly meetings and come on the air to oppose the views expressed in commentaries.
"We've never abandoned our commitment to the community," said Mr. Minot, who estimated that the station had an audience of more than 30,000. "And I think that's why our listeners feel a great responsibility to keep the station and its message alive." Like a number of the station's 65 staff members, Mr. Minot said he started as a volunteer in the early 1970's after working in commercial radio. Mr. Minot, who was a disk jockey on a commercial station in Danbury, recalled tuning to WPKN for the first time and hearing Ray Terlaga, whose specialty is international music and readings of scientific news stories and prose.
"I had always been programmed to be up and bubbly and uncontroversial on the air, no matter what," said Mr. Minot. "Then I found myself listening to this guy who was talking very freely about how depressed he was, in between poetry readings of Armand Rauband, who committed suicide, and I thought, 'Now here's a station that does not compromise its artistic integrity.' "
One of WPKN's best assets, say staff members and listeners, is its relaxed, non sequitur style. Programs segue from Latin jazz, classical music, rockabilly and Cajun zydeco to discussions on topics like catching bluefish, art events, natural hygiene and prison issues.
"There's probably many listeners who may not like all of what goes on at the station but who listen anyway, to find out what happens next," said Cliff Furnald, a freelance writer and musician whose Monday afternoon program offers music from around the world. "I mean, where else are you going to hear Bulgarian electronic experimental music, unless some character gets on the air and plays it?"
Rod Ross, who has been as an announcer at WPKN since the early 1970's and has worked at stations in New York and Connecticut, started volunteering at WPKN 15 years ago. His program, which is heard twice a month on Saturdays, includes occasional journeys into the marine life and fishermen's lore of Long Island Sound. "The station's genuine and honest approach gave me a totally new insight into radio," he said. "Not only does it introduce you to various types of music, at its heart WPKN is a complete social structure where your listeners become your friends."
Mr. Ross's mother, Ruth Lampland Ross, a longtime arts reviewer in Fairfield County, is 84 years old and the oldest member of the station staff. She augments her roundup of the region's cultural events with personal reminiscences.
The 10,000-watt station first went on the air in the early 60's and now broadcasts to most of Connecticut, Long Island and parts of Massachusetts and Rhode Island. In those days, like many college radio stations, it trained students who would later pursue work in commercial radio. Yet when Mr. Nolan and other community announcers came on board, they began charting new ground.
Mr. Nolan recalled scouting black churches in New Haven, Hartford and Bridgeport for gospel groups to perform live on his program in the 1970's. "Some of these people had sung together for 40 years," he said, "and I can tell you that there isn't anything like gospel music performed on the air live. It just knocked us out."
He started the R. & B. Society after an on-the-air round-table discussion with 20 listeners on the social and cultural impact of rock and roll, he said. Over the years, he said, his organization has lobbied the music industry to promote dozens of American blues artists like Johnny Copeland and Memphis Slim, whose careers had been stymied by the British rock movement of the 1960's and 1970's.
In between music sets, Mr. Nolan embellishes the records he plays with anecdotes about the artists and their contribution to American music and often refers to his listeners as cats and kittens. Over the harmonies of the Hollywood Flames singing "Ride, Helen, Ride," Mr. Nolan told his audience recently: "Yessiree, rock and roll, just as fresh today as it was 30 years ago. It changed the social life for me and for you. Lest we never forget it."
As a student at the university in the 1970's Ruth Eddy found that listening to "Antique Blues" inspired her to create her own style of radio show, which she described recently as a spontaneous rendering of what's on her mind. "My philosophy is based more on what stirs the heart," said Ms. Eddy, now a massage therapist. "Often my programs reflect where I am in my life."
Her theme song, "Everything Reminds Me Of My Dog," by Jane Siberry, a folk artist, opens her Thursday afternoon program. While Ms. Eddy conducts interviews, reads essays, plays music or discusses health issues, her two dogs, Lucy Carmichael and Fred Mertz, snooze at her feet.
"I don't refer to them as my pets," she tells her listeners. "Rather, I'm their human companion."
 
Robust Opinions
 Since the late 1970's the station has also offered a range of public affairs programs that have included forums and listener call-ins on the Vietnam War, the civil rights movement, nuclear power plants, United States policies in Central America and, most recently, the Persian Gulf war. The public affairs coordinator, Scott Harris, a pretrial intervention counselor for Norwalk Economic Opportunity Now, said the station is planning to hold a forum on urban problems later this fall and has invited the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Jack Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, to participate.
To have their own programs, volunteers must have Federal Communications Commission operator's licenses and go through a training session at the studio before presenting an audition tape, Mr. Minot said. If approved, the volunteers often fill in for colleagues until a slot opens. In general, he added, those who audition are musically sophisticated and hold robust opinions.
"There's no question that the personalities WPKN attracts are anything but dull," he said.

HEADLINE: Stamford, Hoping for Growth, Chooses a Mayor

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
WHOEVER is elected mayor of Stamford on Nov. 5, the road ahead is clearly marked: the city will try to attract more offices, more jobs, more growth. Stamford has followed the same road for the last 20 years, as it shook free from its fading factories along Interstate 95 and remade its economy in the image of the white-collar suburban neighborhoods that spread north for miles, in ascending lot size, to the Westchester line.
What promises to be different now is the speed of change, as Stamford competes with cities across the country to fill its empty office buildings, and the mayor's style, as the incumbent, Thom Serrani, departs after four two-year terms. 
 Both the Democratic candidate, Sandra Goldstein, president of the city's Board of Representatives for the past 10 years, and the Republican, Stanley Esposito, a member of the board for six years, say it is past time for Stamford to promote itself aggressively. "The city that is today is different from the city that was 10 years ago," Mrs. Goldstein, a 49-year-old real estate agent, said in an interview. "That is because the entire Northeast is experiencing a recession. But the one mistake we can make is to sit on our hands during times of recession and not plan for the future." Mr. Esposito, 43, a property manager, said, "We need that economic shot in the arm." Differing little on their goal of spurring more economic growth, Mrs. Goldstein and Mr. Esposito have battled mainly over their qualifications and Mr. Serrani's record. Both issues raise questions about Stamford's government and how well suited it is to manage the unusually varied community within the city's 38 square miles: part ghettos, part middle-class and upper-class suburbs, and part regional business center.
Mr. Serrani, a 44-year-old Democrat who has frequently fought with the city's elected boards, acknowledges his growing frustration with the limited powers of his office, especially as the recession has ended the steady growth of the city's tax rolls and made governing a matter of cutting services rather than adding them. "What you have is a nighttime government of experts, who get elected and by virtue of getting elected become instant experts, coming in once a month to sit at a board meeting," Mr. Serrani said of the 40-member Board of Representatives, one of the largest city councils in the country. "And then you get the daytime government that sees how government is operating on a daily basis."
The 40-member board dates from 1949, when the rural part of Stamford north of the Bull's Head section was consolidated, against its wishes, with the city. To give the unhappy north more voice on the board, the charter called for two representatives from each of 20 districts. It also weakened the mayor's powers.
The accommodation with now-suburban North Stamford, which still rumbles occasionally with talk of secession, created a structure that Mr. Serrani says is outdated. He recommends a strong four-year mayor and a 15-member council, with 10 members elected from districts and 5 elected at large as a finance committee that would take the place of the separate Board of Finance.
"If you're going to have a mayor, give him power," Mr. Serrani said. "If we're electing mayors just to go to social events, then have a city manager. Someone's got to run this operation every day."
But Mr. Serrani's impatience with the elected boards, with labor unions and with other groups in the city often seemed to be another side of a Mayor who thought he could do it all, from negotiating labor contracts to recruiting new corporate tenants. While business leaders give him credit for managing the city well and making tough decisions that kept property-tax increases low and preserved the city's triple-A bond rating, there is also a feeling that the administration has been too isolated to take full advantage of the help many corporations are eager to offer.
 
'He Participated'
 "The business community is looking for a city government that would work with it better, use it better," said David E. Anderson, president of the Stamford Partnership, a coalition of business, community and government leaders formed in 1978 to help the city plan for its future.
"Thom Serrani was a very effective Mayor for the Stamford Partnership for much of his tenure. He participated. He was the draw. But he didn't use it as much as he could have. I think he was unnecessarily distant from the business community."
In the campaign Mrs. Goldstein, a Democrat like Mr. Serrani, is the Mayor's chief critic, while Mr. Esposito, the Republican, tends to defend him, especially on budget issues.
"Whether you agree with him or disagree with him," Mr. Esposito said, "he was forced to make some really hard decisions. We're all adults. You have to respect a guy who's willing to put his money where his mouth is."
Mr. Serrani suggests that Mrs. Goldstein and other Democrats with ambitions caused many of his confrontations with the elected boards in his last term. Mrs. Goldstein, who takes credit for organizing her unwieldy board's committees to streamline its work, says the problem is not the form of government but people's willingness to work within it.
Stamford has a weak-mayor form of government, she said, but in practice only the mayor can propose spending, and he has the power to appoint all other boards and commissions. Mr. Serrani, like his Republican predecessor, Louis Clapes, has not acted like a weak mayor, she said.
 
Experience Cited
 "Your strongest time with Thom as Mayor, and Lou Clapes as Mayor, was when they took the time to bring the boards into the process," Mrs. Goldstein said. "Because our charter requires so much board approval, it's when you decide to do it alone and act in a vacuum that the system breaks down. You can't act in a vacuum in our form of government."
Mrs. Goldstein, given her experience directing the Board of Representatives, says she is the person best equipped to work within the existing structure and draw in the expertise and aid of the business community.
She has pledged to start a professional development program, with a committee that would find companies to recruit. And she has criticized many of Mr. Serrani's service cuts and layoffs, saying that some cost the city more than they saved, and that others would have been unnecessary if the city were managed better.
Mr. Esposito, she says, lacks any experience directing a government department.
Mr. Esposito, running in a Democratic city where his party holds only 10 of the 40 seats on the Board of Representatives, says he wants to work through the Stamford Partnership to encourage more corporations to choose the city.
He says his years on the board have earned him the respect he needs from other representatives to be effective. And spending must be tightly controlled, he says, to keep property taxes from driving more middle-class families out of the city.
"If you want to see some of the people I graduated from high school with," Mr. Esposito said, "you have only to look at the exit ramps of the Connecticut Turnpike first thing in the morning, or see them again on the entrance ramps at 5 o'clock. They've moved farther away, because they couldn't afford to live here."
 
'Almost Made It'
 The new mayor will take over at a time when overbuilding has left 25 percent of Stamford's office space vacant. Yet to secure its gains, the city needs to fill in and complete its downtown.
Planners say there is no question that Stamford, with its concentration of businesses and services, is marked for more growth. But the next phase will take much more planning and effort, they say, partly because competition has intensified, but also because Stamford needs to attract companies to its downtown. It will be competing as a city, rather than a suburban refuge.
"Here's a place that's almost made it," said Richard Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan. "With such a place during recession, the question is: What do you do to prepare for the next phase of economic development?
"The new mayor is building on success. That can be more difficult than the challenge Thom Serrani and his predecessors faced."

HEADLINE: County Uses New Tactic On Criminals' Unpaid Fines

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AN aggressive new effort by Hudson County officials to collect millions of dollars in outstanding criminal fines and penalties is being viewed as a potential model for similar programs that could be used on a statewide basis.
The program, through which officials collect delinquent fines by placing liens on property, garnishing wages, suspending drivers' licenses and seizing state tax refunds, is seen as an effective, efficient way of collecting overdue fines from recalcitrant offenders. 
 Collecting fines by such methods, officials say, is a more sensible alternative to imprisoning offenders for nonpayment and will prevent criminal deadbeats from ignoring their financial obligations by taking advantage of inherent inefficiencies in the present collection system.
Interest in the program arises as officials struggle to standardize and improve fine-collection practices statewide while keeping a cautious eye on increasing overcrowding in state prisons and county jails.
"We have introduced a whole new thrust in collecting and enforcing fines that have been imposed by the courts," said Joseph C. Mollica, the assistant to the court administrator of Hudson County. "The courts have never been very good at the collection business." Mr. Mollica said that in addition to statutory fines, the courts could also order restitution to crime victims and could assess penalties to offset costs of medical treatment of those injured in violent crimes. And all drug cases, he said, carry mandatory minimum penalties.
"A fine can be made a very severe sanction and an alternative to incarceration," Mr. Mollica said. "And if judges see that fines are collected effectively, they might tend to use them more."
Using a $166,000 grant from the State Justice Institute in Alexandria, Va., a federally financed organization that provides grants to state and local court systems, officials in Hudson County have been making aggressive use of standard civil remedies like garnishing wages and placing liens on real estate to collect outstanding criminal fines and penalties.
More than $16 million in criminal fines is now outstanding in Hudson County alone, Mr. Mollica said. Only a fraction of that amount is likely to be collected through traditional collection methods, he said. Last year, for example, only $1.6 million in outstanding fines was collected in Hudson County.
"We know that most of the time people do not pay their fines," Mr. Mollica said, adding that many convicted offenders simply "drop out of the system" before their fines are paid in full. "We needed to come up with better ways of collection and enforcement," he said.
Maureen Cassidy, coordinator of fines and restitution in Hudson County, said a better way was to take advantage of the New Jersey Department of Labor's Wage Reporting System. The system, Ms. Cassidy said, identifies the employer of every person covered by unemployment insurance.
Using an offender's Social Security number, she said, officials can find an individual's employer and obtain a court order for garnishment of wages. Once a person is found, Ms. Cassidy said, officials are able to obtain a civil judgment that allows them to seize personal property like automobiles, jewelry and bank accounts.
 
Lien on Property
 If the person owns a house, she said, the judgment can be used to place a lien on the property that must be satisfied in full, with interest, before the property can be sold.
Another tool that Hudson County officials are using to collect unpaid fines is automatic seizure of homestead rebates and state income tax refunds. Ms. Cassidy said that any time a taxpayer or homeowner owed a debt to any agency of state government, the State Division of Taxation was authorized to apply any tax refund or homestead rebate to satisfy the indebtedness.
Finally, she said, officials are also using a provision in the state statutes that permits the suspension of an offender's driver's license for nonpayment of certain fines.
"We've done a lot of those," Ms. Cassidy said. "Eventually, they're going to want their license back, and when they do, they're going to have to pay the fine before the license is restored."
 
Laws Were Rarely Applied
 Ms. Cassidy said that laws allowing civil liens for criminal penalties had been in existence for some time, but that they were rarely applied. "The traditional approach when an individual stopped paying his fine was to follow up with a violation of probation," she said. That, however, usually resulted in a judge's setting up a new payment schedule that the offender would eventually ignore.
"There's no backup there," Ms. Cassidy said. "There's no way to make sure that those payments keep coming in."
Under current state law, all criminal fines and penalties imposed by State Superior Court judges, along with some fines imposed by municipal judges, are collected by the probation department of the county in which the fine is imposed.
The department usually sets up a payment schedule for a convicted offender so that the fine can be paid in regular installments. Typically, the payment schedule runs for the term of the offender's probation, but it can be extended if necessary.
Very often, however, Mr. Mollica said, offenders fall behind on their payments, finish probation before fully paying the fine or simply drop out of the system altogether. When that happens, he said, probation officers can do little more than request the issuance of a warrant for the offender's arrest.
 
Enforcing Payment Termed Difficult
 Such a warrant, Mr. Mollica said, is often not a high priority with law-enforcement officers and seldom results in the arrest of the offender.
But even when an offender is arrested, Mr. Mollica said, the alternatives available to probation officials for enforcing payment are minimal. They can renegotiate the payment plan, a futile action in cases where offenders have already exhibited an inclination not to pay, or they can ask a judge to hold an offender in contempt and sentence him to jail.
"But then society ends up paying for the guy's room and board," Mr. Mollica said. "If a guy is working, why jail him when you can garnish his pay?"
Mr. Mollica said that using civil remedies was often more productive than threats of imprisonment.
"What usually happens is that the idea that we're coming after them prompts them to pay the fine or set up a new payment schedule," Mr. Mollica said. "In my opinion, every county should be doing this."
 
State Preparing a Report
 State officials agree that radical changes are necessary to make the system for collecting fines and penalties more efficient.
Harvey M. Goldstein, the state director for probation services, said that representatives of the county probation departments had been meeting monthly to develop ways to improve collections. Recently, he said, the state hired an accounting concern to prepare a report on collection practices and to suggest improvements.
"They had two major recommendations," Mr. Goldstein said. The first was to develop a uniform statewide collection process. Secondly, he said, "we've got to automate."
Mr. Goldstein said that while Hudson County's experience with using civil remedies was apparently proving successful, such a system could be used statewide only if all the county probation departments' procedures were automated. "We have 21 counties with 21 different systems, and not one has complete automation," he said.
 
Total Unpaid Amount Is Unknown
 In fact, he said, since each county handles its collection procedures separately, state officials do not even know the total amount of unpaid fines outstanding. "The number of cases we're talking about is 100,000," he said. "To try to add that up manually is an impossible task."
Some figures the state has compiled, however, provide an indication of the amount of fines outstanding on a statewide basis. The total amount of fines collected statewide in one year, Mr. Goldstein said, averages $17 million or $18 million, roughly the amount owed in Hudson County.
Mr. Goldstein said collection figures were skewed by the fact that most fines are being paid under installment plans and are not technically due yet. In addition, he said, some fines are owed by people who have left the state or are currently in prison and will probably never make full payment.
Peter N. Brill, chief probation officer for Bergen County, agreed that all collection practices should be standardized and automated. "If we were automated, every one of these people could be billed every month," he said.
But the main obstacle to automation, he said, is lack of money to make the transition. "The problem here is that this fine money is not going to the county," he said. "When you say to the county, 'I need X number of dollars,' their answer is that they don't see any of the money."
 
Most Fines Turned Over to State
 Most of the fines imposed against convicted defendants, Mr. Brill said, are turned over to the state. Such fines are those imposed under the Violent Crime Compensation Board, which provides a fund for victims of violent crimes, and the Drug Enforcement Demand Reduction penalty assessment, which carries high fines that are used for drug treatment and rehabilitation.
Some experts say they believe that high fines themselves might be the reason officials have difficulty collecting outstanding penalties.
"I think that there is great potential for using civil remedies," said Dr. George Cole, an expert in the administration of criminal justice at the University of Connecticut. "But you can only talk about successful collection of fines when the fines are commensurate not only with the severity of the offense, but also within the means of the offender."
Dr. Cole said that high mandatory fines in New Jersey took discretion away from judges. That, he said, leads to the imposition of fines that are essentially impossible to collect.
"It's silly to fine someone $5,000 if they're unemployed and poor," Dr. Cole said. "It's just never going to be paid."

HEADLINE: ART;
A 'Mountain-Climbing' Canal

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN

 BODY:
THE Erie Canal was born in 1825 and still lives. The Morris Canal opened six years later but had stopped functioning by 1929, and all that remains today are a few stretches -- at Boonton, Clifton and Wharton, for example -- and the mass of memorabilia on view here, at the Macculloch Hall Historical Museum.
This Georgian pile was erected in 1810 by George Macculloch, a prosperous businessman who had arrived in this country a few years earlier. His business had to do with banking and overseas trade and, evidently, his reason for immigrating was the economic inconvenience caused by the Napoleonic wars. 
 Once settled in Morristown, Macculloch plunged into local life, opening a school and, though a Presbyterian, assisting in the building of St. Peter's Episcopal Church. His chief contribution, however, was promoting the Morris Canal, for which he invoked nature as a justification.
She "seems really to have intended it," Macculloch wrote in Morristown's newspaper, The Palladium of Liberty, "by holding out every facility in the form and texture of the ground," the position of the water and its abundance. The big capitalist in the sky had even provided the incentive of minerals -- the iron, zinc, copper, black lead and lime that lay along the route the canal was to take, a route that led to the Delaware, Pennsylvania and the coal needed to process these elements.
It was 1822 and the United States, having lost three years to the War of 1812, was scrambling to catch up with England in the rush to industrialization. This meant implementing the recommendations in "Roads and Canals," a report by Jefferson's Secretary of the Treasury, Albert Gallatin.
The notion of Manifest Destiny cannot have been alien to Macculloch, for he had been born in India (1775), the son of an East India Company officer. Orphaned nine years later, the boy was sent home to Scotland, where he was educated -- unusually well, from the sound of it.
Macculloch, the family man, is covered in a booklet put out by the museum; the general focus is on the entrepreneur, along with his friends in high places. These included DeWitt Clinton, who, as Governor of New York, pushed vigorously for the Erie Canal, and James Renwick, a science and engineering professor at Columbia College and father of the architect of the same name.
Among the likenesses is one of Robert Fulton attributed, perhaps optimistically, to Benjamin West. Though he had died in 1815, Fulton is present as an eminence grise, notably by way of his illustrated treatise on canal navigation (1796) and the inclined plane invention that it includes. A powerful influence on waterway design the world over, this was a Rube Goldberg portage whereby cars or "cradles" mounted on rails were loaded with boats at one level and, attached to cables operated by water-powered machinery, hauled up to the next level.
The canal ran first from Newark, later Jersey City, to Philipsburg, on the Delaware, a distance of 102 miles. Approached from the eastern end, it climbed 914 feet -- to Lake Hopatcong -- and from the west, 760 feet, an accomplishment that called for 23 planes and 23 locks.
They are the best part of the show, these photographs of the equipment, the craft and the people who made a living from the canal. Unlike the present era, the machine age provided jobs in abundance and, for the "water gypsies," shelter, too. An entertaining picture features two small children chained to a boat's superstructure. The alternative, illustrated by a Harpers Monthly cartoon of 1860, was "Child Overboard."
The boat captains came in all types: the bewhiskered "Billy Black" Maccullough is captioned "the wildest kind of Irishman"; but, alas, he finally settled down as a "God-fearing, Sabbath-respecting citizen." James (Camel) Campbell, in his tweed suit, was one of several black captains.
The show's piece de resistance is the 15-foot-long mural of one craft drawn by mules and another in the cradle. Painted for the Wharton Town Hall by Louis Valdemar Fischer, the picture was recently reproduced in The Star-Ledger, much to the surprise of the 87-year-old artist, who hadn't laid eyes on it since completing it in 1938.
With its topographical maps, letters, samples of cargo like the nails that put Boonton on the map as an iron town, this is an encyclopedia, the work of Richard Simon, a museum trustee. But it says little about the Morris Canal and Banking Company and even less about its investors beyond mentioning the financial scandal that resulted in the appointment of Cadwallader Colden as president in 1827. It does, however, report that Washington Irving was on the board, from 1836 to 1840.
"The Morris Canal, New Jersey's Mountain-Climbing Waterway" is on view through Nov. 17. The museum is at 45 Macculloch Avenue and is open Thursday, Saturday and Sunday from 1 to 4 P.M.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The inclined plane at Port Colden, a photograph in "The Morris Canal, New Jersey's Mountain-Climbing Waterway," an exhibition at the Macculloch Hall Historical Museum.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK IN THE NINETIES

 BODY:
Yes, there are similarities between 1890 and 1990, but as noted in the article, certainly the level of suffering has increased. I have lived in New York City almost all of my life and have learned to take certain things in stride. However, what I find so disturbing is the explosion within the last decade in the number of people living on the edge.
 
BERT FICHMAN, M.D.
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Pressure Grows on Aid-Thirsty Israel to Adopt Reforms

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
While economies from Chile to New Zealand are shaking off the heavy hand of government and embracing freer markets, Israel seems stuck in a time warp.
"The Israeli economy is an anomaly in the world today," said Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs until earlier this year. "It's statist when everybody else is becoming un-statist." 
 Mr. McCormack and others maintain that Israel needs to "marketize" its economy by selling off state-supported enterprises, lifting restrictive labor practices and stripping away pervasive regulation.
A recent internal report by the International Monetary Fund takes a similar stance. Jerusalem is still more meddlesome than most European governments, the report says, and despite some significant reforms, has been lagging behind many countries in opening its economy.
Now pro-Israel charities and American taxpayers in general are being asked to dig deeper into their pockets to help Israel, already the largest recipient of American economic aid, absorb a huge wave of Soviet immigrants. Instead of framing the decision only in moral, military or foreign policy terms, some of the prospective donors are asking tough economic questions as well.
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir acknowledged these concerns. In his official request to the United States for $10 billion in loan guarantees, he stressed that "the Government of Israel is committed to continuing the full implementation of reforms undertaken since 1985."
To be sure, Israel has many thriving private enterprises and its economy has recently been growing briskly. Since the mid-1980's, the Government has freed up financial markets, eased foreign exchange controls and slashed subsidies. The long-term economic prospects have brightened, according to a recent Standard & Poor's report, with "a significant lessening of the external threat facing the nation" and the influx of emigres from the Soviet Union.
Still, many of Israel's staunch supporters see the nation's recent request for $10 billion in loan guarantees as an opportunity to press the Government to tackle privatization and to lift obstacles to job creation. Such reforms, advocates say, would make the Israeli economy more efficient, attract foreign investors and help to reduce economic dependence on Washington. Israel now gets $3 billion a year in military and economic aid.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat from Vermont, has said he wants to make economic reform a quid pro quo for loan guarantees. "That way the Israelis can do what they have to do but blame the unpopular choices on us," he said.
Two prominent American economists who have been long-time economic advisers of Israel -- Stanley Fischer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Herbert Stein at the American Enterprise Institute -- recently urged the Government of Yitzhak Shamir to commit itself publicly to a timetable of reform. "Israel cannot count on a large, continuing, unconditional flow of aid from the United States Government," Mr. Stein said in a recent speech.
And some members of the American Jewish charitable community, which is sending $1 billion to Israel this year, are starting to focus on the issue. "Saying to Israel that you have to develop a plan for economic reform in return for aid might be a good thing," said Herbert Kronish, a leader of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies.
As it turns out, there is a precedent for the United States to employ aid for a bit of arm-twisting of the Israelis. In 1985, when Israel was facing 400 percent inflation and a run on its currency, Washington shelled out an extra $175 million in grants after Israel agreed to adopt an emergency program to stabilize the economy.
The Secretary of State at the time, George P. Shultz, formed the Joint Economic Development Group -- of which Messrs. McCormack, Fisher and Stein are still members -- to consult regularly with the Israeli Government on the stabilization program. According to Michael Bruno, a former Governor of Israel's central bank, and other top Israeli economists, the advisory group was effective in getting the Government of Shimon Peres to adopt painful measures that the Israeli economists had already been advocating.
Many Israeli economists think that reviving the group's advisory role could be helpful. "There's a lot of room for agreement," said Leonardo Liederman, an economist at Tel Aviv University. "I'm not worried about conditions." "Calling for faster reforms is very healthy," said Eram Yashiv, an Israeli who is a visiting professor at M.I.T.
Despite some reforms to date, Israel's bloated welfare state owns more than 90 percent of all land and controls more than one-fifth of the industries and services. And even with a shrinking military burden, the Government gobbles up half of the nation's gross national product, compared with one-fifth in South Korea, for example. The consequence has been a tendency toward "stagflation" -- a nasty combination of high unemployment and high inflation with low growth.
The big challenge now is for the nation of 4.5 million people to open its economy, not just its borders, to hundreds of thousands of immigrants. Up to one million Soviet Jews are expected eventually. These people, many of whom are highly skilled, could eventually increase Israel's growth potential by a third or more. But in the meantime, a mammoth $50 billion investment in housing, infrastructure and, most of all, jobs will be needed. Israel hopes to finance half of this undertaking abroad.
United States loan guarantees are supposed to enable Israel, which has an unimpressive BBB- credit rating from Standard & Poor's, to pry open capital markets and borrow as much as $2 billion a year from foreign banks and bondholders.
"Israel needs long-term financing," said Amnan Neubach, the Economic Counsellor at the Israeli Embassy. "The guarantees send a signal about a long-term commitment."
From the perspective of the United States, the American Treasury would be agreeing to pay Israel's creditors in case Israel cannot service its debts. Some American officials, including economists at the Export-Import Bank, worry that the American taxpayer will have to ante up. But Israel has never defaulted on a foreign loan and Standard & Poor's assessment is that Israel "should be able to cope with the increased debt."
The momentum behind supply-side changes aimed at lowering the cost of doing business seems to have petered out. "A year and a half ago there was a push for reforms," said Patrick Clawson, editor of Orbis, a foreign policy magazine. "Now it's dead, dead, dead."
The political gridlock can be traced to populists in both of the major political parties, according to Howard Rosen, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, who until recently was a visiting researcher at the Bank of Israel.
Though the economy is rebounding from recession, inflation has been running at a 24 percent annual rate and the budget and trade deficits are ballooning.
The biggest problem is that job creation is hamstrung by high taxes on employers, universal benefit guarantees and rigid work rules. "Start-up costs in Israel are very high," Mr. Rosen said, and Israeli businesses tend to hold back on hiring.
"The more sclerotic a labor market," said Nicholas Eberstadt, author of the book "Aid and the American Purpose," "the less it can benefit from an influx." Unemployment is already 10.8 percent, the highest level ever, even though most of the new immigrants have yet to join the work force. That reflects, Mr. Eberstadt said, "the dysfunctions of the modern Israeli economy."
By contrast, he notes, the freewheeling West German economy achieved its economic miracle immediately after World War II even as refugees from the East poured in.
Archconservative supporters of Israel have urged the United States and Jewish philanthropies to send no more aid until Israel has restructured its economy. But most others think that an abrupt withdrawal is too risky. "It's a very different situation from policy reform in Brazil," Mr. Eberstadt said. "There is no prospect of Brazil's being pushed into the sea."
Again, there is a precedent for a gradually reducing economic aid and one that pertains to another close ally of the United States that faced threats to its survival. Early in the 60's the Kennedy Administration decided that its huge aid progam was retarding economic reform in South Korea.
The Administration put the Seoul Government on notice that only military aid would be forthcoming in the future. (Despite the threat, economic aid actually continued for some years.) The realization that aid would not go on forever evidently spurred South Korea's Government to put changes into effect for which wide support already existed. What followed was one of the most spectacular 30-year growth spurts in economic history.
 
 
 
THE LIMITS OF PUBLIC SPENDING
 Israel's economy has recently rebounded, but this appears attributable more to a debt-financed Government spending spree than to reforms aimed at lowering the cost of doing business.
"The economy is not growing in a sustainable way," said Efraim Sadka, chairman of the Tel Aviv-based Housing and Construction Holding Company, wholly owned by Histadrut, the near-monopoly labor union. "Most of the growth is coming from housing."
A recent I.M.F. report said this reflects the Government's "disturbing tendency" to rush in where private enterprise treads in other countries.
The Israeli Government is spending huge amounts, for example, to build housing for immigrants. Tel Aviv has offered bonuses to builders for speeding up construction, has agreed to buy back unsold apartments and is offering immigrants cheap mortgages.
Though housing starts have quadrupled to about 80,000 a year, the Government's involvement has been extremely costly, Mr. Sadka said. A free-market solution -- letting a temporary shortage push up prices until supply catches up with demand -- would have been cheaper, he said.
The worst thing, Mr. Sadka said, is that the Government program "won't solve the housing problem." adding, "More houses are being built in the South, where there are no jobs, than in the North, where there are jobs."
Indeed, the Bank of Israel's latest report on the economy stated that it was "increasingly probable that the Government will have to honor a large proportion of its buy-back guarantees" on unsold apartments.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Hedging Bets on the Mark and Yen

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The dollar seems to be holding its own, despite new gloom about the economic recovery in the United States.
With the sudden burst of talk in Washington about a tax cut and the decline in durable goods orders in September, many people are wondering where the recovery is. 
 And as long as the upturn in the economy is in doubt, there will be downward pressure on the dollar because there is the possibility that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates again in an effort to give the economy a boost. When rates are cut in the United States, dollar-denominated investments become less attractive.
But the United States economy is ultimately expected to begin to grow while the economies of both Germany and Japan slow down. And this disparity more than offsets the whither-recovery downward pressure.
The economic slowdowns in Japan and in Germany are expected to prevent the dollar from taking a big dip below its recent low of about 1.65 marks to the dollar. The dollar closed on Friday at 1.7000 and recently reached about 1.7150.
At a conference in New York last week, David Morrison, the chief international economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company in London, said, "It would be a dangerous time for medium-term investors to buy Deutsche marks against the dollar."
He said that Germany's combination of a monetary policy featuring high interest rates along with heavy Government spending had propelled the mark to record highs against the dollar and that as this policy was undone, the mark would lose support.
Already, the Government is slowing its record spending. As the blending of the two Germanys moves ahead, the old East Germany shows some signs of new growth. And next year, with an economic slowdown in what was West Germany, the central bank, the Bundesbank, is expected to ease interest rates.
The yen never moved to the heights of the mark, but the Bank of Japan has followed a tight monetary policy that it is now being loosened as signals appear that the Japanese economy is losing momentum. This means the dollar will not strengthen as much against the yen as against the mark. But there is still an upward bias.
Mr. Morrison's view of the dollar is rather bullish. He expects it to be in a range of 1.64 marks to 1.82 marks three to six months from now. In a year to 18 months, he projects, the dollar will be more than 13 percent higher than it is now, in a range of 1.82 marks to 2.02 marks.
The risk of a decline in the dollar will be greatest in the next month or two, he said, because of the chance of a further cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve. Still, he projects that the dollar with remain in a range of 1.61 marks to 1.77 marks.
After that, he said, the dollar will move. "There are no fundamental barriers to the growth of the dollar," he said.
Part of Mr. Morrison's optimism is based on Goldman's expectation of a solid economic recovery in the United States. The firm's growth forecast, in fact, is more optimistic than the one the Bush Administration is apparently revising downward.
"I see the match," Robert Giordano, the director of economic research at Goldman, explained. He believes that relatively lean inventories mean business executives will have "to run to catch up" when demand is re ignited. And he disagrees with the stance of economists who argue that high debt levels, lagging consumer and business confidence and low income levels will keep the match of demand from being lighted.
Nicholas Sargen, chief investment officer for Global Fixed Income Advisers in New Jersey, is less sanguine about the pace of the recovery. But he is not worried about any sharp moves of the dollar in either direction. The dollar is protected from a steep decline, he said, by the slowdown in Germany and Japan and restrained from a sharp rise by the threat of a Fed interest rate cut.
All this adds up to a dollar that is, in his words, "fairly valued." And he believes that Americans who invest overseas face little risk from sharp moves in currency trading. That is a far cry from earlier this year when the dollar rose by nearly 30 percent and gains from investments abroad were cut to nothing or even to losses.
Until recently, Mr. Sargen was director of international bond research for Salomon Brothers, which meant he gave advice on how to invest. Now he is putting his analysis into action at Global, which is a subsidiary of Prudential. He favors bonds in Europe slightly over those in the United States, which gives him a currency exposure that would hurt him if the dollar rose sharply.
What is attractive about this bias in European bonds is that the fund can earn the higher European interest and not worry about a move in the dollar that would be strong enough to wipe out these gains.
He said that once he was assured the American recovery had begun, he would switch his portfolio so that he was better hedged against a rise in the dollar. "But it is too early to do that, with the uncertainty about the recovery and the moves of the Bundesbank and the Federal Reserve," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 20-25

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
How the U.S. Economy Is Handicapping Detroit
 
This is Detroit's worst year -- ever. The General Motors Corporation lost $1.1 billion and the Ford Motor Company lost $574.4 million in the third quarter. The Chrysler Corporation reports earnings this week and big losses are expected. Sales are down for Japanese auto makers, but most are still showing profits. "Don't blame this on Bob Stempel," said James Womack, co-author of "The Machine That Changed the World." Mr. Stempel is G.M.'s chairman. The problem, Mr. Womack says, is that as companies move to newer production techniques they are more vulnerable to the economy's ups and downs. The Japanese manage their economy better, he said, so their companies do better. "Lean production can't function in the extreme cyclicality that is normal in this country," he said. What will turn things around? "I can't see a way out without the Government stepping in. It's starting to happen with mini-vans."
 
Bad Timing for F.D.I.C. Chief
 
William Taylor took over as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation last week. He may wish he hadn't. Just after his confirmation, the F.D.I.C. told Congress it was tripling its estimate of how much money it will need next year to protect the nation's bank deposits. Instead of a "mere" $3 billion, the F.D.I.C. said it will require $9.6 billion. In 1993, it will need $8.7 billion more. The F.D.I.C. estimates that more than 200 banks will fail next year with assets of about $86 billion. But the estimates assume the economy will grow at about 3.5 percent, which is unlikely. If it continues to limp along the fund could require as much as $28.9 billion over the next two years, the F.D.I.C. said. That casts a pall over the Administration's proposal to raise the F.D.I.C.'s credit line to $30 billion for two years. In a slow-growth economy -- with $28.9 billion needed -- there would be just $1.1 billion left to insure about $2.3 trillion of deposits -- not much of a safety net. It is now up to Mr. Taylor to mend that net.

A Big-Ticket Surprise
 
Durable goods are big-ticket items like refrigerators and railroad cars. They are supposed to last at least three years (some actually do). These big items are an important engine for the economy. But according to the Commerce Department, sales of these goods took a 3.2 percent slide in September after falling 4.1 percent in August. Economists were surprised; the consensus was that orders for durables would increase by 1 percent.

The Economy's Political Clout
 
After the coalition forces defeated Iraq in March, President Bush's popularity soared. But since then confidence in Mr. Bush's ability to manage the economy took the mother of all tumbles. According to the most recent New York Times/CBS News poll released last week, 57 percent of Americans disapprove of the way Mr. Bush is handling the economy. Sixty percent feel "things" have gotten "pretty seriously off on the wrong track." In January -- even as the gulf war loomed -- only 31 percent of all Americans thought so. The recent poll said 44 percent of Americans feel the country is in worse shape now than it was five years ago. With just 13 months left to the election, Mr. Bush had better hope the slow-growth economy has a quick rebound.

The 'Beige Book' Looks Bleak
 
The Federal Reserve's "beige book," released last week, was hardly a confidence builder. The book is a compilation of reports from the Fed's 12 regional banks. The book said the recovery had lost much of its oomph in September and early October. Retail sales were flat; factory output -- while improving -- was doing so at a laggardly pace. How will the Fed react to its own book? "It will cut the discount rate by Thanksgiving to about 4.5 percent," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. Such a cut, he said, will drive money out of money-market accounts and into stocks.
 
A Whole New Telephone Game
 
The Federal Communications Commission proposed last week that local telephone companies be allowed to package and transmit video programs on their wires. With next-generation fiber-optics lines phone companies could offer a myriad of interactive services from entertainment libraries, recipe banks and educational programs, each tailored to a customer's needs. The $18 billion cable industry is likely to fight (unsuccessfully) against the ruling. "Among the top two or three concerns of every cable operator has always been head-to-head competition against local telephone companies," said John Mansell, of Paul Kagan Associates, a research firm.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
End of an Era at Compaq
 
Legend has it Rod Canion wrote the business plan for the Compaq Computer Corporation on a napkin while seated in a Houston coffee shop. Six years after he founded Compaq, it was a $2 billion company dominating the portable-computer and I.B.M.-clone market and Mr. Canion was its chief executive. But though Compaq got off to a quick start in the 1980's, it has languished in the 1990's, losing market share to a new generation of clone makers. Early last week the company reported a loss of $70.3 million in the third quarter, its first ever, compared with a $123.6 million profit the year before. To cut costs, the company announced it would slash its work force by 1,400. Late in the week, Compaq raised the number to 1,401, when its board of directors relieved Mr. Canion of his job. Eckhard Pfeiffer, Compaq's executive vice president, will take over.

Chase's Impressive Showing
 
Chase Manhattan managed to turn in a third-quarter profit of $136 million. For a company that was near the brink due to a huge portfolio of bad real estate and foreign loans, the turnaround reported last week was impressive. Chase, which had $630 million in losses for the same period a year ago, embarked on a massive cost-cutting program last year. That program -- coupled with lower interest rates, which gave the bank larger spreads between what it pays for money and what it charges -- helped make the company profitable. "Chase is turning itself around," said Thomas Hanley, a bank analyst at Salomon Brothers.

Time Warner Inches Back
 
When Time Warner Inc. released its earnings reports last week, the big media company seemed to be limping its way back to health. True, Time Warner lost money -- $62 million in the third quarter -- but that was significantly less than the $91 million it lost in the comparable period the previous year. Revenue in the third quarter rose (somewhat) to $2.94 billion, from $2.90 billion a year ago. And some of the big media company's units, like the records group, showed genuine strength.

Prodigy Can Do No Right
 
A year ago Prodigy Services Company, one of the largest electronic bulletin boards and information services, got into trouble for screening the subscribers' messages. Rights groups, like the American Civil Liberties Union, said Prodigy had no business censoring those communications. Last week, Prodigy got into trouble for not censoring its subscribers' messages. The Anti-Defamation League, a division of B'nai B'rith, accused the information service of failing to prohibit anti-Semitic messages some subscribers were putting on the company's electronic bulletin boards. The organization said that since Prodigy advertised itself as a "family service," it should keep certain messages off the screen. The A.C.L.U. disagreed. "The way to answer speech is with speech," said Jerry Berman, director of the A.C.L.U.'s technology information project.

The Clifford Defense
 
When Clark M. Clifford testified before Congress about his involvement with the Bank of Credit and Commercial International last week, he told the same story he has told twice before. He was deceived by B.C.C.I., the bank accused of wrongdoings such as working with terrorists and laundering money for drug lords. But a former B.C.C.I. official, Abdur Sakhai, told the committee earlier that Mr. Clifford, a former Defense Secretary, and Robert A. Altman, his law partner, knew about B.C.C.I.'s ownership of First American Bancshares, the Washington bank for which Mr. Clifford served as chairman. Mr. Clifford denied the accusations. "We have not violated any law," he said. "We have not committed any impropriety." Senator John F. Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, presented the witnesses with documents that he said seemed to tie them to B.C.C.I. and that suggested they knew who really owned First American. "Totally untrue," Mr. Clifford said of the charges.
 
Salomon Brothers Inc. estimated the profits it made from its illegal bidding in the Treasury securities market at between $17 million and $19.7 million.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Snatching the Soviet Purse
 
Mikhail S. Gorbachev borrowed an idea from Alexander Hamilton last week. The Soviet President decreed that the Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs would be the sole agency responsible for servicing the country's foreign debts. The decree was approved by leaders of 10 republics eager to rid themselves of debts. But like Hamilton, Mr. Gorbachev was not making an altruistic gesture. By taking responsibility for foreign credits, the central Government in Moscow will also be at the center of any future borrowing. As Hamilton knew, power rests with the purse.

A Car of One's Own, Literally
 
Unlike previous shows, the companies that mounted displays at the Tokyo auto show last week highlighted their smaller, sportier and -- yes -- more frugal entrants into the market. Some, like Mazda's HR-X, were powered by hydrogen. Others were electric. But some attending the show said the car everyone wanted to see was not displayed: Saturn, made by G.M. in Tennessee. The Saturn is called America's import fighter.
 
The General Strike That Wasn't
 
When strikes were common in Italy, Italians joked that only when the country's union leaders went out on strike did everything work. No more. Italy is a smoothly running, smoothly growing country that recently surpassed Britain in per capita income and has little labor unrest. So last week, when the unions called a four-hour general strike to protest the budget-cutting plans of Prime Minister Giulio Adreotti, they met with meager success. A lot of workers went out -- but not enough to stop the country. And when they did go out, they were just as apt to grab a long lunch as to take to the streets.
