HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Equity, Parity And Money

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
These are painful times for the minority business community.
"Minority businesses almost by definition are small, so the current economy is hurting them," said Harriet R. Michel, president of the National Minority Supplier Development Council, a New York-based network of 3,500 corporate purchasers and 15,000 minority-owned suppliers, vendors and contractors. "Their cash positions are thin and they are undercapitalized. That makes them extremely vulnerable." 
 Ms. Michel, 49, was busy last week overseeing the council's annual convention, which attracted some 1,500 people. She said about half of the 1.2 million minority-owned businesses in the country are suppliers of goods and services to corporations.
A job as head of a business networking group might seem incongruous for someone with Ms. Michel's activist and academic background. She has been, among other things, president of the New York Urban League, an official in the Labor Department during the Carter Administration and a fellow at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
But she is also, with her husband, Yves Michel (pronounced mi-SHELL), the owner of parking garages and a taxi company in New York.
"This is an extension of what I've always done: addressing issues of equity and parity" in the minority community, she said. "The last unaddressed agenda is economic; we have political power and legislative power but not economic power."
Ms. Michel sees particular promise in what superficially looks like a contraction of opportunity: a feeling among many members of minority groups in corporations that they have hit the glass ceiling. Instead of sitting still, they are setting out on their own.
"This new group has advanced degrees and lots of skills," she said. "There is a great thirst for people to control their destiny. It's more important to have their own business than to be well employed by someone."

HEADLINE: Latvia Moves to Open an Air-Route Window on the West

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE

DATELINE: RIGA, Latvia

 BODY:
In the two months since Latvia gained independence from the Soviet Union, Western airlines and investors have become keenly interested in the rights to fly to this Baltic capital at the center of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.
The Latvians also have ambitious plans to form their own national airline as a joint venture with a foreign investor. But Latvia's concerns about how much control foreign investors might have and problems with a small, crumbling main passenger terminal threaten to stall plans to turn Riga into an air hub for the Baltics and the Soviet Union. 
 So far, Lufthansa, Swiss Air, El Al, Austrian Airlines, Hamburg Airlines, and even Malev Air, the Hungarian national airline, have all expressed interest in joining Scandinavian Airline System and the new United States-based Baltia Airlines in obtaining landing rights in Riga, according to the Transport Ministry.
"We are looking forward to the opening of these airlines and are very interested in cooperation with the West," said Janis Janovskis, Latvia's Minister of Transport.
The nucleus of the Latvia's new national airline would be the planes, staff and routes that make up the Latvian division of Aeroflot, soon to be turned over to Latvia by the Soviet Government. But the venture would also need Western investors' money, about $25 million of it.
A group of Houston-based investors say they have nearly completed negotions begun with the Latvian Government last spring to form the new national airline, to be known as Baltic International Airlines, though interviews here make it seem less than certain that the Texans will succeed.
According to Homi Davier, the head of the Houston group, and Girts Lejins, his lawyer in Riga, Baltic International would use Riga as its hub, to serve mainly European passengers bound for various parts of the Soviet Union. For a $25 million investment over five years, the Americans would receive a 45 percent interest in the new airline and Mr. Davier would become its president.
The new airline would receive from the Latvian division of Aeroflot up to 30 medium-size Soviet passenger jets, 400 pilots and the rights to fly to 76 cities in the Soviet Union. Thirty percent of ticket sales would be made in rubles or in the new Latvian currency, once it is introduced, so tickets would remain affordable for Latvians.
There are also plans for a joint venture between Riga's airport and the Americans to refurbish and expand the airport.
But several Latvian officials expressed reservations about signing the final agreement with the Houston investors. Ojars Blumbergs, chairman of the Latvian Parliament's Committee on Energy, Transport and Communications, said a foreign partner for the new airline should be chosen by bid.
Austris Zobens, the newly appointed Latvian director of the national airline, emphasized in an interview that a final agreement had not been signed with the American investors. He said that Latvia has a pressing need for financial and technical assistance, but expressed a hope that it would come in part from Western governments.
"The decision is up to the Latvian Government. I believe we have many opportunities and we must choose the best partner," Mr. Zobens said. "Only one thing can be said firmly. It will be difficult for us to have a good company without Western help."
Mr. Zobens also said, and other Latvian officials confirmed, that other investors have expressed an interest in forming a joint venture with the national airline.
Several Latvian Aeroflot employees wondered whether Latvians were being slighted in the proposed joint venture. One employee, who declined to give her name, said of the Americans, "They're just trying to get the best deal. Why should the president of the Latvian national airline be American? Is it fair?"
Even with an investor in place, the airline will have to overcome significant obstacles. Mr. Blumbergs acknowledged that most of the airport facilities the airline would use and the Aeroflot jets themselves are largely outmoded.
And Mr. Zobens, who would be a vice president in the airline and its senior Latvian executive, said that he lacks experience running an airline. He spent 15 years as an Aeroflot pilot and two years as the head of a small civilian airport on the outskirts of Riga before assuming his current post.
Still, the Latvians sense they are sitting atop a potentially lucrative capitalistic enterprise. Mr. Blumbergs said that the airline's routes to 76 cities in the Soviet Union would increase in value as more Westerners travel and do business in the Soviet Union.
"There will be a lot of confusion in the Russian economy in the next few years," he predicted. "It's important that Latvian Aeroflot take advantage of these routes and exploit the opportunity that the poor quality of Aeroflot's other divisions presents us with."
But exploiting such opportunities will also require a modern, competitive airport in Riga. While the city is ideally situated, a tour of what will soon become Riga International Airport revealed the enormous task the Latvians and a Western partner face.
The airport now handles a million passengers a year and has 20 daily domestic flights and 5 international flights each week. SAS, the only foreign airline, has two flights a week to Copenhagen.
"The airport was built in 1974 as a domestic airport and little maintenance has been done on it since then, except for the addition of the control tower," said Vilnas Azas, the airport's new director.
His most immediate problem is the terminal's leaky roof. "In most international airports you have leaks, but not in all parts of the roof all day. It must be completely replaced," he said.
The main terminal has few gates, which seem destined to invite long, Soviet-style lines. Serving possibly eight foreign airlines with a single international gate would require tricky scheduling. With only two baggage claim areas, two working fuel trucks, no hangars for passenger jets, and one customs area for passengers entering and leaving Latvia, drastic changes would have to be made to accommodate more Western airlines, Mr. Azas said.
Riga International will also have to cope with the attitudes of 300 airport employees. "Our employees must learn to smile and keep smiling all day," Mr. Azas said. "I see a big problem in changing our staff's mentality and pushing them up to a Western service level."
Mr. Azas, a 37-year-old former Aeroflot navigator, said he had seen only three Western airports: JFK in New York, Montreal and Stockholm.
"I am not afraid of my lack of knowledge of this kind of business," he said. "I realize that there is a huge task in front of me, but I want to complete it. I want to make this airport good enough to be one of the best in Europe," he said.

HEADLINE: Three Whiz Kid Economists of the 90's, Pragmatists All

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Economists make youth a prerequisite for winning one of the profession's top honors, the John Bates Clark Medal. "We tend to think that everything important is done early," said Paul Samuelson, who won the first Clark Medal, in 1947 at the age of 32, and like five others went on to garner a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science.
Most economists already know who this year's Clark Medal winner is -- indeed, committee members at the American Economics Association, which makes the award, have sent him congratulatory notes -- although medal traditions preclude a formal announcement until January. 
 He is Paul R. Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, an expert on international economics. The favorite for the next biennial award is Lawrence H. Summers a Harvard professor who is currently in Washington serving as chief economist at the World Bank and was once an adviser to Presidential candidate Michael Dukakis.
A third overachiever who might have been in the Clark Medal race, Harvard's Jeffrey D. Sachs, effectively took himself out of the running by deciding that saving the economies of Latin America and Eastern Europe was more important than churning out scholarly articles, another requisite for the Clark.
All three can claim remarkable accomplishments and influence far beyond the walls of academia. All reflect the ways in which economics is changing, in style as well as substance. All are part of a countervailing current that contrasts with the highly abstract, Olympian, laissez-faire brand of economics that dominated the nation's universities in the 1970's and early 80's.
They are also likely to be around for a while. The graybeard of this group, Paul Krugman, has just turned 38.
Mr. Krugman, an elegant theorist, has re-written the book on global trade and finance, a field better known for received wisdom than lively innovation. He did so by inventing a theory, based on imperfections in the way markets function, that helps to explain why countries exchange similar goods, why protectionism can sometimes lead to lasting advantages and why a system positioned between completely fixed and freely floating monetary exchange rates can work.
"Paul is to international economics what I.B.M. is to computers," said one admirer.
Then there is Mr. Summers, 36, dubbed by one Clark selection committee member "a phenomenon," the rare economist who is equally at home in the ivory tower of pure theory and the down-and-dirty world of policy. Instead of turning a single subject on its head, Mr. Summers has cut a swath through half-a-dozen disciplines with clever, mostly contrarian contributions, like his finding that making it too cheap and easy to trade securities can be bad for the economy.
His colleague Jeffrey Sachs, also 36, is a virtuoso of still another stripe. Since the mid-80's, Mr. Sachs has made transformation of populist or socialist economies like Bolivia, Poland and, more recently, the Soviet Union his personal crusade. For this he won the prestigious Seidman political economy prize, an annual award whose past winners include Nobel laureates Gunnar Myrdal, Robert Solow and James Buchanan. But despite several important articles on 1970's stagflation and 1980's third world debt, Mr. Sachs probably has not produced enough pure scholarship to be a serious Clark contender.
Nobody makes as big a splash as these three without provoking criticism. Some economists simply think that there are other, equally gifted, economists who are getting far less attention. "Summers is advising Lithuania. Taylor, a really good conservative economist, is advising the United States," said Robert E. Lucas Jr., chairman of the University of Chicago economics department, referring to John Taylor, until recenly a member of President Bush's Council of Economic Advisors. "That's about the right division of labor between those two guys."
Some finance experts dismiss Mr. Summers's enthusiasm for taxing stock trades, saying such a policy has few benefits and many costs. Free traders resent the fact that Mr. Krugman's arguments have lent intellectual respectability to old-fashioned protectionism. Liberals often blame Mr. Sachs's economic shock therapy in countries like Bolivia and Poland for causing mass unemployment. "If the Bolivian Government decided to wipe out the tin miners, they could have done it without Jeff Sachs," said Lance Taylor, an economist at M.I.T.
Today's young superstars have much more in common with one another than with the superstars of a decade ago, many of whom are high-wire mathematical geniuses and laissez-faire theorists at the universities of Chicago and Minnesota. The previous generation tended to be proponents of rational expectations, a theory that holds that Washington's efforts to boost economic growth through fiscal or monetary policy are doomed to failure.
By contrast, the three young Cambridge, Mass., economists are on terra firma. "Each one is someone who thinks economics is to be used in analyzing real-world problems and finding solutions." said Stanley Fischer, an economist at M.I.T.
The three share a strong desire to make models fit facts. Mr. Summers's articles are brimming with data. Even Mr. Krugman's work, the most academic of the three, fits this reality-checking mode. Mr. Krugman proposed his new trade theory, for example, after observing that most global trade didn't fit conventional models. "I discovered a lot of contrary evidence that had accumulated in search of a theory," he said. "One of my principals ever since has been 'Listen to the people outside the mainstream.' "
Such fact-grubbing is complemented with a passion for history. "It's a data bank to draw on," Mr. Sachs said. His insistence that debt relief for countries like Bolivia and Poland made sense was partly based on the fact that in the past creditors have never insisted that essentially bankrupt nations repay their loans in full.
To varying degrees, the three see more scope for activist government intervention than do the Chicago and Minnesota economists. Partly for that reason, they are sometimes called neo-Keynesians, influenced by the British economist John Maynard Keynes, the patron saint of those who believe in economic intervention.
Mr. Krugman allows that some very limited industrial policy might be justified. Mr. Summers sees scope for government meddling with corporate taxes to stimulate investment. And Mr. Sachs contends that aid and active engagement by the West are critical to helping reform-minded governments overseas survive.
It would be a mistake, however, to view the three economists as younger incarnations of John Kenneth Galbraith, who thinks that markets often don't work, or even the liberal 1960's Keynesians like Paul Samuelson at Harvard or James Tobin at Yale.
"Larry's generation re-emphasized the importance of markets and the failures of government," said Anita Arrow Summers, Mr. Summers's mother, an economist who recently retired from the Wharton Business School at the University of Pennsylvania.
What was Mr. Krugman's reaction upon hearing that he had won the Clark Medal and that his nomination letters compared his scholarly articles to Japanese haiku, Emily Dickinson's poems and Henri Matisse's drawings? Ninety seconds of elation followed by hours of depression, he said. "I was concerned about my creative juices. I wondered whether I could keep it up."
Few people share Mr. Krugman's anxiety on that score. Even at unlikly moments, Mr. Krugman ideas flow. His ideas on the role of historical accident in shaping economic geography was sparked by a board game based on the evolution of the American economy that his wife, Robin Bergman, gave him.
The standard view when he came on the scene was that countries traded because they have different, more or less naturally endowed resources and tastes, that free trade was almost always ideal and that fixed exchange-rate systems were fatally flawed.
Mr. Krugman demonstrated that technology and the dominance of many industries by a few firms explained most trade between similarly endowed nations. He showed that countries could benefit by pursuing strategic trade policies, like import protection and export subsidies.
As dissatisfaction with floating exchange rates grew in the 80's and governments took steps -- like the European Monetary System -- to reduce currency fluctuations, Mr. Krugman proved that currency target zones were inherently stable.
An only child, Mr. Krugman grew up mostly on Long Island. His mother describes him as a dreamy boy who loved history and played for hours with toy soldiers. "Paul staged the battle of Gettysburg and then he loved to lecture us about it," she recalled.
Mr. Krugman got interested in economics at Yale, earned his doctorate at M.I.T. and eventually wound up on the M.I.T. faculty. Ms. Bergman, his wife, is a painter turned clothing designer and knitter. "Our working styles are very similar," she said. "We work in our heads a lot. We're not overly impressed with technique. We're more interested in a unifying theme."
Jeffrey Sachs has preached the virtues of free markets to Bolivian union militants, the new leaders of the Russian Republic and, yes, even the Pope.
While most of his colleagues were vacationing on Cape Cod last summer, Mr. Sachs was shuttling between Mongolia, which is privatizing the national herd of 24 million yaks; Slovenia, whose newly independent government is trying create a capitalist economy with close ties to Western Europe, and Poland, where the economic reforms of the Solidarity government face a critical electoral test today.
More and more of his attention in recent weeks has focused on helping the Russian government devise a plan to revive its economy. And from time to time, he looks in on Argentina and other Latin debtor nations.
"These societies are at a fundamental crossroads with one fork leading to political and economic chaos and the other way leading them back to being a prosperous part of the world economy," said Mr. Sachs. "That's very captivating."
When possible, his wife, Sonia Ehrlich, a Harvard-educated pediatrician who describes herself as "a happily married single parent," and his two children, Adam, 6, and Lisa, 9, tag along. The last Sachs family trip took them to Athens, Budapest and Warsaw.
The Sachs philosophy rests on a set of interconnected convictions.
One is that, contrary to populist dogma, workers and entrepreneurs, not government, create prosperity. "Economists, spoiled by a bastardization of Keynes, often talk as if all you had to do is turn a dial marked 'economic growth,' " said Mr. Sachs.
Another conviction is that government's job is to create a framework for growth, namely stable prices, a convertible currency, private ownership and legally enforceable private contracts.
A third Sachs idea, the one that originally attracted wide attention, is that debt forgiveness for struggling third world debtors is not only just and necessary but ultimately in the best interests of the creditors.
Being an outspoken advocate for underdogs is part of the Sachs family tradition. A Democrat, his father is a prominent labor lawyer from Detroit who has argued several cases before the Supreme Court.
But some bemoan Mr. Sachs's decision not to become a cloistered researcher. "He was clearly capable of doing pretty important work, but I don't think he did it," said Robert Barro, another Harvard colleague. "It's a major loss."
Mr. Sachs's reaction is characteristically impatient. "I do not believe in the life cycle model that says an economist ought to be isolated and insulated until age 60. I know I get better at this having confronted real problems." He adds: "With my views on what's important in economics, getting the Seidman prize was delicious."
A purposeful pursuit of objectives was evident long before Larry Summers set foot in Washington. A favorite story of his mother is about her son at about age 10 when she sent him off to a tennis tournament with a casual, "Have fun, Larry."
Young Summers reappeared at the the door. "Fun? Fun? It's 90 degrees and you think I'm going for fun?"
"O.K., Larry, O.K.," she said. "Go win."
Said James Poterba, a colleague at Harvard and one of Mr. Summers's many co-authors, "Larry has always had a clear idea of what he wants to do and how. He finds a unique, clear image of what he wants to say, how he wants to argue, what the supporting data and modeling will have to look like."
Mr. Summers came to economics from a remarkable family. Two of his uncles are Nobel laureates and both of his parents, lively and articulate, are also economists. Mr. Summers was offered a full professorship at Harvard before he had even finished his doctoral dissertation. To the surprise of his liberal parents, he followed Martin Feldstein to Washington for a year when the latter became President Reagan's chief economic adviser. He and his wife, Victoria, are the parents of 13-month-old twins, Ruth and Pamela. Mrs. Summers, an attorney and professor, is one of his many co-authors.
Indeed, Mr. Summers has produced an unusual number of eye-catching papers.
Although he has weighed in on everything from the effect of welfare programs on poverty to the role of machinery investment in economic growth, his main work has focused on unemployment, the taxation of capital and, recently, the behavior of the stock market. And like Mr. Krugman, Mr. Summers won attention by taking aim at conventional wisdom. "I always preferred to not be 100 percent certain of a world view," Mr. Summers said, "but relate to what's happening instead."
In the late 70's, when conventional wisdom said that unemployment wasn't a problem because most jobless spells only lasted a few weeks, Mr. Summers showed that while most episodes were indeed short, there existed a hard core of the unemployed that experienced many such short spells.
"Larry's biggest impact is that he has showed by example that you can be a superstar doing applied economics," said Andrei Schleifer, a Harvard colleague. "Larry is probably the most influential teacher in economics since Bob Solow."
Added Mr. Barro of Harvard, "You don't exactly see a home run, but when you add it all up you have a strong body of work. It's pretty clear that the favorite for the next Clark Medal is Larry."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1141 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Computer;
The New OS/2: Impressive Rival for Windows

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
The International Business Machines Corporation formally introduced the second generation of its beleaguered OS/2 operating system software last week at the Comdex fall trade show here. Company officials say it will be available in March 1992 -- even though I.B.M. had all but promised it would be ready by the end of the year. The officials said they decided to postpone the release after receiving requests for new features from many of the 20,000 I.B.M. customers who have been testing the software.
"In the larger scheme of things, three months doesn't matter very much," said Amy Wohl, president of Wohl & Associates of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., a consulting company. "But it is going to cost I.B.M. dearly in terms of marketing momentum. The big mistake they made was in being so firm about shipping by the end of the year, and then deciding to add to the feature set." 
 Discussions of the release date should not obscure the many virtues of the new software, which appears to be far superior to Windows on a technical level. In fact, OS/2 2.0 can run Windows software without modification, along with DOS and previous versions of OS/2 software.
"It's a better DOS than DOS, a better Windows than Windows, and a better OS/2 than OS/2 version 1.3," said Lee Reiswig, general manager of I.B.M.'s system software development effort. That's easy for him to say. But in demonstrations here, Mr. Reiswig showed how OS/2 2.0 can run the DOS-based Wordperfect word processor in one window on screen, Microsoft's Windows-based Excel spreadsheet in another, an OS/2 1.3 communications program in a third window, and a new OS/2 2.0 application in a fourth window, with all programs active at the same time. This ability is called multitasking, and it is one of the great advantages of OS/2 over DOS. Users can grab information from one application and easily paste it into another.
What will be central to the acceptance of OS/2 2.0 is the availability of useful application software, like database managers and spreadsheets, that take specific advantage of its 32-bit operating system. I.B.M.'s chief personal computer executive, James Cannavino, said more than 700 OS/2 2.0 applications from 500 different software companies are in the works.
"The key is, when do those 700 applications ship?" said John McCarthy, a senior analyst with Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. "If it's dribbleware, they're doomed."
John A. Soyring, an OS/2 manager, responded that 25 to 30 percent of the anticipated 700 programs will be ready within 30 days after the operating system ships in March. The Lotus Development Corporation and the Wordperfect Corporation were among those vowing early support for OS/2 2.0.
As a 32-bit operating system, OS/2 2.0 is capable of processing information at double the rate of DOS, Windows and earlier versions of OS/2. Overall system performance will not double, because many other factors are involved, but in general, 32-bit software will operate much more quickly than 16-bit software running on identical machines.
The drawback, at least for most users, is that OS/2 2.0 requires a lot of overhead in order to be able to juggle such tasks. Mr. Reiswig said the new operating system will require a minimum configuration of a 386SX microprocessor, 4 megabytes of random access memory and a 60-megabyte hard disk. Companies are notorious for understating operating system requirements, so plan on a fast 386- or 486-based system, 8MB of memory and at least 100MB of disk storage. Very few computers on office desktops have such features, although they are increasingly common on new machines.
OS/2 needs such hardware support because it is essentially three operating systems rolled into one. It will come on 13 diskettes, and will consume anywhere from 18 to 30 megabytes of hard disk space, depending on which features are installed. In other words, it needs half the hard disk space on a PC equipped with a 40- or 60-megabyte hard disk -- a demand that may cause many users to balk. Yet many people who use Windows today are giving up almost as much of their disks without realizing it.
Some major software developers are adopting a wait-and-see attitude before committing programming resources to the 32-bit version of OS/2. Borland International Inc., which earlier this year signed an agreement to work with I.B.M. in the development of 32-bit OS/2 programming tools, was noncommittal on future plans for OS/2 versions of its Paradox and dBASE database managers and its Quattro Pro spreadsheet.
As rewritten, OS/2 is expected to appeal to individuals and small-business users as well as to the large corporate customers that are I.B.M.'s traditional power base. With the necessary hardware, OS/2 2.0 appears to be attractive even if it is used merely as a replacement for DOS (suggested list price will be $195, or $149 for current users of DOS or OS/2, I.B.M. officials said). And it is much easier to use than DOS, thanks to a new graphical set of commands called the Workplace Manager.
The Workplace Manager makes it much easier to manage applications, files and printers. To print a document, for example, the user selects an icon representing the file and, using a mouse, drags it over to an icon representing a printer. Click. That's it. Even the installation process has been transformed by graphics. Users choose which OS/2 features they want by clicking on boxes on a checklist. To save space, for example, a user might not care to install the built-in PS/2 games, or the simple spreadsheet. The memory requirements of each feature are listed, which is helpful.
Strategically, this OS/2 should be a useful weapon for I.B.M., which has been desperate to hold off the onslaught of Windows. Windows clearly has the momentum, outselling OS/2 by more than 10 to 1 and winning over many independent software developers who might have built new spreadsheets, data bases and other applications for OS/2.
I.B.M.'s decision to postpone OS/2 2.0's release was helped by Microsoft's recent decision to delay the introduction of the next release of Windows, version 3.1, an improved 16-bit system, until spring.
Microsoft and I.B.M. had once been partners on OS/2, each vowing in 1987 that OS/2 would be the foundation for personal computing in the 1990's. But customers shunned OS/2, saying it was too hard to use, lacked suitable applications and required more computing power than most desktops had.
While Microsoft shifted its focus to Windows, a less-advanced and more easily used system, I.B.M. steadfastly clung to OS/2. The rift was so great that the two former allies are now adversaries. I.B.M. assumed total control of OS/2 last year, and Microsoft embarked on a strategy to build an advanced Windows operating system called NT, a 32-bit system, for delivery next year.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2903 words

HEADLINE: Too American for Its Own Good?

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: TORRANCE, Calif.

 BODY:
In Yukiyasu Togo's first overseas assignment for the Toyota Motor Corporation 20 years ago, he donned the saffron robes of a Buddhist monk and begged in the streets of Bangkok so he could understand the Thai people. When he was transferred to Canada five years later, he sold cars door-to-door in order to learn English and understand the Canadian mindset. Finally in 1983 Toyota decided what its American workers needed most was a cheerleader, so Mr. Togo moved to the company's United States headquarters here, just south of Los Angeles, and began conducting pep rallies and handing out bonus checks, which have since become known as Togo bucks.
Mr. Togo's chameleon-like management style, so unusual for a senior Japanese executive, has proved particularly adaptive in the United States, igniting the enthusiasm of Toyota's work force and dealers. 
 During his eight years as president of Toyota Motor Sales USA, the company has vastly expanded its model lineup -- including moving upscale in 1989 with the Lexus luxury brand -- and become the biggest-selling foreign auto maker in the United States, posting sales of more than one million vehicles last year. Along with the Honda Motor Company, Toyota has already surpassed the beleaguered Chrysler Corporation in car sales; when trucks and mini-vans are figured in, Chrysler is still the third-largest in the country, behind General Motors and Ford, but Toyota is closing in.
At a time when Japanese-American trade relations are increasingly fractious, success on such a scale can spell big problems as well as big revenues. Indeed, Toyota's relentless growth has helped to unleash a political storm in Washington.
The Big Three auto makers, smarting from a weak economy and gains by Toyota, Honda and other Japanese competitors, are applying unprecedented pressure on Washington for protection. As the election year approaches, talk is being heard once more of proposals to restrict Japan's share of the American market. The situation was not helped by a spate of bad news last week: G.M. and Ford reported combined losses of nearly $1.7 billion for the third quarter and sales of domestically produced cars by the Big Three were off 16.7 percent in mid-October from the same period in 1990.
 
A Prime Target
 As the Japanese auto maker with the greatest clout in the United States, Toyota would be the prime target of any American reprisals, even though its sales have also been hurt of late by the lingering economic malaise.
"The momentum that is developing against import car companies is going to fall the hardest on Toyota, because it is No. 1," said Richard Recchia, executive vice president of Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America in Cypress, Calif.
All of which means that for political purposes, Toyota must slow down -- or at least give that impression -- or risk being pulled over by Washington.
But slowing down isn't a simple matter. For one thing, Toyota is going too fast to ease off at a pace that would satisfy many critics. For another, the company may not want to cut growth, despite the risks, when market share is there for the taking by Japanese competitors who are not as much in the limelight. Finally, Mr. Togo and his executive vice president, Bob McCurry, have been so hard-driving that it simply may not be in their natures to drop to a lower gear.
Both Mr. Togo, who is 67 years old, and Mr. McCurry, who is 68, are expected to step down from active management sometime next summer. That has sparked a lively debate within Toyota about just how coy the company should be in pressing forward for more American customers and dealers.
Where the debate will take Toyota is not clear. What is clear is that the company has been issuing mixed messages about its intentions, with a lot riding on which message Washington chooses to hear.
George Borst, who is in charge of Toyota's strategic planning for the United States, has been one of those voicing a conciliatory line. Three weeks ago in Detroit, he introduced the 1992 model lineup as the product of a "kinder, gentler" Toyota. He professed to be pleased that Toyota, because of capacity constraints, would actually lose market share to the Big Three next year if the economy improved. Toyota, he said, has abandoned its goal of 1.5 million United States car and truck sales, or 10 percent of the market, by 1995. It now has 8 percent, compared with 6.6 percent for Honda and 12 for Chrysler.
The 10 percent goal "was just a rallying cry," Mr. Borst said. "We don't really have the production capacity to get there anyway."
Yet at the annual dealer meeting in New Orleans last month, Mr. Togo punctuated a rousing speech with his trademark slogan: "Sell, sell, sell like hell." Mr. McCurry, who earned the nickname Captain Crunch for his handling of dealers and subordinates who miss their sales objectives, hasn't shown any signs of mellowing either: "I'm the meat grinder," he said in a recent interview.
 
Big Push for a Pickup
 Dealers, meanwhile, have been lobbying Toyota to proceed with production of a large pickup truck, a pet project that Mr. Togo and Mr. McCurry recommended to top management. The pickup truck, which has been designed specifically for the American market, is ready to go: It has been engineered and a prototype has been built. But the brain trust in the parent company's headquarters back home in Nagoya is nervous. Senior executives are concerned that a large-truck model could maim the Big Three, which derive a disproportionate share of their profits from the full-size pickup market segment. The danger of political retribution would be increased.
The Big Three's high profit margins in large pickups stem precisely from the fact that they have not had Japanese competition in that segment. The new pickup truck, if approved, would be portrayed by Toyota as posing little or no threat to Ford's F-100, Chevy's C/K series and the less dominant Dodge Dakota midsize model from Chrysler, which together account for about 1.2 million sales a year.
"If we brought them in, it would be less than 80,000 annually," Mr. Borst said of the large pickups, sounding almost apologetic. "They're bigger than compact trucks but not full size. We're not trying to attract owners away from G.M. or Ford; we're just trying to create a vehicle for the owners of our compact trucks who need more room."
Toyota has good reason to worry about retaliation. In response to Big Three instigation, the Bush Administration earlier this year started a dumping investigation against Japanese importers of mini-vans. The Treasury Department has also been auditing Honda to assure that its Canadian-built cars meet local content requirements.
But the most ominous development is on the legislative front. Senator Donald Riegle, Democrat from Michigan, Representative Richard Gephardt, Democrat from Missouri, and other lawmakers friendly to the domestic auto industry and the United Automobile Workers union are writing legislation that would limit Japanese vehicle sales to a fixed percentage of the United States market, including Japanese vehicles produced in the United States at so-called transplant factories. The idea gained steam last summer after the European Community passed an automotive market-share cap of 16 percent against Japan, including transplant production, through 1999. The Japanese already have nearly 25 percent of the American market.
 
Apologies and Anger
 Publicly, Toyota has been trying to mollify its critics. "We have been too ignorant of and too apathetic about the feelings that our growing influence arouses in people and nations around the world," said Shoichiro Toyoda, the company's president, in a speech earlier this month in New York before the Japan Society. "Overwork and overachieving without regard for our fellow humans does no good for anyone."
Privately, however, Toyota executives are fuming. They don't think a market-share limit has much chance to become law in the United States. But they fear the Bush Administration may have no choice but to pursue dumping investigations and other trade actions more aggressively to relieve election-year pressure exerted by Congressional Democrats. The Lexus brand might be a juicy target for a dumping investigation, as Big Three executives have long insisted that Toyota is selling the luxury vehicle for less than what it costs in Japan.
The irony, according to Toyota executives, is that they have comported themselves exactly as Lee Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, suggested they should in the early 1980's. At first, the Japanese acquiesced under Government pressure to curbs on imports. Then, when imports continued to take sales away from the Big Three, Mr. Iacocca challenged the Japanese to build plants in the United States.
Toyota and the other Japanese auto makers did that and much more, including opening research laboratories in which American engineers and planners develop new models.
"One of the great tragedies is that there has been too little education about what Japanese auto makers have done in terms of jobs and investments" for the United States economy, said Mr. Recchia of Mitsubishi.
Toyota now has a multifaceted American presence, with a sprawling network of assembly plants, technical schools, research labs and 1,300 Toyota and Lexus dealers, not to mention a corporate contributions program that donates about $10 million a year to local institutions. Toyota directly employs 17,000 people in the United States, and 55,000 work for its franchised dealers here. Moreover, its purchases of American-made parts have increased fivefold since 1986.
The problem, from Detroit's point of view, is that as Toyota and the others have become more Americanized, they have taken even more of the market from the Big Three.
Now, Mr. Iacocca wants a market-share cap, ostensibly as punishment for the trade deficit with Japan and weak sales of American models there.
 
'Confidence Is Down'
 Mr. Togo seems more sad than angry about Detroit's hostility. "Unfortunately, Detroit Big Three used to have a strong confidence," he said. "I think the confidence is down. G.M., Ford and Chrysler have potential but it is not properly done. The American car man in Japan is not trying hard enough," he said, adding that few American models exported to Japan are equipped with right-hand drive.
Though Toyota has not named the next head of its United States operations, it is a safe bet he won't be another Mr. Togo, who is quite unlike the typically reserved, understated Japanese executive. Gregarious and informal, Mr. Togo encourages everyone to call him Yuki. His business card -- round, not rectangular -- carries a sketch of his smiling face. His rallies at headquarters often are capped by the announcement that everyone is getting a $50 bonus -- the celebrated Togo bucks.
 
The Camry Challenge
 Toyota's 1992 Camry, introduced last month, typifies the Americanization that Mr. Togo has pursued. It also reflects the aggressive approach that has brought Toyota success while drawing Detroit's ire.
The new model, built in Georgetown, Ky., as well as in Japan, is a dramatic redesign of what has long been a popular compact car.
Like many early Toyota models, the new Camry would have reflected more Japanese than American taste. But Mr. Togo and Mr. McCurry made sure that did not happen.
Visiting Japan three years ago to inspect the Camry's final clay model, they were crestfallen by what they saw: The sides of the car were flat, causing the vehicle to appear stiff and square, a far cry from the elliptical styling that was becoming popular. And the model needed another two inches of shoulder room for heftier Western bodies.
Sure that the new Camry was wrong for American customers, the executives delivered their frank assessment to Dr. Toyoda. "That sort of thing just isn't done," recalled Mr. McCurry. "We really bent some noses."
Nonetheless, Dr. Toyoda heeded his executives' advice. Within 30 days, a new clay model was constructed. New tooling was ordered. Last summer, Toyota rolled out its first bifurcated car model ever: one Camry for Japan, a second, specially styled Camry for America.
Like the pickup truck, the new Camry represents a significantly enhanced threat to the Big Three. Early reviews of the vehicle have been overwhelmingly positive. In redesigning the car, Toyota enlarged it from compact to mid-size class, thus positioning it as a true competitor for the Ford Taurus, Chevy Lumina and the new Chrysler mid-size models due next summer, which are a key to Chrysler's survival. Like pickup trucks, mid-size cars have been an important profit maker because Japanese competition has been scant -- until Honda's enlarged Accord and now the Camry.
A second Camry assembly line that is being built in Georgetown will double United States production capacity to 400,000 mid-size cars annually by 1994 or 1995.
Mr. Borst tried to throw cold water on Detroit's speculation that Toyota wants Camry to displace Accord as the best-selling car model in the United States. That cachet is not only important for ego gratification; it strengthens brand image, increases profit margins and helps sell more cars.
"Our goal is for Camry to be the most desired car, not the best-selling," Mr. Borst insisted.
That type of posturing will become increasingly more difficult for future Toyota leaders. With other Japanese brands nipping at its heels and dealers pressing for more and better models, Toyota may have little choice but to keep doing what it does best -- Detroit, and Washington, notwithstanding.

 
 
A Manager With a Feel for the Grass Roots
 Unlike many Japanese executives assigned to work in the United States, Yukiyasu Togo has had little trouble embracing American culture or building relationships with American colleagues.
Indeed, Mr. Togo has no thought of returning to Japan next year when he retires from active management. He is building a house in Kona, Hawaii, where he can play his stereo at a decibel level that would surely prompt angry complaints in a crowded Japanese neighborhood.
"People in Japan say, 'Yuki, you are an American,' " he said. "Quite an honor to be called an American."
Mr. Togo's self-immersion in the day-to-day operations of Toyota's American workers and dealers is consistent with the auto maker's goal to weave itself ever more deeply into the fabric of the American automotive business.
"I do not like the ivory tower,"
Mr. Togo said. "My career is always on the front line."
Mr. Togo's transfer to the United States in 1983 was at once the pinnacle of his automotive career and a demotion. In Canada he had reached the level of Toyota senior managing director. But Toyota didn't promote him to one of the four Tokyo-based executive vice president posts, the level just below chief executive.
This didn't bother him at all, he insisted. He was just as happy to work at a grass-roots level, where "human beings learn to understand one another."
David Shepherd, a Toyota dealer in Fort Scott, Kan., was witness to this belief. Mr. Shepherd sells only about 200 Toyotas annually, compared with about 20,000 for Toyota's largest dealership, owned by Roger Penske, in El Monte, Calif.
Nevertheless, Mr. Shepherd was astonished to receive a huge potted plant from Mr. Togo at his dealership's grand opening in 1988. "My family has been in the car business almost 30 years -- we have many different franchises -- and that was the first gesture like that from any auto company," Mr. Shepherd said.
 
 
 
Targeting The Heartland
 A big reason for Toyota's growth in United States sales and market penetration has been its aggressive pursuit of Midwestern buyers.
In the last five years, the company has added 140 dealers nationwide, giving it about 1,300 in all, including the 100 or so that sell the Lexus. More than one-third of the new locations -- 53 -- are in the Midwest, principally in the vicinity of Cincinnati, Kansas City and Chicago.
The results have been encouraging, if not yet overwhelming.
"Some of these points will sell 1,000 vehicles a year, some 300," said Irving Miller, Toyota's manager of new dealerships, who is looking for more growth soon.
"I think with the new Camry, which is a mid-size car, we're going to attract the Midwestern buyer," he said. The Camry had been a compact model.
The Midwest also will be an important market for a large pickup truck, if Toyota decides to offer it.
There had been little incentive to take on the Midwest, home of the Big Three, when Toyota was selling every vehicle it could import on both coasts and throughout the Sunbelt. But by opening plants in the United States, Toyota started to produce enough extra vehicles to make it worthwhile to find new opportunities.
One of Toyota's concerns initially was that anti-Japanese bias might be strong in small Midwestern towns and farming communities.
David Shepherd, a Toyota dealer in Fort Scott, Kan., since 1988, recalled hearing some people say they would not buy Toyota products because of Japan's role in World War II. But such feelings have subsided during the last two years, he said.
"Toyota has made a genuine effort to be considered an American car company," Mr. Shepherd said. "We explain to people that Toyota makes Camrys in Kentucky and trucks in California."

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Amherst;
Admission Policy Blind to Finances Will Be Retained

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
The Amherst College president, Peter R. Pouncey, announced last week that the college will be able to retain its "need-blind" admission policy, despite earlier predictions by him and the trustees that the only methods of insuring the college's financial security would be either to eliminate need-blind admission or to require students to repay or work off a larger proportion of their financial aid awards.
The announcement came after two forums in the last month at which students press trustees and administrators to retain the need-blind policy, in which applicants are considered for admission regardless of their ability to pay. Students who are accepted then receive aid packages based on financial need. Approximately 45 percent of the student body now receives financial assistance from the college, which will spend $8.5 million on financial aid this year. 
 In a letter to the college community, Mr. Pouncey said, "The problem arose because the financial aid budget showed signs of spiraling out of control into increasing deficit -- $384,000 last year and $520,000 in the current budget." But the letter continues, "Need-blind admission will be retained by the college, by dint of some careful economies and adjustments elsewhere in the budget."
Among the adjustments, the letter continues, is a decision by the board to resolve the budget deficit over a two-year period, rather than in one year as had originally been intended. Students receiving financial aid will be asked to secure $570 more than currently required through loans and jobs, and Amherst's nonsalary expenditures will be held to an increase of less than 1 percent in next year's budget. The college will budget a 4.5 percent increase in financial aid, bringing total aid expenditures to a projected $8.9 million, Mr. Pouncey said in the letter.
Lisa Grumet, an organizer of the Financial Aid Coalition, a coalition of student groups that has pressed the college to retain its need-blind policy, said she was surprised by the move. "We're very happy about the announcement," she said.
But Ms. Grumet, a senior in American studies from Albany, said her group still had a number of concerns including the size of the increase in the financial aid budget, the additional burden of larger loans and work-study requirements on financial aid recipients, and the length of the college's commitment to a need-blind policy.
Ms. Grumet added that although student pressure could not be held directly accountable for the policy decision, "I think that students did have an impact in causing the trustees to think about it again."
In an interview, Mr. Pouncey said the trustees realized that it would be "extremely difficult" to make up the deficit in one year and remain competitive in the size and composition of financial aid packages. And while he played down the effect of student protests, he said, "The force of concern shown by students" at an Oct. 3 trustee-student forum "may have prompted a kind of gentleness of response."

HEADLINE: Restore the Road to Democracy

BYLINE: By Jean-Bertrand Aristide; Jean-Bertrand Aristide is President of Haiti.

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
During these days of anguish and sorrow, the Haitian people find comfort in the generous support of the United States and the world community. The unanimous condemnation of the Sept. 29 military coup has earned our gratitude.
But as news of massacres and repression slip off the front pages, there is a danger that active support will wane, and with it the hopes and dreams of the Haitian people for democracy. 
 We have paid a high price for democracy in Haiti, struggling over 200 years against a series of vicious dictatorships. Institutions inherited from the past were rotten.
When the people overwhelmingly elected my Government in December 1990, accountability was unknown: The political system was designed to perpetuate internal colonialism. We inherited a nation with one physician for every 3,000 inhabitants, but a soldier or policeman for every 200. A nation in which more than 90 percent of the population lived in abject poverty, while the elite enjoyed a lavish standard of living.
Perhaps it is not surprising that Haiti's past cast a dark shadow on our future, erupting into a violent overthrow of the constitutional democracy the Haitian people had fought so bravely to craft.
The coup leaders have charged our Government with abuses of human rights and suggested that this justifies their violent actions. But what could be a worse human rights violation than overturning the constitutional democracy that is a guarantor of human rights?
Restoration of democratic rule in Haiti will require a comprehensive social dialogue, including a program to address the army's role as the key instrument of internal colonialism. Since Haiti has no war to fight, it does not need weapons for its defense. Tanks, cannons and armored vehicles have been used only to control crowds and to seize power, in lieu of allowing political speeches, arguments, polemics and fair elections.
The army's role should be limited to areas in which prompt and disciplined intervention is necessary: prevention of national disasters, search and rescue operations, assistance in the development of deprived areas, building and maintaining highway systems and patrolling our border and coastline.
A police force, as required by the the Constitution, will also insure order in various communities and will comprise people from the concerned communities.
Even as we triumphed in democratic elections, we recognized the danger posed by elements in the military -- people who had been tied to the previous dictatorship or aligned with the traffickers who turned Haiti into a key transfer point for drug smuggling. When we took the reins of Government, we spoke of a marriage between the army and the people. We spoke of security as the first child this marriage would yield, a security and peace never before known by our people.
The marriage was never fully consummated. But the initial effort yielded a remarkable reduction in human rights violations. The record speaks for itself. During the rule of Prosper Avril, from June 1989 to February 1990, there were 725 violations of human rights, according to the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees. During the 10-month administration of Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, from March 1990 to January 1991, 590 violations were documented. In the seven months of our Administration, only 120 violations were recorded, and none were attributed to our Government.
Reports that our Government incited the people to violence or revenge have no basis in reality. Not one political assassination occurred during our Administration. Not one political prisoner was jailed. No boat filled with frightened, political refugees fled Haiti for U.S. shores.
Ours is an Administration based on charity and inclusiveness. We were elected under the Creole adage that all should sit at the table, not just a few. True, the gap between the haves and have-nots must be narrowed. But our agenda has never encompassed nationalization, seizure of property or encroachment on the legal rights of any Haitians, including those who enjoy tremendous wealth.
In the short seven months that Haiti's democracy flourished, we worked to create a Government that was accountable for the first time in Haitian history. We resurrected an independent judiciary, an institution that had been destroyed and corrupted by previous regimes. We unmuzzled the press. We initiated an unyielding crackdown on drug dealers. We began the arduous task of fostering a healthy, free-market economy that could benefit all Haitians. In June, for the first time, a positive balance of $8 million was recorded in our national treasury, which had been virtually emptied by former regimes.
Those accomplishments will be at risk if the will of the people is allowed to be overturned. The answer is to act quickly and decisively to return the democracy for which the Haitian people have sacrificed so much. The trade embargo initiated by the United States with the Organization of American States must be resolutely enforced. Except for shipments of humanitarian aid to Haiti's poor, the embargo should amount to a total blockade.
We seek a peaceful solution to our crisis through social dialogue among the different components of Haitian society. That is why we have requested that an O.A.S. civilian delegation be dispatched to the country as soon as possible to act as official observers. That is the only way to insure that the restoration of the legitimate Government in Haiti is carried out without compromise, within the framework of the Constitution and with respect for human rights.
Would-be coup leaders in other countries are watching the response to the assault on Haitian democracy with keen interest. The international community's unwavering support for our Constitution and our democracy will nurture the blossoming of democracy all over the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Rich Aren't Paying at All in Congress's Boat-Tax Fiasco

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the name of making rich people bear their share of balancing the Federal budget, Congress last fall enacted a luxury tax on new boats. The result has been a disaster for the United States boat-building industry: more than 20,000 people out of work, bankruptcies among boat yards and economic depression in communities that depend upon boat building. 
 Now Congress has an opportunity to right that grievous wrong. It can repeal that tax and enact a more broadly based excise on marine diesel fuel, which now carries no Federal tax. By drafting the new law with appropriate safeguards for the commercial boating sector, fuel providers like marinas, and boating-safety interests like the Coast Guard, Congress can get rid of a bad law and tax the rich more effectively.
The rationale for the boat luxury tax was that if you taxed the things rich people buy, then you automatically taxed the rich. Any boater could have told Congress how misplaced that rationale is. Many boat buyers are modest-income people who sell their homes to live aboard their boats full time; they are buying a roof to cover their heads, not a luxury. Because the rich have money they also have choices, and they are choosing not to buy boats. Does the tax hurt them? Not in the least.
The boat tax was supposed to raise $145 million over its five-year life. Fortunately there is a more efficient and equitable way to get $145 million from wealthy yacht owners.
Ever since 1951 Washington has taxed diesel fuel used in highway vehicles. But a large pleasure yacht, which generally burns diesel, is an "off the road" vehicle and exempt from the tax. Like the farmer with a diesel-powered combine, the large-yacht owner pays no Federal tax on the diesel fuel he consumes. To carry the irony further, the gasoline generally used in smaller power boats carries a 14-cents-per-gallon Federal tax.
Like the luxury tax itself, the diesel tax could carry an exemption for commercial boaters. A small portion of the tax could also be earmarked to reimburse retailers for the costs of administration. And Congress could use the tax creatively to improve boating safety. I propose that one-half of the tax be earmarked for the Coast Guard and Boating Safety Fund.
Substituting a modest tax on diesel fuel used in pleasure boats for the clearly counterproductive luxury tax could save thousands of jobs, give hope to communities that depend on the boat-building industry, bring parity to the tax treatment of wealthy versus lower income boaters, encourage the design of fuel-efficient boats, and actually raise money from the rich.
 
JOHN G. SHANNAHAN 3D
Oxford, Md., Oct. 8, 1991
 
The writer owns the Oxford Yacht Agency.

HEADLINE: Maybe Grade Crossings Aren't All Bad

 BODY:
Elimination of these crossings has been studied for many years. The need for this project has become more acute as rail traffic increased and the Ronkonkoma electrification went into service. Accidents caused by thoughtless drivers continue, as they attempt to drive around lowered gates. A separate and valuable dividend from the grade separation would be the provision of a third track, badly needed to relieve congestion on what has become the busiest L.I.R.R. route.
In the original plan for separation of rail and roadway, the railroad was to be elevated, just as it all along the South Shore. Elsewhere in our country, the West Coast, Florida and other communities where commuter railroads are being built, elevated structures are accepted. Depressing the railroad would be costly, something like 50 percent more than elevation. In this depressed economic period, it is imperative that the most economical choice must be made. Indeed, the existing route through Mineola is elevated, both east and west of Mineola.
 
ARTHUR HARRISON
Locust Valley

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;
Preservation Of Last Farm

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST

 BODY:
STATE and city historical preservation societies have joined to save what is believed to be the last farm with it buildings intact in Providence. Known as the Whitman Farm, the property consists of a 13-room farmhouse dating from 1750 and several smaller buildings on a shaded half-acre lot in a crowded residential neighborhood.
The Providence Preservation Society Revolving Fund stepped in five days before the property went to a foreclosure auction in May and negotiated a price of $117,000 with the second mortgage holder, ITT Financial Services. The society paid an additional $5,000 for expenses like back taxes and water and sewer bills. 
 The $1 million fund usually focuses on the preservation of houses in low-income neighborhoods. But Clark Schoettle, executive director of the revolving fund, says it bought the farm, in a middle-income neighborhood near two colleges, to prevent the auction sale. The Rhode Island Historical Preservation Commission has since financed the purchase price for the Providence organization with a five-year loan at 5 percent.
"The context of the half-acre of land and the original character of the house itself is very representative of the agricultural heritage of at least that part of the city," Mr. Schoettle says.
The society plans to sell the farm to someone who will restore it. An open house there last month attracted about 200 people, some of them longtime neighborhood residents. The society is asking for $134,000, but at least $75,000 more will be needed for restoration work, including repairing structural damage caused by powder-post beetles.
The state preservation commission will provide a low-interest loan to cover the restoration work.
Originally, the farm stretched across 200 acres; it was last used for farming purposes -- chickens and corn -- in the 1950's by Prescott Whitman. The building that served as the corn crib and chicken coop is still on the property, along with a carriage barn, a Gothic-style well head, and a one-room schoolhouse.
The house was built in stages. The middle portion was built in the 1750's, while the Federal-style front portion and L-shaped kitchen were added in 1810. The added rooms were configured around the original chimney to allow each of four rooms to have a corner fireplace. The house has only one bathroom, and there is no heat or electricity upstairs.
The previous owner held the farm for at least 15 years, Mr. Schoettle said, but had two mortgages and debts on the property of more than $200,000. Two previous foreclosure auction sales fell through before the revolving fund stepped in.

HEADLINE: Adding on the Costs of Emissions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Using Compressed Air to Store Up Electricity" (Sept. 29) presented an optimistic view of the economics of compressed air energy storage, given the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990 and other legislative and regulatory trends. In general, utilities and independent power producers will find that the quantity and cost of additional air pollution emissions associated with energy storage will often be decisive in negating the benefits of new storage projects. 
 A new cost component arises from the Clean Air amendments. Their acid rain provisions will create a value (or opportunity cost) for every ton of sulfur dioxide emissions. For every kilowatt-hour of generation that results in some emission of sulfur dioxide, there is a new cost: the cost of emissions.
Every electric system is different, with different marginal costs and sulfur dioxide emission rates for on- and off-peak periods. Nevertheless, many systems would use medium- or high-emission coal generation during off-peak periods to "pump up" compressed air units. During on-peak periods, when the compressed air would generate electricity, lower-emission generation would be displaced. The new economics of the Clean Air Act must then be applied.
Furthermore, the cost of coal generation -- and energy storage -- may be forced up further. Government may compel utilities to internalize the cost of environmental externalities in all planning and decision-making. There may be a Federal carbon tax, for example, or utilities could be required to internalize the cost of carbon dioxide emissions in their operations.
 
STEVEN A. MITNICK
McLean, Va., Oct. 3
 
The author is chief economist of the Science Applications International Corporation.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
As Cuomo Ruminates, The World Of Politics Calculates

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
For a homebody who rarely spends enough time away from New York to need even an overnight case, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would embark on a year-long Presidential campaign burdened by enough political baggage to keep a typical candidate from walking, much less running.
Mr. Cuomo isn't typical, though. Mostly by word and sometimes by deed, the Governor has cultivated an image that distinguishes him from most candidates. His acknowledgement this month that he is weighing a Presidential campaign has quickened the pulses of all politicians who believe he can magically transform perceived liabilities into assets and galvanize a party and a nation yearning for leadership. To be sure, a disproportionate number of the press's stethoscopes are wielded in New York. But few other public figures could generate so much interest in the mere possibility that they might run. 
 Six Democrats, including two governors, have declared their candidacies. So far, none has filled the vacuum that politics abhors, which has made Mr. Cuomo even more appealing. If he ran it would be considerably more difficult to dismiss the field as the Seven Dwarfs, as the Democratic primary contenders were dubbed in 1988.
"I would urge him to get in," said one of the seven, Michael S. Dukakis, the former Massachusetts Governor and Democratic Presidential nominee that year.
"He's the only person who can punch," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, who joined Representative Thomas J. Downey of Long Island in igniting the fuse of a Cuomo-for-President boomlet in Congress last week.
"It's as if a Broadway show opened," one Washington political consultant said, "but nobody's playing the lead."
The producers who want Mr. Cuomo to audition are convinced that he would begin as the best-known and best-financed of the group and the best able to argue the Democrats' case in 1992, win or lose. As Governor of New York, he is automatically granted a national platform and endowed with the stature of a Presidential prospect. But no New York governor has been elected President since Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932 -- nor has any other incumbent governor.
For all the messenger's eloquence and his faith in his own message, Mr. Cuomo's liabilities, on paper at least, would appear to make him eligible for a savings and loan bailout. Unlike Roosevelt, he has had no experience in Washington and even less in foreign affairs. He has never run in a national campaign. He is not only from New York, which is still regarded with fear if not antagonism in many places, but is also an Italian-American and a Roman Catholic, which may make him even more alien to many other Americans.
He is a governor, which may remind voters of the last one who ran -- Mr. Dukakis. If Mr. Cuomo runs without resigning, he may be held accountable for every crisis that develops at home during the campaign and every problem that is precipitated by Republicans who dominate the State Senate. He is grappling with a state deficit that he disclosed last week was approaching $800 million in the current fiscal year and, even without leaving the state, has already been accused of dereliction in dealing with New York City's political and financial deficits. He has been firmly opposed to the death penalty when the national mood may be better reflected by Congress's recent decision to expand the list of capital crimes. Finally, his rivals might turn the tables 180 degrees and ask New Yorkers, as Ronald Reagan asked Americans in 1980 and Mr. Cuomo is asking them today, whether they are better off now than they were four years ago. Even among the Democratic contenders, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia has indicated he can't wait to compare his initiatives to Mr. Cuomo's.
 
Compassion and Candor
 Mr. Cuomo's ability to spin straw into gold, however, is legendary. Problems once peculiar to New York are now part of a national dilemma. Mr. Reagan and Jimmy Carter, both former governors, had little foreign policy experience too (although they did offer a basic philosophy, as does Mr. Cuomo). His championing of middle-class values and his position on the death penalty, which has never cost him pivotal votes, demonstrate compassion, candor and political courage that might be admired, if not embraced.
Mr. Cuomo would, of course, be held accountable for his record and for his response to emerging crises, but, as Mr. Dukakis said last week, "he doesn't have any greater burden than the incumbent President." Indeed, Mr. Cuomo's response to deficits can be contrasted to the President's. And Candidate Cuomo could be expected to make a convincing case that deficits in New York, Connecticut, California and elsewhere can be blamed on the national economy and on the Federal Government's abdication of its responsibilities to urban America.
On Friday, Mr. Cuomo did just that before the Radio and Television News Directors Association in New York City, where he indicated that a Democrat who has the courage to tell the truth could win. "Maybe you can't win with it," he said cynically, then added coyly: "I don't know because I'm not a candidate."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
The Connecticut Tax Drama, Act 2

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S Legislature, hurrying toward a proposed special session next month to reconsider the state's two-month-old income-tax law, has come in recent days to resemble the cast of a whodunit more than a deliberative body. With public passions fully aroused against the tax, a recession stubbornly lingering and the two main political parties mutually mistrustful, nearly everyone appears to have both a motive in mind and an intense fear of being stabbed in the back.
Underlying each suspicion is the question of repeal or repair. Since more than 40,000 people descended on the capitol three weeks ago to rage against the tax in one the largest protest rallies in Connecticut, the sense of urgency to do something has become a force that many lawmakers predict is unstoppable. The tactics boil down to whether to try to fix the tax -- by easing the burden on middle-class families -- or to try to kill the tax outright. 
 "This is a popular uprising -- that kind of environment is one that people approach very carefully," said State Representative Reginald L. Jones, a Republican from Darien, who supports a repeal and opposes any effort to revise the tax, at least for now.
The tax, which ended Connecticut's distinction as one of only 10 states with no tax on wages, was passed by a razor-thin margin in the General Assembly Aug. 22 after a summer-long deadlock between Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and the Democrat-controlled House and Senate. Mr. Weicker, a third-party independent Governor who lacks even a single member of his party in the Legislature, proposed the income tax in February, then vetoed three budgets that supporters said would have solved the state's fiscal problems in other ways. The state faced a shortfall of nearly $1 billion for the year that ended in June and another $2 billion if spending commitments and taxes remained unchanged.
 
Plotting and Positioning
 Through the long summer, coalitions of Republicans and moderate Democrats found they could make majorities for those so-called "conventional" budgets -- which were based on an increase in sales tax collections -- but that they could not surmount Mr. Weicker's vetoes with the necessary two-thirds majority.
Lawmakers in both parties say that strong majorities now stand ready in the House and Senate to repeal the income tax and start over, and Mr. Weicker has said he stands ready to veto such efforts. Once again the two-thirds majority needed to override has not yet emerged.
The resulting environment is one where plotting and positioning may be all that is finally achieved. And there is no shortage of plots. Moderate Democrats in the House who support repeal have announced plans to devise an alternative, no-income tax budget because of suspicions about the Republicans' intentions.
State Representative Carl J. Schiessl, a Democrat from Windsor Locks and a leader of the moderate group, said he believes most Republicans in their hearts want the income tax dropped. His fear, though, is that their heads will win out: retaining the tax would keep the issue alive as a powerful weapon in the 1992 elections against the mostly Democratic majority that voted for it. All 187 members of the General Assembly are up for re-election next year.
Other Republicans, especially Thomas Scott, a former state senator who helped organized the Oct. 5 rally, have expressed similar fears about their own colleagues. Mr. Scott, who ran unsuccessfully for Congress last year in New Haven, said his group, the Connecticut Taxpayers Committee, will publicly identify and target for defeat Republican backsliders.
Mr. Scott has also vowed to oppose any bill to repair the tax, because making the law more palatable to the public "would ultimately make repeal more difficult," he said, and the best thing for the state is a complete repeal.
Lawmakers seeking to fix the tax say their strategy is to make repair seem inevitable with a bill that would cut taxes for a majority of residents, stimulate the economy and short-circuit the long-term repeal effort.
Those repair forces, led by the deputy majority leader in the House, Jonathan Pelto, a Democrat from Storrs, say their first goal would be to sustain Weicker's veto of the repeal bill. If that is achieved, a bill will immediately be introduced that would overhaul the income tax and provide cuts for families earning up to $100,000 -- at the expense of taxpayers at the upper-income levels, who would see their taxes rise further.
Those opposing the repair bill because they are holding out for complete repeal later on would then have to vote no to tax cuts for tens of thousands of residents in the midst of a recession. And if they vote for repair, they're on record for accepting the idea of an income tax.
But Mr. Weicker could play a role in any repair scenario as well. He has said he strongly opposes such fiddling with the income tax until enough time has gone by to judge realistically what works and what doesn't in the law, though he hasn't used the veto word -- yet.
