HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Stalinist's Paradise In Korea Flounders

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
No country has so successfully created a Stalinist society as North Korea. It is a nation where every home has a speaker that broadcasts Orwellian propaganda throughout waking hours, where every adult must wear a button of the "Great Leader," Kim Il Sung, where affection is banned until marriage in the mid- to late-20's, where there are no novels or light reading, where citizens must get permission even to travel to another town.
These days, the worker's paradise is in trouble. President Kim, who is 79 years old but in apparent good health, remains in absolute control of the nation's 22 million people, but North Korea is staggering economically from the effects of the disintegration of Soviet Communism. The Soviet Union used to supply oil and accounted for nearly half of North Korea's trade; this year Moscow put trade on a cash basis instead of barter, and imports and exports have plummeted. 
 For the first time in several decades, there are credible reports of hunger in North Korea. Koreans tell visiting relatives from China, Japan and America that what they want is food; they are now believed to be limited in some areas to two meals a day of just rice and kimchi, a kind of pickled cabbage. Virtually all food is rationed -- meat four or five times a year, two eggs a month, 1.5 pounds of rice a day for an adult male manual laborer.
"About one-third of factories are closed down, and half of the remaining ones are only operating part of the time because of the shortage of energy and raw materials," said a Russian who lives in Pyongyang. "Outside Pyongyang, at night it's all dark -- the electricity is cut off." One indication of the desperation, the Russian said, is that on the Pyongyang black market, the special kind of currency that foreigners use to buy food or clothing is worth 40 times the ordinary currency.
Still, it is difficult to gauge the seriousness of the problems because so little information is available. North Korea rarely admits Western correspondents and even those foreigners who live in the country and speak Korean say they are not allowed to have local friends with whom they can talk freely. There were reports of protest demonstrations last summer, but there is no conclusive evidence and in the past such rumors have often been incorrect. As for the Government's credibility, it is almost non-existent, partly because officials make ludicrous statements such as that there has never been a single murder or rape in the country.
North Korea had been increasingly distressed in recent years by the changes in the Soviet Union, and Pyongyang initially seemed to welcome the coup attempt in Moscow. These days relations between the former comrades are severely strained.
"They go out of their way now to show their malice," said another Russian who lives in Pyongyang. "If we're in a shop and they hear us speak Russian, they scoff at us. If we're in a restaurant, they wait 20 minutes before serving us."
The collapse of the Soviet putsch has not affected the stridency of North Korean rhetoric, which lately has been as xenophobic and unreal as ever.
"Socialism in our country does not waver in the face of the atrocious anti-revolutionary offensive of the imperialists and reactionaries," the Central Broadcasting Station reported last month.
North Korea also seems intent on continuing with its effort to build a nuclear bomb. Pyongyang ridiculed the declarations by American officials that they intended to withdraw nuclear bombs from South Korea as "empty words." A North Korean radio broadcast on Oct. 8 made a remarkable proposal: the North would agree to international inspection of its nuclear facilities only after foreign countries stopped demanding the inspections.
In a step forward, however, the Prime Ministers of South Korea and North Korea agreed Wednesday to work for an accord on easing their mutual hostility. The agreement, still a long way from being implemented, came during the fourth round of meetings between the Prime Ministers.
With the Soviet Union no longer seen as trustworthy, North Korea has moved closer to China. Just this month, the Great Leader spent 10 days touring eastern China and meeting with Chinese leaders. One item high on his agenda presumably was a request for more oil or other assistance, but most experts doubt he got it. The Chinese Foreign Ministry declines to comment, or to confirm reports that beginning in January all trade between China and North Korea will be moved to a hard currency basis.
Kong Dan Oh, a Korea specialist at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., believes that the collapse of Soviet Communism has led to a cleavage within the North Korean leadership about whether more reform is needed. She cites some indications -- including calls for more joint ventures and the rising star of Kim Yong Sun, a senior party official who seems reform-minded -- that those who favor changes may be gaining ground. The recent admission of North Korea into the United Nations may also encourage more pragmatic and responsible attitudes, she believes.
Still Mrs. Oh and most other specialists doubt that North Korea will change drastically so long as Kim Il Sung lives. The next major opportunity for far-reaching change, they say, will be the succession of his son, "Dear Leader" Kim Jong Il. The younger Mr. Kim, who is 49, is generally thought to inspire much less support in the army and party leadership than his father. Perhaps he will unexpectedly institute radical change, or be pushed aside by others.
"The framework for the succession is no problem," Mrs. Oh said. "But Kim Jong Il will have to prove very fast that he has not only the biological legitimacy, but also the brain power to lead." She added: "That's the time we're looking for a crisis."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Soviet Fallback For Economic Reform: Hope for a Miracle

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
In an economy that is half Dostoevskian gloom and half Kafkaesque absurdity, where it is unclear who, if anyone, is in charge, where most prices are fixed, but inflation is soaring by more than 100 percent a year, where staples like eggs and sugar cannot be found in stores, but are somehow hoarded in many homes, where people cry out for a market economy, but brand as criminal anyone who buys an object wholesale and then resells it at a hefty profit, it seems that only a worker of miracles can turn the economic morass into a Western-style success.
But economic policymakers in the Soviet Union -- or what used to be the Soviet Union -- are eager to attempt such miracles because they say if they do not embrace bold reforms the mess will grow only messier. In this divided land it is perhaps not surprising that there are differences over how change should come. Mindful that any scenario is likely to mean more hardship, some leaders, including the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, have shown some reticence amid the warnings of urgency. 
 And while Soviet officials trumpet their desire to move to a market economy, they know that the transformation will be far tougher than Eastern Europe's.
Recognizing this, the United States and other Group of Seven industrial nations have pledged large-scale humanitarian and technical aid to make the transition easier. They are also debating whether to grant Moscow short-term relief in handling its more than $60 billion in foreign debt. But even with such help, optimistic forecasters say the Soviet economy has a minimum of two years of tremendous turmoil ahead.
As with Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, the Soviet Union's economic reforms are coming at the same time as a democratic revolution. But unlike them, the Soviet Union is also undertaking the potentially explosive task of redrawing its political map and shifting power wholesale from the center to the republics. Launching its reforms over a far larger land mass with a much bigger, less homogenous population, the Soviet Union is also set to begin its reforms after its economy has been in free fall for a year. The Eastern Europeans, who endured four decades of Communism, have as another advantage that they can remember how a market economy functions.
Probably the greatest factor working on behalf of economic reform is that the Soviet people, sick of long lines, empty shelves and shoddy products, are ravenous for change. Warnings abound that with a winter of food shortages ahead, the normally stoic Soviet people could explode unless their leaders deliver some palpable change.
"They are coming to the point where enough is enough," said Anders Aslund, director of the Stockholm Institute of Soviet and East European Economies. "They want to have change and they don't see it coming."
 
An Obstacle to Unity
 President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Grigory Yavlinsky, a top economic policymaker, are pushing for quick reform, but their plans have been delayed by the republics' haggling over a barrier-free economic union. Russia and 7 of the 11 other republics have signed the economic union treaty, but the Ukraine, the nation's breadbasket, has refused. But even with 8 republics signing, it appears that the fractious republics rather than the center will call the shots on reform.
The coup's failure eased the road to reform by ousting the conservative forces, but Yevgeny Yasin, chief economist for the association of large state-owned enterprises, said, "In ways, the conditions for radical reform are worse than before because there is no longer any firm executive to push through reforms."
With the center fading, the public is looking to Mr. Yeltsin. But the man who was so decisive in stopping the coup has been Hamlet-like on economic reform. He is caught between two groups of advisers: one wants Russia to coordinate reforms closely with other republics, while the other urges a Russia-first, let-the-others-follow approach. Reformers hope Mr. Yeltsin will embrace radical change soon, perhaps in a program that he has reportedly promised to unveil tomorrow at the opening of the republic's legislature, the Congress of People's Deputies.
Mr. Yeltsin and other policymakers find they must walk a tightrope: once they begin pushing through reforms, the miserable economy is likely to grow worse, before returning to health. Reforms would likely entail removing price controls, slashing food subsidies and the budget deficit, privatizing shops and factories and allowing bankruptcies and layoffs. Economic output is expected to plunge by 17 percent this year, and these reforms could cause a further drop for at least two years, some economists say. Real growth could be three years away, and prosperity, at least a decade or two away.
Ivan Materov, Russia's First Deputy Minister of Economics, predicts that unemployment could soar to 30 percent once reforms are begun, permitting bankruptcies and forcing industry to become more efficient. "We have always thought that one-third of the Soviet economy did not function," he said.
 
Rubles for the Printing
 He added that once price controls are lifted, inflation could soar 800 percent before they start to stabilize. Inflation is already being fueled by the central government's budget deficit, which many economists say will climb this year to more than one-fifth of the gross national product. To finance the deficit, the nation is printing rubles around the clock, and the amount in circulation is expected to soar to twice last year's levels.
The 64,000-ruble question is whether the Soviet people, raised in a land where prices were stable and official unemployment did not exist, can endure the reform-induced shocks without exploding.
Ukrainian officials are convinced, after seeing the chaos in the central government's money supply, that the best way to achieve monetary stability within their republic is to establish their own currency. Byelorussia is weighing the same course.
Many officials argue that if the republics adopt different currencies, that will spur a further economic decline by making it harder to conduct trade among republics. "Keeping the ruble in all the republics will help create an economic union," said Mr. Materov, the Russian official. "In my view, this is much more important than nationalistic considerations. But not everyone buys this view."
The Ukrainians respond that the ruble is already worthless and that this has contributed to the breakdown in inter-republic trade.
To many officials, even more worrisome than the multiplication of currencies is the refusal of some republics to export products to other republics. Fearing shortages at home, the Ukraine is refusing to ship coal to Russia, and Russia is threatening to retaliate by withholding oil shipments.
Many reformers say this every-republic-for-itself approach is a recipe for disaster. What is needed, they say, is a coordinated approach to reform, whether within or without the economic union framework. But among those who would have to implement reforms, the details of such changes are not yet a matter of widespread agreement.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
As Soviet Republics Gain Power, U.S. Scrambles to Decide on a Policy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Speaking before the Ukrainian Parliament in Kiev on Aug. 1 -- 20 days before the Soviet coup attempt -- President Bush put his Administration clearly on the side of a central Soviet government strong enough to pull together republics increasingly separating from each other. Now United States policy, especially on economic matters, is no longer so clear-cut.
"We will maintain the strongest possible relationship with the Soviet government of President Gorbachev," Mr. Bush had declared in Kiev, and he had gone on to argue that economic prosperity in the former Soviet Union required "greater voluntary interaction" among the nation's 12 republics. 
 True, the President hedged his remarks with the statement that the United States also wanted "good relations, improved relations, with the republics." But given the circumstances -- an American President addressing a parliament bent on Ukrainian independence and defiantly critical of Mikhail S. Gorbachev -- the Bush speech stood out as a bold statement of Administration policy: a clear preference for a strong central authority recognized by the republics.
Then came the unsuccessful coup, with its fresh outburst of nationalism and its new blow to the Gorbachev Government. And slowly, reluctantly, the Bush Administration has been moving with the Soviet tide, toning down its call for a Moscow-centered authority and speaking frequently of a "new reality" that requires greater recognition of the republics and more dealings with them.
"Power in the Soviet Union has shifted dramatically from the center to the republics and that heightens the need to deal with the republics," a senior State Department official said last week. "But at the same time, we are saying to the republics, 'Don't overlook the areas of cooperation.' We are nudging them toward the benefits of cooperation."
The Administration's increasingly evident ambivalence is mostly over economic issues. It still holds that political concerns like Mideast peace negotiations and control of the military and nuclear weapons are the province of a central government. But bring up economics -- the glue for nationhood -- and the language changes.
"There is an evolution in U.S. thinking in that we see centrifugal forces at work," said David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs. "Agreements among the republics will replace central institutions."
The implications of this shift are significant. The old Bush Administration preference for a single Soviet currency and a single central bank to preside over its value is giving way in the State Department, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve to talk of accepting multiple currencies and central banks -- if the republics coordinate exchange rates and monetary policies.
"What we would do would be to find ways to link the financial system, to argue for a council of the central banks of the republics," said David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.
 
Backing the Republics

 American food aid, once earmarked for distribution through Moscow, might now go to republics, Administration officials say. There is talk in the Administration of supporting republics that push free market goals. Thus, endorsement would go to those that privatized state companies, removed price ceilings and subscribed to trade agreements that encouraged the flow of goods among the republics. Support would be pulled back, on the other hand, from republics that insisted on pouring funds into a separate military, as the Ukraine plans to do.
Above all, Administration officials insist that the United States cannot control the Soviet drift toward autonomous republics. The American power of the late 1940's, when the Marshall Plan shaped Western Europe, is not an option today. Instead, officials hope that central authority and cooperation will againbe acceptable when the republics see that prosperity requires federation.
"The desire to be separate from a totalitarian center after 70 years of misrule by that center is so strong that you need to have them come to their own conclusions about the benefits of cooperation," the senior State Department official said.
 
Ukraine and Russia
 But that could take a decade, and in the meantime separatism might produce some undesirable results, says Jan Vanous, president of PlanEcon, a Washington research group that specializes in the Eastern bloc. The rich Ukraine could build ties with Western Europe, leaving behind a nation dominated by the huge Russian republic. Russia, with its vast oil and gas deposits, could drain wealth from lesser republics by charging them world market prices for these fuels.
"We are seeing a breakup of the Soviet Union, but it won't break up," Mr. Vanous said. "First, you will see a breakup and then a going-back to a confederation where instead of domination through the army and political force, the domination will be through economic strength."
The Administration's shift in policy was noted at a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations -- the United States, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and Britain -- in Bangkok this month, when Mr. Mulford proposed letting the Soviet Union postpone principal payments on more than $60 billion it owes in foreign debt.
European bankers and governments, to whom most of the money is owed, opposed that idea. But in the Administration's new view, debt repayment requires that the republics put money in a central fund, and neither an inter-republic agreement nor a central fund exist.
"Postponing payment," said Robert D. Hormats, a vice president at Goldman, Sachs & Company, "is a way of getting around the sticky issue for the time being of who owes the debt and who is to pay it."

HEADLINE: North Korea Digs In Its Heels on Nuclear Inspections

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Despite an elaborate international campaign of pressure on North Korea, the Communist Government in Pyongyang appears as determined as ever to become a nuclear military power, and Western diplomats and scientists say they are uncertain what to do about it.
This conclusion has become widely accepted even after the most recent round of direct talks last week in Pyongyang, where Prime Minister Chung Won Shik of South Korea made the latest direct appeal to North Korea to halt its nuclear weapons program and agree to international inspections of its nuclear installations. 
 North Korea has denied that it is developing a nuclear bomb. But the Government of President Kim Il Sung, increasingly isolated and laboring under a collapsing economy, is generally assumed to be pursuing a nuclear weapons program in an effort to preserve its legitimacy.
"I have a feeling it's inevitable," said a Western diplomat who monitors North Korea. "The more a campaign is orchestrated to pressure North Korea, the more they may see nukes as a way to hold on to their power."
 
How Soon a Bomb?
 Analysts differ on how soon North Korea can produce a bomb at its main nuclear research center at Yongbyon, north of Pyongyang. Some Americans and Japanese say it could be five or six years, but the South Koreans say it could be a year or two.
But recent disclosures about Iraq's nuclear weapons program have increased alarm among many experts about North Korea. And Defense Secretary Dick Cheney recently said he feared that the breakup of the Soviet Union could lead Soviet nuclear scientists to sell their expertise to Pyongyang.
The talks last week between the Prime Ministers of North and South Korea did achieve a modest breakthrough in easing tensions. The two sides dropped some of their most extreme demands and agreed to try to negotiate a single comprehensive peace accord.
But on all major issues of substance, the two sides remained far apart, and discussions on the nuclear issue hit at an apparent dead end.
"We could not find any significant change in the position of the north," Chang Man Soon, South Korea's assistant foreign minister, told reporters at the end of the talks.
 
Opposition Hardened
 Indeed, North Korea's opposition to inspections hardened, with Pyongyang demanding not only that all American nuclear weapons be removed from South Korean soil, but also that Seoul renounce the United States nuclear umbrella before it would agree to nuclear inspections.
Moreover, North Korea's official Communist Party newspaper went back to the old tones of vilification after the talks, accusing Seoul of "brazen and provocative" behavior in its demands for nuclear inspections.
North Korea's newest hard-line position meant that President Bush's recent moves on nuclear disarmament had failed to achieve any immediate dividends in the Korean peninsula.
Not only has the North Korean response been negative, but South Korean officials privately say they are nervous and uneasy that Mr. Bush is rushing into a conventional and nuclear withdrawal of the American military presence from South Korea without any concessions from Pyongyang.
South Korean officials make it clear that their concerns will be presented forcefully to President Bush when he visits Seoul in December.
 
Further U.S. Reductions
 There were 43,000 American troops in South Korea last year, but the Pentagon has cut the number to 39,000 at present and plans to reduce it to 36,000 next year. There have been reports in the Korean press that the Bush Administration plans to lower the number to 30,000 by the mid-1990's.
The reductions are described as being dictated more by budget problems than any policy of withdrawal from Asia, and Bush Administration officials insist that they will not lessen American preparedness here.
But in addition to cuts in conventional forces, President Bush announced plans earlier this month to remove all remaining nuclear weapons from South Korea as part of his plan to eliminate tactical nuclear weapons worldwide.
American officials decline to supply any numbers. But Robert Norris, an analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, estimates that the United States has about 40 nuclear-tipped artillery shells in Korea and another 60 nuclear bombs stored at Kunsan Air Base near Seoul.
 
Public and Private Views
 In public, South Korean officials have welcomed all these unilateral disarmament proposals, saying they would offer an incentive to North Korea to follow suit. The measures may also soothe the fears of South Koreans who do not like the idea of their country as a nuclear battleground.
But in private, many South Koreans are nervous that Mr. Bush may leave their country vulnerable. Officials decline to be quoted on this sensitive subject, but they indicate that the Ministry of Defense and the armed forces are especially upset about the latest American initiatives.
"People fear that all these pullouts may be premature, especially if North Korea doesn't concede anything in return," said Yang Sung Chul, professor of political science at Kyung Hee University in Seoul. "Bush will have to reassure South Korea on that score when he's here."
Already, for instance, the South Korean military is saying it wants the United States to compensate for the withdrawals by selling sophisticated new military equipment. Washington is unenthusiastic about such sales, because doing so would tacitly dmit that it is indeed leaving South Korea more vulnerable.
 
Fear of Military Action
 There is also a fear that the South Korean military may use this feeling of vulnerability to strike out on its own in some fashion. No one fears a military takeover right now in Seoul, but South Korea remains shadowed by its history of the military taking things into its own hands. Especially unsettling are the repeated comments of the Defense Minister, Lee Jong Koo, that a commando raid or some other military action might be necessary to stop North Korea from making its bomb.
South Korea has scored enormous gains in its campaign to isolate North Korea diplomatically. The Soviet Union has recognized the Seoul Government, China is improving its ties and last month Seoul fulfilled a longtime wish when both North and South Korea entered the United Nations.
The Soviet Union, which may have supplied some of North Korea's nuclear technology, is now pressing Pyongyang to accept inspections. So are countries in Europe, including former allies of Pyongyang in Eastern Europe.
Finally, Japan has insisted on nuclear inspections before it would consider any of the financial aid that North Korea desperately needs. Still, North Korea is seen as going ahead with its bomb, in part because it seems to feel even less secure as the world unites in telling it what to do.

HEADLINE: A Dying Fish May Force California to Break Its Water Habits

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SUISUN CITY, Calif.

 BODY:
A decade ago, Peter Moyle would trawl the sloughs of the Suisun Marsh and haul in nets thick with delta smelt, an unremarkable creature smelling of cucumber and barely three inches long that was of interest only to a few fishery biologists.
Now the delta smelt is all but gone from these brackish waters and is vanishing elsewhere in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River delta, a casualty of California's drought and the huge pumping projects that divert fresh water from the rivers and estuaries in the northern half of the state to the farms and cities of the arrid south. 
 Unheralded when it was plentiful, the delta smelt has become a cause celebre in its passing, a little fish that could have a big impact both on water policy in California and on the future of the Endangered Species Act, the nation's most powerful environmental law.
 
Blocking the Water Pumps
 Last month, after much dispute and delay, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service proposed that the delta smelt be listed as a threatened species, the start of an 18-month process that could lead to protection of the fish and its critical habitat.
Environmentalists hailed the proposal as a step toward preserving the fragile delta ecosystem, a varied and dense seam of nature where the smelt is just one of many species that once flourished and are now in decline.
Farmers and water suppliers, on the other hand, predicted doom for the state's flagging economy and hardship for its 30 million citizens if the pumps were slowed at the state's primary water source.
The debate is reaching full boil as Congress prepares to reauthorize financing for the 1973 Endangered Species Act next year. And it comes at a time of growing concern in some quarters that wildlife conservation has gone too far, that jobs are being sacrificed to nature.
 
Saving Species or Jobs
 "Times are different now and it's not just some abstract law," said Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for Manuel Lujan Jr., the Secretary of the Interior and one of several members of the Bush Administration who has indicated a desire to weaken the Endangered Species Act. "It's one thing for you or I to say we must protect species at any cost. But what if the cost is your father's job?"
Environmentalists are aware that the act, always the subject of some dispute, will be scrutinized this time around as never before.
"The people whose toes are being stepped on want to weaken the law, that's for sure," said Michael R. Sherwood, a staff lawyer with the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund in San Francisco. "But endangered species remain popular with people at large. There may be some fine tuning of the act, but I'm confident it won't be substantially weakened."
To date, the most bitter environmental battle of the decade, and the biggest challenge to the Federal law, pitted the timber interests of the Pacific Northwest against the defenders of the northern spotted owl, which is dying out because of heavy logging in the ancient forests. The owl was listed as a threatened species in 1990 after years of litigation, which is also expected in the case of the delta smelt.
And looming is another collision between conservation and commerce, this one involving the California gnatcatcher, a tiny songbird that lives in the chapparal along the Southern California coast, a habitat much prized by real estate developers.
 
'Worthless Little Minnow'
 The delta smelt is sometimes compared to the snail darter, which delayed construction of the Tellico Dam in Tennessee in the mid-1970's. Both are small fish of little innate appeal -- harder creatures to warm up to, say, than owls, grizzly bears or even salmon.
"For Joe Sixpack, it's just a worthless little minnow," said Jason Peltier, the manager of the Central Valley Project Water Association, an organization of 80 urban and agricultural contractors.
Defenders of the delta smelt, or Hypomesus transpacificus, know that pleading the case of this fish will not be easy.
"We seem to relate better to mammals than to reptiles, to plants with big showy flowers and to insects with big showy wings, like butterflies," said Gail Kobetich, a field supervisor in the Sacramento office of the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service. She recommended an "endangered" listing for the smelt, which was overridden in Washington in favor of the lesser category of protection.
The argument for the smelt must be made on much broader grounds, environmentalists say. "What's at stake here is not a little fish, it's a whole ecosystem," said Thomas J. Graff, a lawyer with the Environmental Defense Fund in Oakland.
The smelt population has declined sharply since 1979, when Mr. Moyle, a professor at the University of California at Davis, first began counting them. A decade ago, he counted hundreds of smelt each season in Montezuma's Slough, which meanders through Suisun Marsh, also home to otter and elk, egrets and kingfishers, bulrushes and wild fennel.
But in the last five years, in the largest estuarian marsh in America, Mr. Moyle has netted a total of three delta smelt, which feed on zooplankton and are themselves nourishment for larger fish. Overall in the delta, Mr. Moyle said, the smelt population has dropped 90 percent, to 280,000 from 2.6 million.
Other species are also suffering from altered conditions in the delta, Mr. Moyle, Mr. Graff and others say. The striped bass catch has been meager in recent years. There are hardly any salmon, and last year five salmon species were listed as threatened. There are fewer catfish, fewer opossum shrimp, and, of course, fewer fisherman on the levees of the murky rivers.
Because the smelt live only one year and reproduce during prime pumping season for the reservoirs, between February and May, the fish is a particularly vivid indicator species. It requires a spawning and nursery ground where clear Sierra Nevada runoff mixes with salty ocean water -- in other words, an estuarial basin where rivers meet the sea.
That so-called mixing zone here in the delta has shrunk substantially in recent years because of the drought and the operation of the two huge pumps in nearby Byron and Tracy, which siphon off millions of acre feet of fresh water that would otherwise flow west, through Suisun Bay, San Pablo Bay, San Francisco Bay, under the Golden Gate and into the Pacific Ocean.
No one is sure what exact measures will have to be taken to protect the smelt if it is listed as a threatened species. But there is widespread agreement that it would include some restriction on the pumping stations, which provide water to thousands of farms and to two of every three residential customers in California.
The likelihood of restricted pumping has prompted water suppliers to make gloomy assessments, beginning with a seat-of-the-pants guess that one-third of the water that passes through the delta would not be delivered. The suppliers predict draconian rationing, acre upon acre of fallowed fields and countless lost jobs.
"This translates into tremendous economic and social dislocation," said Mr. Peltier. "Can we tolerate putting other animals ahead of homo sapiens, because that's what the Endangered Species Act does?"
 
Defining the Choice
 In counterpoint, the prospect of less pumping is a cause for celebration among those who consider California's system of pricing and distributing water to be irrational and inefficient, encouraging farmers to squander the scarce resource because they buy it at below-market rates.
Among these advocates of water reform is Representative George Miller, the new chairman of the House Interior Committee, who has earned the enmity of the agricultural interests here by pushing legislation that would alter their historic water rights. The demise of the delta smelt, Mr. Miller said, "only confirms what we already know -- that the state and Federal water projects are being run in an irresponsible fashion, subsidizing these farmers with our own environment."
If the system were redesigned, advocates of water reform say, there would be plenty of water for farms and cities and to protect the environment as well.
"There may be situations that come down to protection of a species or economic well-being, but this isn't one of them," said Mr. Graff. "We do not have to choose between the agricultural industry, the drinking water in Los Angeles and San Francisco and this little fish. That is a false dichotomy. That is just political rhetoric."
 
At the Pumping Station
 Even at the state water project pumping station in Byron, about 50 miles southeast of Suisun Marsh, there is some pro-smelt sentiment. Just ask Marvin J. Niemi, the chief of operations, who recently showed a visitor around the massive, rumbling plant.
Mr. Niemi explained the workings of seven electric pumps that set steel shafts spinning. He pointed to the head of the California Aqueduct, where the water begins its journey through the Central Valley, over the Tehachapi Mountains and into the Los Angeles Basin. He raved about the aluminum louvers that divert 17 million fish each year from the pumps that would otherwise kill them.
What Mr. Niemi does is move water, thousands upon thousands of acre feet of it, and so he has given plenty of thought to the possibility that pumping could be restricted because of a little fish.
"It's something that's way out of my field," Mr. Niemi said. "But looking at the other ecological mistakes man has made, you've got to respect that."

Status of some of the American speices listed as endagered or threatened.
 
Black-Footed Ferret: Ranged through the Great Plains from Montana to northern Texas. Placed on endangered species list in 1967. Breeding program began in 1987. First ferrets were returned to the wild in September 1991.
 
California Condor: Ranged from British Columbia to Baja California. Placed on endagered list in 1967. Fifty-two are in captivity. Two birds are being reintroduced into the wild this fall in a sanctuary north of Los Angeles.
 
Bald Eagle: Listed as endangered in lower 48 states in 1967. Population declined because of shooting, loss of habitat, and pesticides like DDT that weakened egg shells. Making a comeback and may be classified threatened in some areas.
 
Grizzly Bear: Listed as threatened in lower 48 states in 1975. Decline due to shooting, trapping and poisoning. The status is reported as stable, with recovery efforts centered on the Rockey Mountain area.
 
Snall Darter: Listed as endangered in 1974 and reclassified as threatened in 1984. Only known population was in the Tennessee River, halting construction on the Tellico Dam, a decision upheld by the Supreme Court. Congress disagreed and transplants of the fish were planned, before populations were found elsewhere.
 
Whooping Crane: Listed as endangered in 1967. Tallest North American bird, with males standing 4 1/2 feet. Ranged over most of North America, but declined due to hunting and agriculture,. At low point in 1941, 16 birds migrated to Texas for winter. Population is now 150.
 
American Crocodile: Listed as endangered in 1975. Found in tidal marshes of the Everglades and in Florida Keys. Hunting is major cause of decline. Now about 500 adults in the wild.
 
Northern Spotted Owl: Listed as threatened in June 1990. Found in forested areas of the Pacific Northwest. Fish and Wildlife Service is in the process of designating a critical habitat, which may include areas used for logging.
 
(Source: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service)

HEADLINE: The Banks That Built Connecticut Are Crumbling Under the Recession

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 25

 BODY:
The mid-sized banks that helped build Connecticut, and then basked for decades in the state's image of Yankee industry and wealth, have been smashed by the recession and are not likely to recover soon, if ever, economists and bankers say.
Two years ago, Connecticut looked smugly north toward the troubles of banks in Massachussets. Now the state is facing some of worst banking problems in the nation: a financial landscape dominated by big money-center banks from out of state, small local banks that are left with little power and a general tightening of lending policies and jobs. 
"I would call it a credit catastrophe rather than a crisis," said Peter M. Gioia, the director of research for the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, the state's largest business group. "Banking in Connecticut is changed forever from this."
 
13 Banks Seized in 10 Months
 In the last 10 months, 13 commercial banks with assets of nearly $12 billion have been seized by Federal regulators, including two more last week. That represents one-eighth of all the banks in the nation taken over by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in 1991, and more than 19 percent of the total assets seized. In the most recent reports in June, Connecticut banks had the highest percentage of bad loans, on which borrowers were three months or more behind on payments, of any state.
Although Federal deposit insurance has prevented the kinds of depositers' losses that were common in the 1930's, the state's last great rash of bank failures, the wave of seizures and bleak headlines have regularly reinforced an impression of a deep recession. That impression has added its own momentum to the downturn, some bankers and economists say, by tightening the lending policies of the banks that remain.
What has been almost as unsettling, especially for an industry where counting and careful planning is part of the ethos, is the lack of precedent. Falling real-estate prices and falling employment on top of a go-go decade's worth of optimistically acquired debt have made study of past recessions little help in gauging this one.
"In 20 years, I've never seen anything comparable to it in terms of the size or the impact that the problems have had," said Robert J. Higgins, the chairman and chief executive of Fleet Bank, a unit of the Fleet/Norstar Financial Corporation, a company based in Providence, R.I., that took over the failed Connecticut Bank and Trust Company this year. "I don't think we've bottomed out, but at what point we are on the cycle I'm not sure."
 
Pending Bankruptcy Cases Up
 In past recessions, for example, people who got behind on home mortgages because of lost jobs could sell their homes and get out from under the debt.
"Now if we rattle the saber, the person says, 'What can I do? I've got the house on the market and it's the third one on the block,' " said Thomas E. Hylinski, a vice president for residential lending at People's Bank, one of the state's largest mortgage lenders.
And while falling real-estate prices have been a phenomenon throughout the New York metropolitan region, Connecticut's problems have been aggravated by its dependence on a defense industry that is in retreat, and by its geographic and economic ties to Massachusetts and the rest of New England, where the banking crisis has been centered. For the 12-month period ending on June 30, Connecticut had the second sharpest increase in the nation in pending bankruptcy cases, up 77.6 percent over the previous year. Rhode Island was first and Massachusetts was third, according to Federal Bankruptcy Court figures.
Behind the numbers are tens of thousands of individual stories: from people who lost jobs and fell behind on their mortgages, to real-estate developers who borrowed money to build condominiums or office buildings that could not be rented or sold, to healthy businesses that found that they could not expand because banks had become gun shy about taking risks.
 
State Losing Economic Culture
 In addition, an entire slice of the state's economic culture is being lost because the victims of the crisis have been so heavily concentrated among the mid-sized state banks that linked their fortunes to those of Connecticut. The Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, the state's largest bank last year, had roots in the 19th century as a center of Connecticut economic life. Fleet/Norstar is to begin changing the names on Connecticut Bank signs and closing down 34 branches over the next two months.
In August, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, based in New York, took over two other failed Connecticut-centered banks, Citytrust and Mechanics and Farmers Savings Bank. Chase says some branches of both will have to be closed.
"Maybe we've all been too spoiled," said Thaila Kottler-Watkins, who was laid off from her job as a retail sales clerk last year. Ms. Kottler-Watkins said she and her husband have fallen more than $3,000 behind on the $688-a-month mortgage on their home in Unionville, even though the bank, American Savings, already set up a flexible payment plan in which the couple pays whatever they can each week.
She said she would find out on Monday whether the family qualified for a Federal Housing Authority mortgage that would allow payments to be reduced or worked out over time.
 
Dealing With Troubled Loans
 Other banks have for the first time established specific units to deal with troubled mortgages. At Bridgeport-based People's Bank, for instance, the new home mortgage "workout" department is designed to select delinquent mortgages in which some accommodation might be found, like lowering monthly payments to keep the customers in their houses and at least paying something to the bank.
Bank officers say their motivation is, at least in part, to help themselves. With foreclosures in Connecticut up more than 300 percent over the last two years, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, and prices continuing to fall, the last thing many banks want is to seize property that might be worth less in six months than it is now.
"Are we more liberal than we have generally been? Yes," said Mr. Hylinski in the residential lending department. "We look for more creative solutions because it's in our best interest."
Ray Landreville, a Stratford resident who said his household income has fallen about 50 percent in the two years since he was laid off from his construction supply job, said he and his wife, Annie, did not want to wait until we were "panic stricken." They called People's Bank in July, just as Mr. Landreville's final unemployment checks were coming in.
 
Refinancing Troubled Mortgage
 "We went to them and said, 'Next month we're not going to have the money; that's where we're at,' " Mr. Landreville said. The bank refinanced the loan, reduced the monthly payments by about $200, to just under $600, and set up an escrow account under which the Landrevilles would have to pay only half of the monthly bill for eight months. But the deal had its price: the couple lost all the equity they had paid down on their modest duplex home in 1985.
Other casualties can be measured in the dashed hopes of those who tried to ride the banking wave and contributed to what some economists say was an oversupply of lending institutions. Between 1984 and 1991, 36 new state-charted banks started doing business in Connecticut, according to the state Department of Banking, compared with only 13 new banks in the 14-year period before that.
Whether the bottom is near or still yet to come is also a matter of speculation, although even the most optimistic banking officials say that the wave of failures is not over. Some see a rosy view if only in that some old bankers have learned new tricks.
"The adjustment to a recession and falling real-estate prices was traumatic," said Nicholas Perna, chief economist for Connecticut National Bank, a unit of the Shawmut National Corporation in Boston. "But we're fully adjusted now."

HEADLINE: Garment Makers Find New Home in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Beyond a sprawling storage room piled high with fabrics and filled with rack upon rack of skirts, scores of mostly Chinese workers attend to the meticulous but mind-numbingly repetitive tasks of attaching zippers and pockets with row upon row of Japanese-made Juki sewing machines.
The scene, at first glance, is familiar to anyone who has ventured into the small garment-making shops that have been a fixture for generations in crowded Chinatown and in commercial buildings in lower Manhattan. But this garment contractor, called the Metropolitan Fashion Center, neither fits the Jacob Riis-like image of a brutalizing sweatshop nor is it in Manhattan. 
 The center, which is in the historic Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park, is only the most prominent of a growing number of garment manufacturers and contractors that have moved to the 97-acre terminal, which is being rehabilitated as an industrial park. The terminal, which was the embarkation point for millions of American troops during World War II, has become a magnet, particularly for Chinese-owned garment-makers because of its proximity to New York's third and newest Chinatown, in Sunset Park.
 
Economic Success Story
 Although it accounts for only a small part of the city's garment trade, the terminal is a rare economic success story for Brooklyn in 1991, and a major provider of jobs for Sunset Park.
"We moved here in February because Manhattan has become more expensive, and this gives us more space," said Edison Wong, managing director of this consortium of 22 Chinatown-based garment-makers, explaining why they have set up shop on the fifth floor of the terminal's Building B.
Indeed, Mr. Wong's consortium is far from alone in the 5 million-square-foot, eight-story building. Two floors below Metropolitan Fashion, at E. B. Design, dozens of women in white frocks and caps laminate thousands of earrings a day, while others glue rhinestones to pieces of costume jewelry. And on the fourth floor, at J. Abouchar & Sons, women fold and staple pricing bar codes onto mountains of multicolored towels that are embroidered next door in a room filled with the relentless din of 100 sewing machines.
"This is the cleanest and best-developed factory I've worked in," said Sean Reagan, a designer for E. B. Design, whose 160 employees, mostly of Chinese, Hispanic or Russian descent, reflect the polyglot population of southwestern Brooklyn. The company had moved from Coney Island.
 
2,000 Jobs at Terminal
 About 40 garment- and apparel-making companies, with about 2,000 employees, have moved into the partially renovated waterfront complex in the last few years, said Ira N. Brophy, the terminal's director of industrial business development.
And because of economic need, demographic change and city planning, the Army Terminal is rapidly becoming a new hub for New York City's garment industry. Small manufacturers have been attracted to the building not only because of its comparatively low rents but also because of its proximity to the expanding community of Chinese immigrants who have settled in Sunset Park, largely since the mid-1980's -- and who provide a convenient labor pool for an industry that has long employed many Chinese workers.
Other apparel-related companies that have moved in include Crest Shoulder Pads, True Colors Sportswear, with a $10 million-a-year business in medium-priced sportswear, and Frank Mode, which makes women's coats and employs about 200 sewing-machine operators.
Specialized garment contractors, like Gem Knitting, Lazer Beam and A & T Stitching and Pleating, also rent space in the terminal, as do even more esoteric fabric-related businesses, like Linen Star, which buys close-out sheets from manufacturers and remakes them to fit the needs of hospitals.
Also typical of the many light-manufacturing tenants are Lowell Light, which makes photographic lighting equipment, and C & W Sewing Machine Attachments, founded by Felix Salganik, a Soviet emigre.
Among the other tenants are the in-house printing divisions of financial-services companies, like Smith Barney and Salomon Brothers; the New York Railcar Corporation, a renovator of subway cars, and a repair shop for the Circle Line sightseeing boats.
But space, rents of about $5 a square foot and a nearby population desperately in need of jobs are not the only reasons that this mammoth, indoor industrial park is among New York's relatively few economic success stories in 1991. The landmark building has been transformed into a futuristic complex that, as Mr. Reagan said, "is like something out of 'Blade Runner.' " In fact, the Ridley Scott movie, as well as episodes of the television series "Kojak" and music videos by performers like the Rolling Stones have been filmed here.
More than 3 million American soldiers passed through the terminal en route to combat during World War II, but it fell into disuse in the late 1960's after serving as an Army postal building and as a site where bodies of American servicemen killed in the Vietnam War were brought.
The city bought the terminal in 1981 for $8.5 million, renovated the northern half of Building B by 1987 and the southern half last fall at a cost of $77 million. Renovation of part of Building A is to begin soon, but a timetable for work on other buildings in the complex has not been set, Mr. Brophy said.
Despite New York's economic problems, Mr. Brophy said the city's investment has been vindicated by the terminal's growth into a center for the garment industry and other light manufacturing. "Our public purpose has been to stop the industrial out-migration from New York," he said. "The 40 companies here are 40 companies that probably would have left the city."

HEADLINE: TAIWAN SETS PLAN TO REBUILD NATION

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
Like the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, Taiwan wants to modernize its concrete skylines and cracking sewers, but unlike them, Taiwan not only has the dreams but also the money -- $72 billion in official foreign exchange reserves, more than any other country.
And so it has embarked on a bold program to lift itself into the upper ranks of developed nations, planning to spend more than $300 billion for new railroads and highways, a subway system, power plants, refineries, schools, housing, medical facilities, water treatment plants and sewage systems. The six- year construction program -- which will cost more than three times as much as rebuilding Kuwait -- has prompted a contest among American and other foreign contractors for some of the biggest plums of the 1990's. 
 The 779 projects involved in the plan were announced by Prime Minister Hau Pei-tsun this summer. The magnitude of the proposals stunned many business people.
 
'A Gigantic Project'
 "This is a gigantic project and will be Premier Hau's legacy," said James F. O'Hearn, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei. "There aren't too many six-year plans around the world where countries have the money, capability, intent and the wherewithal to make them happen."
American executives estimate that Taiwan will spend $50 billion to $70 billion on foreign purchases over the next six years. Japanese and European companies are expected to be among the major bidders, but American companies have historically won a large number of contracts there. Although the United States has no diplomatic relations with Taiwan, in 1990 American companies received 34 percent of Taiwan's major contracts, worth about $650 million, many of them part of the six-year plan.
American companies are likely to be strong bidders to provide engineering expertise and equipment for incineration, pollution control, oil refining, transportation and communications.
The General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation have built all three of Taiwan's nuclear power plants and are strong contenders to build the fourth, which is part of the plan. Companies like Combustion Engineering Inc., Ebasco Services Inc. and Sargent & Lundy that have supplied equipment for the other plants are also likely to vie for contracts.
 
Rapid Transit Contracts
 American companies have also won leading roles in Taipei's effort to build the initial phase of its first rapid- transit system. The Union Railcar Partnership, of Yonkers, won a $170 million contract for the rail cars; the General Railway Signal Company, of Rochester, received a $100 million contract for signaling equipment, and a consortium that included Bechtel Group Inc. won a large share of $200 million worth of engineering consulting business. "We have tremendous interest in it," said a representative of an American company bidding on contracts. "There are big, big dollars."
But American companies will be locked out of the main contract for a high-speed railway system, partly because the United States does not have such a system. Instead, companies from Japan, France and Germany will compete.
Purchases of American equipment and technology should help reduce the United States' trade deficit with Taiwan, which declined only slightly in 1990, to $11.9 billion -- the second highest deficit, after Japan. Taiwan, which had a total trade volume last year of $122 billion, is clearly mindful of the impact that contracts can have on its trade balances with other nations. Last year, Taiwan had an overall surplus of $12.5 billion. Because Taiwan has a trade deficit with Japan, it has opened bidding in some cases only to American and European companies.
 
Wealth, but Little Gloss
 Despite its astounding economic development of the last few decades and its enormous wealth today, Taiwan's appearance is dull. Mercedes- Benz and Porsche automobiles fill the streets of Taipei, but scarcely move during rush hour because of the poorly designed traffic system.
The reasons for such disparities have much to do with Taiwan's history. The Nationalist Chinese regime that fled here in 1949, after its defeat on the mainland, saw the island as a base and temporary refuge, and always intended to return to the mainland. Only in the last few years, as the older generation has died off, have Government leaders seemed to reconcile themselves to the notion that Taiwan is their home, and well worth modernizing.
Taipei is planning to finance most of the projects through its normal annual revenue sources, and economic planning officials say the Government can pay all but one-eighth, or about $38 billion, of the costs without dipping significantly into its foreign exchange reserves. To cover the shortfall, Taiwan says it will probably issue bonds and encourage the private sector to invest in some projects.
 
Diplomacy May Benefit
 The Government's goals in announcing such a huge program are in part diplomatic. Officials are trying to entice government delegations from countries, including the United States, that no longer have diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
In August, the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei sent a letter to President Bush calling on him to lift a ban on visits by Cabinet-level officials to Taiwan. The chamber fears that visits by European delegations will encourage the Government to award many contracts to European, rather than American, companies.
Taiwan's leaders respond coyly to suggestions that they are using the plan to reduce their diplomatic isolation.
"If people have the kind of assumption we are using this economic strength to upgrade our political relations with other countries, this is wrong," John H. Chang, a vice foreign minister, said in an interview. "The only purpose and goal of the six-year plan is to upgrade the quality of life on this island. If at the same time we can help further develop relations with other countries, why not?"
 
Skeptics See a '12-Year Plan'
 Critics of Taiwan's plans point out that past large-scale projects have encountered delays. Now the Government will face squabbles over eminent domain as it tries to purchase land from people who may not want to sell at Government prices. It will be a tall order merely to assemble the needed labor and materials in six years.
Some business executives are skeptical that the projects will be completed on schedule and mockingly refer to the program as the "12-year plan." It has also been criticized for its scale and for the packaging of old, continuing projects with new ones to attract greater attention from the foreign business community.
About 60 percent of the projects are already in planning or construction, some for several years.
 
Growing Wealth
 For some time, Taiwan has successfully relied on labor-intensive industries to create wealth. After years of rapid economic growth, per capita income is about $8,000. While that leaves Taiwan well behind the United States' figure of $20,900, South Korea is at only $4,400 and China is at $350, according to the World Bank. Now, Taiwan authorities hope the economy will grow by 7 percent a year so that per capita income will reach $14,000 by 1996.
The spending plan is the clearest sign of Taiwan's recognition that it must upgrade its technology and move into more sophisticated industries if it wants to increase its wealth. Thus, the plan also includes money to improve manufacturing processes, enhance research and development in many industries, including agriculture and electronics, and expand Taiwan's airports and airplane fleet.
Besides spurring economic growth in the next decade, the plan is a means of gaining foreign expertise, technology and equipment to build a base for growth in the next generation. "It is something desperately needed," said Liang Chang, president of the Shearson-Global Financial Services Company. "This is a chance to show how to build a country."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Democrats Try to Cool Tax Fever With Campaign Cash

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 25

 BODY:
New Jersey Republicans may have outrage working for them in state legislative races on Nov. 4, but the Democrats have the money.
Anger over the Florio administration's $2.8 billion tax program has prompted grass-roots campaigns to unseat incumbents and support Republican candidates. But collectively, incumbents have raised $2 million more than their challengers, and Democrats, the targets of the anti-tax sentiment, have raised and spent more than Republicans. 
 Democrats control the Governor's office and both houses of the Legislature and have been able to use that political muscle to mine political contributions that match the level of fund-raising in 1987, the last year all 120 seats in both the Senate and General Assembly were on the ballot.
Total fund-raising by all candidates reached $7 million this month, according to figures released by the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission, and is expected to top $14 million when final campaign reports are submitted after the election. At this point in 1987 all candidates had reported raising $7.3 million, and the final amount raised was $14.8 million.
 
Appearance Tomorrow Night
 The Democratic State Committee reported having about $2.1 million on hand, and the Republican State Committee $775,000. Since then the Republicans have had one fund-raising event that Jeff Michaels, executive director of the Republican committee, said brought in about $150,000. He said the party is expecting another financial boost from the appearance on Monday of Nicholas S. Brady, the Secretary of Treasury and a New Jersey resident.
"We're going to keep raising money until the end and spend every penny of it," Mr. Michaels said. In addition to intensive tracking of voter sentiment starting this weekend and sending campaign mailings, the Republican campaign will increase its use of radio advertisements attacking Gov. Jim Florio's tax program and the Democratic incumbents who voted for it. Republicans are also considering buying television time.
 
'Still Very Bullish'
 The state's Republican chairman, Assemblyman Robert D. Franks of New Providence, said he believes that the party "has enough money to get the job done, but I have a certain level of discomfort from the fact that the Democrats have raised three times the amount of money we have."
"I'm still very bullish about our chances of capturing the Legislature," he said, "but it catches your attention."
The Republican strategy is to picture the Governor's tax program as aggravating the effects of the recession instead of positioning the state to rebound. Democratic candidates avoid talking about the tax program, but several campaign on the benefits, likeincreased rebates to homeowners to offset property taxes and increased aid to education paid for by the taxes.
The executive director of the Democratic State Committee, Steve DeMicco, said that in addition to a larger cash reserve, the state party is getting help from the national organization in the closing days of the campaign, something the Republicans have not yet been able to report.
The party will have the money to take people to the polls, and several staffers from the Democratic National Committee have already arrived to lend expertise "in very precise targeting" of likely Democratic supporters to be taken to the polls, Mr. DeMicco said. Earlier in the campaign, the state committee hired campaign managers, some from out of state, to run legislative campaigns in the close districts and provided support in polling and consulting.
Mr. DeMicco said the Republican campaign strategy of making Mr. Florio and his tax program the issue has had limited success. "They aimed a bullet at the Governor and hoped it would ricochet, or pass through and hit our candidates," he said. "It has succeeded in suppressing the Governor's popularity numbers, but it hasn't affected the ability of our legislative candidates to get their messages out."
But some of those messages adopt an anti-Florio stance, showing that some Democratic candidates are worried about the Governor's lack of popularity. A campaign mailer paid for by the Democratic State Committee for Senator Paul J. Contillo, Democrat of Paramus, who did not vote for the Governor's income tax, describe him as one Democratic senator who "had the guts to vote against Florio's tax plan." The mailer states: "Paul took a careful look at the plan. He saw that hard-working families struggling to make ends meet would be hurt."
 
Shift of a Few Seats
 Mr. Contillo's 38th legislative district is one of seven that leaders of both parties say could hold the key to control of the Legislature. Democrats now hold a 23-to-17 majority in the Senate and a 43-to-37 majority in the Assembly. The shift of a few seats could give Republicans control of both houses for the first time in 20 years.
Collectively, Democratic candidates reported raising $3.8 million and spending $2.7 million by Oct. 11, while Republican candidates raised $3.1 million and spent $2 million, according to election commission figures. By contrast, although there are 47 minor-party and independent candidates -- more than in any previous legislative election -- they have been able to raise a total of only $92,842 and have spent $45,499.

HEADLINE: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS;
U.S. HOPES SESSIONS ON MIDEAST CREATE A NEW ATMOSPHERE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Bush Administration policy makers say the core of their strategy for the Madrid peace talks is very simple: keep the Arabs and Israelis talking long enough to create a changed environment so breakthroughs that now seem impossible might become possible.
There is no "Bush peace plan" that the President will suddenly pull out of a briefcase when he arrives in Madrid, replete with maps, compromises and novel ideas to settle all outstanding issues, say American officials who have been planning for the peace conference, which opens on Wednesday. 
 But there is an American conviction that the very act of getting all the parties to sit down with one another for the first time will create a new dynamic between them and open the door for compromises down the road. The United States plans to nurture such compromises, first from the sidelines and later as a direct mediator with bridging proposals of its own if the parties alone cannot make any headway.
 
The U.S. Balancing Act
 The trick, say American officials, will be to carry out such mediation without supplanting the direct, face-to-face encounter between the parties, which is essential for changing how they look at, and deal with, one another.
The Administration's strategy, said one senior policy maker, is based on the assumption that over time "the very act of the parties' sitting down will begin to shatter mythologies on both sides." In particular, they hope to destroy the Israeli argument that there are no Arabs to talk to, and the Arab argument that all the Israelis want is Arab lands.
But for those long-held views to be shed, and for concrete peace agreements to be produced, the senior official added, "it is critical that this process continue over time."
 
Defining Areas of Substance
 He elaborated: "The longer these negotiations go on, the greater the likelihood that areas of substance will be defined to hook them into something that in fact is a real negotiation."
Officials acknowledge that this strategy is untested, and has three potential weaknesses. First, they could discover that the problem between Arabs and Israelis is not that they fail to understand each other, but that they understand each other all too well, and therefore the more they talk directly, the more the fundamental disagreements will be highlighted instead of bridged.
Second, a change of the atmosphere and dynamics between Arab nations and Israel ultimately requires change within the countries. Is a minority Government like Syria's -- dominated by members of the small Alawite sect of Islam in a country with a Sunni Muslim majority -- really ready to end its conflict with Israel and slash its army? Can Israel's governing Likud party, whose very raison d'etre is its commitment to keeping the West Bank, conclude agreements that would gut its ideological core?
Third, the United States did not get the parties to agree to talk by gentle dialogue, but by using economic clout over Israel, by letting the leaders of Saudi Arabia know that they owed Washington for the Persian Gulf war, by using the Soviet Union and the Saudis to press the Syrians and by tacitly threatening the Palestinians with international isolation.
 
Washington's Hardball Tactics
 American officials say privately they know that these same hardball tactics, if not tougher ones, will be required to promote actual agreements. But the challenge will be to twist arms without contradicting the terms of the conference, which President Bush described innocently on Friday as not intended "to impose a settlement" but "to bring people together so they can achieve a settlement."
For now, Washington is not discussing these issues publicly. To pursue its strategy -- which was worked out by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Administration's senior Middle East experts, Dennis B. Ross, Daniel C. Kurtzer, Aaron D. Miller, Richard N. Haass and William J. Burns -- Washington has evolved a game plan.
It deals with each phase of the talks: from the three-day opening conference at the Royal Palace in Madrid starting on Wednesday, through the first bilateral negotiations that will follow that meeting and into the third phase of detailed negotiations.
Phase one in the Administration's strategy involves getting the most mileage from the ceremonial opening in Madrid.
 
Bush's Presentation
 President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will address the opening session. Mr. Bush is planning to use the opportunity, officials say, to lay out a broad American vision of why peace is in everyone's interest, as well as what Washington regards as the basic ingredients of a settlement -- themes like trading land for real peace.
Already, the two sides have publicly put forward their well-known positions. The Arabs have insisted that Israel give up all of the territory it gained in the 1967 war -- namely the Golan Heights, which once was controlled by Syria; the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which once were under Jordanian control, and the Gaza Strip, which was controlled by Egypt. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government has repeated its position that it does not intend to give up any more land.
While the Administration does not expect any party to drop or modify its basic positions at this opening session, it is nevertheless quietly coaching Israel, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan and the Palestinians to use their opening speeches to convey the message that there really are new possibilities.
For instance, the Administration would like the Israelis at least to hint, even vaguely, that the Golan Heights might be negotiable -- or to say that while Israel wants to keep that territory forever, it is looking forward to hearing Syria's views on the subject because alternatives might be possible.
Similarly, the Administration is urging the Syrians at least to hint that the payoff for Israel if it returns the Golan Heights, with its commanding view of northern Israel and of Damascus, could be more than just nonbelligerency, but real peace.
Phase two of the talks starts after the opening, when Israel and Syria, Israel and Lebanon and Israel and the joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation are supposed to sit down for separate, face-to-face, two-way negotiations.
 
Confidence-Building Gestures
 The Administration wants these talks to evolve in two stages. Washington expects the parties to make conflicting demands. But it hopes to prevent these collisions from derailing the bilateral talks by encouraging the parties to consider first trading small, confidence-building gestures.
For instance, Administration officials say they hope to encourage a deal in which Israel would agree to suspend building settlements in the occupied territories in return for suspension of the Arab economic boycott of Israel and suspension of the Palestinian uprising, against Israel.
Prime Minister Shamir has rejected such a deal already. Washington is talking to the Israelis as well as to the Saudis and other Arabs about ways to "sweeten the pot" for all sides.
Exactly how the United States will make its suggestions, though, raises what American officials say is the most sensitive aspect of the bilateral talks. How does the United States encourage the parties to keep talking long enough to produce psychological transformations without stepping in and becoming a mediator interfering with the give-and-take of direct talks?
 
Standing Outside, Whispering
 According to the conference invitation, Washington is allowed to attend the bilateral talks only if both sides invite it. Initially at least, the Israelis are unlikely to do that, because they want to underscore the face-to-face aspect of talks and the implicit recognition this connotes.
Therefore, said an American, Washington's representatives will stand "just outside the door," whispering to both sides.
"We have told all parties that we expect these to be genuine and meaningful negotiations," said a senior American official. "Our role will be to go in at times to offer advice on how best to approach certain problems. We are not going to go in and say, 'You ought to do it this way or that way.' But we will say: 'Hey, if you are going to present something that way, you are bound to get the following response. So you need to think that if you are going to say X you have to couple it with Y.' "
When President Carter mediated between Egypt and Israel in 1978 and when Henry Kissinger mediated between Syria and Israel after the 1973 war, both Americans had a very clear idea of what the bottom lines were for all parties. Arabs and Israelis sought American intervention to bridge their positions; this time Washington forced the parties together.
The framework for negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians is already agreed on. The two sides, according to the conference invitation, will begin with "talks on interim self-government arrangements" for Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
But the Israeli-Syrian negotiations have no agreed framework. Washington's first challenge is to find some imaginative way to bridge Syria's desire for a return of total sovereignty over the Golan Heights with the Israelis' insistence on not giving up the strategic high ground.
The second challenge posed by the Syrian-Israeli negotiations, say American officials, is that if they deadlock, the Syrians not be allowed to exercise a veto over the Israeli-Palestinian talks.
But this is easier said than done. The Syrians have already announced that they are not going to take part in the multilateral talks between Israel, Jordan, the Palestinians, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, Oman, Morocco and the United Arab Emirates, which are supposed to accompany the bilateral negotiations. These talks will deal with regional problems like water, arms control, refugees and economic development.
Washington has managed to persuade the other Arabs to go despite the Syrian objection, but the Syrians struck a quiet deal in Damascus last Wednesday with the Saudis and other Gulf Arabs in which the Arabs promised Syria that while they would engage the Israelis in a dialogue in these multilateral talks, they would not "close" any agreements until Syria was satisfied that Israel would cede territory in the bilateral negotiations, Arab diplomats said.
 
 
REPRESENTING THE UNITED STATES

 
The American delegation to th eMiddle East peace conference in Madrid includes five foreigh policy specialists chosen for their expertise in issues related to both Israel and the Arab states.
 
DENNIS B. ROSS
 
Director of State Department's Policy Planning Staff, a research group that explores new ideas and policies ... senior foreign policy adviser to George Bush's presidential campaign ... from 1986-88, National Security Council director of Near East and South Asian Affairs ... in early 1980's, a member of the planning staff that he now leads, working on Middle East issues ... spent a decade working on Middle East peace proposals with his key aides, Daniel C. Kurtzer and Aaron D. Miller ... Baker's right hand in the recent Mideast peace shuttle ... Ph.D. from U.C.L.A. ... analytical, a conceptualizer of new strategies and policies.
 
 
AAQRON D. MILLER
 
State Department Policy Planning staff member ... Political officer at American Embassy in Amman in 1984 ... Middle East analyst at State Department from 1980 to 1984 ... Ph.D. in Middle East history ... author of two books on Palestinians and the P.L.O. ... expert on Palestinian question in inter-Arab politics .. pragmatic analyst who often takes centrist position on Middle East isues .. helped write the letters of assurance and invitations to Arab and Israeli leaders.
 
 
DANIEL C. KURTZER
 
Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, Policy Planning Staff ... First Secretary of Political Affairs at American Embassy in Cairo from 1979 to 1982 and in Tel Aviv from 1982 to 1986 ... United States delegate to talks on Palestinian autonomy in 1979 ... helped negotiate terms for arbitration between Israel and Egypt during Taba border dispute ... Ph.D. from Columbia University, B.A. from Yeshiva University, where was dean in the late 1970's ... an Orthodox Jew from New Jersey who, while working in Cairo, traveled to Israel to buy kosher food ... praised by Arab and Israeli diplomats for his knowledge of Middle East history ... argued for years that the U.S. must reach out to the Palestinians, including the P.L.O. ... helped draft the carefully worded letters of assurance and invitations that are bringing Arab and Israeli leaders to the negotiating table.
