HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Having Ridden Racial Issues, Parties Try to Harness Them

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26

 BODY:
Race is one of the enduring forces in American politics, but the events of the past few weeks forecast a new and far more complicated racial politics as the nation heads into the 1992 campaign.
Each party is struggling to adjust, and neither seems fully in control. 
 The Republican Party has long recognized the political value of issues like racial hiring quotas and welfare abuses in helping to swell its white majorities. But now a shaken party confronts the rise of David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader whose campaign against affirmative action and the welfare system could carry him into the Louisiana Governor's mansion -- as a Republican.
Although the White House has publicly disavowed him, Mr. Duke has given new ammunition to the critics who accuse the Republicans of practicing racial politics, at great cost to the country.
 
Democrats' Delicate Task
 The Democrats are dealing with their own racial complexities. They have long relied on near monolithic black support, but they suddenly found themselves in opposition to most black Americans who had an opinion in the fight over Judge Clarence Thomas's nomination to the Supreme Court, according to the public opinion polls. The Republicans are quietly trying to chip away at the black vote, while the Democratic Presidential candidates have begun the delicate, difficult task of trying to woo back whites with appeals to "middle-class voters."
Moreover, White House acceptance on Friday of a compromise on civil rights legislation it long attacked as a "quota bill" has some analysts wondering whether Mr. Bush had pulled off yet another deft move in racial politics. He presented himself Friday as both the opponent of quotas and the defender of civil rights, a comfortable place to be in American politics.
All this maneuvering comes in an unsettled time of economic anxiety and deep public cynicism. When Mark Tubbs was asked about the debate over affirmative action, the 34-year-old Birmingham, Ala., construction contractor, who is white, replied: "The problem is that the politicians are the ones debating it. Their basic motivation is not human rights but in being elected and making as much money as possible in and out of office."
In interviews in several cities last week, many people seemed to be carefully sorting out their feelings on race and race-related issues and how their politicians handle them. They voiced concerns and doubts about the way some affirmative action programs work; The New York Times/ CBS News Poll has shown a growing majority in recent years opposed to giving racial preferences in hiring or promotions to correct past discrimination.
 
The Duke Dilemma
 But many people also expressed concern over the success of Mr. Duke, a Louisiana State Representative, and what they perceived to be a general rise in racial tensions. Asked if he felt racism was growing, Roger J. Park, a 35-year-old Republican real estate appraiser from Corona, Calif., who is white, replied: "Yes, dramatically. Just look at Louisiana."
This underscores the Republican dilemma with Mr. Duke, and it helps explain why the White House was trying to send some strong signals of racial moderation this week.
Ever since the 1988 campaign, Democrats have been accusing the Republicans in ever more forceful terms of playing the race card, notably with the case of Willie Horton, the black convicted murderer who committed rape after escaping on a weekend furlough from the Massachusetts prison system. The two-year-long feud over civil rights bills, in which Mr. Bush tried to depict the Democrats as advocates of racial quotas, added fuel to the fire.
Now, the Democrats cite Mr. Duke as an example of a Republican politics of racial division carried to its logical conclusion. "David Duke has found this bed very comfortable, but it's the bed that Bush and Reagan made," said Representative Mike Espy, the first black Congressman from Mississippi since Reconstruction.
The Republicans have angrily disavowed Mr. Duke and brushed aside the Democrats' allegation, but they are clearly concerned. "I have not liked these characterizations that I really didn't want a civil rights bill," Mr. Bush said, with a wounded air, as he signed off on new civil rights legislation Friday. "I've wanted it all along."
Democrats were skeptical. "They clearly realize that they've gone too far and they're trying to reclaim it by their positioning vis-a-vis Duke and their capitulation on the civil rights bill," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic poll taker.
Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, one of the strongest critics of Mr. Bush's handling of racial issues, said Friday afternoon: "Maybe some of the pleas to have the President de-escalate his use of race are paying off. The campaign remains ahead, though, so you don't know."
At the same time, Democrats are facing new Republican attempts to chip away at their most faithful constituency -- black Americans, who have given 80 to 90 percent of their votes to Democrats in recent Presidential elections.
Republican efforts to recuit black support have met with little success in recent years; indeed, many Democrats question their sincerity, arguing that Republicans are really concerned with making enough gestures to ease the fears of white moderates, who do not want to feel they are voting for an anti-black party.
Still, Republicans are keenly aware that even the shift of a small segment of blacks can make a huge difference in many Southern states. "If we can hold the vote we've got and get 25 percent of the black vote, we're going to win every election in North Carolina," said Jack Hawke, the state Republican chairman.
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, now exploring a third race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, argues that the Democrats need to take these Republican efforts very seriously. "All these books are coming out, saying that Democrats can't win with minority votes," Mr. Jackson said. "If Democrats can't win with minorities, with 12 million registered black voters, try winning without 25 percent of them."
Clayton K. Yeutter, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, told reporters this week that the Thomas hearings "coupled with a number of other elements of the political picture, provide us with an opportunity to garner black votes that goes beyond anything we have had in a substantial period of time."
All of this accounts for the strange and complicated way that race is filtering through politics these days. "There's some cross-cutting politics and positioning going on," said Stan Greenberg, a Democratic polltaker. The old, simple rules and the political arithmetic of race and politics are changing.

HEADLINE: Health Care Costs Are the New Crux of Contract Talks

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The question of who will pay for sharply escalating medical costs -- employers or employees -- has replaced haggling over wages as the most contentious issue in labor negotiations, management and union representatives say.
Health care was once a fringe benefit, something to be considered after the critical matter of pay raises. But as health costs have increased rapidly in the last three to five years, medical benefits have quickly taken center stage in collective bargaining and have often been the prime reason for strikes, many labor experts say. 
 At the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan, for example, long and difficult negotiations that included a two-hour walkout by 100 unionized staff members were concluded only after an elaborate compromise was reached on sharing medical costs. At Indian Point No. 3, a nuclear power plant in Westchester County, employees worked without a contract for almost two years until the wrangling over medical benefits was resolved last month.
One of the most prolonged and disruptive strikes in the New York metropolitan area in recent years was over health benefits: the 17-week walkout in 1989 by 60,000 workers at the Nynex Corporation.
"It is the impasse area," said John Phillips, a professor of health science at the State University of New York at Brockport and an expert in the economics and politics of health care. "In my judgment it has become the most difficult issue to resolve."
Some unions have been able to keep all their medical benefits, although many labor leaders admit that they have done so at the expense of better wage packages. Many other unions have made concessions to employers, who have been aggressively seeking to share more of the burden of double-digit inflation in medical care.
The concessions have taken many forms: increasing deductible expenses, having employees pay more of covered medical expenses, making them pay some of the cost of premiums for family coverage and sometimes eliminating family coverage altogether.
"It's a battle every time," said Jack Sheinkman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, which represents 250,000 workers in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. "I'm not going to lie to you and say we've held the line every time."
Often it has led to strikes. The most recent statistics come from a study last year by the Service Employees International Union, which found that nearly two-thirds of the 43 major walkouts in the United States in 1989 were caused by disputes over health benefits. Thirty percent of the 66 major strikes in 1986 were over medical care, the study found.
But even that does not fully measure the impact on collective bargaining over the last five years. The union study determined that the largest, most prolonged and most bitter strikes of 1989 -- including the one against Nynex and a nine-month walkout by miners at the Pittston Coal Company in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky -- were over management attempts to reduce health coverage or to have employees shoulder more of the cost.
 
'The Major Obstacle'
 These walkouts, while the most public and emotionally charged manifestations of difficulties over health care, reflect a broad problem for most companies and unions. "It has increasingly become the major obstacle in collective bargaining in virtually every industry," said Jan D. Pierce, a vice president of the Communications Workers of America in charge of New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and five other Northeastern states.
Health care spending increased nationally by more than 10 percent a year through much of the 1980's, and it rose about 10.5 percent in each of the last three years, according to the Federal Health Care Financing Administration.
The Federal Government, as well as many state governments, have sought to limit increases in health-care costs by shifting some of the burden to the private sector. For example, companies that provide medical benefits must insure employees older than 65. They used to be covered by Medicare.
As a result, some companies have endured increases of as much as 20 to 30 percent a year in their premiums, Professor Phillips said.
 
Tab None Want to Pick Up
 In the New York region, companies have typically faced annual increases of 10 to 20 percent in their medical plans, said Thomas E. Burns, Nynex's corporate director for benefits and compensation. Many business officials said that they had little choice but to try to shift more to their employees.
Union leaders and their members, accustomed to improvements in their medical coverage over many decades, have generally resisted picking up more of the tab.
The unions that struck Nynex in 1989, the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electricians, took great satisfaction in a settlement that kept their medical benefits intact.
Last month, the Communications Workers reached an agreement with Nynex on their next contract, nearly a year before the current one expires. The unusually early settlement was possible, Mr. Pierce of the union said, because the company decided not to press for health-care concessions.
 
Concessions From Unions
 But many unions have agreed reluctantly to share more of the costs of medical care and many others are being pressed to do so. Businesses whose workers are not unionized have had even more success in shifting health-care costs, business representatives and labor leaders said.
Mr. Sheinkman said that his union had managed to keep medical benefits in the two national contracts that it negotiates, with manufacturers of men's suits and men's leisure wear. But the price was clear: "It has obviously impacted on the wages," he said.
Many union leaders, particularly those like Mr. Sheinkman who represent workers making relatively low wages, said that they have been willing to sacrifice part of a salary increase. They are not always successful. Mr. Sheinkman said that the contracts his union negotiates with individual textile manufacturers have often included concessions on medical costs.
 
Eventually Paying More

Escalating health-care costs have had an unsettling effect on negotiations throughout the New York region.
At the Museum of Modern Art, the museum basically agreed to maintain existing benefits and the union granted several concessions that are to begin when the contract reached in December expires in 1993.
The union, which is affiliated with District 65 of the United Auto Workers and which represents 227 professional and administrative workers, agreed that its members would eventually pay more of their medical costs. Union members now pay 20 percent of their first $2,000 in medical procedures each year. In 1993, the members' contributions will apply to the first $4,000 in medical costs.
At Indian Point No. 3, about 500 employees worked for nearly two years without a contract because of disputes over health care. A new contract was approved last month after the union agreed to some concessions, said Jeff Cuffee, a nuclear plant operator who is a shop steward. Workers will now pay $8 toward each medical procedure, said Mr. Cuffee, a member of Locals 1 and 2 of the Plant Utility Workers of America. Management, in return, agreed to drop other demands, including a fee for family coverage, he said.
One large union medical plan almost shut down last month because of debt. The plan, operated by District 65 of the United Automobile Workers, covers more than 40,000 workers in 27 states. About 25,000 members -- most of whom do not work in the auto industry -- are in New York and New Jersey.
 
Companies Agree to Pay More
 The health plan spends $42 million a year for medical care. But it had also run up an accumulated debt of $30 million that threatened the plan's financial viability, said David Livingston, the union's president. An arbitrator ruled that all benefits would be suspended unless management and the union found a solution.
Under union pressure, several dozen companies agreed to increase their payments from 15 percent of annual wages to 16.5 percent, Mr. Livingston said. When the union's medical plan was created in 1945, the contribution was 3 percent.
Some local unions are anticipating great pressure for health-care concessions in negotiations. One union, Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, has told members to expect a strike.
Formal talks on the union's prime contract, covering 65,000 workers in more than 400 private hospitals and nursing homes in New York City, on Long Island and in Westchester and Rockland Counties, begin in March. But Dennis Rivera, the local's president, said the hospitals have already indicated that they want to cut costs. Mr. Rivera said he expected the hospitals to demand that some benefits be eliminated and that new out-of-pocket payments by employees be added.
Mr. Rivera said the union would oppose that. "The irony to us is that the health-care workers who provide these services to the community are now going to have some of the services we provide taken away from us," he said.
Many union leaders say the only long-range solution is national health care, because it would reduce administrative costs and be more equitable. "It has to be addressed systematically," said John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union and chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s health committee.
Organized labor is split over whether national health care should be operated by a single quasi-governmental entity or built on existing health plans to include the estimated 38 million Americans who lack medical insurance.
 
Shifting the Costs
 Either way, there are formidable opponents to national health care: the United States Chamber of Commerce and many corporations as well as insurance companies and the medical profession, which are often viewed as beneficiaries of the existing system.
Many opponents say that it would represent just another attempt to shift costs to someone else, in this case the Federal Government. It would be better, they say, to concentrate on managing medical costs by using networks of doctors and hospitals that agree to limit costs.
"We should build on our current system," said Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York Chamber of Commerce and the New York City Partnership. "I think it's a bit simplistic to say that if you create a Federal system it will magically make all the problems go away."

HEADLINE: '92 Elections Outlook: Divide and Distract

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peggy Noonan's "Bum Ride" (Op-Ed, Oct. 15), while not valuable as regards the Clarence Thomas confirmation, was very revealing as to Republican plans for division and distraction in 1992. 
 By now we should be familiar with the false distinctions. Pejorative labels stand in place of facts. The only difference between being the voice of "the real" (normal, regular Americans) and "the abstract" is which side you are on. The article offers no arguments, only classifications meant to distract.
In 1992 we can expect more misuse of class, race and ideology to divert the public's attention from the record of the Administration. Republicans will even try to convince the middle class and black Americans that they have done better in recent years when in reality they have lost ground. Will facts intervene? We have the question for 1992. Will the politics of distraction continue to work?
For our kinder, gentler nation, what is "real" is that we have had an Administration that has been indifferent to working people, the environment, drug abuse and a whole host of domestic issues that are important to "regular Americans." The growing legions of long-term unemployed are not an abstraction; they are real. What is abstract is the effort that is being used to divert our country's attention from the serious problems we face.
 
STEVEN OTIS
Rye, N.Y., Oct. 17, 1991

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 76 Units in the Bronx;
Low-Income Housing

 BODY:
The big developers may be sitting on what is left of their money, waiting for home building to resume, but the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal is still putting up new units for the poor and those with low incomes.
The latest example is in the Crotona Park area of the Bronx, where Eae J. Mitchell Terrace, a six-story, 76-unit brick rental project at 945 East 174th Street, between Hoe and Vyse Avenues, will have a grand opening at 3 P.M. Wednesday, with the first families moving in soon after. Financed by the state and sponsored by the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes, the housing advocacy group, the development has 10 studios, 45 one-bedroom and 21 two-bedroom apartments, a 13-space indoor garage -- the rent for a space is $50 a month -- indoor and outdoor recreation areas and a laundry. The Liebman Melting Partnership was the architect. 
 Sixty-eight of the apartments will be reserved for families earning no more than $21,000, which is 80 percent of the city's median income. They will pay rents of $400 to $500 per month. The rest of the apartments will go to people on welfare, with their rents adjusted to family size.
The project cost $8 million in state funds.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 3, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Postings column last Sunday about Eae J. Mitchell Terrace, a low-income housing project in the Bronx, described its developers incompletely. It was developed jointly by the Procida Construction Corporation of the Bronx and the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes.

HEADLINE: At Moscow's Planning Agency, Many Economists Look for Work

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
As he climbed the career ladder at Gosplan, the Soviet ministry of central planning, Oleg Yun used to have a heady sense of power, helping the ministry's efforts to pull every economic lever from Azerbaijan to Vladivostok.
 In the 1960's, he helped prepare a grandiose 20-year plan that sought to fulfill Nikita S. Khrushchev's goal of overtaking the American economy. In the 1970's, he was part of a trailblazing team that developed computer models on maximizing production. 
Now in the 1990's, with central planning heading toward the dustbin of history, the 56-year-old economist finds himself worrying that he will soon be out of a job. Now that Adam Smith's invisible hand is set to replace Stalin's heavy one, the ministry that bestrode the Soviet economy like a Colossus risks being abolished.
 "The ministry is disintegrating," said Mr. Yun, a Moscow native whose father was Korean. "It has lost face and importance."
 Gosplan, the once-omnipotent ministry that gave orders to every cell in the nation's giant economic organism, has been slowly dying since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power in 1985. The agency lost considerable influence after a law passed in 1987 gave managers autonomy in running their enterprises, and suffered even more in the wake of the failed coup in August. But still, despite efforts to dismantle it, a shrinking staff and the fact that many managers ignore its commands, Gosplan still functions.
 Mr. Yun, a short, dark-haired, cerebral man, has been a witness to the rise and fall of Gosplan, which is still called that although its name was changed in April to the Ministry of Economics and Prognosis. He joined the ministry in 1960, three years before it was named Gosplan, when ministry officials were confident they could build the world's strongest economy. He was there in the 1970's, when officials began to recognize the flaws in the Soviet economic model. And now he has a close-up view of the ministry's struggle to survive.
 "A lot of people in the ministry are thinking about their fate, where they're going to work next," said Mr. Yun, whose newest job is analyzing the long-term needs of heavy industry. "When you don't know what's ahead, your mood cannot be happy."
 The mood at Gosplan's imposing headquarters, just across from the Kremlin, is a far cry from what it was when Mr. Yun signed on. For those who dreamed of creating the perfect economy, it was paradise. Across the vast economy, Gosplan commanded how much steel should be made and how many eggs should be laid.
 
Times Have Changed
 But times have changed. Its work force has fallen from 2,800 to 1,800. Mr. Yun and many Gosplan colleagues are holding on, hoping there will be a role for a successor to Gosplan, although it is so discredited for botching up the Soviet economy that many officials want to dismantle it. Every year, Gosplan continued to issue thousands of commands, but as the Communist Party's grip weakened, it was unable to force enterprises to obey.
 Although Mr. Yun says he believes that a market economy delivers the goods better than central planning, he said shunting Gosplan aside before a new system has replaced it has pushed the nation's weak economy into chaos.
 "All the vertical structures of managing the economy were destroyed, but the horizontal system of market relations had not been established," he said, retaining the vocabulary of bureaucratic socialism. "It turned out to be economic anarchy after 1988."
 Mr. Yun, who displayed an encyclopedic knowledge of the Soviet economy, talked while sipping black coffee in a room decorated with an Oriental rug and portraits of Marx and Lenin.
 For decades, Gosplan and its little brothers -- Gossnab, the ministry of material supplies, and Goskomtsen, the ministry of prices -- controlled production and commerce. But after industry stopped listening to Gosplan, many enterprises found they could no longer get supplies.
 The economic chaos that has accompanied Gosplan's decline has made many conservatives want to turn back the clock. Last spring, Prime Minister Valentin S. Pavlov, now in jail for taking part in the coup in August, sought to restore Gosplan's powers.
 "Pavlov sent around a plan that wasn't much different from what I received under Leonid Brezhnev," said Vladimir S. Kostakov, director of Gosplan's economic institute. He said one goal of the coup was "to restore the centralized system in which the party commanded the economy while ignoring all laws of economics."
 The coup's failure hastened Gosplan's decline. After the coup, Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic, ordered that the ministry cease activities there. His decree was overruled, but once again Gosplan was humiliated.
 Nonetheless, it still plays one traditional role: formulating state orders, which are mandatory orders to sell to the state. Planners often use state orders to redistribute goods.
 For instance, the Ukraine is rich in grain and poor in oil, while Russia has abundant oil but not enough grain. So central planners place state orders for Ukrainian grain that they redistribute to Russia, while they buy Russian oil that goes to the Ukraine.
 But many enterprises and farms ignore these state orders, knowing that they can earn far more by selling goods on the open market. This is one reason St. Petersburg and other cities fear a food shortage this winter. Because many collective farms are not turning over the food they are supposed to under state orders, central planners do not have enough food to distribute.
 "Gosplan was the keystone of the command economy system; it was at the top of the pyramid," said Gennadi Zoteyev, deputy director of the ministry's economic institute. "But now the pyramid has been destroyed, and we have the top, but no bottom."
 In the early 1960's, Mr. Yun did the calculations for the ambitious 20-year plan. "It called for catching up to America and overtaking it," he said.
 Instead, the Soviet Union's economic growth rate declined, and the plans were often embarrassingly inefficient.
 Mr. Yun told of a factory that was ordered to make "100 tons of pans." Seeking to make its job easy, the factory turned out a small number of huge, heavy, almost useless pans rather than a larger number of the light ones that consumers prefer.
 The question remains of what to do with Gosplan. Mr. Yun says Gosplan should be preserved to make economic forecasts and recommendations for the whole nation.
 "There are still a lot of economists at Gosplan whose expertise could be used for the good of the nation," he said.

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
The Independents See Vultures Circling Overhead

BYLINE: By DAVID BROWNE; David Browne is a senior writer at Entertainment Weekly.

 BODY:
As long as there have been hungry young rockers, there have been independent record labels, or indies, as they're known. From Sun Records in the 60's to rap labels like Def Jam in the 80's, the independents -- small-staffed, low-budget operations -- have helped steer the course of pop music. Even the Beatles' first singles in America were released on Vee-Jay, an independent doo-wop label from Chicago. More recently, the independents have played an important role in the development of the alternative rock music scene.
The equivalent of the small presses, independent record companies stumble upon young talent before the huge, slothful corporations step in. "I have to believe that the majors will overlook some great bands and the indies will fill that void," says Michael Gallelli, a director of artists and repertory for Columbia. 
 Independents are still responsible for much of the folk, jazz, blues and gospel found in record stores. But with the recent consolidation of the record business (six conglomerates are responsible for 93 percent of all records released), the independent labels are in trouble.
At one time, underground rock stars like R.E.M., Sonic Youth, the Replacements, Nirvana and the Meat Puppets all recorded for guerrilla companies like I.R.S. (now distributed by CEMA), Homestead, SST and Twin/ Tone, which released their albums when no one else would. But today many of the independents face cash-flow problems stemming from a slump in the record business, the defection of their most popular bands to the major labels and the financial burden of switching from LP's to CD's.
In the last two years, such prominent independents as Enigma (which recorded such diverse groups as the Smithereens and Stryper) and Coyote (the Feelies and Yo La Tengo) have closed shop. Others have laid off employees. The sharpest blow to the world of the indies occurred last May, when the record company Rough Trade, a leading distributor of independent labels in America and Great Britain, filed for bankruptcy. By overextending itself in both recording and distributing, the company went heavily into debt, estimated at $1.3 million in the United States alone.
"It was a real confidence shaker," says Robert Haber, publisher of the College Media Journal New Music Report, the college-radio tip sheet. "Two years ago, it would have been unheard of that Rough Trade would have folded. Combined with the economy and no one getting paid, it doesn't bode well for the future of new music. It's not a pretty picture."
The alternative music of the early 80's was never pretty; a refined outgrowth of punk and hardcore, it was brash, feisty, rooted in suburban ennui and disdain for the mainstream. The music and attitude found a sizable audience of mostly confused, disgruntled college-age rock fans.
"Suddenly it spread like wildfire," says the guitarist Thurston Moore, whose band, Sonic Youth, recorded for four independent labels -- Homestead, Neutral, Blast First and SST -- before signing with David Geffen's big-time DGC label. The Replacements' "Let It Be" became a best-selling record for Twin/ Tone, with 120,000 albums sold to date, a huge figure for an independent.
It was only a matter of time before companies like CBS and Warner Brothers swooped in. By the end of the decade, many of the leading alternative bands were sharing record company accountants with Madonna and Sting. According to Gerard Cosloy, co-manager of Matador Records, a New York-based independent label, the major labels are "vultures." "They're eager to step in and take the lead from the indies," he says. "And when major labels start taking bands away, there's nothing left to support the indie network."
Even college radio, one of the last bastions of free-form radio, became more institutionalized. Whereas independently produced records once represented at least 30 percent of the albums played on college radio, a look at the Oct. 18 issue of the New Music Report shows that the share is down to 20 percent.
"The turning point was the success of R.E.M.," says Greg Ginn, the owner of SST Records and formerly the guitarist for Black Flag, one of SST's leading bands. R.E.M. started with the ultra-obscure Hib-Tone Records, then moved to I.R.S. before hitting the big time at Warner Brothers Records in 1988.
"A lot of groups went chasing after that dream," Mr. Ginn says, "and it produced worse music without reaching the goal of selling more records. Just because you can build up sales of 30,000 to 40,000 records doesn't mean you can move on to a major and sell more than that." (Indeed, a number of musicians who moved from the independents to the majors -- the Mekons, Husker Du's Bob Mould, Big Dipper, Redd Kross -- had disappointing sales and are now without contracts from any record company.)
Sagging sales aggravated what was already a hand-to-mouth existence for many independents. According to Alan Becker, director of purchasing for Important Record Distributors, which handles 30 small labels, the independents have always been the last to be paid by the record stores, and, with the slump in record sales, many of those payments are past due.
Not all independents are in trouble, of course. The rap labels that emerged in the 80's prospered, thanks to major-label distribution and the loyalty of hip-hop fans. According to one New York record store owner, rap fans often ask for the latest releases from a particular label, such as Priority Records, the company that recorded Ice Cube and N.W.A.
By contrast, college listeners tend to be fickle. "Rock indies depend on a crowd aged 15 to a year or so out of college," says Paul Stark, president of Twin/Tone. "What's hip to one group isn't hip to another."
Perhaps most devastating for the industry was the defection of many of the scene's biggest names. Over the years, the independent labels developed reputations for paying little, if anything, making the lure of a corporate contract that much more enticing. "We became disenchanted with working with indie labels," says Mr. Moore of Sonic Youth. "We knew we were selling records, but we weren't getting paid for it. To this day, getting money from SST is like pulling teeth." Mr. Ginn of SST admits that payment was "definitely" a problem; he attributes it to a loss of more than $400,000 when four of his distributors, including Rough Trade, went out of business.
Twin/Tone is currently $100,000 in debt, according to Mr. Stark, and 70,000 of its records are languishing in a San Francisco warehouse. Mr. Stark says he has lowered the typical recording budget from an already modest $15,000 an album to a paltry $2,500, which means that each record has to be turned out in a few days. "The records might not sound as clean, but I'd rather put out three records than one," he explains.
Bar/None, a Hoboken, N.J., independent that made its name with They Might Be Giants, hasn't released an album in more than a year because it has no distributor. "There are times when we're more a state of mind than a record company," says Glenn Morrow, the creative director.
A slew of active independent labels -- Sub Pop in Seattle, Caroline and 4 AD in New York, Touch and Go in Chicago -- continue to turn out records that are sometimes striking, like this year's "8-Way Santa," a biker-rock album by Tad, and This Mortal Coil's "Blood," which sounds like a ghostly murmur. But these records seem far less vital than the independent rock releases of the past.
This week the annual College Media Journal Music Marathon convention will be held in New York, bringing together 4,500 musicians, record company executives and other new-music hangers-on. Among the questions that will surely be debated in the hallways and hotel rooms are: Will the indies have to sell out to the conglomerates? Indeed, do independent labels have anything to offer, now that alternative rock can be found on major labels? Even more key, has alternative rock simply run its course?
Not according to Matador Records. The label, started two years ago and based in a ramshackled office with a three-man staff in lower Manhattan, has released eight albums and some singles. Its most popular band, Teenage Fanclub, has already been scooped up by a major label (Geffen) after selling 10,000 copies of its first album, "A Catholic Education."
"These are great records, and if we don't put them out, who else will?" asks Mr. Cosloy of Matador, as he sits surrounded by grating and uncompromising albums from bands like the Dustdevils and Superchunk.
Yet he is probably speaking for many independents when he adds, "Whether anyone's paying attention, it's hard to tell."
 
 
 
TREASURES FROM THE INDIES
 Here are some of the more memorable alternative rock records produced by American independent labels in the 80's.
The Dream Syndicate, "Ghost Stories" (Enigma, 1988). Tales of loners and losers in Los Angeles, played with bench-pressing power.
The Feelies, "The Good Earth" (Coyote, 1986). Pastoral, meditative dronings from the Haledon, N.J., cult icons -- music to accompany a late-night conversation with a friend.
Husker Du, "Zen Arcade" (SST, 1984). The underground "Tommy," a double-album chronicle of a day in the life of a skinhead, rendered with ballistic noise and pop melodies by a Minneapolis trio.
The Minutemen, "3-Way Tie (for Last)" (SST, 1985). The best album from the San Pedro, Calif., band that set leftist political commentary to feisty punk-rock.
The Original Sins, "Big Soul" (Bar/ None, 1987). Part garage rock, part wistful folk-rock, all from Bethlehem, Penn.
R.E.M., "Murmur" (I.R.S., 1983). On their first album, artfully murky folk rock for a new generation.
The Replacements, "Let It Be" (Twin/ Tone, 1984). You thought alternative bands weren't supposed to combine straight-ahead rockers, ballads, a Kiss remake and mandolins, right?
Sonic Youth, "Daydream Nation" (Blast First, 1988). The New York iconoclasts harness their fuzzy-guitar assault to actual songs; their finest hour.
Various artists, "The Wailing Ultimate" (Homestead, 1987). A sampler featuring such groups as Live Skull, Dinosaur and Big Dipper.

(Michael Tighe/Warner Brothers) (pg. 26); Sally Timms, left, and Tom Greenholgh of the Mekons--disappointing sales with a major label (Jack Vartoogian)

HEADLINE: THEATER;
In Westport, 'Flora, the Red Menace'

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
THE first time around, "Flora, the Red Menace" was a slight, short-lived musical. That was in 1965, when the composer, John Kander, and the lyricist, Fred Ebb, were first teaming up, and the star, Liza Minnelli, was making her Broadway debut at age 19. For Flora's next time around, a 1987 Off Broadway revival, the producers reasoned that the renown of the original creators, who included Harold Prince as producer and George Abbott (book and direction), would spark new interest in an old flop.
Beyond that "Flora" needed a new frame of reference. The cartoonish and cumbersome story focuses on an ingenuous high school graduate, class valedictorian and new recruit in the Young Communist League, right after the Depression. For the 1987 staging at the Off Broadway Vineyard Theater, David Thompson reworked the book, originally adapted by Abbott and Robert Russell; Kander and Ebb deleted three, and wrote three, new songs. Perhaps most tellingly, the new production highlighted the importance of thinking small. A big-time Broadway musical was reduced to a single setting and piano, with 9 actors playing 25 roles -- a good idea. 
 It is the Vineyard version that is being produced by the Boston Post Road Stage Company at the Westport Playhouse. Given its intimate space and partiality for non-mainstream, often neglected, works, it is just the theater for the occasion. For all that, "Flora" remains a minor league musical, and neither the local, ever-busy cast nor the staging by Peter Flynn -- fluid but lacking in climaxes -- alters the impression of a slow-witted musical with a few terrific songs and a bunch of extraneous, dopey ones.
While the audience is instantly made aware of plot relevance ("till the economy turns around") and production design ("please use your imagination"), the effect is of musical comedy pallidity, rather than social significance.
Standing on bread lines and picket lines, selling pencils and apples, moving crates and boxes to denote changes of scenery, the nine players echo the refrain, "Give Me a Job," but ultimately they succeed in complicating and diverting a bittersweet story from its real purpose.
Unavoidably, the best songs -- "Quiet Thing," "Dear Love" and "Sing Happy" -- with their wistful melodies, mounting intensity and simply exquisite phrases, reverberate with the distinctive sound of Ms. Minnelli, a new talent with a floundering style when she first sang them 26 years ago and a second choice for a role that had been offered to Barbra Streisand. Now, it is thrilling to hear how Flora's songs presage a sustained, continuing association among Minnelli, Kander and Ebb, with "Sing Happy" emerging as the first of a line of exciting, upbeat anthems of affirmation, resilience and defiance that eventually led to "Cabaret" and "New York, New York."
As Flora Meszaros, aspiring fashion illustrator and all-around do-gooder who unwittingly becomes a young comrade until her own sense of fair play and assertiveness wins, Ellen Grosso might have made a more original stab at avoiding the unavoidable. The wide-eyed vulnerability, the catch in the voice, the dogged kookiness are all too familiar knockoffs on an established style.
Most lively in an earnest company are Adrienne Doucette, adept as an insinuating party leader who vamps Flora's stammering party-loyal boyfriend, Harry (played by Stephen Stout). Stacey Todd Holt and Leslie Beauvais are seen in, among others, a pair of irrelevant new parts, a dance team for whom Flora gets an audition at the Rainbow Room.
Somehow, a sincere, almost dour sense of purpose overhangs a silly, often muddled musical that puts too many obstacles -- and plot holes -- in the way of its intentions, for all "Flora" means to me is a story about idealists who are determined to change the world -- in too many different ways.
"Flora, the Red Menace," at the Westport Playhouse, 25 Powers Court, Westport. 227-1072. Remaining performances today and next Sunday at 3 P.M., Wednesday at 2 and 8 P.M., Thursday and Friday at 8 P.M., Saturday at 5 and 9 P.M. Closes next Sunday.

HEADLINE: Focus: Bakersfield, Calif.;
Affordable Homes Help Slumping Oil City

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

 BODY:
THE growth of this high-desert city has come in lurches over the last decade. Now it is counting on affordable housing to help propel it into a new role as the latest suburban outpost of Los Angles, 100 miles to the south.
In the mid-1980's, when energy was a growth business, this city close to oil fields and refineries expanded. The collapse of oil prices later in the decade, however, resulted in the loss of 10,000 jobs, the departure of several major employers and foreclosure for a clutch of office buildings. 
 The real estate market had nearly recovered when the combined force of the savings-and-loan fiasco and the real estate slump hit, leaving empty and unfinished buildings in its wake. Downtown vacancy rates are a sobering 30 percent.
But in the slow economy, the combination of affordable housing, low office rents and abundant cheap land has made the city attractive to corporations.
Affordable housing, in particular, helped persuade the State Farm Insurance Companies to choose Bakersfield as the site of a 500,000-square-foot regional headquarters. By 1996, the company plans to have 1,000 employees at work there.
Many State Farm employees are expected to relocate to the city from other parts of California and to be able to buy homes here, despite the state's notorious reputation for out-of-reach prices.
"You can buy a fine home in Bakersfield for about half of what you would pay in Orange County," said Roger Tompkins, a State Farm vice president in Westlake Village, Calif.
In August, the median home price in Bakersfield was $95,000, compared to $241,300 in Orange County, according to the California Association of Realtors.
Home prices also figured in a decision last year by Chevron USA to locate its Western Production Business Unit in Bakersfield. A Chevron spokesman, Jonathan Lifa, said home prices looked "especially affordable" compared to those in San Francisco, Chevron's corporate base, where the median price was $290,000 in August.
Bakersfield represents the dividing line between urban southern California and the San Joaquin Valley, an agricultural area that stretches 230 miles north to Stockton. The region -- the destination of the Joad family in John Steinbeck's Dust Bowl-era novel "The Grapes of Wrath" -- remains largely agricultural, although California's urban growth is gnawing away at its edges.
Although some Bakersfield residents cringe at the suburbanization of their city, the phenomonen is familiar in southern California.
Since the 1960's, the quest for affordable housing, coupled with the willingness of Californians to commute long distances, has pushed the suburban frontier of Greater Los Angeles south to Orange County, north to the San Fernando Valley and Santa Clarita, east to Riverside and San Bernardino Counties and west to Ventura County.
THE Antelope Valley, a Los Angeles County region a few miles south of Bakersfield, was the state's hottest homebuilding market in the late 80's.
The Bakersfield boom is part of that larger growth phenomenon. Its population, now 185,000, leaped 65 percent in the last decade, according to the city's planning department, while the number of nonagricultural jobs grew 19 percent in the same period, to 171,000, the state Economic Development Department says.
Bakersfield's resilience, as well as the occasional shocks to the local economy, can be traced to its role as an oil city. It is the seat of Kern County, one of the busiest oil-pumping regions in the country. Although the oil slump of the 1980's induced several "majors" to leave the city, Big Oil is now returning.
Chevron surprised the region last year by pulling up stakes in Ventura, 80 miles south, where the company had already built a luxury office building, to lease offices in Bakersfield. Besides the lure of affordable housing, Mr. Lifa, the Chevron spokesman, said, the move reflected a new company policy to locate management near drilling sites.
ANOTHER recent arrival, Santa Fe Energy Resources of Houston, has leased 40,000 square feet in a suburban office building.
Despite hopeful signs from the oil industry, the city is not out of the woods. Some problems in downtown Bakersfield have so far defied solution.
A half-finished 293-room hotel, abandoned by both developer and lender, and an empty, foreclosed office building have been persistent headaches for the Central District Development Agency, the city's redevelopment arm. It has tried to bring new activity to a downtown area that resembles a time capsule from the 1940's and 50's.
When the seven-story, 92,000-square-foot City Center office building was completed in 1989, the local office market was still reeling from the contraction of the oil industry. Developers of other buildings had slashed rents to induce companies to sign leases; much of that space ultimately went for less than $12 a square foot, considerably less than anywhere in southern California.
Those low rents, in turn, undercut the economics of the City Center building, which needed at least $17.40 a square foot to pay its mortgage. An affiliate of U.S. Bancorp foreclosed on the empty building last year.
The city itself foreclosed on the hotel project when the lender, a savings-and-loan institution, became insolvent; the city was the landowner and was entitled to the project if there was a default. Now it is having little luck finding another developer to buy the rusting, gray hulk.
As in many aging downtown areas, government itself has become a valued tenant. In January, Kern County employees will move into the $32 million, 276,000-square-foot County Courts and Administration Building, where the county plans to employ 600 people.
With homebuilding continuing steadily in Bakersfield and other high-desert areas, the city has been drawn into the commuter orbit of greater Los Angeles.
"I HAVE talked to developers who have sold their entire subdivisions to people who work in the San Fernando Valley" 85 miles to the south, Jack Hardisty, the city planning director.
The suburbanization of Bakersfield may accelerate if state officials make good on plans to build a high-speed train linking Sacramento and Los Angeles; Bakersfield would be a stop on the route.
The train, which would travel at 180 miles an hour or more, could make the city suddenly "seem a lot closer to the Los Angeles basin," said Jake Wager, the city's economic development director.
Employees who work in the San Fernando Valley but cannot afford housing in that area could buy homes in Bakersfield, catch the high-speed train and arrive at their jobs in 20 minutes, Mr. Wager said.
But Mr. Hardisty said he was not enthusiastic about one possible effect of high-speed rail: losing the traditional independence of the local economy.
"We have always been remote enough that people have to bring jobs here," he said. "I'm not fond of the idea of becoming a bedroom community for someplace else."

HEADLINE: Economic Troubles Bedeviling Orchestras

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE

 BODY:
AS their corporate contributors struggle with the recession, most of the state's orchestras and its one remaining opera company have been forced to reduce their dependence on the business community and turn to foundations and individuals. Some have made small increases in ticket prices. Others have cut back on concerts.
"In this economy, you can't get blood from a stone," said the marketing director for the Hartford Symphony, Jean Spivey. "A lot of sponsors and would-be sponsors are pulling back. Many of the corporations we used to go to went out of business." 
Compounding the problems for the Hartford Symphony is the impasse over the orchestra's contract with its musicians. Last week management and Local 400 of the American Federation of Musicians said they were $746,621 apart in their proposals. The orchestra's management said the union's proposal would bring the symphony's accumulated deficit to $1.4 million in fiscal year 1991-92. The orchestra's total operating budget for the year is $2.8 million.
 
'With a Pen Stroke'
 "The alternative is to go out of business in three years," Ms. Spivey said of the 48-year-old institution.
But a spokesman for the musicians said the orchestra is not really in such severe financial trouble. "They could get rid of that deficit with a pen stroke," said Emery Tapley, a French horn player, who one of the musicians' chief negotiators.
Mr. Tapley said the orchestra's proposal would use 29 percent of its operating budget for wages and benefits, while the national average for symphony orchestras is 42 percent. The management plan would give full-time musicians, who have been earning $20,000 a year, "a 37 percent pay cut," he said.
The musicians have "offered to play under last year's contract and continue to negotiate," Mr. Tapley said. "We want to get back to work."
Ms. Spivey said the Hartford Symphony's problems stem from a heavy reliance on corporate contributions, past cost-of-living increases in salaries and the city's own economic difficulties. The symphony used to share a core ensemble of 21 full-time musicians with the Hartford Ballet, the Hartford Chamber Orchestra and the Connecticut Opera. But the ballet company will begin using taped music for its performances this season, the opera company negotiated a separate agreement last summer, and the chamber orchestra is now defunct.
"We can no longer support full-time work for full-time pay," Ms. Spivey said. "That's where the big difference is in dollars."
 
'We Have Subscriber Confusion'
 The impasse, which the musicians are calling a lockout, forced symphony officials to postpone the season's first concerts, which had been scheduled for Oct. 15 and 16. The musicians gave a free concert without pay on the 16th, saying they wanted to garner public support and demonstrate that they want to perform.
"We have subscriber confusion as a result," said Ms. Spivey.
Hartford Symphony management gave the union a deadline of tomorrow for replying to its latest proposal, saying any further delay would hamper planning for the next scheduled concerts.
The New Haven Symphony's contract with its musicans was due to expire this fall, too, but an agreement was reached earlier this fall, after the muscians accepted a substantial reduction in the number of rehearsals, among other changes.
The two orchestras were awarded a grant of $100,000 for each ensemble over two years from the National Endowment for the Arts on the condition that they each raise another $300,000. "The grant will be used to expand each orchestra's outreach programs" in schools and throughout the state of Connecticut," said the general manager of the New Haven Symphony, Catherine Weiskel. "During the two-year period of the grant, the programs will reach 28 communities representing over 900,000 state residents."
The Greater Bridgeport Symphony is projecting a small loss for the first time in several years, said its general manager, Jena Maric.
"The main fallout was in the corporate sector," she said. "Our fund raising is now based so we have a very large public, individual support. If we were relying solely on corporations, then we would be in a very bad situation."
 
'Dealing With an Image'
 Mrs. Maric said she is also dealing with a problem unique to her 46-year-old organization: "We used to get support from the City of Bridgeport. That stopped several years ago," when the city began having severe financial problems of its own, "and we understood why."
Negative publicity about Bridgeport hurts the orchestra, Mrs. Maric said. "We are dealing with an image," she said. "It's a long-term problem. Once people do come to the Klein Memorial Auditorium, they realize it's easily accessible, with easy parking, and the music is high quality.
"Sometimes you need to go through this sort of thing to come out stronger. We are in pretty good shape."
The Eastern Connecticut Symphony, based in New London, is "in general, very pleased" with its prospects, despite being in the red for the second year, said the executive director, Isabelle Singer. "We have seen things occur in the audience, in sales. We usually give five classical and three popular concerts. Last December, in view of the economy, we suspended our pops series, performing only one pops concert."
The orchestra, which has an annual budget of $354,000, had its grant from the Connecticut Commission on the Arts cut by $1,600 this year.
"We are trying to keep costs down and be more aggressive in individual support," she said.

 
Merger Discussions
 The Stamford Symphony's executive director, Barbara Soroca, said that the orchestra has exceeded its fund-raising goals so far this year despite a minor reduction in state funds and slower subscription sales. "We have to be creative," she added.
Last year the Stamford Symphony approached the Fairfield Orchestra (formerly the Fairfield Chamber Orchestra) to discuss a possible merger. Several meetings followed, but the project was dropped.
"I think that financially many of the orchestras across the state should merge and perform around the state, much as the New Jersey Symphony does," Mrs. Soroca said. "It would be much more cost effective. As to the likelihood, it would take a lot of negotiations and emotional energy. For the musicians, it would be a difficult situation."
Also vying for dollars in Stamford is the Connecticut Grand Opera. Financial problems have haunted the company, based in Stamford and Bridgeport, for the last few years. Musicians said their paychecks were often late.
"Our cash flow is uneven," acknowledged John Hiddlestone, the opera's general manager. "We've always managed to scrape through. The problem is that there's no telling when this economy is going to bottom out. You hear talk about an upsurge on the horizon. We're trying to do anything we can to save money without sacrificing the quality of the product."
Last spring the opera postponed a new production of Mozart's "Magic Flute," replacing it with an all-Mozart concert with four soloists.
"We did it for purely economic reasons," Mr. Hiddlestone said. "We saw the beginning of the effects last year of the downturn in the economy in terms of our contributions from corporate sources and the uncertainties of our state and city funding. Those were looking very much in jeopardy. Rather than risking getting into difficulty with 'Magic Flute,' we thought it would be prudent to do a program that cost considerably less to produce. People were very understanding."
 
Promising Newcomers
 "The Magic Flute" has been rescheduled for Nov. 9 in Bridgeport at the Klein, and Nov. 16 at the Palace Theater in Stamford.
Mr. Hiddlestone also pointed out that the company has gradually been implementing a policy of casting young, promising American singers instead of paying more for established stars.
"We're doing a lot more auditioning than ever before," he said.
In the music business, "it's essential to be optimistic," Mr. Hiddlestone said. "At the same time, you have to keep those feet planted on the floor."
And what of the musicians in these troubled times? They have to make some adjustments, said Richard Shillea, 32 years old, of Stratford, a clarinetist with the Greater Bridgeport Symphony, the Stamford Chamber Orchestra and Connecticut Grand Opera, and the Eastern Connecticut Symphony, who is also on the substitute list for the Hartford Symphony. While orchestra jobs used to be his main source of income, he said, in recent years he has had to depend more on private teaching. He is on the faculty of Fairfield University and teaches in the pre-college division of the Juilliard School.
"The amount of work is down to an all-time low in the 10 years I've been freelancing," Mr. Shillea said. "A person like myself is turning toward other areas -- thankfully, for me, musical ones."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1159 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Affordable Homes Help Slumping California Oil City

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: BAKERSFIELD, CALIF.

 BODY:
The growth of this high-desert city has come in lurches over the last decade. Now it is counting on affordable housing to help propel it into a new role as the latest suburban outpost of Los Angles, 100 miles to the south.
In the mid-1980's, when energy was a growth business, this city close to oil fields and refineries expanded. The collapse of oil prices later in the decade, however, resulted in the loss of 10,000 jobs, the departure of several major employers and foreclosure for a clutch of office buildings. 
 The real estate market had nearly recovered when the combined force of the savings-and-loan fiasco and the real estate slump hit, leaving empty and unfinished buildings in its wake. Downtown vacancy rates are a sobering 30 percent.
But in the slow economy, the combination of affordable housing, low office rents and abundant cheap land has made the city attractive to corporations.
Affordable housing, in particular, helped persuade the State Farm Insurance Companies to choose Bakersfield as the site of a 500,000-square-foot regional headquarters. By 1996, the company plans to have 1,000 employees at work there. Many State Farm employees are expected to relocate to the city from other parts of California and to be able to buy homes here, despite the state's notorious reputation for out-of-reach prices.
"You can buy a fine home in Bakersfield for about half of what you would pay in Orange County," said Roger Tompkins, a State Farm vice president in Westlake Village, Calif. In August, the median home price in Bakersfield was $95,000, compared to $241,300 in Orange County, according to the California Association of Realtors.
Home prices also figured in a decision last year by Chevron USA to locate its Western Production Business Unit in Bakersfield. A Chevron spokesman, Jonathan Lifa, said home prices looked "especially affordable" compared to those in San Francisco, Chevron's corporate base, where the median price was $290,000 in August.
Bakersfield represents the dividing line between urban southern California and the San Joaquin Valley, an agricultural area that stretches 230 miles north to Stockton. The region -- the destination of the Joad family in John Steinbeck's Dust Bowl-era novel "The Grapes of Wrath" -- remains largely agricultural, although California's urban growth is gnawing away at its edges.
Although some Bakersfield residents cringe at the suburbanization of their city, the phenomonen is familiar in southern California.
Since the 1960's, the quest for affordable housing, coupled with the willingness of Californians to commute long distances, has pushed the suburban frontier of Greater Los Angeles south to Orange County, north to the San Fernando Valley and Santa Clarita, east to Riverside and San Bernardino Counties and west to Ventura County. The Antelope Valley, a Los Angeles County region a few miles south of Bakersfield, was the state's hottest homebuilding market in the late 80's.
The Bakersfield boom is part of that larger growth phenomenon. Its population, now 185,000, leaped 65 percent in the last decade, according to the city's planning department, while the number of nonagricultural jobs grew 19 percent in the same period, to 171,000, the state Economic Development Department says.
Bakersfield's resilience, as well as occasional shocks to the local economy, can be traced to its historic role as an oil city. It is the seat of Kern County, one of the busiest oil-pumping regions in the country. Although the oil slump of the 80's induced several "majors" to leave the city, Big Oil is now returning.
Chevron surprised the region last year by pulling up stakes in the city of Ventura, 80 miles south, where the company had already built a luxury office building, to lease offices in Bakersfield. Besides the attraction of affordable housing, Mr. Lifa, the Chevron spokesman, said, the move reflected a new company policy to locate management near drilling sites.
Another recent arrival, Santa Fe Energy Resources of Houston, has leased 40,000 square feet in a suburban office building.
Despite hopeful signs from the oil industry, the city is not out of the woods. Some downtown problems have so far defied solution.
A half-finished 293-room hotel, abandoned by both developer and lender, and an empty, foreclosed office building have been persistent headaches for the Central District Development Agency, the city's redevelopment arm. It has tried to bring new activity to a downtown area that resembles a time capsule from the 1940's and 50's.
When the seven-story, 92,000-square-foot City Center office building was completed in 1989, the local office market was still reeling from the contraction of the oil industry. Developers of other buildings had slashed rents to induce companies to sign leases; much of that space ultimately went for less than $12 a square foot, considerably less than anywhere in southern California.
Those low rents, in turn, undercut the economics of the City Center building, which needed at least $17.40 a square foot to pay its mortgage. An affiliate of U.S. Bancorp foreclosed on the empty building last year.
The city itself foreclosed on the hotel project when the lender, a savings-and-loan institution, became insolvent; the city was the landowner and was entitled to the project if there was a default. Now the city is having little luck finding another developer to buy the rusting, gray hulk.
As in many aging downtown areas, government itself has become a valued tenant. In January, Kern County employees will move into the $32 million, 276,000-square-foot County Courts and Administration Building, where the county plans to employ 600 people.
With homebuilding continuing steadily in Bakersfield and other high-desert areas, the city has been drawn into the commuter orbit of greater Los Angeles.
"I have talked to developers who have sold their entire subdivisions to people who work in the San Fernando Valley" 85 miles to the south, Jack Hardisty, the city planning director.
The suburbanization of Bakersfield may accelerate if state officials make good on plans to build a high-speed train linking Sacramento and Los Angeles; Bakersfield would be a stop on the route. The train, which would travel at 180 miles an hour or more, could make the city suddenly "seem a lot closer to the Los Angeles basin," said Jake Wager, the city's economic development director.
Employees who work in the San Fernando Valley but cannot afford housing in that area could buy homes in Bakersfield, catch the high-speed train and arrive at their jobs in 20 minutes, Mr. Wager said.
But Mr. Hardisty said he was not enthusiastic about one possible effect of high-speed rail: losing the traditional independence of the local economy.
"We have always been remote enough that people have to bring jobs here," he said. "I'm not fond of the idea of becoming a bedroom community for someplace else."

GRAPHIC: Photos: New county Courts and Administration Building. Half-finished 293-room hotel, abandoned by builder and lender. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Present at the Reconciliation

BYLINE: By Michael R. Beschloss; Michael R. Beschloss is the author of "The Crisis Years: Kennedy and Khrushchev, 1960-1963."

 BODY:

THE TURN
From the Cold War to a New Era:
The United States and the Soviet Union, 1983-1990.
By Don Oberdorfer.
Illustrated. 514 pp. New York.
Poseidon Press. $25.  
 In December 1988, during a private New York meeting documented in Don Oberdorfer's authoritative new book, Mikhail S. Gorbachev told President-elect George Bush, "You'll see soon enough that I'm not doing this for show and I'm not doing this to undermine you or to surprise you or to take advantage of you. I'm playing real politics. I'm doing this because I need to. I'm doing this because there's a revolution taking place in my country. I started it. And they all applauded me when I started it in 1986 and now they don't like it so much, but it's going to be a revolution, nonetheless."
The Soviet leader could not know how right he was. Completed seven months before the Russian revolution of August 1991, "The Turn: From the Cold War to a New Era" focuses on the improvement in United States-Soviet relations during the middle and late 1980's. In so doing, it anticipates a coming historical dispute that will, no doubt, continue for years, if not decades: When, precisely, did the cold war end?
To reach a firm answer, we will have to have a great deal more hindsight and information -- particularly about internal Soviet decision making -- than we have today. In the meantime, Mr. Oberdorfer, a foreign affairs correspondent for The Washington Post, has brought us the most thorough account yet of what we can all agree was a crucial era in world politics. "The Turn" does much to fill the gap between the daily journalism of the time and the history that will one day be written on the basis of classified documents released by both Governments.
The author's long and excellent reputation for conscientious reporting has helped him to gain useful access to the upper ranks of the Ronald Reagan and George Bush foreign policy hierarchies, especially to his fellow Princetonian, the former Secretary of State George P. Shultz, whom he interviewed 13 times. Mr. Oberdorfer has also exploited opportunities offered by glasnost, interviewing more than 32 Soviet officials, scholars and journalists in Washington and Moscow.
His chronicle opens in 1983, when the Soviets downed a civilian Korean airliner and walked out of the Geneva arms talks; faulty intelligence caused them to fear, we now know, an imminent American surprise nuclear attack. The following year, Soviet-American relations were in such disrepair that a White House visit by the chilly veteran Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, to conduct the highest-level dialogue between the two countries in four years, was greeted with public jubilation.
During the 1984 Presidential campaign, the Democratic candidate, Walter Mondale, complained that Mr. Reagan was the first President since Herbert Hoover who had not met with his Soviet counterpart. Who might have anticipated that seven American-Soviet summit meetings would be held during the next six years? "The Turn" is largely the story of those summit meetings and the interstitial meetings between American and Soviet foreign ministers.
One thread through the diplomacy of the Reagan period was the President's cherished space-based Strategic Defense Initiative, which led Mr. Gorbachev into dark imaginings: a choice between further ransacking the exhausted Soviet economy or being faced someday with American dominion over the world. As the author shows, as early as the Geneva summit meeting of September 1985 Mr. Gorbachev complained: "Why should I believe what you have to say about sharing the results of research? . . . If S.D.I. is implemented, only God himself would know where it would lead."
In 1986, frustrated by Mr. Reagan's undiminished enthusiasm for the program, Mr. Gorbachev dragged his feet on another meeting and then pressed the President for a surprise October meeting at Reykjavik with only one week's notice. There, the Soviet leader dealt the first hand in what Mr. Shultz described to Mr. Oberdorfer as "the highest-stakes poker game ever played." After hearing out Mr. Gorbachev's suggestions for heretofore unimaginable cuts in nuclear arsenals and delivery systems, Mr. Reagan told his aides, "He's brought a whole lot of proposals, but I'm afraid he's going after S.D.I."
Nevertheless Mr. Reagan raised the ante, calling for the elimination of all Soviet and American nuclear weapons. Mr. Shultz was warily silent about this. Sounding like John Foster Dulles on Dwight Eisenhower, the Secretary of State later told the author: "I really felt that he's the President. He got elected twice. He has made no secret of his view on nuclear weapons. So who am I to stop him from saying what he believes and what he's campaigned on?"
Despite the failure of Mr. Reagan's proposal and the Reykjavik meeting's collapse, the two leaders were sufficiently reconciled that they hastened negotiations over a treaty to ban intermediate nuclear forces, which they signed at the White House in December 1987. Mr. Oberdorfer describes a large session in the Cabinet Room that included Mr. Reagan, Mr. Gorbachev and many of their aides. When Mr. Reagan "seemed unable to remember or relate the U.S. position, Shultz took over the conversation," while his boss "sat by in embarrassed silence." Later, Mr. Shultz frankly told the President that it had been "a terrible performance," and persuaded him to move future such meetings to the privacy of the Oval Office.
Mr. Oberdorfer effectively conveys Mr. Gorbachev's growing impatience with Mr. Reagan, and his worries about George Bush's skepticism toward perestroika. Mr. Gorbachev told Mr. Shultz that the Vice President must be "trying to display some muscles" on the campaign trail. At the Malta summit meeting of December 1989, in the wake of the fall of Eastern Europe, Mr. Gorbachev privately confided to the new President that he had been waiting for evidence that Mr. Bush was ready to move the Soviet-American relationship forward more tangibly. No longer. Presented with a host of American proposals to aid Soviet reform, Mr. Gorbachev declared: "Now I know."
The author wisely observes that "we are far too close to the events recorded here" to reach ultimate judgments about them. Yet his readers might have been better served had he strained a bit harder to show them the forest as well as the trees. His prose is usually serviceable, but one sometimes wonders whether his editor occasionally fell asleep. Mr. Oberdorfer writes, for example, that Mr. Shultz "worked patiently to apply steady inputs over time toward his long-range goal of improving U.S.-Soviet relations."
Such flaws do not seriously damage the book's central achievement. Mr. Oberdorfer succeeds in his goal: to record "what can be learned at the present time about one of the great turning points of history, and to convey something of the excitement, vitality and uncertainty with which it unfolded before our eyes."
