SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2114 words

HEADLINE: The Wizard Of Kansas

BYLINE: By Paul Theroux; Paul Theroux's collection of travel pieces, "To the Ends of the Earth," will be published next month.

 BODY:

PRAIRYERTH
(A Deep Map).
By William Least Heat-Moon.
624 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95. 
 A nation's literary history is always rich in phantom pregnancies. As you know, many writers produce a first book, worthy in every respect, and while there is often a muttered mention or a breathless hush regarding a second book, the thing never appears: phantom pregnancy. Isn't there a man in New Haven, sounding as desperate as a woman in a paternity suit, who is always threatening to publish his book? But it's a common condition. And I think most people, reflecting on the silence since "Blue Highways" appeared in 1982, believed -- and who could blame them? -- that William Least Heat-Moon's excellent book would not have a successor.
Yet that had also struck me as peculiar, because there must have been any number of publishers cooing into telephones, urging the man to repeat the formula. Why not try the blue highways of Russia or Brazil? "Or what about the back roads of Italy, Bill?" you can almost hear them saying. "Listen, they got plenty of roads in Australia." In the simple act of writing a travel book about your peregrinating down back roads you sort of lay claim to every back road on earth, or so people think. In that same spirit, it is sometimes felt that the world's railroads, and all their splendors and miseries, belong to me and that anyone else who writes about them ought to be shot for poaching. Travel writing is a queer and insufficient preoccupation, which is why I practice it only with my left hand.
With the appearance of "PrairyErth" it is immediately obvious what Mr. Least Heat-Moon has been doing for the past almost 10 years, and that is researching and writing this densely printed 624-page book. "PrairyErth" (a term used to describe prairie soils that Mr. Heat-Moon draws from "an old taxonomy") is not on the face of it a travel book, any more than is Gilbert White's "Natural History and Antiquities of Selborne" -- a work it much resembles in form and intention. The subtitle, "A Deep Map," is not much help, being at once idiosyncratic and gnomic (I suppose he means the invasive procedure of writing about an alien landscape). But "Blue Highways" proved beyond any doubt that Mr. Heat-Moon is nothing if not gnomic. If "Prairy Erth" is travel at all it is travel in eccentric circles -- but the word "eccentric" in the sense of "off-center" is also wildly inappropriate, since the landscape of Mr. Heat-Moon's book, Chase County, Kansas, is at the geographical center of our country. "I have traveled a good deal in Concord," Thoreau said, and in this book Mr. Heat-Moon has covered just about every inch in the 774 square miles of Chase County, met most of its people, noted most of its Burma-Shave signs, and disproved the scribbled graffito "Living in Kansas is a contradiction."
It is a wonderful and welcome book and has the distinct virtue of being completely unexpected. It is as different from "Blue Highways" as any book is likely to be, but obviously written by the same man, who is thoroughly friendly and patient, rather self-conscious, slightly pedantic (he knows the words "forb" and "chert" and you don't), something of a loner, a trifle old-fashioned, a bit mystical and just as much at home in the tallgrass prairie as on the far side of a cracker barrel. He is also something of a naturalist, though he is lacking in the misanthropy that characterizes that calling -- nature lovers are so often people haters.
Chase County has a total population of 3,013, and on Mr. Heat-Moon's reckoning there is not a bad egg among them. To his great credit, he is lavish in reporting the Kansas idiom: "He's been around the sun bettern fifty times," and "All I ever caught was a limb in the face," and the man who "wasn't worth a bushel of damn hedgeballs" and, in a more sinister vein: "The other guy shot the colored boy in the back of the head and got off on self-defense -- convinced the jury the guy use to wear his hat backwards."
Of the living heroes and just plain folks Mr. Heat-Moon finds, there is the cowboy Slim Pinkston, "a character shaped by the bovine nature of the animals he spends his days with"; Larry Wagner, crippled by polio, who is eloquent in his attempt to save the tallgrass prairie; Linda Thurston, whose cafe went bust: "We never did get the farmers to eat alfalfa sprouts. They know silage when they see it. Maybe we should have tried it with gravy"; and Blanche Schwilling from Bazaar, serving up Scripture tea (a Bible quotation on every tag), and Frank Gaddie of the same hamlet who loves the treeless prairie so intensely that he remarks, "It's got so I hate a tree"; Fidel Ybarra, who remembers every spike he has driven and every railroad tie he has set; Lloyd Soyez, who perhaps saved de Gaulle from being assassinated by German snipers in Paris -- and spared the French nation; and a nameless but memorable customer in the Strong City cafe, who described his Kansas encounter with a history professor in Hush Puppies from Back East: "Couldn't tell a sycamore from a cottonwood, hadn't the least idea of what kind of tree to cut a wagon axle out of. He wasn't exactly sure what an ox is. He didn't know how to make hominy, hadn't ever skinned a squirrel or milked a cow -- and he got paid fifty thousand a year to tell college kids about the West."
This is rural Kansas, but a far cry from the grim lunacy of "In Cold Blood," the fantasy of "The Wizard of Oz" or from Ian Frazier's vivid but shapeless "Great Plains." It is all prairie, and mostly pleasure -- nothing here that smacks of the prairie fear felt by such natives of it as Willa Cather, who had an absolute horror of grassland. If "PrairyErth" has a fault it is that it is almost entirely a celebration, even when it does not mean to be. It is a good-hearted book about the heart of the country. Mr. Heat-Moon does not make much of the xenophobia he encounters, nor does he explore the racism -- the anti-black and anti-Hispanic sentiments he hears. He takes people as he finds them and they put up with his note-taking. Nagged for drinking a beer with his lunch in a cemetery ("This isn't a tavern") he just smiles. "You'll be tolerated even if they do think you're about a half bubble off plumb," a woman tells the author, making him feel he has been complimented. I kept wondering why he apparently spent all his time in motels. If these people are the salt of the earth why didn't they offer him a bed? And while I am quibbling, why was it that few showed much concern about the greater world beyond Kansas? I have recently been in the Solomon Islands, and I heard more intelligent political talk and global concern from one naked Melanesian on Guadalcanal than Mr. Heat-Moon heard from a whole county of Kansas farmers.
It is risky for any book to attempt to be exhaustive, and this is as true for "Moby-Dick" as it is for "PrairyErth." The risk is that lengthy extracts can break the spell of reading, and because such a book -- as shuffling and potbellied with undigested stuff as the Kansans it describes -- may quickly became nothing more than a data base, something to sort and study. The catalogue, the long digression, the essay-within-the-text, the scrapbook, the potted history, the rural lexicon, the natural history exhibit -- all of this served up as narration -- can blunt the edge ofreading.
I was bouncing along quite nicely with "PrairyErth" when I turned a page, came upon a new chapter and read the opening: "A couple of sentences of personal testimony (thoroughfare readers not happy on byways may proceed to the next chapter)," which is hardly a gripping way to begin, or one likely to inspire a reader to dig in. And this diffident caveat is not necessary, since the chapter is a useful disquisition on Mr. Heat-Moon's own name and on the 140 ways Kansas has been spelled. This being an exhaustive book, each different name is lovingly set down.
Another chapter is entirely about Kansas hawks, yet another concerns the Kansas wood rat, there is a disquisition on fence posts (Kansas being particularly rich in this item) and 17 pages containing colorful news stories that the author found in old Chase County newspapers ("Chewed By Hogs," "Homestead Notes" etc.). A 22-page chapter is made up of extracts from eyewitness accounts of the indigenous people, the Kaw Indians. There is a 200-item inventory of the contents of a covered wagon. I have read it all, and because I have I know that some of it seems skippable. There is also, toward the end, a chapter about nothing in particular -- simply a long quasi-mystical rumination about what might have been in that chapter, though in it the author discloses that his book is twice as long as he had intended. A hundred pages, nearly one-sixth of "PrairyErth," are given over to squibs and quotations from the author's "commonplace book" -- extracts from authors as various as D. H. Lawrence, Thoreau, Horace Greeley, Audubon, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, James Agee, Walt Whitman, Laurence Sterne, and -- yes -- Gilbert White's "Selborne."
If Mr. Heat-Moon does not know when to stop, that is the sign of real passion in a traveler. There is a great deal of love and happiness in the book, and because he is truly inspired by the landscape he has achieved something akin to Gilbert White's book, and made his own a home-grown oddity, something that would rather uncertainly be catalogued in a library under "Topography." And yet what is it? It is history, travel, anthropology, geography, journalism, confession, memoir, natural history and autobiography. It is the life and times of Chase County, and incidentally everything you need to know about Kansas. That last might seem a backhanded description, but we live in strange times when every economic refugee and his brother and sister have begun to regard America as a sort of ship that will speed them as far away as possible from their own hungry and quarreling homeland.
America was a good idea, and also an idealistic notion, long before it was a destination for desperate souls. "PrairyErth" is a salutary book because it goes against the notion that America is all flux and newcomers.
Kansas is the way we were, and it is the way many people in this country still are. By concentrating his scrutiny on this small area of rural America, where families have been settled for generations, where folks are folks and there is a strong sense of attachment to the land; by accumulating a vast mass of detail, and querying whether the West was won in quite the way we felt it was, Mr. Heat-Moon has succeeded in recapturing a sense of the American grain that will give the book a permanent place in the literature of our country. I mean to say that in its doggedness, its thoroughness and its ingenious design, the book -- in its intentional crankiness -- has value both as a historical document and as personal testimony.
 
 
 
THE PURGATORY OF MILEAGE
 There are several ways not to walk in the prairie, and one of them is with your eye on a far goal, because you then begin to believe you're not closing the distance any more than you would with a mirage. My woodland sense of scale and time didn't fit this country, and I started wondering whether I could reach the summit before dark. On the prairie, distance and the miles of air turn movement to stasis and openness to a wall, a thing as difficult to penetrate as dense forest. I was hiking in a chamber of absences where the near was the same as the far, and it seemed every time I raised a step the earth rotated under me so that my foot fell just where it had lifted from. Limits and markers make travel possible for people: circumscribe our lines of sight and we can really get somewhere. Before me lay the Kansas of popular conception from Coronado on -- that place you have to get through, that purgatory of mileage.
But I kept walking, and, when I dropped into hollows . . . I focused on a rock or a tuft of grass to keep from convoluting my track. Hiking in woods allows a traveler to imagine comforting enclosures, one leading to the next, and the walker can possess those little encompassed spaces, but the prairie and plains permit no such possession. Whatever else prairie is -- grass, sky, wind -- it is most of all a paradigm of infinity, a clearing full of many things except boundaries, and its power comes from its apparent limitlessness; there is no such thing as a small prairie any more than there is a little ocean, and the consequence of both is this challenge: try to take yourself seriously out here, you bipedal plodder, you complacent cartoon. -- From "PrairyErth."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1702 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
When the Final Act Is Only a Beginning

BYLINE: By A. R. GURNEY; A. R. Gurney's latest play, "The Snow Ball," has had productions in Hartford, San Diego and, most recently, Boston.

 BODY:
People in the theater tend to lament the evanescence of our craft, as performances and productions come and go like bubbles on a stream. Sometimes, however, this very transience gives us an opportunity we might not find elsewhere. Books and films, for example, once they are published or produced, are pretty much frozen for eternity, with all their virtues and flaws permanently in place. A play, on the other hand, can be rewritten and reworked after its initial production, in many cases to its considerable improvement.
Until recently, this process of adjustment would usually occur on the way to New York, where a Broadway opening was deemed the ultimate destination for a new play. Yet nowadays, a very different process can take place to keep a work alive. A play may open for a limited run at an Off Broadway theater, be reviewed and then be rewritten or amended for a new and extended life elsewhere in the country. 
 I myself am going through this procedure right now. Last spring, a play of mine called "The Old Boy," directed by John Rubinstein, with Stephen Collins in the title role, opened at Playwrights Horizons. Good as the production may have been, the play itself had problems from the beginning. Prior to and during the previews, we made many changes, but I don't think any of us was totally content with what we had. Nonetheless, the play worked well enough in the weeks before opening to garner serious offers from two sets of producers. One group thought it should go right to Broadway, while the other was interested in a run at an Off Broadway theater. Of course, once the reviews came in, all smiles stopped. No reviewer gave that loud unqualified shout of praise normally needed to carry a play forward over the shoals of economic risk into the pleasant harbor of an unlimited run on Broadway or Off Broadway.
In our desperation to keep the producers on the line, John Rubinstein managed to cull from all these notices a list of complimentary quotations. But the cost of producing plays in New York being what it is today, and the risk of keeping a problematic one alive during the summer and early fall seasons with their erratic attendance, caused both sets of producers to have second thoughts.
I was harboring second thoughts as well. I had begun to notice an inconsistency of response in the audience, which particularly bothered me. One night, the actors were playing to good laughs, the next, the audience seemed introspective and intense. Houses, of course, vary from night to night, but this variance didn't feel quite right.
In addition, many reviews seemed to circle around a few common complaints: I may have written a number of strong scenes, but there was too much exposition, a slight tipping toward melodrama, and the supporting characters kept running away with the ball. Friends and colleagues also suggested that the ending didn't quite pay off. You can always tell when you're not hitting down the center of the fairway by the coded responses of those who speak to you afterwards: "Congratulations on your play." "I had an interesting time." "You sure pushed a lot of buttons in this one." Very few people said, "I loved it," which is what I was hoping to hear. I thought about all this for a while, and after the dust from the closing settled, decided I'd better get back to the drawing board.
Rewriting can be a dangerous enterprise. You can do too little or too much, particularly when you're not playing nightly to a paying audience, whose reaction should be the final arbiter of whatever you do. Most of us in the theater are so wedded to our work that the smallest change seems to us to send wild tremors up and down the entire evening.
Furthermore, the fact that you feel the need to rewrite at all may be, in itself, a bad sign. Good plays are supposed to be inherently organic, and it may be some sort of violation to mess around with them. Those that need to be tinkered with may end up seeming carpentered and contrived, if they weren't that way to begin with. Did Beckett rewrite "Waiting for Godot" after its first bad reviews? Wasn't Shakespeare supposed to have never blotted a line?
A few times in my life I've written plays that, for better or worse, required very little tuning once they were under way. I know it's a special pleasure to work on these plays, but I also know that these are not the only plays that are any good. "Hamlet," to me, has the feel of a play that Shakespeare fussed with a good deal, and we know how many tries it took Chekhov to come up with "Uncle Vanya." Lucky as we are when works spring to life fully armed, there are many times when we write other things that need to be patted and pushed and pulled into the right shape.
There's another problem with rewriting a play if you reassess it immediately after a production you feel proud of. The actors and the director have, of course, put their special stamp on the enterprise, and in many cases have made moments work, or seem to work, which possibly have no right to. If you are now trying to retool the play for subsequent productions, you can delude yourself into holding onto lines, bits or even scenes that may have been totally dependent on the special talents of your recent collaborators. There are plays that good actors or directors can make particularly their own, and which may evaporate once they're divorced from the talents of the Lunts or Jerry Zaks.
Still, here I am, armed with the hope that I have a good thing at its core, and the conviction that I should take one more stab at making it better. I'm detached by several months from the compelling immediacy of the Playwrights Horizons production, influenced by the insights of several people I've learned to trust, and lured by the anticipation of another production at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego later this year.
"The Old Boy" is about a youngish State Department official, about to run for governor, who is invited to give the commencement address at his alma mater, a distinguished New England boarding school. During the weekend there, he learns that a classmate, for whom he was an "old boy," or mentor, has recently died of AIDS. Through a series of flashbacks, the politician comes to recognize the bankruptcy of the old-boy values by which he both lived his life and guided his friend, and therefore his own complicity in his friend's death. He proclaims as much in an emotional address at the school graduation, possibly destroying his career but liberating himself as a human being.
Most rewrites require a certain amount of carpentering -- the sort of cutting and shaping and sanding that writers learn to do if they've been around awhile. The trick is not to let the seams show. I've tried to make these adjustments on "The Old Boy," hoping to simplify the beginning, shore up the strange dip from seriousness to solemnity in the middle of the first act and keep the ball in the air more effectively throughout.
Yet, I had two knottier problems. One was the climactic commencement address, which, no matter what we did, always seemed self-conscious and stagy. In our attempt to do something different -- have the main character give an impassioned speech while another character comments cynically on it -- we seemed to take the audience out of the play, rather than pull them in deeper. This sense of a double perspective is achieved all the time in the movies or in opera, but we couldn't do it on the Playwrights Horizons stage. We tried scrims, microphones, cutting, adding, but we never got the thing quite right. The result always seemed tricky and artificial, and the audience came away more concerned with a sense of the device than with what we were trying to say through it.
Another problem was that my main character, the "old boy," didn't seem to engage either the audience or the critics as much as several minor characters did. William Sloane Coffin makes the distinction between a "nice guy" and a "good man," and in one sense my play was supposed to be about a conversion from the former to the latter. Yet his transition wasn't happening the way we wanted on stage. Other characters with less subtle journeys to make kept attracting attention. "Too many stories," Elia Kazan told me after he came to see it.
In addressing these two concerns, my hope was that if I could get the hero right, his final speech would fall into place in the right way. I found myself exploring in more depth the limits of his own emotional life, and once I had found those, I could revise the dialogue so that he became more understandable as he tried to impose similar limits on his friend. I also tried to simplify and smooth out the more baroque elements in the plot lines of the supporting characters so that they would remain firmly in the same play, and therefore more firmly supportive of the protagonist.
Having done all these things, I found, when my hero arrives at his final speech, that our scrim, microphone and synchronized dialogue were no longer needed. He seemed to want to talk simply and directly to the audience. The tonal complexity we strove for is, to a degree, still there, but it now emerges from the form and nature of the speech, as the speaker provides his own commencement by giving himself a final exam.
The producer Roger Stevens is fond of saying, "O.K., now take out the improvements," and possibly Old Globe audiences for "The Old Boy" will tell me to do the same. But I like to think I've been plugging the leaks, recaulking the seams, reshaping the bow and stern in the hope that this time the ship will have a longer voyage.
This is not to say that the New York experience hasn't been extremely valuable. New York preview audiences are the savviest in the world -- with their strange combination of skepticism, empathy and professional awareness -- and the changes I've made are largely the result of their responses. But I also have to conclude that, at least for me, a New York production of a play has become more and more like the "Go" square on the Monopoly board. You have to pass through it to stay in the game, you may collect your $200, but landing there is not necessarily the end of the game.

HEADLINE: The 'Man Shortage' and Other Big Lies

BYLINE: By George F. Will; George F. Will is a syndicated columnist. His most recent book was "Suddenly: The American Idea Abroad and at Home, 1986-1990."

 BODY:

HENRY CLAY
Statesman for the Union.
By Robert V. Remini.
Illustrated. 818 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $35.  
 In 1832 a gangly 23-year-old grocery clerk was occasionally seen in a skiff on the Sangamon River in central Illinois, charting depths and wondering how improvements might bring steamboats and prosperity to New Salem. Politically attuned people would not have needed to ask about his politics: young Abraham Lincoln obviously was a Henry Clay man. When in the winter of 1837 the Illinois legislature passed an enormous ($10 million) appropriation to subsidize construction of railroads, canals and turnpikes, there were bonfires and dancing in the streets of the state capital, Vandalia.
To understand why such things engaged such passions, and why they should have, read Robert V. Remini's fine biography "Henry Clay: Statesman for the Union." One of the master builders of modern America, Clay was a man of the middle, and not just politically, in his role as "The Great Compromiser" of sectional disputes. His career flowered smack in the middle of America's protracted founding. How protracted was it? Precisely fourscore and nine years. The process of coming together, institutionally and emotionally, from a loose aggregation of colonists to a single body politic -- citizens of a nation with a competent central government -- began in Philadelphia in early July 1776, and was punctuated with an exclamation mark in April 1865, at Appomattox.
Clay was 29 years old and constitutionally under age when he was first sent to the United States Senate by the legislature of Kentucky. But he preferred the turbulence of the House, to which he won election at the age of 34. He became Speaker on his first day as a member. He, together with the other two-thirds of "the great triumvirate," Daniel Webster and John C. Calhoun, was a star of "the next generation," the one that would build a commercial society on the political foundations the Founders had put in place.
Clay came as a young man to a Washington where rain often made Pennsylvania Avenue impassable. It was a Washington where President Thomas Jefferson agreed to sign the bill authorizing Federal construction of roads, but admonished Congress that the Constitution should be amended to authorize such activities, lest the doctrine of "implied powers" become a large loophole and the Constitution itself mostly a loophole. Clay quickly became what the country became and still is. Rhetorically he was a Jeffersonian; actually he was a Hamiltonian, asserting implied powers sufficient for his "American System." That system involved enactment of tariffs, "internal improvements" (roads, canals, railroads) and other elements of the infrastructure of a unified commercial nation with an energetic central government "adequate to the exigencies of the Union" (Hamilton's words).
 Mr. Remini, a historian at the University of Illinois at Chicago, has spent most of his professional life in the company, as it were, of Clay's most formidable enemy, Andrew Jackson. He has written many books about the general, his era and the ideology to which Jackson gave a name: his own. Jackson's name became an adjective; Clay's never did. Clay was a legislator; Jackson was a leader.
Clay's name is usually near the top of lists drawn up to support the assertion by the British political theorist, Lord Bryce, that America's greatest statesmen generally do not get to the White House. But reading Mr. Remini's book leaves one far from certain that Clay, although unquestionably a great man, was suited to the Presidency. Clay, who had an acute sense of the dynamics of America's rapidly evolving society, was remarkably blind to the public's changing political values and expectations.
Clay is primarily remembered for relentlessly pursuing an ambition that went unfulfilled, and for meticulously crafting and doggedly enacting compromises that ultimately failed. He burned with Presidential ambition, burned so fiercely that he irrevocably blighted his chances early on, in the Presidential election of 1824 -- or, more precisely, the election of February 1825.
Today, as this nation sleepwalks into a remarkably dull Presidential season, it is instructive, diverting and amusing to read Mr. Remini's account of the events of 1824, when John Quincy Adams, Andrew Jackson, William Crawford and Clay competed for the Presidency. Clay wildly misjudged his strength in the various state procedures that selected Presidential electors. When these procedures failed to produce a majority for any candidate, the choice went to the House, which had to pick from among the top three. Speaker Clay had finished fourth. There was bargaining galore, some of it involving trivialities that were ludicrous in light of the great office at issue (the man who alone would cast Missouri's vote presented Adams with a list of printers he wanted appointed to print the laws in Missouri). And Clay supposedly made the "corrupt bargain" that was to haunt him the rest of his life.
Was there an explicit agreement between Clay and Adams? It is hard to say for sure. But against the instructions of the Kentucky legislature, which favored Jackson, Clay supported Adams, who had not officially received a single popular vote in Kentucky. When Adams became President he named Clay his Secretary of State, an office Clay craved because he was sure it was a stepping stone to the White House.
Reading Mr. Remini's book it is hard to avoid the conclusion that Clay, when operating outside of legislative chambers, was a lousy politician. He was comfortable in Congress; indeed, he was an artist in Washington's ways. But he was barely conversant with what was just then beginning to matter: public opinion. A century before there was a Washington Beltway, Clay had what is now known as the "beltway mentality."
He had a melodious voice, a flair for self-dramatization and a sense of style that he acquired in his youth (he had heard Patrick Henry speak) and modified with appropriate anecdotes and profanity for Kentucky tastes. Mr. Remini's descriptions of Clay, the consummate actor, evoke an era when rhetoric, sent forth by the unamplified human voice, was a vital instrument of governance.
He was full to brimming over with the juices of life, frequently injuring his own political interests by acts of inadequate calculation. But his incaution makes him particularly alluring to any student of today's politicians. Clay, you see, was utterly unmanaged and unpackaged. He had what the 41st President was to call "the vision thing." He created it from his own observations and passions, without the help of polls or "focus groups" massaged by committees of consultants. Further, he was on speaking terms with the English language, which he wielded energetically, sometimes as a club, often as a stiletto, occasionally one too sharp for his own good.
Clay not infrequently drank too much and gambled recklessly. Westerners, as Kentuckians then were, were thought susceptible, and even entitled, to such behavior. His strenuous conviviality, which political enemies insisted was much more unsavory than that, included a conspicuous enjoyment of the company of various women when, as was frequently the case, Mrs. Clay was away. It is as impossible to know the truth of the innuendoes that swirled around him as it is to know their consequences, but they cannot have helped his career.
Part of the poignancy of Clay's life is that we can now see that his clever attempts to legislate compromises concerning slavery amounted to attempts to lasso a locomotive with cobwebs. Consider, for example, Clay's last great work, the Compromise of 1850, which addressed conflicts concerning the treatment of slavery in the several jurisdictions within the vast territories acquired in the war with Mexico (1846-48). Mr. Remini believes, reasonably, that the Compromise postponed the Civil War for a decade, and may thereby have saved the nation. Thanks to Clay, the nation had 10 more years to enlarge its manpower and develop its industrial might and find that good Clay man, Lincoln, and thereby prevail.
It is a measure of Mr. Remini's thorough yet understated scholarship that he notes, but does not dwell on, the fact that after winning passage of the Compromise of 1850, Clay "left Washington on Saturday, September 28, and arrived back in Lexington on October 2, a journey of incredible speed, thanks to the railroad." Seven hundred pages earlier Mr. Remini had written of Clay's trip from Kentucky to Washington in December 1806, "traveling by boat up the Ohio River and then by stagecoach over almost impassable roads."
By the 1850's the roar of steam powering steel wheels over steel rails was the sound of American society -- meaning, primarily, the economy -- preparing to settle what politics and legislatures could not. The supposedly prosaic (as we are apt mistakenly to think) matter of "internal improvements" was crucial to the improvement of the nation's inner, meaning moral, life -- and to the showdown over slavery. Railroads carrying conscripts, who were carrying weapons mass-produced from interchangeable parts, would be the North's decisive riposte to the South's constitutional arguments. Railroads, and the steel mills and coal mines and immigrant labor behind them, closed the question that could not be compromised.
Clay's "American System" helped to save the American experiment. Thus the life of the Great Compromiser illustrates the practical importance of political programs. But it also illustrates the limits of politics as a leash on large, rushing events.

HEADLINE: Bailout Data Questioned

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Congressional auditors say they cannot determine the accuracy of the savings and loan bailout's financial statements because of uncertain real estate markets and the agency's poor accounting controls.
The refusal of the General Accounting Office to offer an opinion on the Resolution Trust Corporation's 1990 statement, although expected, is another blow to the two-year-old agency's efforts to obtain $80 billion from Congress to continue its cleanup program. 
 It has received $80 billion since its creation in August 1989 and says it will run out of money in weeks. It is asking for another $80 billion to finish its work by October 1993.
Some Democrats in Congress have warned that they will vote against the fund request unless G.A.O. auditors give the R.T.C. financial statements what accountants call a "clean," or unqualified, opinion.
"Our audit disclosed that significant uncertainties exist affecting the corporation's cost estimates for resolving institutions and that the corporation lacked certain internal critical controls in 1990"' the G.A.O.'s head, Charles A. Bowsher, said in a letter to Congressional leaders.
But he noted that the R.T.C. had begun new procedures to cure its internal control problems. And he said that the chief sources of uncertainty were beyond the agency's control, including the weak economy and overbuilt real estate markets and their effect on the value of the properties the R.T.C. had inherited from failed savings and loans.

HEADLINE: Third World Debt Relief

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The Paris Club of creditor governments will meet in November to review Britain's proposal for greater debt forgiveness for the world's poorest nations, the Treasury Department says.
Officials of the club, made up of Western creditor nations including the United States, met last week in Paris to discuss debt relief requests. 
 Treasury officials said on Friday that the British debt-forgiveness proposal, which calls for write-offs of two-thirds of about $25.5 billion in debts held by 20 low-income nations, received support from some of the 18 Paris Club states present at the meeting.
But a Treasury spokesman said representatives at the talks were seeking further review of the proposals with their government ministers before giving a specific response.
The Paris Club officials were formally presented with Prime Minister John Major's appeal to put into effect quickly the so-called Trinidad terms he proposed in September 1990, a Treasury spokesman said.
The Trinidad terms allow debtor countries to renegotiate their entire debt instead of rescheduling parts of it, provided the eligible countries have begun economic reform programs sanctioned by the International Monetary Fund.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Clients See Better Service From Agencies and Media

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
THE relationships of American advertisers with their advertising agencies and the media are improving, the departing chairman of the Association of National Advertisers says, as agencies and the media rediscover that "their focus has to be on one thing -- how to build business for their clients."
"If the clients' business prospers, all prosper," Philip Guarascio, the executive in charge of corporate marketing and advertising for the General Motors Corporation and the association's departing chairman, said in a telephone interview before the group's 82d annual meeting and business conference. The conference, at the Arizona Biltmore Hotel in Phoenix, began yesterday and will continue through tomorrow. 
 With rare exceptions, prosperity is a quality in scant supply among the association's members, companies that account for almost 80 percent of the regional and national advertising spending in the United States. As the enonomic doldrums drag on, those afflicted include not only advertisers like General Motors, whose businesses are cyclical in nature. Also hampered are advertisers like the Procter & Gamble Company, whose businesses were once deemed recession resistant if not recession-proof.
"Given the pressures we are under," Mr. Guarascio said, "we all understand we have to deal with problems unique to our own industries." Even so, he added, he is pleased that during his year as chairman, the association's members have been able to spend more time on "what we share in common."
And what they share most is a recognition that "the structure of the business has irrevocably changed," he said, "in terms of our relationships with agencies and the media."
Elaborating on the agencies, Mr. Guarascio said, "for too long, they got into the business of managing their business first and their clients' business second; that order has to be reversed."
Mr. Guarascio said he was now glimpsing signs that agencies were indeed "making a major effort to get that back in balance." In particular, he added, "agency resources are being concentrated on client business, and senior managers are spending more time on clients."
Mr. Guarascio gave no specific examples, but among recent evidence is Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide's announcement last week of a restructuring meant to enable top executives to devote more energy to key advertising and direct-marketing accounts and less to public relations and sales-promotion activities.
As for the media, Mr. Guarascio said, they are "doing less prepackaging and more listening."
He said, for example, that they are de-emphazising cross-media advertising sales programs based solely on what properties they happen to own. Instead, he continued, the media are "saying first, 'Let us understand what your problems are,' " and then designing programs to meet those needs.
Two media companies that Mr. Guarascio cited as having shifted focus in such a manner were Time Warner Inc. and Hachette Publications Inc.
Mr. Guarascio's one-year term as chairman of the association is to end today, when members are scheduled to elect as his successor L. Ross Love, vice president of advertising of Procter & Gamble Worldwide. Mr. Love has served as the association's vice chairman for the last year. Scheduled to be elected to succeed Mr. Love as vice chairman is Harry E. Davis, director of communications in the external affairs department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.
Among those scheduled to speak during the conference are Edwin L. Artzt, chairman and chief executive of Procter & Gamble; Robert L. Crandall, chairman and chief executive of American Airlines Inc.; Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman and chief executive of BBDO New York, and David Ogilvy, the founder of Ogilvy & Mather.
The conference is expected to draw 450 people, up from about 430 last year.

HEADLINE: FINANCE BRIEFS

 BODY:

Debt
 
* Finland's $17 billion of long-term foreign debt has been placed under review by Moody's Investors Service, which might lower the AA1 rating because "the current economic crisis" is "proving deeper than anticipated." Finland's exports to the Soviet Union have collapsed, it said. 

 
* Michigan Strategic Fund Ltd.'s $98.375 million refunding revenue bonds were priced through Morgan Stanley to yield 6.625 percent for the 2021 maturity. The issue, for the benefit of the Detroit Edison Company pollution project, is insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company; the bonds are rated AAA.
 
* International Business Machines Corp. sold five-year certificates backed by installment sales of computers to state and local governments. The tax-exempt certificates, totaling about $125 million, were priced to yield from 5.04 to 5.33 percent and have an expected average life of 1.62 to 1.83 years.
 
* Ilio Inc., Secaucus, N.J., a maker of women's cotton shirts, filed for $5.5 million of debentures through Offerman & Co., Minneapolis.
 
Ratings
 
* San Diego County Water Authority's certificates of participation were raised by Moody's to Aa, from A1, in conjunction with a sale planned for Nov. 6. The authority's $21 million of general-obligation debt was raised to Aaa, from Aa.
 
* Cranston, R.I., received a higher rating from Standard & Poor's on the city's $27.5 million of general-obligation debt. S.& P. lifted the rating to A, from A-, citing a history of financial stability.

HEADLINE: Lower Pollution Tied to Prosperity

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
A study correlating economic development and air pollution by two Princeton University professors has concluded that pollution tends to diminish as a country's economy grows beyond a certain level of prosperity.
The study, which taps international pollution data not readily known to economists, also finds that patterns of United States investment in Mexico do not indicate an effort by companies to avoid American pollution controls. 
 The research tends to support the Bush Administration's position that a free-trade agreement with Mexico would not be environmentally destructive. And it suggests that some environmentalists' predictions that economic growth and free trade in the developing world may ravage the world's environment are overstated.
The study was done by Gene M. Grossman and Alan B. Krueger, economics professors at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, and was presented at a conference at Brown University on Oct. 18. Mexico's Ministry of Commerce and Industry sponsored the conference and indirectly helped to finance the research, although the authors said the Mexican Government took no part in their work.
The study compared national economic output figures with air-pollution studies conducted in several dozen cities worldwide over the last 14 years by the United Nations Environment Program and the World Health Organization. It found that air pollution was most severe for countries with an economic output of $4,000 to $5,000 a person and less severe for considerably poorer and considerably richer countries.
Mexico, with an output per person of $5,000, "is at the critical juncture in its development process, where further growth should generate increased political pressures for environmental protection and perhaps a change in private consumption behavior," the report said.
 
Suspicions Confirmed
 Vinod Thomas, the World Bank's chief economist for Asia, said the study was the first to confirm many experts' suspicions that pollution increases during the early stages of a country's development and then begins to diminish as countries gain adequate resources to tackle pollution problems.
Jagdish Bhagwati, the Columbia University professor of economics who is overseeing a report on trade and the environment for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said, "There's been no systematic work" until now. He added that the GATT report would include a separate discussion of the new findings.
Justin R. Ward, a senior resource specialist and trade expert at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a New York-based environmental group, said that while the Princeton study's results were encouraging, specific environmental safeguards should be written into the agreement to insure that Mexico did not prove an exception.
 
Savings in Labor Costs
 To examine the role of pollution regulations in trade and investment with Mexico, the Princeton professors used Census Bureau data on pollution control spending as a percentage of total costs in each of many different industries. Savings on labor costs dwarfed pollution control savings, they found, and American industries with the highest pollution-control costs have lost an almost imperceptibly larger portion of their markets to imports than industries with average pollution control costs.
Mr. Bhagwati expressed skepticism at the report's conclusion that companies move operations to Mexico to take advantage of low wage costs rather than lax enforcement of environmental rules. "I find it difficult to believe people aren't going to pay attention if the pollution abatement costs are at least 20 percent less, much less 50 percent," he said.
Mr. Grossman, who assumed in his analysis that companies faced no pollution-control costs in Mexico at all, said that his work only showed that there were few companies for which even the elimination of pollution-control costs would make a difference in deciding where to locate factories.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Higher U.S. Cost Is Seen In New Auction Rules

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Changes announced last week to broaden participation in Treasury auctions will probably not have a noticeable impact on the quarterly refunding auctions next month, some analysts and Wall Street executives say.
But they add that the changes in the auction rules, in conjunction with other shifts under consideration, could drive up the Government's borrowing costs in the future. 
 The changes follow the Salomon Brothers bidding scandal, which has severely shaken faith in the decades-long manner in which business has been conducted by the Treasury, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and the primary dealers of Government securities.
With the economy soft and inflation under control, fundamental conditions remain favorable for the coming auctions. Moreover, the rule changes announced by the Treasury will not change the auction process much.
 
Some Short-Term Risk
 Nevertheless, by choosing to put the changes into effect at the start of the refunding auctions on Nov. 5, the Treasury has opened itself up to some short-term risk.
The size of the refunding is expected to be announced on Wednesday. Most analysts expect the Treasury to sell a total of $38 billion worth of 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
The overall size of the auctions and the existence of the speculative 10-year and 30-year offerings make these quarterly debt sales the riskiest the Treasury conducts each year.
And the auctions will take place in the week after credit market participants will have digested a series of important economic reports, including the Commerce Department's preliminary estimate on third-quarter economic growth, and October employment data from the Labor Department.
 
Potential Market Shift
 If those statistics are stronger than currently anticipated, the market's mood could suddenly shift. And a shift in market sentiment could make even the mildest changes in auction rules difficult and possibly expensive for the nation's taxpayers by driving up interest rates.
"I don't think there will be any impact, but financial regulation is subject to the law of unanticipated circumstances," said Louis van B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm. "And when you change auction rules, the last place you want to experiment with is the refunding."
Apart from the potential effects of the economic statistics, Mr. Crandall and others said that for the time being, the Treasury's decision to open the bidding process would not mean much. Until now, only primary dealers have been permitted to submit bids for clients.
"Until the Treasury automates the auction process and allows customers to bid directly through a computer facility, it is to customers' advantage to continue bidding through primary dealers," said Richard M. Kelly, chairman of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a primary dealer.
 
Choice for Customers
 Without an automated system, customers will have the choice of physically submitting tender offers to the New York Fed before auction time, or telephoning primary dealers to place their bids. The Treasury has made it plain that it will accelerate efforts to automate the process. But that job will not be completed before the refunding auctions.
For the time being, the decision to increase the maximum amount of securities awarded to noncompetitive tender bids to $5 million, from $1 million, will also not have much impact.
But Mr. Crandall said that under different market conditions, increasing the size of noncompetitive awards, which are made at the yield reflecting the average of accepted competitive tenders, will drive up borrowing costs.
"There is no way that change is more favorable to the Treasury," Mr. Crandall said. "We are in a bull market right now, so it won't have any impact. But in a down market, where you have a wider dispersal of bids, the larger noncompetitive awards will produce higher yields for the Treasury. At the margin, this rule change can only be bad for the taxpayer."
 
Righting Another Wrong
 Along with promoting broader distribution of securities at the auctions -- which presumably will make it more difficult for dealers to gain control of a particular security at an auction -- the Treasury also intends to right another wrong Salomon committed by developing a way to prevent primary dealers from placing unauthorized bids on behalf of customers.
The method under discussion would require customers to send letters of verification to the Treasury before the settlement dates of securities sales indicating they had bid for a certain amount of securities.
Mr. Kelly, who served as a Treasury official in the Carter Administration, contends that policing firms and their customers in this manner would be inefficient and costly.
"I already find customers who have indicated reluctance to send letters of any kind to the Fed or Treasury verifying an auction bid," he said.
"Some customers might find this to be such a nuisance that they choose no longer to bid at the auctions but rather to purchase their securities in the secondary market," he added. "That in turn will transfer the auction risk to the primary dealers."

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Various Culprits for Ailing Recovery

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
It was forecast to be the recession that Washington could safely ignore -- a stumble in response to gulf war jitters, then a graceful return to growth with hardly a break in stride. But somebody apparently forgot to tell Corporate America, whose efforts to regain financial stability and to become more competitive have slowed the recovery to a crawl.
Bad news keeps trickling in: falling auto sales, depressed lending activity, rising unemployment insurance claims. And last week the Federal Reserve reported flat manufacturing output and flatter moods across the economy. A plausible guess now is that it will take another year to erase the effects of national recession -- and at least five more to complete the recovery in the badly depressed Northeast.
 
Two Reasons Cited
 What went wrong? Americans are used to seeing the economy bounce back after recession. But the sharper business swings of the past are not useful as a benchmark for this recovery for two reasons, says Neal Soss at the First Boston Corporation. Mild recessions like the one we have just had, he argues, are generally followed by weak recoveries because as companies scramble to increase inventories, the built-in kick is smaller. 
 But more important, Mr. Soss says, are the unique forces that are chilling the recovery this time around.
There are several, and everyone has a favorite culprit. The Bush Administration blames bank regulators and banks, which no longer seem willing to bet the depositors' money on anything less than a sure thing. Liberal Democrats and their sometime allies among supply-side conservatives blame the deficit-reduction agreement, which made it far more difficult to use the budget to stimulate private spending. And many business economists blame a sobered Corporate America, whose survival strategy is built on keeping payrolls lean and moving profit-draining inventories onto someone else's balance sheet.
 
A Painful Transition
 Robert Reischauer, the head of the Congressional Budget Office, says they all have a point. He argues that both Government and business were insulated from pressures to become more efficient in the 1980's. The chickens may not yet have come to roost, he says, but they are "circling the barn."
The modest downturn precipitated drastic cost-cutting measures in many industries, which have made it far more difficult for the economy as a whole to rebound. When the transformations are complete, American industry in general and service industries in particular will be more productive and, presumably, more competitive in the world economy. But in the meantime -- a period likely to be measured in years, not months -- the transition will be painful.
The first signs that the economy was headed for hard times actually date from mid-1989, when stable growth dissolved into a wobble. But America's first recession since 1982 began only in the summer of 1990 with the Hussein-inspired spike in oil prices.
Buffered by a timely easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve, the 1.2 percent slip in output was less than half the decline in the 1982-83 recession. Unemployment, which peaked at 7.0 percent in July, seems a mere glitch beside the 10.7 percent recorded in Nov. 1982. If, as widely anticipated, the economy had rebounded briskly this summer, the latest recession would surely have been written off as the least traumatic in two decades.
But while the recession probably is over -- output did grow a bit in the third quarter of this year -- the bloom is likely to remain missing from many a cheek for a very long time. David Hale of Kemper Financial Services notes that the recovery in employment is proceeding at just one-third the pace of the 1981-82 and 1974-75 recessions. First-time claims for jobless benefits in early October reached a five-month high. And auto sales this fall have been running well below last year's already depressed levels, virtually guaranteeing that Detroit will post its worst-ever losses in 1991.
The No. 1 villain at the White House is the credit crunch. Unlike previous recessions in which inflation was seen as a problem, the Federal Reserve moved nimbly to make money available for private spending: interest rates on short-term loans are down by a third since last year. But this financial easing has apparently been largely offset by banks' reluctance to make risky loans after taking a bath in commercial real estate in the 1980's. Moreover, the banks' born-again conservatism has been reinforced by regulatory reforms (imposed long before the recession) that require them to back higher-risk loans with extra capital.
 
Struggling Service Industries
 Alan Blinder of Princeton University notes that there is a lot of anecdotal evidence that small businesses are feeling the effects of the banks' zeal. And "while the data has yet to dry," he said, research by Ben Bernanke of Princeton and Cara Lown of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York support the idea that credit is being rationed by region: the volume of business loans has collapsed in New England and the Middle Atlantic States, where banks are in deepest trouble.
Another factor draining wind from the recovery's sails is widespread corporate reluctance to add to overhead costs as orders increase. Robert Giordano of Goldman, Sachs & Company notes that employers are making more use of overtime, thereby limiting employment gains in recent months to just half what might have been expected.
Tightfistedness is also working to slow orders for industrial supplies, the classic antidote to recession blues. At the beginning of September, manufacturers' inventories were still 2 percent below the level at the trough of the recession in April. And manufacturers like the General Electric Company, which have been pushing "just-in-time" supply policies for years, continue to pare away at inventory expenses. Gary Rogers, a senior vice president, says G.E.'s appliance division can now transform piles of parts into finished washers and refrigerators in just three hours.
Yet more troublesome to those pinning their hopes on a speedy recovery in employment is the special plight of service industries. The speculative boom in commercial real estate has left a legacy of boarded-up shopping centers and see-through office buildings. And the resulting glut of office space, David Shulman of Salomon Brothers Inc. predicts, will take 11 years to work through.
Other service industries are not in quite so dire straits. But the prospects for jobs in banking, advertising, insurance and publishing are considered poor because all of these businesses now see consolidation and cost-cutting as their best hope of survival in a more competitive economy.
Robert Hall, an economist at the Hoover Institution in California, offers the perspective that no recession takes place in a vacuum. Every business cycle, he notes, is layered on top of economic trends that can affect private spending and employment. But the timing of these structural changes, Mr. Reischauer of the Congressional Budget Office argues, could hardly have been worse because the Federal Government is in a poor position to take up the slack.
Under the deficit reduction agreement negotiated last year, spending can be raised beyond an arbitrary "baseline" only if savings are found somewhere else in the budget. This budget lock can be broken only if Congress and the President declare an "economic emergency." And thus far President Bush has been unwilling, even vetoing a Democratic initiative to extend jobless benefits for the hundreds of thousands of workers who have run through their 26 weeks of eligibility.
As a consequence, the fiscal response to the recession has been tepid. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the net stimulation from changes in the budget at about one-half of a percent of the G.N.P. -- just one-third the response to the recessions of 1982 and 1974. And Mr. Bush's likely strategy for stimulating private purchasing power without undoing the budget accord is not likely to win friends among Congressional Democrats.
 
Capital Gains Cuts
 A key part of the fiscal package expected from the White House next week is a cut in tax rate on capital gains. Unlike other tax cuts, this one would actually generate revenue in the first year as property owners rushed to realize capital gains from the past. And that, concedes George Perry, an economist at the Brookings Institution and no fan of Mr. Bush's economic policies, would make room in the budget for the increased domestic spending and family tax credits favored by Democrats.
The catch, Mr. Perry notes, is that most Congressional experts believe the capital gains cuts would generate revenue losses in the future, leaving Washington to cope with bigger budget deficits after the 1992 election. Moreover, many Democrats are loath to make the rich even richer at a time when middle-class living standards are falling.
The Federal Reserve could act if Congress and the White House do not, enticing new spending by lowering interest rates. But the Fed has already gone a long way down the path of easy money and is reluctant to signal the slightest tolerance for inflation as the price of recovery. In any case, the lag in response to monetary stimulation is long: its full impact might not be felt for a year, after demand had already recovered.
"We chose not to make the structural adjustments necessitated by the excesses of the 1980's when the economy was strong," Mr. Reischauer concludes. Now, he suggests, we are fated to adjust when adjustment is most painful.

HEADLINE: Europe's Shifts on Trade May Help World Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The agreement last week to create a 19-country common market in Europe, combined with a recent shift in Germany's position on agriculture subsidies, means that a broad international agreement lowering trade barriers worldwide may well be reached by February, senior European and American officials say.
The sticking point in the five-year-old world talks on freeing trade has been agriculture, with the United States and other countries with internationally competitive farm economies refusing to strike a deal unless the 12-member European Community substantially reduces its agricultural export subsidies, import quotas and direct farm subsidies. 
 International trade in grain and other commodities has stagnated as many countries have subsidized overproduction to prevent their farmers from losing jobs as advances in production techniques have made small farms uncompetitive.
Two major developments have improved the odds of a successful conclusion to the talks, conducted under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said a senior United States trade official who insisted on anonymity and European officials who insisted that they not be identified.
First, on Oct. 9, the German Cabinet changed its position concerning the European Community's agricultural policy. The Cabinet decided that instead of relying on consumers to subsidize full production through prices inflated by import restrictions and other measures, production should be reduced and farmers' incomes should be maintained through payments ultimately coming from taxpayers.
European farmers have opposed such a move, which would make their subsidies vulnerable to cuts during fiscal crises, and both France and Ireland criticized the German move. But American and European officials said that Bonn's decision to break ranks with Paris significantly increased the chances that the European Community would reach a compromise with food-exporting countries.
Then last week, the European Community in western and southern Europe and the seven-member European Free Trade Association in central Europe and Scandinavia struck a last-minute accord. Negotiations leading up to the accord had absorbed the attention of senior European Community officials, who now ought to be able to pay more attention to the GATT talks.
But last Tuesday's agreement between the European trade group and the community could also create new complications for the GATT negotiations, European officials said.
While the agreement creating the new trading bloc specifically excludes agriculture, the trade association sought the deal in large part to influence European Community decision-making on economic policies and technical standards and may seek at least to be consulted in the already bitter debate over agriculture.
On the other hand, European officials said, the participation of strong free-trade advocates in Scandinavia could tilt the balance in the European Community. Its northwestern members tend to favor free trade; its Mediterranean members tend to be more protectionist. The addition in recent years of Greece, Portugal and Spain had begun to weight the community toward more restrictions on trade.
Considerable pressure has been mounting on the Bush Administration in recent months to put more emphasis on environmental issues during trade negotiations. But several environmentalists and trade experts told the Senate Finance Subcommittee on International Trade on Friday that they accepted that the current round of GATT negotiations was too close to completion for the environment to be included.

HEADLINE: Mexican Trade Pact Advances

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZACATECAS, Mexico, Oct. 27

 BODY:
Four months into their discussions on a North American Free Trade Agreement, negotiators from the United States, Mexico and Canada said today that they were ready to begin drafting treaty language.
But even as they swapped smiles and handshakes, they declined to specify areas in which they had moved closer to agreement, and a senior American trade official who privately discussed the talks acknowledged that in some areas, they had run into roadblocks. 
 "We're not at the point where a lot of these issues are ready to be decided," the official said.
 
Skepticism by U.S.
 Contrary to the predictions of several Mexican officials that a treaty could be ready early next year, several American negotiators suggested that progress would be slower. The senior American official said he did not expect a complete first draft to be ready when trade ministers from the three countries are to meet again early next year.
Even before the talks began, some American officials said they were losing hope of being able to deliver an accord to Congress without handing Democrats a political issue at election time.
Under the "fast track" procedures approved in May, legislators will vote either for or against whatever agreement is negotiated but cannot amend it. But from the time a treaty is ready, enabling legislation could still take as long as eight or nine months -- which could force the Bush Administration to weigh political considerations against economic ones.
 
Denial by Hills
 In a telephone interview this afternoon, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, denied that campaign politics would influence the timing of a trade accord.
"I don't see our elections in November as a problem or an impediment at all," she said. "It's not a Republican issue; it's an issue of vision."
Other United States officials say the growing demands of groups concerned about the effects of free trade on American jobs, the environment and the future of Mexican democracy are another complicating factor.
For Mexican officials, there is extraordinary sensitivity about cutting deals with a neighbor that their history has portrayed as an untrustworthy bully. Canadian officials, meanwhile, have had to grapple with fears that Mexico's inclusion in a continental free-trade zone could jeopardize some benefits of the trade pact they made with the United States two years ago.
As the Mexican negotiations have moved forward, the three teams have made notable progress only on the subject of tariffs. The three sides exchanged proposals for reciprocal tariff cuts on Sept. 19.
Mexico's heavily protected energy sector, which appeared not long ago to represent a major stumbling block, has fallen on the list of concerns. With Mexican officials adamantly opposed to opening the exploration and production of their oil to outside risk capital, American negotiators said last week that they were not inclined to press the issue.
 
Loosening on Petrochemicals
 In an area where United States officials had hoped for concessions, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari indicated this week that Mexico was likely to remove more petrochemicals from the list of those barred from development by foreigners.
Agriculture, another politically sensitive issue in Mexico, will not be settled so easily, Mexican and American officials said.
The United States' push for access to Mexican grain markets comes as Mexico is about to announce what officials here say will be a radical but lengthy transformation of the inefficient, almost feudal land-tenure system. The Government is expected to soften laws that bar peasants from selling or leasing communal lands and from bringing in business partners to help them develop.
But while Mexican farmers would like freer access to American markets, they would also like continued protection.
Similarly, the framework of a new North American textile trade may be determined by both the worldwide General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade talks and changes that some American manufacturers are seeking in the Multifiber Arrangement covering world textile trade.
Mexico's single biggest bargaining chip may be its automotive market. Car sales are expected to boom with the country's economy. With about one-third the population of the United States, Mexicans now buy less than one-tenth the cars.
Mexican negotiators want the United States to do away with its 25 percent tax on imported light trucks and to change fuel-efficiency rules so that compact cars produced here can count as part of an American company's domestic fleet.
The odd wrinkle is that while American negotiators want to clear Mexican restrictions on car imports, Detroit's Big Three want continued protection in Mexico. Along with Nissan and Volkswagen, Ford Motor, Chrysler and General Motors -- which have produced cars in Mexico for years -- would like to keep other manufacturers out while they adapt to the demands of free trade.
The issue of how much North American content a product must have to pass beneath the tariff barriers of a new free-trade zone also pits the United States against Canada. The Canadians, who cut their high auto duties in 1965 in return for assurances that American car makers would remain in Canada, want content rules set no higher than 50 percent in order to attract and keep Japanese manufacturers. Mexican officials, who have similar hopes, say they would support those levels.
 
Contentious Issues
 Several negotiators said the broadest issues have been the most contentious. Mexican representatives, for instance, have demanded the same recourse of appeals now given to Canadians who are hit with American antidumping sanctions.
"What we want is that Mexican exports have access to Canadian and American markets with certainty," the country's chief negotiator, Jaime Serra Puche, the Commerce and Industrial Development Minister, said in an interview late last week.
A senior Mexican official added, "There is no way we can accept anything less."
American negotiators have pushed hard for a Mexican commitment to national treatment -- the principle that American companies working in Mexico be treated by the Government like any native company. But for some Mexicans, this idea goes well beyond the definition of free trade.
Yet, as negotiators move from such principled discussions to draft-treaty language on specific topics, one American trade official predicted that all sides would show greater flexibility. "There is not a lot of flexibility so far," he said. "You can't compromise on principles. You can compromise in text."

HEADLINE: Brady Sees Sign of Growth

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the nation's economy was not recovering "as strongly as it should," but that economic data to be released this week would indicate that the recession was technically over.
In a television interview on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Brady acknowledged that the White House viewed President Bush's recent decline in public opinion polls as a serious problem. 
 Mr. Brady said he expected, however, that soon-to-be-released figures on the nation's gross national product would show that the United States economy grew at least 2.5 percent in the third quarter.
A Newsweek poll released on Saturday found that Mr. Bush's overall approval rating had slipped to 55 percent, with nearly one in three Americans saying he deserved most of, or a lot of, the blame for economic problems in America.

HEADLINE: Gains but No Profits at Eagle Snacks

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Staring at two six-foot racks of salty snacks that flank the entrance of an A.& P. in Manhattan, Malcolm Horton pointed to a red, white and blue bag of Eagle potato chips.
"It's really a super-looking design," said the 22-year-old shopper, dismissing the cascade of Frito-Lay chips on the other rack just four feet away. "At 99 cents, how can you go wrong?" 
 But at such a low price, the question in the world of snack foods is, how can Eagle go right?
Eagle Snacks Inc. is a rising force in the $10 billion snack food industry. Owned by the Anheuser-Busch Companies, which knows a thing or two about mass marketing, Eagle emerged from practically nowhere three years ago and zipped by the Keebler Company to become the nation's No. 3 purveyor of salty chips, nuts and pretzels.
In doing so, it woke up the giant of the industry, Frito-Lay Inc., which is now trying to knock Eagle out of the business. By cutting its costs to keep retail prices low, Frito-Lay hopes it can prevent Eagle, which is losing $10 million to $20 million a year, from ever making a profit.
Eagle, which sells its products under the Eagle and Cape Cod brands, now says it is prepared to overtake Borden Inc., a distant No. 2 from Frito-Lay in the industry. Borden, the New York based maker of Wise potato chips and other snacks, says it, too, is mustering a counterattack.
If Eagle continues losing money long enough, its competitors hope that Anheuser-Busch will eventually be forced to call it quits.
"Eagle has shown that it has a good product, good marketing and good packaging," said George E. Thompson, a food-industry analyst at Prudential Securities. "But it hasn't shown it can make a profit. What you ultimately end up with is that Frito-Lay is going to determine in large part when and how much money Eagle makes in the business."
This year, Eagle expects to lose more than $12 million on sales of $400 million to $500 million, after losing more than $15 million last year and the year before.
 
Future Profits Seen
 But the company's top executives, led by Kevin Bowler, the president, predict that over the next few years Eagle will churn out large profits for Anheuser-Busch, which is eagerly searching to diversify from the slow-growing beer business.
Since Eagle first started selling its products nationally in 1988, the company has waged a savvy and successful marketing campaign. It has expanded its sales by an average of about 25 percent annually and captured nearly 6 percent of the market for salty snacks. The campaign relied on sprightly packaging, television commercials featuring Tony Randall and Jack Klugman in their "Odd Couple" roles, and low prices.
Since 1988, Eagle's share of potato-chip sales in supermarkets grew to 9.4 percent, from 5.5 percent, while Borden's fell to 12.7 percent, from 15.2 percent, according to Information Resources Inc., a leading market research firm in Chicago. Keebler had about 7.7 percent and Frito-Lay's share stood at 31.3 percent.
But Frito-Lay is striking back.
Last month, Frito-Lay, a Pepsico Inc. subsidiary based in the Dallas suburb of Plano, announced a restructuring to cut Frito's costs by $100 million, including a work force cut of 7 percent, or 1,800 people. The move was intended to keep the company lean to be able to compete with low prices and take advantage of economies of scale unavailable to its smaller competitors like Eagle.
 
Profit Margins Trimmed
 Earlier this year, Frito-Lay lowered prices on two of its most heavily advertised products, Fritos and Dorritos corn chips, and other products by more than 15 percent and reduced its profit margins to 17 percent from 21 percent.
Roger Enrico, Frito-Lay's chairman, said the company's goal was to increase its market share by 1 percent annually and to continue its double-digit earnings growth through increased sales rather than higher prices.
To meet that goal, the company introduced small 25-cent packages of all its snack foods this year and has begun selling a stream of new products including Sunchips, a low-salt multigrain chip, and Suprimos, a low-oil wheat-based chip. Several other new products are now in test markets around the country.
In addition, Frito-Lay says it is drawing up plans to double the number of outlets that receive Frito-Lay products to 800,000 and to begin a new media and marketing campaign next year to freshen the images of its major products.
The head of Borden's snack division, George Wado, acknowledges that his company erred seriously in its competition with Eagle earlier this year when it cut back on its marketing campaigns on salty snacks, and as a consequence lost a half-point of market share in the first quarter.
 
14 Borden Acquisitions
 In addition, the company has suffered from some high costs and redundancies resulting from its acquisition of 14 snack food companies in recent years.
But Mr. Wado said the company had been moving aggressively to increase its market share and reduce costs by closing redundant plants, creating more-efficient delivery routes and laying off 400 of its 7,400 employees
Borden has more than 38 brands, including major regional ones like Wise on the East Coast, Jays in Chicago and Laura Scudders in California. It has cut prices on many of its products, like Crunchers, which previously sold for $1.69 and now appears on supermarket shelves as low as $1.19 a bag.
By organizing its companies into three regional groups and finding new ways to cut costs, like switching from peanut oil to corn oil, the company says it can match Frito's 17 percent profit margins. Borden's margins on salty snacks, Mr. Wado said, are now near 10 percent.
In any case, he added, Borden will do whatever is necessary to stay ahead of Eagle.
"We can't allow them to achieve their goal at our expense," Mr. Wado said. "We are doing everything we can to prevent it."
Keebler Mum on Strategy
A spokesman for Keebler, Stuart Greenblatt, said his company would not discuss its marketing strategy. He did say Keebler hoped to gain market share with some new products, like its Pizzeria snack chips. Keebler, based in Elmhurst, Ill., is a subsidiary of United Biscuits (Holdings) P.L.C. of Britain.
The central question for many analysts is when will Eagle be able to turn a profit, if it can.
Mr. Bowler, Eagle's president, declined to disclose Eagle's production, transportation and delivery costs. Such costs are crucial questions in an industry where 22 to 30 percent of every sales dollar is spent on getting products to supermarket shelves.
Recently, Eagle pushed back the year it expects to become profitable to 1993, from 1992.
But Eagle executives argue that their company can survive and prosper despite the price pressure from competitors because its costs are already low. Production is centralized at three modern plants. In addition, Mr. Bowler said the company's staff remained lean, with only 60 of 1,500 employees at its corporate headquarters in St. Louis.
"Remember the little engine that could?" Mr. Bowler said. "I will reach my goal of being a successful No. 2 in the snack food industry. We will prevail."
 
Beer Market Slows
 Another question for Eagle is how much patience Anheuser-Busch, the nation's largest brewer, will have with Eagle if it continues to lose money. A combination of factors, including higher excise taxes, a social climate that the beer industry regards as neoprohibitionist and the aging of the population, is holding the United States beer market to annual growth of no more than 1 or 2 percent.
But Busch experienced disappointment with other ventures in the 1980's, including a failed cruise line and an abortive attempt to market natural sodas. A $1.1 billion acquisition of theme parks came with surprisingly poor profits and a host of unexpected headaches, like a $6 million settlement to buy back the rights for Sea World's Shamu the killer whale.
As a result, several analysts suggest, Busch, a company with annual earnings of more than $800 million, may want to stand behind Eagle, even as it loses money for years.
