HEADLINE: U.S. Tool Orders Up by 3.4%

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools showed a modest rise of 3.4 percent in September, the fourth straight month of increases, the Association for Manufacturing Technology says in a report to be released today.
The gains in September, however, were well below the 22 percent surge of orders in August, the trade group said. September orders rose to $243.65 million, from $235.75 million in August. 
 And orders last month were off by 7.8 percent from a year earlier, when they totaled $264.35 million.
Machine tools are used to manufacture a broad range of goods, from cookware to jet aircraft. The industry is closely watched by economists as a guide to the general health of manufacturing.
Actual shipments of machine tools rose 16.4 percent in September to $213.50 million, from $183.35 million in August. They declined 28.6 percent from $298.90 million a year earlier.
Export orders surged 20.4 percent, to $37.80 million, from $31.40 million in August. Compared with September 1990, export orders were up 36.5 percent.
"I am encouraged by the developments over the past four months," the association's president, Albert W. Moore, said. "Orders are up, cancellations down, and backlog levels seem to be firming."
The group said the September backlog of orders was $1.39 billion, up from $1.36 billion in August.
Huge gains for metal-cutting tools last month were offset by fewer orders for metal-forming machines. Orders for metal-cutting tools shot up 36.8 percent, to $172.90 million, from $126.40 million in August.
Metal-forming tool orders skidded 35.3 percent, to $70.75 million, from $109.35 million in August.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Negotiators from the U.S., Mexico and Canada said they were ready to begin drafting language for a North American Free Trade Agreement. But even as they swapped smiles and handshakes, they declined to specify any areas in which they had moved closer to agreement. A senior American trade official acknowledged they had run into roadblocks in some areas. [Page D1.] 
 Last week's agreement to create a 19-country European common market, combined with a shift in Germany's position on farm subsidies, means a broad international agreement lowering trade barriers may well be reached by February, officials say. [D3.]
A new study correlating economic development and pollution concludes that pollution tends to diminish as a country's economy grows beyond a certain level of prosperity. [D3.]
China has declared its willingness to reduce certain tariffs and eliminate an import surcharge on American products. [D3.]
 
The Media Business
The biggest network TV star of the last decade will soon walk away from network television. Starting next fall, Bill Cosby will be seen in a new series, "You Bet Your Life," a revival of the classic Groucho Marx game show. The show will not play on the networks, but will be syndicated to individual stations. [D1.]
The BBC intends to take on the Cable News Network around the world, emphasizing that it is not American and insisting that more than one global TV news network is needed. [D9.]
The turnaround of a Los Angeles radio station illustrates the advantage of the medium's chameleon-like quality: when a format fails, it can be changed quickly to find a new audience. [D9.]
A new analysis has found that an astonishing 1,238 new magazines were started from 1985 through 1989. And 35.5 percent of these are still being published. Deirdre Carmody: Magazine Notes. [D8.]
The relationships of advertisers with agencies and the media are improving, the departing chairman of the Association of National Advertisers says. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]

HEADLINE: Dinkins Plans Munich Trip, Expenses Paid

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, whose international travel plans have stirred controversy in recent months, said yesterday that he has accepted an expenses-paid invitation to attend a tennis tournament in Munich, Germany, in December.
The Mayor, an unabashed tennis fan, added that he hoped to use the trip for other purposes, including exploring economic opportunities for New York City in Central Europe and visiting a memorial to Germans who defied the Nazis. 
 But Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, whom Mr. Dinkins invited to attend the event as his guest, said last night she would decline, in part to avoid a possible appearance of a conflict of interest.
 
No Conflict Seen
 Both the Mayor and Ms. Shulman have been negotiating with the United States Tennis Association over its request to expand the site of the United States Open tournament in Flushing Meadows, Queens. The association is a member of the International Tennis Federation, which sanctions the Munich tournament.
The invitation was extended by a promoter of the Munich tournament, the Compaq Grand Slam Cup, said a spokeswoman for the Mayor, Jennifer Kimball. The invitation includes airfare and hotel accommodations for the Mayor, a guest and two aides, but the tennis portion of the trip is purely for pleasure, Ms. Kimball said, and is not connected to the association negotiations.
"We don't believe there is any conflict of interest in accepting an invitation from a private entity that does no business with the city," Ms. Kimball said. "Many mayors in the past, in this city and others, have accepted trips from private entities to promote their cities."
Ms. Kimball said there were numerous precedents for the Mayor to accept a trip from a private group, including Mr. Dinkins's trip earlier this year to Israel, which was financed by the American-Israel Friendship League.
But Ms. Shulman, who said she was too busy to attend the tournament, expressed reservations about the appearance of a conflict. "I just feel very uncomfortable about it," she said in an interview, "and I say that not knowing any of the facts."
Ms. Shulman said she had yet to inform the Mayor of her decision. Later last night, Ms. Kimball said that "it's our understanding after speaking with the Borough President's office that there is a conflict of schedule, not of interest."
The trip, tentatively scheduled from Dec. 10 to 15, would follow the Mayor's planned journey next month to South Africa, where, he said, he hopes to forge an economic partnership with those who he believes will lead post-apartheid South Africa.
Critics of the South Africa trip have questioned its purpose, as well as the size of the delegation, which originally was to include several dozen people. But the Mayor, who has often described the visit of Nelson Mandela to New York City as a high point of his term, has angrily defended the journey, saying it would bring the city both economic benefits and influence in post-apartheid South Africa.
 
Plans Visit to Memorial
 The Mayor first mentioned the Munich trip in a passing reference during an address yesterday morning to more than 1,000 Jewish civil servants gathered at the New York Hilton.
"In December, I expect to go to Munich, if plans go as I expect," Mr. Dinkins told the civil servants at the annual breakfast of the Council of Jewish Organizations in Civil Service in the hotel's Grand Ballroom.
Mr. Dinkins then told the group that while he is in Munich, he intends to visit a memorial commemorating the White Rose, a small group of German students who were beheaded in 1943 after denouncing the Nazis. Mr. Dinkins said he had first visited the site in 1985, when he accompanied members of the American Jewish Congress to protest President Ronald Reagan's controversial visit to the Bitburg military cemetery.
Though the Mayor made no other mention of the Munich trip in the speech, he and Ms. Kimball later sketched out the details in response to reporters' questions.
 
Still in Planning Stages
 Mr. Dinkins said that by itself, the tennis tournament did not warrant a trip to Germany. "I would not go to Munich only for that purpose," the Mayor told reporters. "I've directed my staff to look at other things we might do."
Ms. Kimball, the Mayor's spokeswoman, said the trip was in the "very preliminary planning stages," and that Mr. Dinkins and his aides have focused on two major concerns. She said the first is the pursuit of economic opportunities in Germany, a topic that Mr. Dinkins hopes to broach with the mayors of Munich and Berlin, among others.
Any side trips from Munich, like one being planned to Berlin, would be paid for by the New York City Alliance for International Business, a private nonprofit organization that is not affiliated with city government, Ms. Kimball said.
Ms. Kimball said the Mayor was uncertain which of his aides would join him, but he would be accompanied by an undisclosed number of police bodyguards, which will be paid for, as is customary, by the city.
The second part of the trip, which Ms. Kimball described as far more solemn, might involve outings to the White Rose memorial and the Dachau concentration camp, as well as meetings with German Jews.
The Mayor recently received an invitation to the tournament from Dr. Axel Meyer-Wolden, a prominent German businessman whose company is promoting the tournament. He formally accepted the invitation on Friday, Ms. Kimball said.
A spokesman for the tennis association, Edwin S. Fabricius, said in a telephone interview yesterday that he was unaware of any association role in the invitation to Munich.
The Mayor announced plans in February for a $150 million expansion of the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, the site of the United States Open since 1978. Though the cost of the expansion will be paid for by the tennis association, it still has no business agreement to extend its lease on the property with the city, which is its landlord.
The association plans to begin construction in 1992, and open the new center, which will have three new stadiums, in 1995. The Mayor said yesterday that the two sides were "pretty close to agreement."

HEADLINE: Zaire's Chief Vows to Stay in Power and Warns West Not to Meddle

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Oct. 27

 BODY:
President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire vowed today to stay in power despite growing opposition to his rule. He accused Western governments of wanting "my head at any price" and declared, "They cannot dictate how I run Zaire."
In an interview with foreign reporters at his home near Kinshasa, the capital, the President said there would be no compromise with the main opposition leader, Etienne Tshisekedi, whom he dismissed as Prime Minister last Monday. 
 Mr. Tshisekedi was appointed under intense pressure from Western governments after rampant street violence spread across Zaire late last month. The rioting and looting were led by disgruntled soldiers who had not being paid in several months.
 
'Flagrant Interference'
 In the interview, granted to reporters from Reuters and two French newspapers, Mr. Mobutu repeatedly accused Western governments of "flagrant interference" in Zaire's internal affairs. He said the West had acted inconsistently by criticizing Zaire while maintaining military and financial aid to African countries that have not even considered democratic change.
A virtual cutoff of American, French and Belgian assistance in recent months has eroded morale in this central African country of nearly 40 million people.
The remarks today by President Mobutu were the most extensive he has made since the violence erupted last month. He has recently kept a relatively low profile, and Western analysts said that he appeared to have finally acceded to a power-sharing arrangement with opposition groups after 26 years of near-absolute rule.
But Western and African diplomats said today that Mr. Mobutu has reneged on his promise to relinquish some of his powers and allow Zaire to join the shift toward democratic government sweeping much of Africa.
"He intends to hang on as long as he can," a senior Western diplomat here said, "and he really doesn't seem to care one bit whether the country slides into chaos."
Mr. Mobutu spoke amid signs of renewed violence in the capital. The state-run radio and television broadcasting center in Kinshasa was seized Saturday night by soldiers loyal to the President after announcers read a series of letters criticizing Mr. Mobutu and his choice of Bernardin Mungul-Diaka, the leader of a minor opposition group, as the new Prime Minister.
 
Attack on Opposition Paper
 Today a big explosion destroyed the offices of the leading opposition newspaper, Elima. Crowds outside the building accused the military of sabotage, though no witnesses came forward.
Mr. Mungul-Diaka vigorously defended his decision to accept President Mobutu's offer to replace Mr. Tshisekedi. The Sacred Union, an opposition coalition of more than 150 groups, has branded Mr. Mungul a "traitor" and vowed to boycott any government he forms.
At a news conference, Mr. Mungul-Diaka insisted that he was among President Mobutu's oldest opponents, saying, "I have opposed his regime for 22 years, since August 1969."
Asked whether he wanted Mr. Mobutu to resign, he replied: "The whole opposition has been fighting for that. So I say yes." But he added that "radical change" would have to come peacefully, through elections.
Mr. Mungul-Diaka also criticized the way in which Western countries have severed economic aid and political ties with Zaire in recent days.
"Everyone must take their fair share of blame. During 26 years your respective governments supported his regime," he told a group of reporters, mostly representing foreign newspapers and agencies. "Now that the Zairean people are fighting to obtain democracy, the West leaves.
"People could at least eat and drink under the dictatorship," Mr. Mungul-Diaka added. "But now they are beggars. The West should help us during this crisis, or the people will think you are more for dictatorship than for democracy."
It is unclear whether any political accord could end the unrest at this point, for groups of marauding soldiers seem to be beyond the control of even Mr. Mobutu. Another sector that is not automatically responsive to political pressure is the huge and mostly poor urban population, which could wreak further violence if no cure is found for the swiftly deteriorating economy.
Several Western governments urged their citizens again today to leave Zaire as soon as possible. They advised foreigners to depart on one of the Belgian flights or military-escorted convoys leaving over the next three days from provincial centers in Zaire.
Officials at the United States Embassy said that about 125 Americans were still in Kinshasa, and that another 300 are living elsewhere in the country.
The French Minister for Cooperation, Edwige Avice, urged the estimated 500 French citizens in Zaire to "use every means at their disposal" to flee the country.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Western diplomats said that President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire had reneged on promise to relinquish some of his powers. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: F.B.I. Says Reports of Crime Rose This Year

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
The number of crimes reported to the police rose 2 percent in the first half of 1991, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today, and some criminal justice experts say a weak economy may be a factor.
Violent crime reported to law-enforcement agencies increased 5 percent over the same period last year, while property crime edged up 1 percent, the bureau said. 
 About 16,000 law enforcement agencies across the country supply information for the F.B.I.'s crime index. The agency did not provide a state-by-state breakdown.
The agency's report comes after a household survey made public a week ago showed that crime over all for 1990 declined 3.9 percent. That survey issued by the Justice Department is considered a more accurate reflection of crime trends because it measures crime generally, not just crime reported to the police.
Less than 40 percent of major crimes are reported to the police, the Justice Department estimates.
According to the F.B.I. index, there was a 3 percent decline in the Northeast in the amount of reported crime in the first six months of 1991. But there were increases elsewhere.
The increases have some connection to unemployment and drug addiction among poor youths in the most crime-prone age group, ages 15 to 24, said Gene Stephens, a professor in college of criminal justice at the University of South Carolina.
The youths' situation is worse with the economy in the doldrums, he said.
The bureau not break down crime statistics by age.
There were indications in the Justice Department's household survey that crime might be rising, said Alfred Blumstein, dean of the school of urban and public affairs at Carnegie Mellon University.
For example, robberies in 1990 were up sharply, by 5.3 percent.
A recession can tend to drive crime rates down in some categories, Mr. Blumstein said. Many people are home more, which can lead to less household crime like burglary. Attempted forcible household entries, larcenies and car thefts were down sharply last year.
The F.B.I. said that in the first six months of this year robberies reported to the police were up 9 percent, murders were up 5 percent, forcible rape 4 percent and aggravated assault 2 percent. In property crimes, there was a 1 percent increase each in burglaries, larcenies and motor vehicle thefts.
The nation's biggest cities showed a 2 percent decline in reported crime. The biggest increase was in cities of less than 10,000 population, where there was a 5 percent rise.

HEADLINE: THE MIDDLE EAST TALKS;
Golan Heights' Return Called Syria's Chief Aim

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, Oct. 26

 BODY:
The Syrian Government of President Hafez al-Assad is going to the Madrid conference on Wednesday with the hope that it can, above all else, persuade Israel to return the Golan Heights, Western diplomats say.
But Syrian officials have repeatedly said that they will not strike separate deals with Israel. They say that any exchange of land for peace must be part of a package that would include all of the occupied territories and be approved by all neighboring Arab countries and the Palestinians. 
 The Syrians have adopted the toughest stance of any of Israel's Arab neighbors, vowing not to attend the proposed third stage of the negotiations, in which Arab countries will discuss regional issues like water rights with Israeli officials, until Israel makes "progress" in returning occupied territory.
"It all depends, to a great extent, on the intentions of the Israeli Government," President Assad said in a Cable News Network interview. "Do they want peace or do they want the situation to remain as it is now?"
 
Israelis Harsh About Syria
 Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel has said that peace treaties must be signed and the Arab economic embargo of Israel lifted before he will be willing to discuss further issues with his Arab neighbors. He has ruled out trading land for peace.
Israeli officials have reserved their harshest criticism for Syria, blaming it for continued guerrilla attacks against Israeli troops in southern Lebanon and for giving sanctury to radical Palestinian groups and questioning its commitment to the peace process.
Shlomo Ben Ami, Israel's Ambassador to Spain and a member of the Israeli delegation, complained recently that the Syrian President "has not even used the word peace."
The meeting between Syrian and Israeli officials in Madrid, a meeting in which the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, has already said he will not shake the hand of his Israeli counterpart, will nevertheless mark a watershed for one of Israel's most implacable foes.
Syria, which under Soviet sponsorship once sought to achieve "strategic parity" with Israel, has been moving closer to the West, although relations remain cool because of Syria's support for Palestinian groups the United States believes are engaged in terrorism.
 
New Channels to U.S.
 But Syria's decision to send troops to join the allied coalition in the Persian Gulf and its help in bringing about the release of Western hostages has opened real channels of communication between the Assad Government and the United States for the first time in many years.
Syrian officials express support for the Bush Administration's move to defer a decision on Israel's request for $10 billion worth of housing loan guarantees.
"For the first time the Syrians believe that someone in Washington is willing to listen to them," a Western diplomat said. "They hope that an end to the cold war will diminish Israel's importance as a regional ally and that the U.S. can pressure Israel to give the Arabs the territory they want."
The Syrian Foreign Minister, noting that the United States will be the "moving force" in the coming conference, said, "We are confident we will arrive at the desired results."
The decision by the Syrians to sit down with the Israelis, something they vowed in the past never to do, has required verbal acrobatics on the part of the governing Baath Party.
 
Return of Land Demanded
 "Syria now goes to the conference in Madrid not because it has changed its position," a Baath Party statement said, "but because changes in the positions of other Arab countries showed they were nearing the Syrian position, which reflects the interests of the Arab nations."
Syria, Jordan and Lebanon have all agreed not to make separate deals with Israel.
With the Palestine Liberation Organization, the three Arab countries have demanded a return of all occupied land, including East Jerusalem, a freeze on Jewish settlements in the occupied territories and the restoration of Palestinian rights before normalization of relations with Israel.
But in a meeting last week in Damascus, the Jordanians, Palestinians and Lebanese refused a Syrian motion that would preclude the Arabs from entering into the third stage of negotiations -- the multilateral talks on a wide range of issues like water rights and arms control -- until the Israelis make "progress" in handing over occupied territory.
Western diplomats still worry that if the Syrians boycott the third stage it will be harder, if not impossible, to induce other Arab countries to sit down with the Israelis.
The Syrians appear to want to act in concert with their Arab neighbors and the Palestinians, or at least to give the appearance of acting in concert, before stepping forward to take back the Golan Heights, which Israel captured in the 1967 war and annexed in 1981. And they want to make Israel pay in advance of any deal. What the Syrians fear most, Western diplomats say, is that they will sit down with the Israelis, breaking their pledge, and come up empty-handed.
Syrian policy, in the end, will rise and fall on the whims of one man, President Assad, diplomats contend. And few are ready to predict exactly how far he will be willing to go.
"I think that at this point even the Syrians do not know what they are going to do," a Western diplomat said. "They will see what happens, what Israel is willing to offer and send back their reports to the President. Then they will wait for him to decide."

HEADLINE: Uncertainty on Gorbachev Gives New Twist to Meeting With Bush

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27

 BODY:
For the first time in the long history of East-West summit-level diplomacy, the American President will go to meet the Soviet President in Madrid on Tuesday uncertain whether the man across the table has real power to represent his country or is little more than a figurehead.
The talks between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev are not even planned as a full-scale summit conference, a far cry from past meetings that rewrote Europe's map, forged arms control agreements, provided the setting for cold war confrontation or ushered in warmer phases in Soviet-American relations. 
 Demonstrating how this peculiar diplomatic art has moved so far from center stage in world affairs that it is in danger of becoming an anachronism, the two leaders will confine themselves to a two-hour lunch session on the day before they attend the opening of the Middle East peace conference. "They're both going to be in town, and they're having a long lunch together," a senior Administration official said.
In a way, this is what Mr. Bush has sought to achieve since he took office and began trying to make his meetings with Mr. Gorbachev more routine and less fraught with expectations. The far-reaching progress in solving the major Soviet-American disputes has clearly reduced the urgency of summit meetings and made it possible to have such a quick get-together with no formal agenda.
But more significant, the aborted Kremlin coup in August and the disintegration of the Soviet Union have so eroded Mr. Gorbachev's power that American officials are uncertain about what kinds of deals they can negotiate with him and wondering whether the days of formal summits may indeed be over.
"What's a thing of the past," the senior official said, "is the focus on two human beings sitting down and talking their way through a list of issues."
It is still possible that the two leaders might come up with some surprise, as they have in past meetings. But the Madrid meeting seemed likely to be less a meeting of equals than a recognition of Mr. Gorbachev's accomplishments, an observation of diplomatic protocol and a courtesy to a man who American officials believe sees his relationship with Mr. Bush as one of the last threads of his power, and who seems to enjoy his appearances at summit meetings.
Clearly Mr. Gorbachev has more at stake than Mr. Bush in the meeting, and it is not clear whether the Soviet President settled willingly for such a brief encounter on a day in which Mr. Bush will also meet with the Spanish King and Prime Minister, as well as a string of other dignitaries who will be attending the peace conference.
 
Food Loans Unlikely
 Administration officials said they did not expect Mr. Bush to give Mr. Gorbachev the emergency food loans that they had hoped at one point to take to Madrid. Washington has yet to work out the details of those credits, they said, in part because of uncertainty among American officials about what political entity in the Soviet Union could accept a loan intended for more than one republic and then be counted on to repay it.
Administration officials said they were even more uncertain about how to proceed after the President of the Russian federated republic, Boris N. Yeltsin, telephoned Mr. Bush on Friday to tell him of his plans to announce major economic reforms in a speech on Monday.
No real progress in arms control is expected to be made -- or even attempted -- at the Madrid meeting, officials said. With Mr. Gorbachev's command of the Soviet armed forces an increasingly tenuous thing, the Administration has already shifted arms control from the traditional domain of summit meetings to a largely unilateral process in which each side is proposing to cut its nuclear stockpiles and challenging the other to go further.
Indeed, officials said the concerns of the United States had suddenly shifted from persuading the Soviet Union to cut its weapons stockpiles to discouraging independence-minded republics, like the Ukraine, from trying to build armies of their own -- a prospect that Washington has indirectly suggested would make it harder for those republics to receive Western assistance.
Although the ostensible purpose of the summit meeting is to put the Soviet-American stamp of approval on the peace conference, the Soviet Union's role in that event is peripheral as well.
A senior official said a fundamental shift in the currents of Soviet- American summitry was evident when Mr. Bush went to the Soviet Union for a more formal meeting with Mr. Gorbachev in July. "Even there, it was becoming more of a meeting with the leadership, rather than a leader," he said.
But since the aborted coup in August, officials said, uncertainty about Mr. Gorbachev's powers as a negotiating partner has increased sharply. That has left the Administration in what an official called "an end-game situation" in which Washington is approaching the point at which it must decide whether to deal with the central Government or the republics.
"The talk for the past two months is how they are going to create a center, but everything that we've been seeing is moving away from the center," an official said.
Max Kampelman, a career diplomat and longtime arms control negotiator, argued that the change in the tone of summit meetings is a healthy product of the improvement in Soviet-American relations. There is no need, for instance, for Bush and Mr. Gorbachev merely to get together as a way of reducing tensions.
 
Frequent Telephone Contact
 "You've got two people who have met each other on many occasions, know each other well, don't have any ground to break and talk on the telephone in between meetings," Mr. Kampelman said.
But he and others said Mr. Gorbachev's crumbling power was also an important factor. Alexander M. Haig, the former Secretary of State, said, "Mr. Gorbachev is yesterday's leader, to whom we owe a great debt because he didn't resort to force to prevent the breakup of the empire, but as far as the future is concerned, is history."
One area where this is strongly felt, officials said, is in economic relations. Mr. Bush is committed to providing the Soviet Union with short-term humanitarian food and medical assistance and is trying to work out the details of more long-term aid. But officials said that there had to be some guarantee of repayment and that it was not clear that Mr. Gorbachev could provide that authority.
"The fact that the Ukraine just unilaterally declared it will no longer be responsible for any debt incurred by an entity called the Soviet Union means that we've got to pause and think about further lending," said Jan Vanous, research director of Planecon, a Washington concern that has been helping the Soviet Union plan reforms of its central economy.
Administration officials said they were studying the newly created economic union, covering eight republics, as a possible recipient of loans. But they said it was not clear whether that entity was a reliable debtor.
The Ukraine's talk of having its own army and controlling nuclear weapons on its territory complicates matters, since the United States does not want to subsidize such an effort.
This sort of uncertainty, officials said, is one reason why Mr. Bush clings to the relationship with Mr. Gorbachev. "Bush likes Gorbachev and recognizes him as the Soviet head of state, and there is real concern here about the consequences of the collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union," an official said.
He added: "For Gorbachev it's almost a summit of desperation. He's clearly hanging on by his fingernails and trying to stay a domestic political player by sustaining the Soviet Union's great-power role abroad."

As they prepare to meet tomorrow in Madrid, it is unclear whether Mr. Gorbachev has real power or is little more than a figurehead. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Cuomo Struggles Toward Answers To Big Question

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:

Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pith and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry
And lose the name of action. -- "Hamlet," Act III, Scene 1
To run or not to run away -- that is the question. 
 Can Gov. Mario M. Cuomo justify, to his constiuents and to himself, leaving New York to run for President? Can he afford not to, when he argues convincingly that fundamental solutions to state and local crises rest with Washington, not Albany? Can he get his message to the nation -- a case he is espousing with growing passion and self-confidence -- without being the messenger?
Any conventional politician would respond reflexively: Yes, no and no.
But Mario Agonistes, on the verge of delivering his answer, has defied convention before. He is grappling with philosophical questions that would have confounded even Hamlet, whose ambivalence was finally resolved when mere spectral evidence was confirmed by personal observation during the play within a play.
For Mr. Cuomo, the campaign's the thing. He will not run, even in this abbreviated campaign, though, until he reconciles his commitment to the state with his mission for the nation as every other elected Governor of New York has done for decades.
Like another Governor, Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois, was, Mr. Cuomo is thoughtful and thinks aloud. Two events nudged him to ratchet up his Presidential pondering in a process taking on a life of its own.
Last month, an article in The New York Times on Mr. Cuomo's visit to California focused on his noncandidacy, rather than on the substance of well-received remarks, the gist of which he had delivered before. Mr. Cuomo said he was angry that reporters semed to have decided that if he was not a national candidate, his message would go largely unreported, regardless of its value. He was also incensed over the shortcomings of senators from both major parties in the confirmation hearings for Judge Clarence Thomas.
Though critics would object, Mr. Cuomo may have already convinced himself that he has done as much as he can as Governor to mitigate New York's economic woes and can make only a marginal difference from Albany. But what of his implicit commitment to his constituents? And if he runs, should he resign as Governor?
In 1986, he insisted that running for Governor again meant he would not and could not run for President, a personal vow that went beyond his oath to "discharge the duties" of office. In 1990, Mr. Cuomo declined to make a similar commitment because, he said, nobody believed him the first time. But he seems genuinely troubled by the prospect of disclosing a grim deficit and budget cuts one day and then abandoning his job the next to campaign out of state. "There's a little bit of an awkward character to these moves," he said last week, although he has finessed more difficult contradictions before.
Mr. Cuomo recalled that the last Governor nominated for President, Michael S. Dukakis in 1988, ran "when Massachusetts was still a miracle." No New York governor has been elected President since Franklin D. Roosevelt was chosen at the 1932 convention after minimal personal campaigning.
As late as Nov. 9, 1931, though, Mr. Roosevelt remarked: "I'm too busy right here as Governor to give any thought to anything else." More than two months later, allowing his name to be entered in the North Dakota primary, Mr. Roosevelt cited his obligations as Governor and cautioned: "Were I now to divert my efforts in any degree by personal efforts in furtherance of my own political future, I would not only be untrue to my own convictions but I would also stamp myself as one unworthy of my party's choice as leader."
If Mr. Roosevelt harbored doubts then, he succumbed to what he described as "the simple duty of any American to serve in public position if called upon." If Mr. Cuomo does, he seems unlikely to quit as Governor under provisions of his personal constitution. Resigning would demonstrate unusual single-mindedness and would free him from daily decision-making for which no alter ego has been delegated.
But quitting would not insulate him from responsibility or blame for problems that are no longer unique to New York or those that are. And, with the possible exception of his modest Lieutenant Governor, Stan Lundine, Mr. Cuomo says: "I don't see anyone out there I would consider turning the state over to."
A decade ago, before declaring for governor, Mr. Cuomo wrote: "When will we learn? If one wants to run, one should simply run; put your head down and go if it's worthwhile." This time, Mr. Cuomo wants to, but won't if he hangs down his head after concluding that his rationale for running is only a rationalization.

HEADLINE: In California, Nature Refuses to Remain Mastered

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 24

 BODY:
In a grim way, it was symbolic that the deadly fire that swept Oakland and Berkeley last Sunday should have started near the Caldecott Tunnel.
The tunnel, opened in 1937, was one of those daring and defiant acts of engineering that Californians have long used to tame a harsh environment that has proved to be as dangerous as it is beautiful. The tunnel punched a nearly mile-long hole through the Berkeley Hills, opening the way to vast suburbanization of the arid and geologically unstable hills east of San Francisco Bay. 
 The newcomers built their California dream, landscaping barren neighborhoods with eucalyptus and Monterey pines, trees never intended to grow in such an arid place, and planted shrubs near their homes -- all fine fuel for fires. They built a natural environment that was not at all natural. It was as beautiful as it was artificial, fragile and dangerous.
"The fire underscores the fact that all of California is a vast artificial environment," said Kevin Starr, a historian at the University of Southern California. "We are constantly being reminded what an artificially engineered construct" the state is, he went on, "and consequently how fragile."
California is like "the skin of an enormous egg, with infinite curve but no thickness so fingers of shock reach up," to quote the poem that Jeremy Larner, a screenwriter and poet, wrote after the 1989 earthquake. This time it reached up and burned down his home on Grand View Drive in Oakland, allowing him to escape with little more than his life and his computer.
It is no small paradox that the land early adventurers pronounced unsuitable for human settlement or much agriculture is now both the most populous state and the leading farm state in the country. This was achieved with a massive rearrangement of the environment that snubbed nature. Huge dams and aqueducts were built to channel water from the Sierra to the cities of Northern and Southern California. Bridges and huge highways knitted together far-flung towns into metropolises. And houses were propped up against canyon walls.
There have been ample signs that all this was vulnerable: earthquakes leveled San Francisco in 1906, Long Beach in 1933, Santa Barbara in 1925, not to mention the deadly Loma Prieta quake that jolted the Bay Area just two years ago.
Then there have been floods and fires, like the one that destroyed 500 homes near Santa Barbara just last year, repeated droughts, a winter freeze last year that killed millions of trees, adding to the fire danger. And the Oakland fire, which denuded about 1,800 acres of steep terrain, will almost certainly be followed by another California hazard, mudslides, when winter rains erode the bare land.
 
Allure Remains Undiminished
 Yet little of this seems to have dulled the allure of California. There were the predictable recriminations in Oakland over who was to blame, and promises of new legislation to outlaw roofs of wooden shake shingles and other fire hazards. But even as rescuers searched for more bodies in the scorched rubble here, residents were already planning to rebuild and replant, as have hundreds of property owners who were wiped out by the Santa Barbara fire.
The author James D. Houston marvels at this disdain for nature's forces in his 1982 book "Californians: Searching for the Golden State." In it he describes a visit to Malibu, on the parched mountainous coast northwest of Los Angeles, after a fire ravaged expensive homes in 1978.
"You wonder how many houses it is wise to build at the bases of these dry and fire-prone mountains," he wrote. "But you don't ask. New and expensive houses are already rising from the ruins and right next to the ruins. It is like asking about the smog. It is like asking about the water." He added: "The question belongs in a science fiction story or a disaster novel: Suppose 10 million people were living in a semidesert where there was not one adequate source of water closer than 200 miles?"
Today, 15 million people live in that semidesert: the Los Angeles metropolitan area. Overall, the state grew by a staggering 6.1 million people in the 1980's, to nearly 30 million people. While a stagnant economy may have slowed migration a bit, the population continues to grow at a rate of more than 10,000 a week and some experts estimate the population could double by the year 2025.
 
More Wilderness Disappears
 Even as the rubble still smolders in Oakland, developers are pushing urban civilization further into the wilderness. The Nature Conservancy in San Francisco, a private group that attempts to buy wild lands to preserve them, calculates that every six months, an area the size of the City of San Francisco is converted from farmland or natural vegetation to residential and commercial use, further endangering numerous animal and plant species.
Increasingly, the California dream means living on a brushy hillside amid the smell of eucalyptus and pines. Already about seven million people, nearly a quarter of the population, live in what local officials call the "urban intermix" zone, where development has pushed into what was only recently desert or forest. State officials are warning of "the fires of the future" that these developments promise. The California Department of Forestry and Fire Prevention says fire is a potent threat in the fast-growing counties in the foothills of the Sierra, in the drought-stricken Santa Cruz Mountains, which have become a suburb of San Jose and Silicon Valley, in Marin County north of San Francisco, and in hilly parts of Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino and San Diego counties in Southern California.
In all this, the hills of Berkeley and Oakland provide a paradigm for California. Nothing is more quintessentially Californian than these neighborhoods, with their steep winding streets lined with eclectic redwood-shingled houses, many of them designed by such pioneering California architects as Bernard Maybeck, John Galen Howard and Julia Morgan in the 1920's. They have been home for the state's literati and Berkeley academics for generations.
On the night of the fire, Herb Gold, a novelist, gazed at the eerie red glow over Berkeley from his apartment on Russian Hill in San Francisco and pitied his poor colleagues who had left the city for the relative country of the hills. "These are people who looked for a peaceful, enveloping, hospitable mother-earth environment," he said. "I don't know what conclusion I can draw except that we live at risk."
 
Every House Is Gone
 Mr. Larner, the poet, considered life in his house on Grand View "the most comfortable life I have ever had." The house was perched on a slope over a ravine and he wrote while looking out over the creek and listening to birds. He said he did sometimes look up as he walked his dog at all the trees killed in the freeze last year and wonder if the city should cut them down as a fire hazard, but he dismissed the thought as needless fear. Today, every house in his little valley is gone. The valley, nothing but a black pit of ash, turned out to be a natural fire corridor.
Luther Nichols, another writer, and his wife, Rhoda, lived only a couple of streets away on Roble Road in Berkeley, but they were luckier. Mrs. Nichols escaped with the dog in a car, not knowing that her husband was talking his way past police barricades back to the house to protect it.
As his wife frantically searched shelters for him, he spent the night manning a garden hose as a blizzard of embers tried to ignite his house. He succeeded, giving much credit to the Spanish tile roof, while most of the other houses nearby were incinerated. "My great lament is that so much charm that took so many years to develop is now gone," he said, while admitting the "inherent vulnerability" of what he and his neighbors had built.
To Mr. Starr, the historian, the earthquake and fire have brought home a lesson about the state's capacity for much more growth. "There are limits to what can be done with California," he said. "We have a new kind of environmental limit, not so much having to do with damage to the environment but how much population is sustainable in the environmental engineering formula. If you over-engineer, there are all kinds of unexpected side products. California is not a nice place. It is very dangerous."

Chart: "Living on the Edge"
 Some of the worst disasters that have hit California
 
Major Earthquakes
 1. Loma Prieta: Earthquake occurred Oct. 17, 1989, 7.1 magnitude, 63 deaths and 3,757 injuries, $5.9 billion in damage.
 2. San Fernando: Earthquake occurred Feb. 9, 1971, 6.4 magnitude, 58 deaths and 2,000 injuries, $511 million in damage.
 3. San Francisco: Earthquake occurred April 18, 1906, 7.1 magnitude, 700-800 deaths and unknown number of injuries, $400 million in property damage.
 
STORM
 4. Southwest coastline: Jan. 27, 1983, 200-mile coastline from Santa Barbara to San Diego hit. At least three municipal piers destroyed, coastal roads were washed out and nearly 1,000 houses from Santa Barbara to the Mexican border were lost or damaged by 15 to 20 foot waves. Total damage over $116 million.
 
WORST FIRES
 5. Berkeley: On Sept. 17, 1923, fire destroyed 584 houses in 130-acre area. 6,000 people left homeless. About 250 people injured.
 6. Bel Air: In 1961, fire destroyed 484 houses. No fatalities. Total damage over $116 million.
 7. Santa Barbara County: On June 27, 1990, fire started by arsonist destroyed or damaged more than 500 structures in a 4,900-acre area. One person killed.
 8. Oakland: Last week's fire, at last count 24 people are known dead and 13 missing. More than 3,000 houses and apartments destroyed over 1,800-acre area. (pg. B8)

HEADLINE: John G. Burnett, 67, an Ex-Head Of Rockefeller Development, Dies

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
John G. Burnett, former head of the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation and the New York State Urban Development Corporation, died on Thursday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.
He died of a heart attack, his family said. 
 He joined Rockefeller Center Inc., now known as The Rockefeller Group, in 1976, and the next year became president and chief executive of its real-estate development subsidary. He continued in those posts until he retired in 1989.
During his tenure at Rockefeller he helped plan several major developments, including the Wells Fargo building in Los Angeles, the Renaissance Center Phase II in Detroit and the International Trade Center in Mount Olive, N.J. He also helped in selling the Exxon building in Manhattan to Mitsui Fudosan in 1986, in buying the Time & Life Building the same year and in negotiating the lease renewal that kept NBC at Rockefeller Center in 1987.
 
Adviser to David Rockefeller
 He also served as a real-estate adviser to David Rockefeller, particularly on the development of the Embarcadero Center in San Francisco.
Before working for the Rockefeller Group, Mr. Burnett spent seven years as an executive of the state's urban development agency, eventually becoming its president and chief executive. Among the projects he oversaw was the high-rise community created on Roosevelt Island in the East River between Manhattan and Queens. He was also in charge during the troubled period when shaky finances forced the agency to reorganize.
Born in Milwaukee, Mr. Burnett was an honors graduate of Princeton University and Yale Law School. After graduation he served two years as a law clerk to Justice William O. Douglas on the United States Supereme Court.
For the next eight years he was the general counsel to the United States Agency for International Development, with special responsibility for aid to underdeveloped nations. For the next nine years he was executive vice president of the Development and Resource Corporation in New York City, after which he was hired by the state urban agency in 1969.
His survivors include his wife, Jane Holmer Burnett; three sons, John S., of St. Petersburg, Fla., Anthony M., of New Canaan, and Mark H., of Bloomington, Ind., and a daughter, Barbara Jean Berman of Bridgeton, N.J..

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Game 7 Was a Gift From Above

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
NOTHING was happening, nothing, nothing, nothing, nothing but increasing tension. The zeros on the scoreboard last night in the Metrodome were dropping inning after inning after inning, as if a row of hens were working overtime. It appeared that the best and concluding moments of this baseball season -- maybe the best of any baseball season -- might last forever.
This was the seventh game of the World Series, and, after three, four, five, six, seven innings, nobody could score. People tried: The Minnesota Twins got a runner to third in the third inning; the Atlanta Braves did likewise in the fifth. But nothing happened. The pitchers, Jack Morris of the Twins and John Smoltz of the Braves, were matching sets of excellence, bookends of bravado. 
 It was preposterous. It couldn't get more dramatic. It did.
In the eighth, both teams loaded the bases with one out, but the Twins turned a double play to end the Braves' threat. In the bottom of the inning, the Braves did precisely the same thing to the Twins, behind Mike Stanton, who had replaced Smoltz.
It went into the ninth inning, 0-0. That is, 16 zeros. Nothing had happened, and it just kept on happening. And into the 10th: zero, of course, to zero. The longest Game 7 with no score in the history of the World Series.
And there it ended. Dan Gladden hit a broken-bat double, and there was a sacrifice bunt and two intentional walks, and then with the bases loaded and a pulled-in outfield, Gene Larkin, a seldom-used infielder, stepped up to pinch-hit. He was facing Alejandro Pena, now on the mound for the Braves. The noisy home crowd of 55,000 was on its feet and creating a snowstorm by waving its white homer hankies. And Larkin responded. He looped a fly ball over the outstretched glove of left fielder Brian Hunter, for a single to score the lone run of the game.
Suddenly it was over. Suddenly the Twins had won. But the Braves did not lose. They just didn't win the World Series, is all.
Sometimes the gods are just. Sometimes even they, taking time from their flutes and lyres and various dalliances, will determine that we, too, down below, could use a bit more pleasure, especially in these times of gloomy national recession and despairing world affairs and the football season. And so they, along with Kirby Puckett, in the guise of a mere mortal, conspired to give us one more game of baseball.
Not just any game, of course, but a Seventh Game of the World Series. And not just any World Series, either. But one that has gone from the dramatic to the melodramatic, from suspenseful theater to the old Saturday afternoon serial thriller.
Four of the first six games between the Braves and the Twins had been decided by one run, and three had been determined only in the home half of the final inning, to break up a tie game -- one concluding in the ninth inning and one in the 12th, with plays at the plate, and, on Saturday night, in the 11th, with Puckett's game-ending home run.
But we needed this game, Game 7, and that's the simple truth. It was only fitting and proper. It was all so unlikely, all so upside-down, but this seems to restore the cosmic balance: Two teams that finished last in their divisions the year before win the pennants. Each team knowing in its heart that it cannot lose, that the fates have ordained that this is their season.
Each team understanding that it has come this far, that it has done it by coming from behind not only during the season, but in game after game, and thus overcoming all the odds fashioned by Las Vegas and Olympus.
Each team has had its improbable heroes: Mark Lemke, brought in for defensive purposes, hits a trio of triples, and is prominent in winning Games 3, 4 and 5; Scott Leius, who was only iffy on making the team in spring training, homers to win Game 2; and Jerry Willard, who had left baseball for a season a few years ago because he was going nowhere, is called in to pinch-hit and hits a sacrifice fly to win Game 4. And finally Larkin.
It just had to come down to the wire, to a photo finish.
The Twins went up two games to none, and then the Braves came back to take a 3-2 lead, and then the Twins tied it up, three games each.
The dream season would end on a dream: Game 7 of the World Series. "Every kid has dreamed about this," said Jack Morris on Saturday night. "When I was a kid, my brother and I used to play whiffle ball and I pretended that I was Bob Gibson and he was Mickey Mantle."
But since this is real life, we know that the gods can be cruel, and, using us for their sport, may turn dreams into nightmares.
Ask Charlie Liebrandt, who got knocked out of Game 1, and then in Game 6 was brought back in relief to start the home half of the 11th inning. He faced one batter, Mr. Puckett, and threw a total of four pitches. Two were balls and two were strikes, including the last, which ended up in the left center field bleachers.
After the game, a large group of reporters gathered around Charlie Liebrandt's locker. After a long period in the trainer's room and the shower, with most of his teammates gone, Liebrandt, lean, grim, a cup of beer in his hand, and his eyes looking only straight ahead, parted the crowd around his locker. "Nothing tonight, guys," he said to the newsy assemblage.
There was nothing tonight, guys.
Except, of course, for the memory, and the dream, and the nightmare.
And there was the tingling anticipation that all this set up: Game 7. It had to be. And better than anyone could have imagined.
As the scoreboard, in its way, had been reminding us: Oh, oh, oh yes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Braves' Terry Pendleton congratulating the Twins' Kirby Puckett and Al Newman after Game 7. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Talk Of Hollywood;
High-Stakes Battle: Midler and Streisand Go Screen to Screen

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 27

 BODY:
There's the Streisand team at Columbia, and the Midlerites at 20th Century Fox.
With the highly competitive film industry in an economic torpor, two of the biggest studios in town have, in not so subtle ways, taken on the public persona of their competing stars: Bette Midler and Barbra Streisand. 
 At Fox, which is soon to release the Bette Midler film "For the Boys," the brash, aggressive, even unpredictable mood is plainly a reflection of their star, who is planning a truly mammoth publicity campaign. But at Columbia Pictures, which is releasing Ms. Streisand's "Prince of Tides," based on the Pat Conroy novel, the tone is more secure, confident and a little disdainful of the upstart Midlerites.
 
So Far, So Good
 Intensifying the competition is the fact that preview screenings have been strong for both films, which are vying for the same adult audience. Both are expensive, too, costing at least $30 million each. And in typical Hollywood style, each studio professes nothing but the best for its rival, while wishing a little ill will, too. (Also in typical Hollywood style, executives at the two studios would not let their names be used, because the studio they criticize today might be one they want to work at tomorrow.)
" 'Prince of Tides' is a beloved book," said one Columbia executive. "It's timeless. This picture will leave you feeling good. On the other hand, 'For the Boys' is a period piece. Nostalgia may be in but it's depressing."
Although they have never acknowledged it publicly, Barbra and Bette, as they are called here, have been rivals for years, in part because of the similarities and contrasts in their styles, backgrounds and talents. Both actresses are powerful singers who began on the New York stage. Ms. Streisand is a megastar, a diva, a performer who selects her roles slowly. Ms. Midler is also a star, but with a more turbulent career, a singer who enjoys performing onstage in contrast to the reclusive Ms. Streisand. They could play each other's roles.
 
Stars, Studios and Money
 Now, with these new movies, the two are colliding almost head-on, and in the current bleak mood seizing the film industry the competition carries financial implications not only for the actresses, but for Fox and Columbia as well.
Ms. Midler's movie, with James Caan, is a musical drama directed by Mark Rydell about 2 U.S.O. performers over nearly 50 years. "For the Boys" is, perhaps, Fox's major entry in the Thanksgiving-Christmas competition, when moviegoing around the nation reaches its peak.
Ms. Streisand produced, directed and co-stars, with Nick Nolte, in "Prince of Tides," an adaptation of Mr. Conroy's best seller about a Southern teacher who comes to New York to pick up the pieces of his life.
Although there are half a dozen other major holiday movies -- including Steven Spielberg's "Hook," Oliver Stone's "J.F.K.," Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" and Martin Scorsese's "Cape Fear" -- the Streisand and Midler films are vying for the same grown-up, largely female audience whose failure to show up at the box office in big numbers over the summer and fall has shaken the industry.
"Everyone's watching this because it's so competitive -- for the same adult audience, for sound tracks, for advertising, for publicity and possibly for an Academy Award," said one film executive at a rival studio. He added, "It's shoot-out time between these two movies."
"For the Boys," opens in New York, Los Angeles, Washington, Chicago and San Francisco on Nov. 22, and around the country five days later. "Prince of Tides," opens in New York on Dec. 18, and in the rest of the country on Christmas Day.
Even in this time of relative austerity, Fox has already taken out a series of expensive three-page ads in major newspapers to herald "For the Boys," which Joe Roth, the head of the studio, calls "an event film." The studio also pushed the opening of the film forward to gain a beat on its competitor.
"They got frightened of 'Prince of Tides,' " said one Columbia executive. "They were supposed to open Christmas. They moved away."
A Fox executive said: "Originally, 'Prince of Tides' was to be released in September. In fact they had a Vanity Fair cover of Streisand timed to the release of the film. They couldn't pull the cover. So a little bit of their campaign broke early."
Columbia executives insisted they were not concerned about the Midler movie.
"These films are going to be released six weeks apart," said one Columbia executive. "If 'For the Boys' holds up well, and plays like 'Dances With Wolves,' until next summer, then Columbia has something to be concerned about. But failing that, and quite likely we won't have that, then chances are good that 'Prince of Tides' will be out in 1,200 theaters and 'For the Boys' will have a lot of its theaters gone."
"As for competition between Barbra and Bette, well, maybe Bette is concerned about Barbra," said the executive, "but Barbra is certainly not concerned about Bette."
 
Well, They Worked Once
 With television, like the film business, in the creative doldrums, the networks are reviving numerous old war horses to lure audiences that have been slipping away.
These include "The Very Best of Ed Sullivan" (CBS, Nov. 24); "Memories of M*A*S*H" (CBS, Nov. 25); "The Return of Eliot Ness" (NBC, Nov. 10), and "Back to the Streets of San Francisco," which began production last week.
Some executives insist that the effort is intended to bring some zest, nostalgia and variety to nighttime programming. Others insist that bringing back new versions of the old shows only underlines the creative void on the major networks.
"Television is feeding on itself and it's obscene," said Barney Rosenzweig, the producer of such shows as "Cagney and Lacey." He added: "It's an attempt to woo back an audience that's not there anymore. It's a strong indication that we're rather bereft of ideas."
Mr. Rosenzweig, who is 53 years old, blamed the creative paucity on television's writers and producers. "The people making television programs are young, they didn't really see movies or plays or read books, but they watched television," he said. "What they're feeding back to the new generation is their own version of 'Eight Is Enough.' It's frightening."
Barry Diller, the chairman and chief executive officer of Fox Inc., said: "It's the last gasp of a dinosaur. I think it was excessive behavior to put on a whole group of television series that were so odd and moderne last season, such as what 'Twin Peaks' became. This is the opposite end of excessive behavior, which is to say that the audience is so conservative that what we'll do is scrape history's barrel. What they're not doing is to be edgy, contemporary and relevant."
 
Roasting 'The Bonfire'>
 Six months ago, Julia Phillips's acid "You'll Never Eat Lunch in This Town Again" was required reading here. Now the most talked-about book in town is Julie Salamon's "Devil's Candy: The Bonfire of the Vanities Goes to Hollywood" (Houghton Mifflin), which documents in grim detail the making of Tom Wolfe's novel of social satire into a disasterous film.
Ms. Salamon, a film critic for The Wall Street Journal, was given unusual carte blanche by the director, Brian De Palma, to the entire production, largely because he believed the film would be a masterpiece about greed that would serve as a metaphor for the 1980's. Instead, the film maker and Warner Brothers made a film that was, according to Ms. Salamon, a metaphor for inept decisions (casting the boyish Tom Hanks as a Wall Street financier, Bruce Willis as a reporter who was British in the book, and Morgan Freeman, who is black, as a character who was a white Jewish judge in the book); out-of-control costs; creative compromises that engulfed the film, and movie stars behaving like petulant children.
Ms. Salamon said she believed Mr. De Palma's claims not to have read the book. "I've spoken to him and he's been friendly," she said. "At the moment he's trying not to think about the movie."
What seriously damaged the film, she said, was an array of decisions, including not naming a producer to replace Peter Guber, who left before full-scale production began, to run Sony Entertainment, as well as the enormous sums of money spent on the movie -- least $50 million -- which often crippled the studio's ability to make decisions.
"Now with movies costing so much, studios want it both ways," said Ms. Salamon. "They want complete control because so much money is being spent. But at the same time they want those lucky accidents in which a bunch of elements are thrown together that can produce a great movie." She added, "A kind of nuttiness just took over this production."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Travel Coalition Turns To Foreign Visitors

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
More than 60 travel-related companies plan to follow up their efforts to encourage domestic travel in the United States with an advertising campaign to encourage overseas travel to the United States.
At a news conference today in Washington, members of Go USA! The Travel Coalition, including hotels, airlines and car-rental companies, are expected to discuss details of the campaign, which could begin running in February if sufficient money is forthcoming. Also participating is the Commerce Department's United States Travel and Tourism Administration. 
 The coalition spent about $7 million earlier this year on a campaign aimed primarily at business people who were reluctant to travel because of the Persian Gulf war or the recession. A small portion of that campaign, created by FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York, was aimed at business travelers overseas.
A spokeswoman for the coalition said no decision had yet been made on an agency to handle the campaign, which is expected to make use of a message from President Bush inviting overseas visitors here.

LENGTH: 771 words

HEADLINE: Coming Back;
See the Future, in the Schools

 BODY:
No issue is more important to New York City's future than the performance of its public schools. The economy cannot prosper without a well-educated labor force, the city's huge immigrant population cannot be assimilated without good schools and more middle-class families will flee if they think the schools are inferior or dangerous.
There is some reason for concern. Test scores are improving slightly, but still only equal the average for the rest of the state. The physical plant was allowed to deteriorate; only since 1987 has there been a coherent building plan. And budget cuts this year have stripped away hundreds of teachers and counselors, forcing crowded classrooms, reduced course offerings and shortages. 
 But the city's schools are not plummeting toward catastrophe. Indeed, by some performance measures, they have at least held their own and may actually have improved over the last 20 years.
What has changed most dramatically is the demands imposed by society. The schools must now educate a population that is markedly poorer, more socially handicapped and less competent in English than 20 years ago. And they must prepare students for jobs that require far more skills than ever before. The schools have to run a lot faster just to keep pace with the new demands.
The school system is the largest in the nation, dauntingly large: a $7 billion budget, 980,000 students, 984 schools, 63,500 teachers, 22,600 principals, counselors and other supervisors and 3,600 administrators. The racial balance has changed. In 1967, half the school population was white. Now, in a city that's 43 percent white, white pupils represent 19 percent of the population, blacks 38 percent, Hispanics 35 percent and Asians and others 8 percent.
In addition, the system must grapple with privation. A third of the students come from welfare families and 60 percent live in single-parent households. About 110,000 students are enrolled in classes for limited English proficiency. The schools are much more dangerous than 20 years ago, although the number of serious incidents last year, 3,843, was down from 5,233 in 1984.
Despite these problems, students are performing better. Overall attendance in 1990-91, at nearly 87 percent, was the highest in 24 years. Reading and math scores showed slight improvements. And students are staying in school longer.
But that's not enough. Students need ever-more sophisticated skills to compete successfully for jobs in this information-based economy. That's why the system must meet the challenge of providing a better education to a needier population.
How can that be done? The first answer is more resources. The city now spends about $7,100 per pupil, 10 percent under the state average. Maximum class sizes, 32 for elementary schools and 34 for high schools, are higher than in many districts; and even those limits are often breached.
The schools are entitled to more state funds. With 37 percent of the state's students, and an even higher proportion of its needy students, the city schools get only 33 percent of state education aid. The difference amounts to $485 million this year. That's more than the grim reduction they suffered this year. More money could provide a longer school day and year and expand pre-kindergarten programs, after-school activities and services for children from troubled families.
Schools need more autonomy. Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez advocates more authority for individual schools, with principals, teachers and parents sharing power. The idea is to let teachers and principals innovate and to encourage parental involvement. It's a promising idea, but schools need more responsibility for budgets, curriculum and hiring. In exchange for more power, teachers could accept more training and less protection for incompetents. And parents ought to have more opportunity to choose schools.
The system needs a stronger curriculum, of just the sort Mr. Fernandez is pushing by increasing math and science requirements.
The system needs authority over custodians. In the past, custodians have been allowed to charge "opening fees" to outside groups using schools and avoid doing routine repairs. Lately, the Board of Education has got tougher with the custodians' union, and just last week Mr. Fernandez said he would hire private contractors rather than give in to unreasonable demands.
New York City has come back from distress before, usually to new triumphs of commerce and culture, transforming neighborhoods, industries and people. The future now, as in the past, depends on the schools.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (93%);

HEADLINE: No Debt, No Money

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Money Supply Doesn't Tell All" (Economic Scene, Oct. 9) breathes new life into a favorite cliche of financial writers, a cliche that should have been given a decent burial long ago. 
 The article says: "No one can ever be sure that stagnant money growth is not a portent of an economic downturn. But simply assuming that it is -- and putting pressure on the Fed to crank up the printing presses -- carries its own risks."
The Fed cannot crank up the printing presses. Our money is debt-based. To create new money requires new debt. All the Fed can do is create new reserves that permit the creation of new debt. But if you do not have borrowers seeking credit you are not going to have new debt. That is the Bush Administration's problem, not any so-called "credit crunch." We have a dearth of borrowers. The consumer is tapped out and can't take on any more debt. So too is the Government.
 
JOHN V. COLLINS
Bay Shore, L.I., Oct. 9, 1991

HEADLINE: Bills Seek More Competition in Electricity Market

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Access to the power transmission grid, a key element of the utilities' monopoly control of the nation's electric system, is up for grabs for the first time in the history of the industry.
As part of the National Energy Strategy package moving through the Congress, a House subcommittee has approved provisions that will require utilities to carry electricity from independent buyers across the utilities' territory to independent sellers, even if the utilities lose electric sales as a result. The version of the bill that the Senate is planning to take up this week does not have the same provision. 
 But the Senate version would repeal a law concerning who may own power plants, the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, and many other participants in the electric market are demanding access to transmission in exchange for the repeal.
Taken together, these legislative proposals would vastly extend the deregulation of the utilities that Congress started in 1978, opening the transmission system and freeing participants to build power plants.
"A key to whether there is any real competition at all is transmission," said Larry Hobart, the executive director of the American Public Power Association, many of whose members are small utilities that serve commercial and residential customers with power they buy from larger utilities. "If you have an independent power producer, that's like a dot inside a circle that is the service territory of an investor-owned utility. We're another dot, outside the circle. Unless you can tie them together with a transmission line, it's of no use to us."
The producers also seek more competition, arguing that they must be freed from "monopsony," a variation of monopoly in which there are many sellers but only one buyer. Under the Public Utilities Regulatory Policy Act of 1978, independent producers now sell to the utility in whose territory they are situated at "avoided cost" -- the price that the utility would have to have paid to make the power for itself. Many independent producers think they could do better if they could offer their product more widely.
 
'Just Like the Phone System'
 The utilities argue that their control of the transmission system is essential to the stability of electric supply. At the Edison Electric Institute, the trade association of investor-owned utilities, Mary Kenkel, a spokeswoman, said the demand to open the transmission system came from "a bunch of people wanting to take something without paying for it."
Many investor-owned utilities see no advantage to a proliferation of independent producers, because no one can build power plants more cheaply than they can. But some utilities would like to see more such plants, because they themselves would like to build them, either inside their territories or far afield. That group of utilities is also seeking repeal of the holding company act, which puts onerous regulation on utilities doing business in more than one state.
Experts say that opening the transmission system would remove a large part of the monopoly power of utilities, turning transmission lines, now private property, into something akin to common carriers. If the market were thrown open to competitors, the amount of power traded that way might be small, but it would go far toward determining electric prices for everyone. When President Bush proposed the National Energy Strategy earlier this year he called for such open access, and there is substantial support in Congress.
"It's got to be opened up, just like the phone system," said Senator Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat. Giving small producers and small utilities more access to transmission would mean big improvements in competition and efficiency, he said.
In a possible model for opening the transmission system, in two recent cases courts or regulators have required open access as a condition of utility mergers.
Lurking behind both the holding company act, which the Senate bill would repeal, and the transmission access issue is the question of whether the utilities' three traditional roles -- as generators, transmitters and distributors of power -- should be split up.
Independent producers say access will create competition that lowers price for everyone. Traditional utilities say that with access, independent producers can go "cherry picking," stealing away the best customers, like major industrial plants, and leaving the utilities with generating stations with no one to serve, creating "stranded investments."
The cost of those plants will have to be spread among small consumers, they say, who will be captive and heavily saddled. "You've built to satisfy all customers equally, and now these customers can go elsewhere, so who pays for all that investment?" said Dick Disbrow, the chairman of American Electric Power, a Midwest holding company. If the cost of idle plants is spread among the remaining customers, he said, the price that the traditional utility must charge will rise further, creating an even bigger cost differential.
 
The Issue of Priority
 On the other hand, the Public Service Company of Indiana favors transmission access and has proposed opening its system in exchange for the right to sell its surplus power elsewhere at whatever price it can get.
"Injecting competition into regulated industries is good public policy," said James E. Rogers Jr., the company's chief executive, in a speech in Chicago earlier this year.
In between is the position taken by a coalition of 17 large public power agencies, led by Richard M. Flynn, the chairman of the New York Power Authority. In this hybrid, small producers would negotiate for access, and impasses would be resolved by binding arbitration.
"The maximum savings from competitive bidding won't flow to consumers unless all potential power suppliers have a fair shot at the transmission system," Mr. Flynn said.
Among the thorny issues is who should have priority on the system. Should it be the third-party buyer and seller, who want round-the-clock access, or the existing utility customers, who use the system far less but save money doing it?
 
'Economy Transfers'
 Utilities currently use their lines for unscheduled "economy transfers," so that if one company has a plant that can produce power for 2 cents a kilowatt-hour but is idle and a neighboring utility is running a plant at a cost of 4 cents a kilowatt-hour, the second utility will shut its plant and buy from the first at a cost of 3 cents a kilowatt-hour. The volume of such transfers increased nearly 20-fold between 1960 and 1985, when a huge difference existed between the fuel costs of oil and coal.
Costs have narrowed somewhat since then, but transfers still save consumers $18 billion a year, the investor-owned utilities stress.
The system was paid for by those customers through their monthly bills, the investor-owned utilities point out. At the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners in Washington, Michael Foley, an electricity specialist, said, "Given the fact that they paid for that hardware, shouldn't they get first dibs on any of the power?"
The Edison Electric Institute casts it in a somewhat grimmer light. "If access to the system is mandated for a few special interests, the benefits now accruing to the majority of a utility's customers may be compromised," it said.
