HEADLINE: At Crossroads, U.S. Ponders Ethics of Helping Others Die

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
For years, in hospitals, courtrooms and the privacy of family discussions, Americans have been grappling with a painful question: What should be the limits, if any, on medical efforts to keep people alive?
Now with two medically arranged suicides in Michigan and a coming statewide ballot on euthanasia in Washington State, that question seems suddenly to have taken another form: What should be the limits, if any, on medical efforts to help people die? 
 In the view of religious leaders and specialists in medical ethics, the United States is approaching a critical juncture in its attitudes toward ending life and caring for the dying. And though much attention in recent days has focused on Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the Michigan doctor who helped two women end their lives last week, the issue that preoccupies these ethicists is Initiative 119, the measure on the ballot in Washington a week from tomorrow.
 
Nightmare or Breakthrough?
 Initiative 119 would make Washington the first place in the world to pass a law authorizing doctors to assist in suicides or give lethal injections to patients who have asked to die.
For some people Initiative 119 is the first step in a nightmare scenario reminiscent of Nazi Germany. For others it is an overdue breakthrough in human rights. Many on both sides believe that the nation is embarking on a struggle as protracted, as emotional and as ethically unyielding as the battle over abortion.
To Margaret P. Battin, a University of Utah philosophy professor who specializes in issues of professional ethics, the vote in Washington and the suicides in Michigan highlight "the most important new civil-rights issue likely to come along: whether one has the right to determine or control the circumstances of one's own death."
But to Dr. Leon R. Kass, a physician and ethicist at the University of Chicago, Initiative 119 represents "a betrayal of the deepest meaning of the art of healing." Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota, calls Initiative 119 "the most important bioethics decision of the postwar era." And the Rev. John J. Paris, a professor of medical ethics at College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass., says, "If Initiative 119 passes it will set the agenda for the entire country."
Such unequivocal judgments are unusual among those professionally devoted to studying and teaching medical ethics. Unlike many voters in Washington, who may base their views on a single, searing family experience or on an appealing slogan, these scholars are forced to consider a wide range of cases, justify their responses on the basis of a broad set of moral or pragmatic principles, and try to calculate the consequences for future policy.
Among medical ethicists there are vigorous advocates of Initiative 119, people who say afflicted patients have a right to medical help in committing suicide or to a peaceful death by lethal injection.
But it is also noteworthy how many ethicists are adamantly opposed to such measures, even though they defend patients' rights to choose or refuse treatment and though they criticize doctors for aggressively prolonging the lives of dying or comatose patients with modern technology.
 
'A Gift From God,' But How to Use It?
 The nation's major religious faiths have adhered to traditional patterns in confronting the issues posed by Initiative 119. Protestants, Catholics and Jews all describe life as "a gift from God" over which humans only have "stewardship." But they differ over how that stewardship can be exercised: whether people have the right to choose when and how to die, or whether the choice must be left to God.
Leaders of the country's two largest Christian groups, the Roman Catholic Church and the Southern Baptist Convention, reiterate their opposition to all forms of euthanasia or suicide. And Rabbi David Bleich, a professor of Talmud and ethics at Yeshiva University in New York, voices a similar view in the name of Orthodox Judaism: "Autonomy does not extend to one's own life. Man's body and life is the property of the Creator."
Assisted suicide and euthanasia are "clearly unacceptable," said Rabbi Avram Israel Reisner, chairman of the subcommittee on biomedical ethics for Conservative Judaism's Committee on Jewish Law and Standards.
But Initiative 119 has also found religious advocates, mostly from liberal and mainline Protestant churches, where euthanasia and assisted suicide appear to be increasingly accepted.
This summer the General Synod of the 1.6-million-member United Church of Christ passed a resolution referring to euthanasia and suicide and affirming "individual freedom and responsibility to make a choice in these matters." And the Pacific Northwest Conference of the United Methodist Church endorsed Initiative 119. The sentiments of the entire nine-million-member Methodist denomination will be tested next May, when its governing body votes on a statement acknowledging that in some circumstances assisted suicide could be "responsible stewardship of God-given life."
Unlike the religious groups, whose statements focus primarily on the choices facing dying patients and their families, medical ethicists have given far more attention to the consequences of legalizing euthanasia for the medical profession, the health-care system and public policy in general.
Many ethicists, including some who do not oppose assisted suicide in all circumstances, question whether doctors should ever be involved in such practices or in killing suffering patients who ask to die.
All medical ethics, they argue, spring from the reality that doctors have an exceptionally intimate, private and powerful relationship with their patients, who are exceptionally dependent and vulnerable. To inject a legal power to cause death into this relationship would alter the role of medicine drastically and ominously, they say.
Dr. Eric J. Cassell, who teaches at Cornell University Medical College and is the author of "The Nature of Suffering: And the Goals of Medicine" (Oxford University Press), said: "I don't think doctors should be killers. The decision to assist someone in their death should be agonized and private. Doctors administering injections is bad for doctors and bad for medicine, not because it is too hard but because it is too easy."
Dr. Caplan, a philosopher, said: "The greatest deterrent to abuse is to ask people to bear responsibility for what they do, and to ask their loved ones to help them. Asking the doctor is often asking a stranger."
 
The Risks of Abuse: A Slippery Slope?
 Much of the debate surrounding euthanasia and Initiative 119 focuses on potential abuses, and on whether such measures place society on a slippery slope that could lead to the elimination of unwanted individuals or whole categories of people, like the retarded, seriously disabled or senile.
Supporters of Initiative 119 emphasize that to be eligible for "aid in dying" -- the term used in the measure -- a person must be conscious and mentally competent, must be certified by two doctors within six months of death, and must sign a voluntary written request witnessed by two unrelated and impartial adults.
Opponents reply that these requirements are not nearly specific enough. For example, they say, the determination that a patient would die within six months could be made by "a dermatologist and a gynecologist," in Dr. Caplan's words.
Many ethicists question whether euthanasia would remain voluntary or whether the terminally ill would feel obliged to "go quickly and quietly" rather than burden their families.
Alexander Morgan Capron, a law professor who directs the Pacific Center for Health Policy and Ethics at the University of Southern California, said the "hard cases" facing medicine, ethics and the law "are those involving long and indefinite course of mental decline." Those cases, he said, "are not addressed at all by the initiative."
Indeed, the women who committed suicide in Michigan with Dr. Kevorkian's help were apparently not terminally ill but anguished by the prospect of prolonged, debilitating illnesses. In the best-selling suicide manual "Final Exit," (Hemlock Society/Carol Publishing), Derek Humphry argues that such people should also be eligible for assisted suicide or euthanasia.
It is just such arguments that worry many ethicists. Daniel Callahan, director of the Hastings Center, says the logic of the case for euthanasia will inevitably lead to its extension far beyond terminally ill people who are mentally competent.
The case rests on two legs, he said: first, the right of people to determine their own fate and, second, the relief of suffering. But if self-determination is critical, why limit assisted suicide or euthanasia to the terminally ill and deny it to those who wish to die for other quite heartfelt reasons? If relief of suffering is critical, "why should that relief be denied to the demented or the incompetent?"
"The ingredients of the argument are inherently unstable," he said.
Dr. Battin of the University of Utah rejects these criticisms. Suicide, she said, "must be regarded as a fundamental right of self-determination where it conduces to the preservation of human dignity." In cases of extended terminal illness where controlling pain is a problem or where the individual suffers other grave impairments, "that right is pretty obvious," and it should include getting a doctor to facilitate the death or, if necessary, cause it.
Medical involvement in suicide and euthanasia is unavoidable, said Cheryl K. Smith, staff attorney and deputy director of the national Hemlock Society. "Physicians are the gatekeepers," she said. "They have the authority to prescribe. They have training in drug dosages and drug interactions, and they're the ones patients turn to for relief of suffering."
 
Must Technology Fight Compassion?
 Ethicists who accept euthanasia often ask whether there is any moral distinction between halting a life-sustaining medical treatment and directly killing someone. "A doctor discontinuing a treatment often thinks he isn't morally responsible but thinks that he is when he gives a lethal injection," said Joel Feinberg, Regents Professor of Philosophy and Law at the University of Arizona. "That is superstitious -- he's responsible either way."
As for the possibility that legalizing euthanasia could lead to abuses, Professor Feinberg said, "Not to let a person cut off six months of unnecessay pain or suffering is an abuse, too."
Opponents and supporters of assisted suicide and euthanasia say remarkably similar things about the shortcomings of American medicine. But they often draw different conclusions.
Both sides worry about introducing euthanasia into a medical system increasingly driven by economic pressures and incentives. Both insist that dying, pain-ridden or anguished patients must be given compassionate care rather than simple prolongation of their lives through technology.
But for some, giving doctors the power of releasing people from life altogether is a necessary form of compassionate care, an essential check on high-tech medicine. For others, it is the ultimate surrender to technology, a dangerous substitute for compassion.
"I think it is the issue of the next 20 years," said Dr. Cassell, "and it won't be resolved on a ballot."

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Sun Belt Shock: High Health Costs

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
COMPANIES that move from states like New York to lower-cost areas like south Florida, Houston or Dallas rarely inquire beforehand about employee medical costs. They are mainly concerned about wages, real estate and taxes, which are indeed lower in most Sun Belt states. But benefits consultants say some executives may be shocked after the move to find health-care costs as high or higher than in New York.
Robert D. Eicher, a principal in New York with A. Foster Higgins, a benefits consulting firm, said several client companies recently moved to south Florida and ended up spending $7,000 an employee for health care -- more than double the national average of $3,200 an employee and 40 percent higher than their New York costs of about $5,000. He said health-care costs for some big companies in Houston and Dallas were also $5,000 or more. 
 Doctors and hospitals in Florida, which has a high concentration of elderly residents, often raise their charges to private insurers to offset cutbacks in Government Medicare allowances. John Sforza, president of the Florida Health Coalition, an employers group, said South Florida had 92 hospitals -- "too many," he added -- and nearly 12,000 physicians. He contended that doctors often inflated charges, and he acknowleged that some South Florida companies "experience costs close to $5,000" an employee. But he said he did not know any paying $7,000.
Mr. Eicher said hospital rooms in Miami often cost about the same as in New York. He added that for-profit general and pyschiatric hospitals, which are numerous in Southern cities, were adept at piling on extra charges. And, he said, physicians often refer patients back and forth so that several doctors can submit bills. "You can easily see psychiatric costs double or quadruple" after moving to South Florida, he added.
The Florida Health Care Cost Containment Board, a state agency, recommended to the Legislature last week that doctors who are among the owners of laboratories or centers for imaging, radiation or physical therapy be prohibited from sending patients to those centers.
Mr. Eicher said Texas, which is also a stronghold of for-profit hospitals, went through two recessions in recent years, but "there has never been a reduction in medical costs." He said oil companies and other large Texas employers had been slow to use health maintenance organizations or networks of doctors who agree to eliminate possibly unnecessary medical services.
Greg Scandlen, a health-policy analyst in Alexandria, Va., who publishes Health Benefits Letter, said only 8.6 percent of Texans were enrolled in an H.M.O., well below the 14.6 percent national average. William Custer, research director of the nonprofit Employee Benefit Research Institute, said many Houston employers had been unable to keep charges for outpatient services from rising.
Mr. Scandlen said medical societies in at least 19 states, including 11 in the South and Southwest, had been able to put restrictions on medical reviewers who "second-guess" doctors about their treatment plans. Insurers and self-insured employers hire review companies to determine if a patient might be treated effectively in a clinic or doctor's office at less cost than in a hospital. State laws generally establish licensing requirements and working rules for the reviewers. But several states are talking of going further and prohibiting reviews by long-distance telephone from other states.
Mr. Custer said the screening process, which insurers call utilization review, is used mainly by large companies because of its relatively high cost. In small cities and rural areas, where doctors and hospitals are scarce, it is often difficult to persuade them to join a cost-control network, he added.
In a study of medical costs in Houston, Los Angeles and Rhode Island, the Employee Benefit Research Institute concluded that utilization review reduced costs in places where there was competition among doctors and hospitals.
But the study said medical inflation was still an unsolved problem. Referring to the cost pressures from new medical technology, hospital workers' pay increases and the growing needs of the aging population, the institute said, "The question remains whether cost-management strategies will ever restrain health-care cost inflation."
Mr. Custer said geographical differences in health-care costs might become "much more important" for companies deciding to move, as health costs continue to rise. Employee benefits add about 37 percent to wage costs at most large companies, with about one-third of benefit costs going to health care. What worries companies is the rapid growth in medical expenses, Mr. Custer said. "The scary part is the rate of inflation."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
A Positive Move For Illinois Central

 BODY:
A leading Midwestern railroad company -- the Illinois Central Corporation -- got a green light yesterday from the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The rating service put the company on its Creditwatch with positive implications, which means that its current B rating on subordinated debt might be raised in the near future, along with improved ratings on other debt like equipment trust certificates. A total of about $177 million of debt is involved. 
 Operating results have been better than anticipated despite the downturn in the economy, S.& P. said. It noted that for the nine-month period this year, the company's pretax income increased 36 percent, to $68.9 million, on $409.1 million of revenue. Bank loan refinancing and a $72 million common stock issue will help improve near-term results even more, the ratings agency said.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Many Banks Are Seeking Help in Sales

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
AS a training specialist from the outside, W. Anthony Turner, executive vice president of the Selbst Group of White Plains gets an inside look into many banks. And he says that despite a wave of layoffs and consolidations in banking, the growing number of brokerage operations at many banks provides some job opportunities for people with sales or financial bankgrounds who have lost their jobs at other types of companies.
Mr. Turner's firm specializes in training bank personnel at many levels, including customer service representatives, branch managers and private bankers who handle the accounts of wealthy individuals. 
 The Selbst Group, for example, is now training 600 branch managers for Great Western Bank in Beverly Hills, Calif. It has also worked for banks like C&S/Sovran of Atlanta, which is now in the process of merging with NCNB of Charlotte, N.C.; Mercantile Bank of St. Louis, and Fleet/Norstar of Providence, R.I. The focus is often on programs to train bank employes to market more effectively a variety of new products, including securities and annuities.
"I think so many of the displaced middle managers today, young and old, have not taken the time to investigate the opportunities in banking," Mr. Turner, who is 31 years old, said in a telephone interview last week. "They are so overwhelmed by losing their jobs and trying to find another with brokerage firms."
Mr. Turner said banks were working to create their own types of sales cultures, now geared more toward building relationships than simply promoting products.
Thirty years ago, many leading brokerage firms had street-level brokerage offices, easily available to the public and often crowded at lunchtime with people watching the stock ticker. Nowadays, many brokerages prefer to do retail business mostly by telephone or computer, and they avoid making their branch offices convenient for tape watchers.
Mr. Turner noted some exceptions, like First Union Brokerage Services, a unit of First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C.. It operates what used to be called "walk-in offices" in Hallandale, Fla., and Charlotte, so that customers, mainly retirees or wealthy individuals with time on their hands, can watch the tape at their leisure.
In Atlanta, First Union Brokerage has a small headquarters office, from which a staff of four makes calls on branches to give investment help to bank customers. "We call that the hub-and-spoke arrangement," Mr. Turner said.
Banks are now moving slowly to take advantage of rising investment interest among customers and turn their bank customers into securities customers as well. Naturally, they want to draw their bank customers away from doing business with brokerage firms.
Recently, for instance, Citicorp ran a large advertisement inviting customers to buy mutual funds at its Citibank branches and offering the advice of fund-wise brokers.
Citicorp, Mr. Turner said, has been a client of his firm. "We provided mutual fund product knowledge training," he explained.
Lincoln Savings Bank in New York has a private banking unit, only a year old, with several registered representatives who make customer contacts and then turn them over to the bank's brokerage unit. Charles Potters, a former registered representative for Prudential-Bache, is one of them. He works under the aegis of Arthur M. Silverman, 33, who came from Citicorp to organize the new division.
Mr. Silverman, said he had four account officers, mainly brokers like Mr. Potters, working with 10 other staff members.
"My experience from being a director of executive banking at Citicorp," Mr. Silverman said, "leads me to believe that registered representatives from brokerage firms come to the job with tremendous product knowledge, as well as the skill, experience and willingness to ask for the business.
"I found that in my former banking environment," he said, "there continues to be a battle between senior management and the line managers to get their people to become more aggressive in terms of selling."
Mr. Silverman said that over the last 30 years, the banking culture had not emphasized sales.
As for training the new brokers and others in banking techniques, Mr. Turner, the training expert, said he usually divided the training into three components.
"First comes the research phase, where we like to get to know the group -- usually no more than 25 persons -- as individuals," he said. "We interview each person about sales experience and what he or she believes is needed to become more effective."
Then, he said, the Selbst Group holds two three-day workshops covering topics from product knowledge to prospecting for new business.
Finally, he said, his trainers go back to the bank and work with each person a few hours once a month for six months.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Expectation Of Strong Report on G.N.P.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher against most major currencies yesterday on optimism that the United States economy might be stronger than expected. Gold prices fell.
Several traders said the dollar's rise came amid speculation that the Government's report on gross national product for the third quarter, scheduled to be issued today, would suggest faster growth. 
 The consensus estimate among economists is that the Commerce Department will report a growth rate of 2.2 percent to 3 percent for the quarter. That would be a sharp gain from the decrease of five-tenths of 1 percent in G.N.P. in the second quarter.
A healthier G.N.P. report will make it less likely that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates to stimulate the economy, traders said. Lower interest rates tend to reduce the dollar's value.
 
Principally Against Mark
 Anticipation of the report sent the dollar higher principally against the German mark, which in turn helped the dollar rise against some other important currencies.
In late European trading, the dollar closed at 1.7100 marks, up from 1.7050 late Friday. Later, the dollar closed at 1.7173 marks in New York trading, up from 1.7000 late Friday.
Currency dealers say the dollar has exhibited surprising strength in the face of pessimistic economic reports that suggest the United States' recovery from recession has stalled.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.92 yen to a closing 132.28 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 132.13 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 132.29 yen, up from 131.45 yen late Friday.
 
Pound Falls in London
 In London, the pound fell to $1.7040 from $1.7115 late Friday. In New York, sterling cost $1.69425 at closing in New York, less expensive than $1.7135 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5060 Swiss francs, up from 1.4870; 5.8580 French francs, up from 5.8000; 1,283.25 Italian lire, up from 1,270.75, and 1.1250 Canadian dollars, down from 1.12625.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $358.60 an ounce from $361.90 an ounce late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $358.45, from $362 late Friday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up on Greenspan Talk

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A pessimistic economic assessment by the Federal Reserve chairman helped to lift the prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday.
In a speech to business executives at the University of Rhode Island, the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the economy had "turned demonstrably sluggish" in recent weeks. 
 Mr. Greenspan suggested that a "credit crunch" was dragging the economy down.
Compared with his recent measured assessments -- he proclaimed the recession over in July, during his official midyear review of the economy -- Mr. Greenspan's comments on the economy struck some credit market participants as almost shrill.
 
Mollifying Bond Investors
 "His remarks were much better than what the market had anticipated," one trader of government bonds said, referring to their effect on the Treasury market, which often reacts favorably to sour economic news.
Many analysts and traders said the comments were almost certainly intended to mollify the bond market, which over the last week has been rattled by talk of tax cuts.
Reacting to early news reports of Mr. Greenspan's comments, which characterized his speech as somewhat more pessimistic than it actually was, analysts interpreted the remarks as a signal that the Fed intended to lower short-term interest rates again soon. In fact, Mr. Greenspan gave no indication even indirectly of what his intentions might be in regard to interest rates.
"It's pretty tough talk," said Edward S. Hyman, president of ISI Group Inc., an investment firm, "and coming on top of other soft economic data it says the economy is faltering and will need lower interest rates to get it to pick up."
"I don't think there is a case the economy is getting a lot worse," he added. "It's just not getting any better."
James Fralick, a principal and senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said the remarks were primarily an attempt to soothe skittish bond investors.
"The Fed has to get this market in the right frame of mind, and there was a lot of damage done last week" by the talk of tax cuts, he said. "But he can't do much to ease policy further until bond yields fall below 8 percent and are moving toward 7.75 percent."
Mr. Fralick added that with the Commerce Department schedued to release what is widely expected to be a healthy estimate of third-quarter economic growth today, Mr. Greenspan may have been trying to remind market participants that "significant difficulties" remain to be overcome.
Most analysts anticipate the preliminary estimate to show that the economy expanded at a rate of 2 to 2.5 percent in the third quarter.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks did have a salutary effect on bond prices, which moved higher.
 
Prices Up in Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 5/32 late yesterday, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 8.02 percent, compared with 8.04 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 5/8, up 7/32, to yield 7.63 percent. And the new 6 percent two-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.88 percent, compared with 5.93 percent on Friday.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell at the weekly auction.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.99 percent, down from an average rate of 5.04 percent at last week's sale.
Bids on the new six-month bills produced an average rate of 5.04 percent, compared with an average rate of 5.14 percent a week ago.
 
European Debt Priced
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the European Community, which rarely sells debt in American capital markets, priced $65.4 million of noncallable securities yesterday through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 6.25 percent securities, which mature on April 28, 1994, were priced at $100, or par, 32 basis points above the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, market participants said prices of most issues were little changed in light trading.
Activity was also sluggish in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities.
With roughly $1 billion in new issues expected to be priced this week, traders said that at this point investors were reluctant to make new commitments.

HEADLINE: New Vistas for Tourism's Mr. Italy

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Until he joined the army in 1944, Mario Perillo had never journeyed farther than 40 miles from his home in the Bronx. But since then he has traveled much of the world, and he has taken more than a million others with him -- most of them to Italy, the land of his parents.
Now, at age 65, Mr. Perillo is striking out in several new directions. Compared with a decade ago, the number of participants in his package tours to Italy has fallen by half, leaving Perillo Tours -- one of the nation's largest independent tour operators, with annual revenue approaching $60 million -- to make up the difference by promoting Caribbean cruises and Hawaiian packages. 
 Some of the continuing changes at Mr. Perillo's family-owned company involve bolstering the non-Italy side of the business. After a five-year association with Merv Griffin's Paradise Island Resort and Casino in the Bahamian capital, Nassau, Perillo recently moved its Bahamas package tours to the Crystal Palace, the 1,550-room resort and casino owned by Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. And next year Perillo Tours will inaugurate a 7-day New York-to-Bermuda cruise.
But the man who refers to himself in his advertising as "Mr. Italy," is clearly eager to reinvigorate tourism to that country. Some of that hope is tied to one of the biggest changes Perillo has ever made. Starting Nov. 14, Perillo Tours customers will no longer fly Pan American World Airways to Italy, as they have for 45 years, but Alitalia, Italy's national carrier.
In an arrangement that involves joint promotion and volume discounts on air fares, Perillo has agreed to use Alitalia exclusively for its Italian tours. To celebrate the alliance, from January through March the new partners will spend more than $2 million on advertising.
The pitchman will continue to be the gray-haired Mr. Perillo, whose untutored voice has for years sung both the glory that was Rome and the glories of trying to recapture some of it on a Perillo tour.
 
A Process of Elimination
 Under ordinary circumstances, Pan Am's loss of Perillo, which had flown Pan Am exclusively to Italy since 1974, would have been a major blow. "They have consistently been our single biggest customer," said Jeff Kriendler, a Pan Am vice president.
But the financially strapped carrier recently sold the routes to Delta Air Lines.
So why did Perillo not simply transfer to Delta, which on Friday will take over Pan Am's routes to Italy? Frances Conner, Delta's general manager of public relations, said that instead of the 747's that Pan Am flew each day from New York to Rome and Milan, Delta -- which does not own 747's -- will fly the much smaller Airbus 310's to Italy.
Mr. Perillo said the impending switch to smaller airplanes is a main reason he chose Alitalia. (Perillo Tours will still fly Delta to Honolulu and Nassau, and it will use Pan Am to take cruise-ship passengers from New York to Miami). "Delta is a fine airline, but they told us they did not have sufficient capacity for us," he said.
Of the other United States carriers that fly nonstop to Italy, American Airlines flies only from Chicago. And for some reason, Mr. Perillo said, talks with T.W.A. simply never got very far.
 
'A Natural Marriage'
 That left Alitalia. The carrier flies daily nonstops to Rome and Milan from New York -- Perillo's most important gateway -- as well as less frequent nonstops from Miami, Boston, Chicago and Los Angeles,
"It is a natural marriage," said Orazio Corallo, Alitalia's general manager for the United States and Mexico. "Perillo is the No. 1 tour operator to Italy, and we carry the most passengers from the U.S. to Italy." Both parties expect to expand Perillo tours to Naples, Venice and Palermo. And both have visions of those glory days a dozen years ago when Perillo Tours carried as many as 45,000 tourists a year to Italy.
But that was before terrorist attacks, war, a weak dollar and recession all played havoc with international tourism. "In the mid-80's there was shooting at the Rome airport, and nobody wanted to go to Italy," Mr. Perillo said.
This year, when the Persian Gulf war crippled international travel for more than three months, only about 15,000 tourists will visit Italy with Perillo, while another 20,000 will travel with Perillo to Hawaii and the Caribbean.
 
To Hawaii by Default
 At first, Hawaii and the Caribbean were merely fallbacks for Perillo Tours. "When nobody wanted to go to Italy in the mid-80's," Mr. Perillo said, "we had to do something. So in 100 days we sold 10,000 people on going to the Bahamas with us."
That was possible only with the support of travel agents, who, for the standard 10 percent commission, generate 95 percent of Perillo's business.
Mr. Perillo, a lawyer by training, worked alongside his father, Joseph, in the family's modest storefront travel agency until 1965, when he took over the business upon his father's retirement. Twenty-six years later, a third generation of Perillos is waiting in the wings -- his daughter, Linda, who isthe liason with the travel agencies and coordinates Perillo's representation at trade shows, and his son, Stephen, whom Mr. Perillo describes as "second in command."
But Mr. Perillo, who moved the company in 1986 from New York to Woodcliff Lake, N.J., is not ready to retire, nor has he ruled out packaging tours to other destinations -- if he is convinced they will produce at least 5,000 customers a year.
But his heart and his agency's future are inextricably linked to that boot-shaped peninsular nation between the Mediterranean and Adriatic Seas. "Italy," he said, "is our Verdi and our soul."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Xerox Net Dropped 9% In Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 28

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation said today that third-quarter earnings fell 9 percent, with slow copier sales offsetting a slight gain in its financial-services division.
The company said net profit in the quarter ended Sept. 30 came to $121 million, or $1.06 a share, down from $132 million, or $1.16 a share, a year earlier. Revenue slipped 2.3 percent, to $4.3 billion from $4.4 billion. 
 Last year's third-quarter results included a $9 million gain from the sale of real estate and third-party financing operations. Excluding last year's one-time gain, earnings from continuing operations dropped 2 percent, the company said.
 
Jump in Service Income
 Third-quarter income from the document-processing business fell 11 percent, to $117 million, but earnings from insurance and other financial-services businesses jumped 59 percent, to $51 million.
Stuart B. Ross, executive vice president and chairman of Xerox Financial Services, said the improvement was primarily from capital gains, although slightly higher investment income helped offset poor property and casualty underwriting results.
Mr. Ross also said the Xerox Credit Corporation sold $600 million in assets during the third quarter to help reduce debt.
 
Further Decline Seen
 Paul A. Allaire, chairman and chief executive, said the company expected profits from document processing to continue to fall in the fourth quarter.
"Lower-end, less-expensive copiers and printers continued to show strong growth worldwide in both the latest quarter and year-to-date," Mr. Allaire said. "However, United States sales of higher-end equipment, which require greater customer investment and have a longer selling cycle, continue to be hurt by the current state of the U.S. economy."
Xerox shares closed at $61.625, up 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
